fields.headline: Threat of ATM charges revived
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Nationwide Building Society has privately warned that fresh charges for cash machine withdrawals could be introduced "by the back door" - just a month after the controversial practice was all but ruled out.
fields.body:
Nationwide Building Society has privately warned that fresh charges for cash machine withdrawals could be introduced "by the back door" - just a month after the controversial practice was all but ruled out.

In a letter obtained by the Guardian, Nationwide warns the Link cash machine network that it risks being brought into disrepute by the proposed changes to its rules to permit surcharges.

The missive, written by Paul Feldman, the building society's divisional director, fol lows a meeting of the Link board last week at which introducing the rules under which surcharges could be levied were put on to the board's agenda.

"Recent announcements have effectively ruled out surcharging outside of convenience locations, which was allowed for under existing rules anyway. Therefore we believe that any attempt to change the rules to once more permit surcharging would risk Link being brought into disrepute," Mr Feldman wrote to Link director Howard Aiken.

The changes contained in the board's resolution would allow surcharges to be introduced at cash machines from January 2001 - provided that at least one months' notice is given to Link.

The letter follows moves by the major banks including Barclays, which first proposed surcharging, to cease penalising their customers for withdrawing money from cash machines - but only after a public outcry over the charges.

The surcharges on rivals' customers using their own machines were designed to replace the disloyalty fees their own customers faced when using rivals' machines.

At the moment some banks, such as Woolwich and Alliance & Leicester, are levying a surcharge in so-called convenience locations distant from their branches, situated in corner shops and book stores.

The capacity to levy such surcharges is also intended to allow the non-bank providers - such as Securicor and Money Box - to start installing cash machines in areas where they might not normally be located but where customers will have to be charged to take out their cash.

John Hardy, the chief executive of Link, said the changes put to the board were in line with agreements at the meet ings which had taken place over the last few months when the possibility of wider surcharging was first agreed by the board.

"Paul Feldman is a new director and clearly misunderstood [the details].

"It is now widely understood that Link cannot be responsible for retail pricing," Mr Hardy said.

Nationwide, which last year threatened Barclays with legal action if it pressed ahead with its proposed £1 surcharge for cash withdrawals, told Link in the letter that the changes to the rules should not be made.

In the letter, Mr Feldman wrote: "The media would be likely to see this as an attempt to introduce surcharging by the back door.

"As I am sure you would expect, we would oppose such a move and would fear for the repercussions for Link and its members in public relations terms should be board decide to pursue it".

Despite the moves by the group of major banks to commit themselves to ceasing all charges for cash machine withdrawals aside from those at "convenience sites", many sources believe that charges will be reintroduced once public sentiment allows it.

fields.headline: More fun in the park
fields.standfirst:
The Pirates of Penzance
Open Air Theatre, Regents Park, London
****
fields.trailText:
The Pirates of Penzance
Open Air Theatre, Regents Park, London
****
fields.body:
This is the souped-up Gilbert and Sullivan standard, adapted and orchestrated by William Elliott, that wowed Broadway in 1980 and later came to Drury Lane. And, even if Ian Talbot's production occasionally overpitches camp, it still works like a dream in Regents Park and offers more fun than most of London's other musicals put together.

How do you play a piece like this today? It is, after all, based on the pre-Wildean paradox of an apprentice pirate who, by virtue of being born in a leap year, is nominally indentured to his trade till 1940. The right approach, as here, is to acknowledge the work's Victorian origins while giving it an extra layer of anachronistic irony. Thus Jimmy Johnston, following in the footsteps of Kevin Kline, plays the Pirate King as a hectic mixture of romantic swashbuckler and comic klutz: Douglas Fairbanks crossed with Ben Turpin. And Mark Umbers as the resolutely upper class, duty-enslaved tyro pirate is not averse to Elvis-like gyrations of the hips.

Talbot's additions generally add to the sense of gaiety: we get toy ships spouting cannon fire and water, a pantomime songsheet and even Keystone Kops sporting extremely phallic rubber truncheons. Only once did I feel a touch of the purist coming on: that was when the Major General, excellently played by Paul Bradley as a stoutly Victorian figure in an MCC cummerbund, was so upstaged by the gravestone-toting chorus in Sighing Softly to the River that we failed to notice the beauty of the song itself.

But Sullivan's numbers, under the musical direction of Catherine Jayes, are generally put across with enormous brio. In particular, Lucy Quick, as a Mabel of crystalline enunciation, and Gay Soper, as the hero's devoted but ageing admirer, reveal true voices that scarcely need the somewhat intrusive amplification.

As on Broadway, the great moment arrives when the Pirates do their full-throttle rendering of Come, Friends, Who Plough the Sea - a song that later mysteriously metamorphosed into Hail, Hail, the Gang's All Here. Yet that neatly symbolises the whole evening which, with its portrait of Queen Victoria set in a spiked corona suggesting the Statue of Liberty, beguilingly combines both English absurdity and American showbiz expertise.

 Until September 5. Box office: 0207-486 2431.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: The sound of Saturday night
fields.standfirst:
Baxendale
Water Rats, London
***
fields.trailText:
Baxendale
Water Rats, London
***
fields.body:
It's not easy being Baxendale. It's hard enough trying to be an irreverent pop band, with that love of Billie and singalong mentality to weigh you down, without having technical problems that would make lesser mortals scowl, shrug their shoulders and leave for sunnier climes. "This is gonna happen on our Top of the Pops debut, I can tell," singer Tim Benton said wearily.

That would be a shame because Baxendale aspire to pop heights. While Pulp told tales of inner-city teen-angst cool, Baxendale celebrate the joy of being young as well as its disappointments: you might not win the girl down the disco but you'll fall in love with the sounds that surround you. It is difficult not to get caught up in their enthusiasm.

As the anthemic Music for Girls begins, Benton jumps up and down like a hyperactive kid who has just completed his Pokémon collection, his arms flailing and his legs in the air. You wonder at what point he is going to knock himself out on the low ceiling. Meanwhile, keyboardist and singer Senay Sargut - looking suitably disco in her spangly strapless top and choker - doesn't stop dancing to the familiar yet contemporary beats programmed by Alex Mayor.

Baxendale take the sound of Saturday night and mix it up with clever lyrics and a wily pop sensibility, making accessible yet intelligent songs to dance to. Benton sprints off the stage and stands among his fans, one fist in the air, eyes closed, lost in music. When he's not dancing, he's winning us over with his charm. Valiantly struggling to keep up the mood while wanting to strangle the sound technician, he takes a camera from the crowd and photographs its owner. When one fan gives him a gift, he seems to be overwhelmed.

Mics pack up, speakers refuse to relay any sound and feedback pierces the air. "Can I have more of me, otherwise I'm going to have to slap someone," Sargut pleads. But Baxendale clearly inspire much affection. The relief is palpable when things finally settle down and we can all get on with the business of having a good time.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Never too old to scat
fields.standfirst:
Sheila Jordan/Dr John
Edinburgh jazz and blues festival
*****/**
fields.trailText:
Sheila Jordan/Dr John
Edinburgh jazz and blues festival
*****/**
fields.body:
There is still a week to go until the Edinburgh Fringe opens, but the trainee stilt-walkers were already teetering around the Royal Mile as the Edinburgh jazz festival launched its programme on Sunday with an electrifying concert by vocalist Sheila Jordan.

Accompanied by local piano powerhouse Brian Kellock, Jordan gave an extraordinary performance. At "71 and a half", as she puts it, she is hardly a household name. But she should be: she can scat like Ella Fitzgerald and break your heart with one extended note like Billie Holiday. Born in Detroit, she sang with her idol Charlie Parker and married his pianist, Duke Jordan. The breaks never came, despite album releases in the 60s.

She had the wit and spontaneity to shape her opening number, Everything Happens to Me, into an improvised narrative about her hassled journey to Edinburgh (delayed flight; traffic jams). She can make elderly standards sound like they were written yesterday - Cole Porter's I Concentrate on You was filled with dizzying vocal dips and curves. A startling break into a native American chant (she is part Cherokee) segued into a hair-raising, tear-jerking version of Jimmy Webb's The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress. She brought the audience to its feet when she recast the traditional song The Water is Wide as sultry, smoky blues.

Jordan is in Edinburgh for a week of vocal workshops and gigs. Don't miss her - this is a reminder that the voice can be the ultimate jazz instrument.

Later, as Elton John pounded away at the Castle Esplanade, a sprightly Dr John almost danced on stage. The entrance of Mac Rebennack from New Orleans is no small thing. As Dr John, he has dedicated his life to reviving and reshaping the sounds of his home town; an appalling sound mix, in which the piano was blotted out by the drums, didn't help him, however, and it all sounded tired and sometimes disjointed. Only on Do Nothing Till You Hear From Me did his beautiful vocal slouch and driving piano make the towering shade of Duke Ellington come alive.

The rest was a heavy trudge around the Creole classics and it was sad to see the self-styled voodoo king of the mystic swamps turning into a hammy musical tour guide.

 Sheila Jordan plays the Hub, Edinburgh (0131-473 2000), tomorrow.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Barclays shut down online banking service

fields.headline: Security fear shuts online bank
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Fresh doubts about conducting business over the internet were raised last night after an apparent security breach forced Barclays to shut down its online banking service.
fields.body:
Fresh doubts about conducting business over the internet were raised last night after an apparent security breach forced Barclays to shut down its online banking service.

The bank, which says it is the country's largest internet bank with more than 1.2m customers, was last night scrambling to restore confidence in its service after customers complained they were able to access other customers' accounts in cyberspace.

While the shutdown once again raised questions about the safety of handling finances online, it also added further embarrassment to the bank which has been battling to restore its reputation after a series of public relations disasters.

These have ranged from the public outcry over the pay package awarded to chief executive, Matt Barrett, to the bank's insensitivity in closing rural branches and its insistence on charging customers for cash machine withdrawals.

A clumsily-timed advertising campaign, fronted by Hollywood stars such as Anthony Hopkins, emphasising the bank's size added to its publicity woes.

The latest problem was described by Barclays as "unacceptable" and the bank said it followed an upgrade to its online services carried out over the weekend.

Four customers, out of 85,000 who have used the online service since the weekend's upgrade, complained that they could see other cus tomers' accounts when they logged on.

"Barclays views this compromise in the security and integrity of its online service as unacceptable - security of customer information is paramount," the bank said.

The shutdown to the online service took place at 3.30pm and was expected to last for four hours while the bank reinstalled the old system.

"The new service will not be rereleased until we are satisfied that this particular issue has been rectified," Barclays said.

The bank posted a message, timed at 3.30pm, on its website for customers trying to log on, which read: "We apologise for the temporary withdrawal of the online banking service and for any inconvenience this may cause. We are currently working on restoring online banking - the service will be available within the next few hours".

Barclays, which is due to publish its profits figures for the first six months of the year later this week, joins a growing list of major financial services providers to experience embarrassing problems with their much-heralded internet services.

Halifax was forced to delay its new telephone-cum-internet bank, Intelligent Finance, just one day before it was due to open to customers after becoming concerned that the system would falter under the potential volume of business.

A new internet bank launched by Abbey National, branded Cahoot, was also crippled by difficulties during the week of its launch when its website was put out of action for several hours by a surge in demand.

While neither of these incidents appear to involve security, the potential for damaging breaches was highlighted in July when Powergen, the gas and electricity supplier, was forced to contact 2,500 of its customers after their bank account details appeared on its internet site.

None of these issues have helped to improve the public's perception of banking on the internet, a channel many of the major financial services would like their customers to adopt for the most basic transactions because it cuts costs and frees up branches for more complicated and profitable transactions such as selling mortgages.

A survey by Henrion, Ludlow and Schmidt, a brand consultancy, has found that just 8% of men and 6% of women would choose an online bank over one with a traditional high street presence. A spokeswoman for the National Consumer Council (NCC), which has been campaigning for better internet security, said the latest mishap at Barclays proved the issue should be taken more seriously by financial groups.

Anna Bradley, director of the NCC, said: "Our research shows that trust is a serious concern for consumers.

"Today's problems at Barclays further undermine consumer confidence and until providers such as Barclays address the problems of security, privacy and customer service, e-commerce will not take off."

fields.headline: Jerry Hall in The Graduate
fields.trailText: Jerry Hall last night stepped into the shoes recently vacated by Kathleen Turner as Mrs Robinson in the stage version of The Graduate at the Gielgud Theatre. She also stepped out of a white bath robe to pose for all of 20 seconds in the nude in the dimmest possible light.
fields.body:
Jerry Hall last night stepped into the shoes recently vacated by Kathleen Turner as Mrs Robinson in the stage version of The Graduate at the Gielgud Theatre. She also stepped out of a white bath robe to pose for all of 20 seconds in the nude in the dimmest possible light. Anyone seeking erotic satisfaction out of the moment would either have to be pretty desperate or in possession of cats' eyes.

Final judgement on Hall's performance will have to wait until the official press night next week. But I can reveal that Sarah Bernhardt's reputation is safe and that the earth certainly didn't move for me.

Turner brought to the alcoholic, sex-hungry Mrs Robinson a mocking stillness, a gin-smoked voice and Mae West timing, all derived from a lengthy film and stage career. Hall, having appeared on stage once before in Bus-Stop, brings only a wealth of inexperience.

It is true she wears clothes with the panache you would expect of a model and that, when she strips to a black slip, something stirs in the stalls. But you never really feel that her Mrs Robinson is a predator, a lush or a bitch - simply a highly glamorous woman fishing for a younger man.

The casting of Hall in The Graduate is most interesting for what it tells us about the state of the West End today. For a start, it shows the triumph of hype over experience. Hall is famous, beautiful and much-photographed. It therefore follows she must be able to act. However, the honest truth is that there are many actresses around better equipped to play Mrs Robinson but they will not get a sniff of the role because they lack the requisite celebrity.

Even more alarming is the feeling that the West End stage is gradually turning into a repository for old Hollywood movies. Currently we have The Graduate, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and The Witches of Eastwick. But, while the last two are lent an extra dimension either by superior acting or by the music, Terry Johnson's version of The Graduate feels like a thin-textured adaptation of a movie that was something of a mirage to begin with: a movie that camouflaged its pandering to youthful narcissism under slick camera work and an entrancing score.

But I have to report that The Graduate was packed on a sweltering Monday night in August and that there was a buzz of excitement in the stalls. That, however, had less to do with the low-key events on stage than with the presence of Mick Jagger in the front stalls. People in the rear craned to get a glimpse of the legendary sexagenarian. Cameramen rushed around frenziedly seeking him in the interval. And, by the end of the show, an exceptionally dense crowd had gathered in Shaftesbury Avenue. Frankly, if I were Hall I would be a bit miffed. It's one thing to be upstaged by your fellow-actors but quite another by your ex-husband.

fields.trailText:
National Museum of Photography, Film & Television, Bradford
*****
fields.body:
The sound comes up through your feet, trembles your knees and pulsates your privates. The video projections interfere with your head, but you are so taken with the spectacle there's no time to think what it might mean.

This isn't a wild club night in the good old days of Ibiza. It's mid-afternoon at Bradford's National Museum of Photography, Film & Television. The museum deserves full credit for being culturally intrepid enough to invite the Austrian artist duo Granular Synthesis here to install Noisegate, a multimedia work of quite dizzying power.

Noisegate has been on a world tour, from Vienna through Hull to New York, but it is unlikely to have achieved a more perfect incarnation than in this museum's massive semi-circular space. Facing you on a curved wall is a triptych of towering double screens. At your back there's a stack of black speakers. You disappear into the darkness in between.

At last, here's a gallery-based video installation as exciting as any rave, rock concert, funfair or fireworks. What's more, this art of gut-wrenching disturbance and elation has real intelligence. Every Noisegate hallucination has clearly been meticulously laboured over. Artaud would have loved it to bits.

Granular Synthesis take their name from the technique of digitally sampling and cloning micro-units of video sound and visuals. Close-up film of Viennese performer Michael Krammer is here almost petrified by the process. His head is portrayed in the kind of glow-in-the-dark colours of joke-shop skeletons. He shifts in slow- motion from side to side, as if not knowing which way to turn. Suddenly he freezes in a turn-the-other-cheek pose reminiscent of Francis Bacon's portraits. Remember the first time you saw a Bacon portrait - that unique frisson of absurdity and alarm? This is hi-tech cyber-Bacon, free of the weight of painterly mannerism. Meanwhile, the backing track thunders away as if all the ghosts of all the machines of the world were turning up for a farewell gig. You'll regret not being there.

 Till September 10. Details: 01274 202030.

fields.headline: Hogarth's Sigismunda in Focus
fields.standfirst:
Tate Britain, London
***
fields.trailText:
Tate Britain, London
***
fields.body:
Painted in 1759, William Hogarth's Sigismunda illustrates a story in Boccaccio's Decameron about a woman grieving for her husband. Fighting back the tears and wearing copious jewellery, she clutches a gold vase containing the heart. The critics were unimpressed. Connoisseur Horace Walpole called Sigismunda "a maudlin whore".

Hogarth was the master of the satirical, the low; a painter of 18th-century London life whose images still gnaw at the imagination. But he wanted more. He wanted to be recognised as a painter of grand themes like the old masters.

Tate Britain has stepped in to rescue Sigismunda, to put the painting in context and argue that it was Sigismunda's overt sexuality that offended men like Walpole. The trouble is that the other works displayed as evidence are far more imaginative. The mistake was to show The Lady's Last Stake (1759). In this comic masterpiece, a woman in a green-wallpapered drawing room has been losing at cards to her beau and is now reduced to her last stake: her body. Cards burn in the hearth, and a clock on the mantelpiece portrays Time with a scythe.

There's a buoyancy to this painting that lifts it off the wall. Apparently, a rich art lover saw it and offered Hogarth a huge sum for something similar. Wilfully, Hogarth painted Sigismunda. Grosvenor was appalled. And who can blame him?

There's plenty of subversion in Hogarth's paintings and prints without having to overanalyse such a minor work. What Tate Britain should do is put on an exhibition celebrating his comic genius, instead of assuming - with a perversity as great as that which prompted Sigismunda - that because something is excluded from the canon it must be interesting. Sometimes works of art fail not because they are threatening to the social order but because they are bad.

 Till November 4. Details: 020-7887 8008.

fields.headline: Carol Rhodes
fields.standfirst:
Tramway, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText:
Tramway, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
Few artists make you think simultaneously of post-apocalyptic poisoning and Battenberg cake. That it should be a landscape painter and not a left-field installation artist who manages this feat is testimony to the allure of Carol Rhodes's work.

Think dreamlike nostalgic visions of futuristic scenarios and you're close to Rhodes's territory: blocks of flats, motorway service stations, car parks, painted with a palette of sugared-almond hues. The effect is unsettling, but calmly so; dystopian, but endearing at the same time.

A sickeningly polluted river runs by bleak, grey flats that could be the eastern bloc's worst, and yet they are studded with jewel-like touches of blue. A motorway scene is all American cool, bleached-out Hopper, and yet there is something of the architectural study about it, too. These are obsessive yet detached visions, beautiful in their small scale and delicacy, yet nightmarish too.

Much of this quality stems from Rhodes's use of aerial perspective and a range of photographic surfaces. Both lend these paintings a clinical edge only softened by the use of the gentle shades. Ultimately, though, this is a dark vision, though, more poison than prettiness.

A reservoir is rendered a deep, swirling, scary thing; hills and trees the cover for some malignant presence in the earth. From a great height and in horror-film colours, the trees are like a fungus, the scum on top of poisoned water. The contours of the earth are stretched over what look like tumours.

Rhodes's depopulated, invented landscapes somehow draw you in with an emotional pull. Maybe it's because she captures the surreal otherness of the built environment as we drive by or fly over or, more appropriately, dream about flying over. Rhodes was born in Scotland but spent her early years in India. Maybe this explains her novel way of seeing, her gloriously dark way of sharing with us.

 Till August 27. Details: 0141-422 2023.

fields.headline: Sutton eases O'Neill's nerves
fields.standfirst: New Celtic manager gets off to a nervy but successful start
fields.trailText: Celtic's would-be saviour Martin O'Neill opened his account last night after goals from Henrik Larsson and Chris Sutton sealed victory against Dundee United.
fields.body:
So far so good for Martin O'Neill. In Dundee, the city of discovery, Celtic's would-be saviour opened his account in the best possible circumstances last night while discovering that his new team may not be so bad after all.

O'Neill departed with a thumbs-up and the vague semblance of a smile after goals from Henrik Larsson and, titter ye not, Chris Sutton had done the trick on the first day of the rest of their lives. Celtic being Celtic they did not make it easy for themselves but, as it was, this was just about as good as O'Neill could reasonably have hoped for.

After the anaesthetic experiences of recent years Celtic's fifth manager in as many seasons guarantees, at the very least, to inject some get-up-and-go into the equation. English football will be a poorer place without the sight of this endearing but slightly manic Ulsterman charging up and down the touchline as though someone had slipped amphetamines into his Bovril.

This was Scotland's first experience of his Basil Fawlty impressions and, while the best is yet to come, there was enough to provoke some startled looks from the two linesmen. Who was this lunatic?

Having got off to the worst possible start at Leicester City, O'Neill's tension was understandable. This promises to be the most nerve-shredding season of his career and before kick-off it seemed as though the butterflies were at work in his mind as well as his belly. "I would be lying if I said I wasn't nervous," he confessed, arms aching from all the handshaking.

At Leicester, remember, they were kicking down the doors and hollering for him to be thrown in the Grand Union Canal within weeks of him taking the job. And that was just the players. But once he had won them over, the way in which he transmogrified the club into the best team in the Midlands became one of the success stories of 90s football.

This, however, is different. The expectations are suffocating, the pressure immense. Celtic are in need of a quick fix but O'Neill knows it will be a drawn-out process. He says he is the eternal optimist yet beneath the one-liners, boggle-eyed enthusiasm and infectious warmth he knows that his new employers finished 21 points behind Rangers last season and are likely to end up a furlong or two behind this time round.

Being realistic, if Celtic were a good side O'Neill would not be here at all. That he is bodes well for a club whose followers have overdosed on depression for longer than they care to remember.

The butterflies were clearly contagious for, if O'Neill was edgy, Sutton looked terrified. At £10m Chelsea thought they had bought a footballing Ferrari last season, only for their then-record signing to clank along like a Skoda with a slow puncture.

O'Neill, however, has a knack for bringing the best out of players and Sutton showed a willingness lacking from his time at Stamford Bridge. He was rewarded for his endeavour by claiming an assist for Larsson's 37th minute goal during an opening half in which Celtic's players should have guaranteed their win bonus without necessarily playing that well themselves.

When Sutton's surging run culminated in Larsson curling an exquisite left-foot shot beyond the badly positioned Alan Combe, everything seemed rosy in O'Neill's garden. But old Celtic habits die hard and United were allowed an unlikely equaliser four minutes after the interval.

Neil Heaney's free-kick did not carry much danger but Jonathan Gould - whose days could be numbered with Mark Bosnich tipped to move to Celtic on a one-year loan - flapped at the ball like the Queen Mum waving to her well-wishers and David McCracken headed into the spot the goalkeeper had vacated.

Had Steven Thompson not wasted a header inside the six-yard area soon afterwards things could have been so different for O'Neill. But the chance went begging and Sutton capped a sustained spell of Celtic pressure by turning in Stéphane Mahé's left-foot shot from all of two yards. Three points and a Sutton goal - not bad for a first day's work.

webTitle: Whelan sale puts Sky Blue war chest at £15m

fields.headline: Whelan sale puts Sky Blue war chest at £15m
fields.trailText: Coventry's weekend takings passed £15m with the sale yesterday of the striker Noel Whelan to Middlesbrough.
fields.body:
As Robbie Keane started to get used to life in Italy after his £13m move to Internazionale, Coventry's weekend takings passed £15m with the sale yesterday of the striker Noel Whelan to Middlesbrough.

City's chairman Brian Richardson pledged that the manager Gordon Strachan would be allowed to spend much of this to replenish his depleted forward line, and acknowledged that West Brom's Lee Hughes was a likely target.

"Gordon Strachan will have a very big chunk of it," he said. "We have targeted three players and most of the money will be reinvested, hopefully, in three very successful players for us.

"We are hugely disappointed that Robbie has gone. The other side is that we're pleased because we've got a very good price for him." Coventry paid Wolves £6m for Keane only last summer.

Richardson also revealed that two Premiership clubs had made late moves for Keane but he denied that Arsenal were one of them.

Whelan, 25, who cost Coventry £2m from Leeds five years ago, has agreed personal terms with the Boro manager Bryan Robson and will make his £2.2m move today after a medical. He had refused to sign a new deal and would have been available on a Bosman free next summer, but said: "It is a wrench because I have been very close to Gordon Strachan and he has helped me a great deal. I will miss him shouting at me in the mornings. But I am sure Bryan will do that."

Keane, 20, who had been on Inter's shopping list since January, is preparing to follow in the footsteps of his fellow Irishman Liam Brady, who had a spell at Inter during seven seasons in Italy during the 1980s.

He has signed a five-year contract worth £1m a year after tax. "When I was on my way to Italy last night", he said on Saturday, "I was thinking to myself how unpredictable things are. This time last year I was getting ready to play for Wolves in Division One. Now I've got to get ready to play alongside people like Ronaldo, Vieri, Blanc, Seedorf, [Luigi] Di Biagio and other great players who, all of a sudden, are now my team-mates."

With the club's first-choice strikers Ronaldo and Christian Vieri out through injury, Inter have been seeking to reinforce their squad before their involvement in August in the third preliminary round of the Champions League.

During Euro 2000 they bought Galatasaray's Turkey striker Hakan Sukur for a reported £4m. The Milanese club had sought to add Lazio's Chilean striker Marcelo Salas and only when that deal fell through last week did they reactivate their interest in Keane, as confirmed by the club owner Massimo Moratti. "We decided to move for Keane just three days ago. He's a good player, technically gifted and we'll give him plenty of time to grow. However, I'm sure that, being an Irishman, Robbie hasn't come here just to be the baby of the squad.

"I don't think he is terrified at the idea of having to compete with players such as Ronaldo and Vieri for a team place; on the contrary that'll just be an extra motivation for him".

Ronaldo's knee will keep him out until next spring at the earliest, and Vieri's thigh injury, though less serious, may mean he will not return until the Serie A season starts on October 1. But Keane will still face stiff competition for a first-team place.

fields.headline: Scottish  round-up
fields.trailText: The Hibernian striker Didier Agathe was left to reflect on the accuracy of a spectator at Easter Road yesterday, who found his target unerringly after throwing a plastic cup at the Hearts goalkeeper Antti Niemi during the Edinburgh derby.
fields.body:
The Hibernian striker Didier Agathe was left to reflect on the accuracy of a spectator at Easter Road yesterday, who found his target unerringly after throwing a plastic cup at the Hearts goalkeeper Antti Niemi during the Edinburgh derby.

Niemi was unhurt but the fact that an absorbing game ended goalless was in part due to Agathe, who was making his debut on loan from Raith.

Having had one effort ruled out for offside, he rounded Niemi seven minutes before half-time and faced an open goal. But he lost his balance, scuffed his shot and neither side came as close thereafter to breaking the deadlock.

Rangers' manager Dick Advocaat promised that his players would raise their game after a poor performance and fortunate 2-1 win over St Johnstone at Ibrox on Saturday. Trailing 1-0 to an Alan Kernaghan strike, Rangers needed two second-half strikes within a minute from Billy Dodds, the first disputed when a delay in letting Nick Dasovic re-enter the field of play allowed Barry Ferguson the space to set up the chance.

Dundee's new player-manager Ivano Bonetti had a dramatic introduction to the Scottish Premier League against Motherwell . After Dundee took the lead through Patricio Billio in the ninth minute, Bonetti collected his second yellow card and was sent off early in the second half. But Javier Artero added a second near the end.

Aberdeen managed a 0-0 draw against promoted Dunfermline despite having Derek Young dismissed. St Mirren, another of the promoted sides, lost to Gary Holt's goal for Kilmarnock .

fields.headline: Ginola picks up Gregory gauntlet
fields.trailText: David Ginola last night signed for Aston Villa in a £3m move from Tottenham with a broadside at the north London club which the Frenchman claims he never wanted to leave.
fields.body:
David Ginola last night signed for Aston Villa in a £3m move from Tottenham with a broadside at the north London club which the Frenchman claims he never wanted to leave.

The French winger announced the completion of his protracted move to the Midlands on his personal website after several hours of negotiations, first with Villa's manager John Gregory and then with the chairman Doug Ellis in a Birmingham hotel yesterday. He has signed a two-year contract worth around £30,000 a week.

Gregory had claimed: "Give me a face-to-face meeting with Ginola and he wouldn't leave without signing." Yesterday Villa's manager received that chance and it is believed he immediately challenged the 33-year-old player to prove that he could still flourish in the Premiership rather than take the soft option of playing out his career in a less demanding league abroad.

It appears Gregory's gauntlet won the day, which has been a long time coming since the middle of last month, when Ginola first learned that Spurs had accepted a £3m offer from Villa. To the Frenchman it was "bombshell news".

"It totally ruined my summer," said Ginola on his website. "I never asked to leave, I was happy at White Hart Lane and my family were settled in north London.

"But it was quite clear that Spurs - and I am not quite clear whether Alan Sugar or George Graham - didn't want me around any more and so were prepared to let me leave.

"Once I got over the shock I was very disappointed to learn that the club had put a £3m price-tag on my head. I am 33 and, although I feel I have still got at least two years left in me, playing at the highest level, I felt I should have been rewarded for my time at Spurs with a free transfer. That would have given me far more freedom in choosing which club to join.

"In fact, Spurs originally quoted Villa £4m but then accepted a bid of £3m. People then said I was being greedy with my demands but I hope they understand that, if I was being pushed out of Spurs - and I fought long and hard to avoid that - then I was going to leave on my terms."

Then, says Ginola, "all I did was to try and get a decent wage, again wildly exaggerated in the press, for having to leave Tottenham and uprooting to the Midlands. People have to appreciate that I did not anticipate any of this, having signed a three-year contract with Tottenham only 12 months ago.

There was little indication earlier over the weekend that the 1999 double player of the year would move to Villa but the deadline issued by Gregory and Graham's decision to leave him out of Saturday's friendly at Birmingham City helped persuade Ginola to sever his ties.

The division at White Hart Lane between Graham and Ginola was clear last season as the manager substituted the Frenchman repeatedely and finally warned him that he could not expect an automatic place in the upcoming campaign.

webTitle: Europe's hooligans give friendlies unfriendly edge

fields.headline: Europe's hooligans give friendlies unfriendly edge
fields.trailText: The season may not have officially begun in most of Europe but football hooligans got off to an early start in Belgium and Germany.
fields.body:
The season may not have officially begun in most of Europe but football hooligans got off to an early start in Belgium and Germany.

In Belgium, Dutch fans at a pre-season friendly between Standard Liège and Ajax on Saturday evening fought with stadium stewards, the police and rival supporters. Four stewards were injured and 16 fans arrested.

The Liège police commissioner François Lovenfosse said some hooligans wielded iron bars. "I've never seen violence like that from the Dutch," he told local television.

Belgian officials said violent fans banned from attending games in the Netherlands showed up for the match. "We had no warning from the Netherlands that there were dangerous supporters coming our way," Lovenfosse said.

Two Dutch fans were arrested before the game, which Ajax won 4-0.

In another incident, 14 Dutch fans were arrested after clashes in Mechelen, where a friendly between the home club and the Dutch team Vitesse Arnhem was called off because of a waterlogged pitch.

In Germany, about 70 home fans were involved in disturbances after Borussia Mönchengladbach marked their centenary with a match against the Dutch side Twente Enschede. One policewoman was hurt by a stone thrown by a hooligan.

Police also arrested seven hooligans at Duisburg station after a chance meeting between fans of Cologne and Uerdingen. Both sides had lost pre-season games in the city.

Away from the violence some football was also played. The French league campaign got under way with Marseille and Lens, two of France's big disappointments last season, scoring impressive wins under new coaches.

Lens, the 1998 champions who missed out on a place in Europe last season, showed new-found determination under the former Marseille coach Rolland Courbis as they won 2-0 away to the cup holders Nantes on Saturday.

Marseille, who only just avoided relegation last term, will be without their captain Patrick Blondeau for three weeks with a foot injury after their 3-1 victory over Troyes delighted their Brazilian coach Abel Braga.

The champions Monaco were held 1-1 on a bog-like pitch at promoted Lille, and promoted En Avant Guingamp were held 2-2 by St Etienne.

fields.headline: Blackburn brawl tests new code
fields.trailText: Blackburn and Everton must wait to see whether the Football Association will make an early example of them to demonstrate it means business over the disciplinary crackdown announced last Wednesday.
fields.body:
Blackburn and Everton must wait to see whether the Football Association will make an early example of them to demonstrate it means business over the disciplinary crackdown announced last Wednesday.

Only three days later an Ewood Park friendly has provided a swift test of the FA's will to apply its misbehaviour mandate which prescribes stiff punishments, especially for mass aggression. This game offered a 12-man brawl as tempers exploded, after which only Everton's £2.5m Danish international midfielder Thomas Gravesen was sent off by the referee Eddie Wolstenholme.

Gravesen now faces a ban for violent conduct, ruling him out of Everton's first three Premiership matches - although Walter Smith is lodging an appeal, backed by video evidence - but both clubs know they may be hit by financial sanctions if the promised hard line is taken over a pre-season match. The FA's spokesman Steve Double said yesterday: "We will await the referee's report before deciding whether or not action should be taken."

Predictably Smith and his Blackburn counterpart Graeme Souness disagreed over Gravesen's dismissal after a wild tackle on Gary Flitcroft that prompted the brawl. Blackburn's Nathan Blake appeared to throw punches but was only cautioned.

Smith said after his side's 2-1 defeat: "There was no doubt he [Gravesen] should have been booked but after that initial incident he was not the instigator of the problem. He was then the victim of the aggression."

Souness countered: "I don't think the boy can really complain. If he plays like that in the Premiership he's in for an interesting 12 months."

Blackburn's manager refused to lambast his players but, referring to the FA crackdown, conceded: "You have to be a bit more cautious now, or you are not going to be much use to your manager sitting in the stands all the time.

"But we are in the entertainment business and the first thing the paying public want to see is people working hard and showing passion. You take that out of the game and what have you got? You have got something that would not be very attractive for the paying public and then you lose your public. It's a balancing act."

Matt Jansen scored two fine goals for Blackburn, the First Division promotion favourites, with Danny Cadamarteri pulling one back for Everton, who gave Paul Gascoigne another 45-minute run-out before he became one of nine second-half substitutions. Gas- coigne was on the bench when the brawl erupted.

Manchester United followed their Roy Keane-inspired 2-0 win at York with an 8-1 demolition of Shrewsbury at Gay Meadow yesterday, the champions scoring five times in the second half.

United set the tone after three minutes when Nicky Butt struck with a thunderous 25-yard left-foot shot. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer scored twice, his second with a wonderful overhead kick, with Teddy Sheringham, Michael Clegg, Quinton Fortune (2) and David Healy completing the rout.

Nick Barmby marked his Liverpool debut by scoring their opening goal in a 4-1 victory over Freiburg in front of an 18,000 crowd in Germany. The £6m recruit from Everton scored after 18 minutes and there were also goals from his fellow England players Emile Heskey, after 40 minutes, and Michael Owen, in the 54th.

Steve Staunton completed the scoring after 74 minutes as Gérard Houllier fielded a different 11 players in each half. Among them was the Germany defender Markus Babbel, acquired from Bayern Munich.

At Molineux the Wolves goalkeeper Mike Stowell was in magnificent form in his testimonial match but could not prevent troubled Aston Villa from strolling to a 2-0 win.

Villa's striker Julian Joachim was again booed by his side's fans after criticising the club and asking for a transfer. He was also thwarted by Stowell on at least four occasions. But Ian Taylor and Lee Hendrie struck for the visitors.

fields.headline: Yorkshire quick to hail Fellows
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire pay for poor bowling as title rivals wag their tail
Lancashire 267 & 127-2
Yorkshire 376
fields.trailText:
Lancashire 267 & 127-2
Yorkshire 376.
fields.body:
Neil Fairbrother, on average, takes a wicket every three or four years. Sometimes, two World Cups and two general elections slip by while his supporters look in vain for an improvement in his tally.

So when the Lancashire captain John Crawley tossed him the ball here yesterday morning, in the middle of a roses match with even more resonance than normal, it was clear indication of how depleted the county's armoury had become.

Fairbrother immediately surprised everyone, including himself, when he had David Byas caught behind with his second delivery. The Yorkshire captain had been in something approaching his best form as he drove and clouted his way to a vigorous 81.

Lancashire, however, will need more than Fairbrother's gentle left arm to sustain them if their challenge for the championship is not to perish in an autumn frost.

To be fair to Lancashire, Fairbrother, who achieved a career best of two for 91 against the Nottinghamshire of Clive Rice and Richard Hadlee in 1987, had only come on to complete a Sourav Ganguly over. Ganguly suffered a groin injury and retired after bowling four balls of his 13th over. But the loss of Ganguly, when added to that of Richard Green, who shuffled from the field with a back injury yesterday, is meaningful.

Lancashire are already without Peter Martin (thumb) and Ian Austin (back), although it is hoped both will be fit for the club's NatWest Trophy semi-final at Bristol on August 13.

Before then, next week in fact, Lancashire face the championship leaders and favourites, Surrey, at the Oval. It is their two matches with Surrey, who they also play at Old Trafford at the end of the season, which will have a vital influence on Lancashire's ambitions.

They would lead the table if they win here - as would Yorkshire - but their principal ambition this morning will be to avoid defeat. At 127 for two they lead by only 18 runs and will need to bat for two sessions. Ganguly will be hampered, if he bats at all, so Yorkshire have a good chance, though a draw is the most likely outcome.

The match was well poised when Yorkshire resumed yesterday morning on 203 for four. But when Darren Lehmann was lbw to Michael Smethurst without adding to his overnight 83, and when Richard Blakey fell to Glen Chapple in the next over, Lancashire had hopes of gaining a first-innings lead. In fact they conceded one of 109.

This was partly due to a plucky innings of 46 from Gary Fellows, his best in the championship, but some ragged new-ball bowling was also responsible. Byas was seventh out at 291 and Yorkshire were only 35 runs on when Lancashire took the new ball at 302.

But Chapple and Smethurst bowled poorly and Chris Silverwood (34) and Matthew Hoggard (14) made Yorkshire's tail appear as short as a Manx cat's. Hoggard was last man out, caught at point off Andrew Flintoff, who is not properly fit to bowl.

When Lancashire batted again they lost Michael Atherton for 17, caught behind off Chris Elstub with the score on 31, though the little shake of the head he gave the umpire Allan Jones suggested he thought he had not touched it.

Elstub, though, ran in briskly. He is only playing because Yorkshire's injury problems are just as great as Lancashire's and might have had a second wicket yesterday when Flintoff, who had scored just five, drove firmly back at him. Flintoff managed 20 more before he was caught by Byas at second slip off Silverwood.

Crawley and Fairbrother then batted positively enough in their unbroken partnership of 53 to suggest that Lancashire had not surrendered the notion of forcing a result themselves.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: It is debatable whether divisional cricket will improve the quality of the English first-class game, but there are signs it is making it more competitive. The prospect of relegation from the First Division is clearly concentrating the mind.
fields.body:
It is debatable whether divisional cricket will improve the quality of the English first-class game, but there are signs it is making it more competitive. The prospect of relegation from the First Division is clearly concentrating the mind.

Kent and Somerset understand the value of at least drawing their current games against teams in the bottom three and both fought ferociously yesterday to avoid the possibility of defeat today.

Kent's recent revival was in danger of being undermined when they slipped to 111 for eight against Derbyshire at Canterbury, still 19 runs short of avoiding the follow-on. But Paul Nixon resisted with 80 not out, his highest score for the county since his move from Leicestershire at the end of last season, and it al lowed Kent to declare 28 runs behind. Min Patel, with 60, also produced a season's best on a day of personal milestones. Kevin Dean's eight for 52 was a career best.

Peter Bowler and Graham Rose rescued Somerset from a similar position at the Riverside. They added 157 for the seventh wicket after coming together at 88 for six in reply to Durham's first-innings total of 290. Bowler's 107, his third hundred of the season, occupied 311 deliveries while Rose curbed his attacking instincts to make 82 not out from 212 balls. Rose had sufficient energy in reserve to take two Durham wickets before the close.

The disparity between Gloucestershire's form in one-day cricket and the four-day game was underlined again at New Road. While all three one-day titles are still within their compass they are threatening to finish as the County Championship's bottom team for the second year in a row.

Glenn McGrath bowled them to defeat by 52 runs as Worcestershire returned to the top of the Second Division, at least temporarily. His match figures of 10 for 69 were the best of his career and he has moved ahead of Martin Bicknell as the country's leading wicket-taker with 62 championship victims. In all competitions he has taken 88.

Gloucestershire, needing 237 to win, had little chance of victory after McGrath had struck twice in his third over to leave them 10 for three. Jeremy Snape and Jack Russell added 63 for the seventh wicket but any victory hopes Gloucestershire may have had were snuffed out by Stuart Lampitt who took three wickets in three overs.

Lance Klusener's third Test century rescued South Africa on the first day of the second Test against Sri Lanka in Kandy. Coming in at 34 for four, he mixed defence with aggression to reach his hundred off 178 balls. His innings of 117 not out included 13 fours and two sixes.

The vice-captain Mark Boucher also played his part. He made 61 before he was run out by Muthiah Muralitharan after Klusener had called him for a quick single. South Africa's last five wickets added 219.

fields.headline: Golden Brown shows true colours
fields.standfirst:
Northamptonshire 318 & 176
Warwickshire 236 & 204
Northamptonshire win by 54 runs
fields.trailText:
Northamptonshire 318 & 176
Warwickshire 236 & 204
Northamptonshire win by 54 runs.
fields.body:
A fair number of folk, no doubt, regard the notion of a Jason representing England at cricket as only marginally less offensive than a Kylie. Jason Gallian was permissible - he is Australian, after all - but a Jason from Newcastle-under-Lyme? Jason Brown's message, therefore, is plain. Be afraid. Be very afraid.

The former Northamptonshire coach John Emburey rates Brown as the best spin prospect in the land. To watch him end Warwickshire's unbeaten record in the championship yesterday was to learn that contradiction is unwise.

Summoned for the 13th over with his side two wickets to the good on a turning but far from spiteful pitch, the off-spinner struck with his initial offering, sent back four men in his first 25 balls, then picked his way through the remainder of the hosts' largely supine order to finish with six for 90. Throw in his five for 88 on Saturday and he has totted up six nap hands in 21 first-class outings, as close to meteoric as any English twirler since Derek Underwood claimed 100 wickets in his maiden campaign nearly four decades ago.

That those 21 games have spanned five seasons is attributable to Northants' preference for Graeme Swann, a vastly superior bat, and Michael Davies, whose recent bout of the yips has allowed Brown his first extended run.

Swann looped most of his efforts in the general direction of Mars. Of his two victims, one was Allan Donald, and Nick Knight's dismissal was entirely due to David Sales's diving interception of a meaty drive.

Not everything is in Brown's favour. A No11 with no obvious expertise afield, he is far from the "three-dimensional" player the England hierarchy crave. Wiser, surely, to reflect on how he earns his corn. David Hemp, Trevor Penney, Dougie Brown and Ashley Giles were all deceived by variations in flight and line as much as turn. Better yet, when Neil Smith decided that attack was the only option, Brown withstood the assault and eventually nailed his man.

All of which distracted from the exploits of the home spinners, who whisked Northants' last seven out for 46. Ultimately the difference between the sides came down to the eagerness of Matthew Hayden and Mal Loye to use their feet in the opening half-hour, scoring 46 runs before the latter fell to a dazzling take at leg slip by Dominic Ostler.

Smith wound up with only his second five-wicket haul in four seasons while Giles claimed 11 for 196 all told, becoming in the process the first twirler to 50 scalps. That he beat Messrs Warne, Saqlain and Kumble will be something to tell the grandkids.

So, perhaps, will the chairman of selectors' assertion that Giles "could not have done more" to turn himself into a worthy No8, confirmation, presumably, that he will be one of three slow men on the subcontinent this winter. To make Brown jump through the same hoop would be a waste of potential.

Smith wound up with only his second five-wicket haul in four seasons while Giles claimed 11 for 196 all told, becoming in the process the first twirler to 50 scalps. That he beat Messrs Warne, Saqlain and Kumble will be something to tell the grandkids. So, perhaps, will the chairman of selectors' assertion that Giles "could not have done more" to turn himself into a worthy No8, confirmation, presumably, that he will be one of three slow men on the subcontinent this winter. To make Brown jump through the same hoop would be a waste of potential.

fields.headline: Bevan keeps Sussex in hunt
fields.standfirst:
Middlesex 227 & 283
Sussex 243 & 118-3
fields.trailText:
Middlesex 227 & 283
Sussex 243 & 118-3.
fields.body:
The Sussex faithful know well enough that Michael Bevan is for them the relevant batsman in this oscillating match. Sussex, with three second-innings wickets gone, are still 150 short.

But the Australian left-hander, the country's greatest crease monopoliser these days, is 57 not out, just 18 runs short of his 1,000 for the season. When Grandsire Triples on the bells of the adjacent parish church had ended, to be replaced by organ sounds for evensong, the game still looked as open as ever.

Little has seemed likely, however, to dislodge Bevan or interfere with his statistical intentions. He immediately took on Phil Tufnell, though the bowler held his nerve, accounting for Toby Peirce - as Mark Ramprakash held a difficult running catch over his left shoulder - and more significantly Chris Adams, with some turn and lift, shortly before the end.

It was again, though, Ramprakash's day. He scored his 50th hundred, but was more ruminative than on Friday. This was the fourth time he had composed a century in both innings; previously it had been at Uxbridge, twice, and Canterbury.

Yet it would not have been achieved without Richard Johnson to lend support with some wisdom, resistance and selective scoring. We still think of him mainly for his 10 wickets at Derby six years ago, but it was Johnson's batting that stopped Sussex in their tracks.

Middlesex, who had lost three wickets overnight, were four more deficient by lunch and the contest, conducive as it was to spin and marathon bowling stints - to counter some heroic, if isolated, batting by the home county - was taking on an intriguing shape. Owais Shah top-edged a return catch to James Kirtley and David Nash was caught down the leg side off the same bowler.

Ramprakash was in danger of becoming a forlorn figure as he searched in vain at this stage for a partner. It did not help when Umer Rashid's accuracy and patience was now rewarded. Keith Dutch slashed wantonly and was caught behind, and Simon Cook prodded to short-leg. Middlesex were 176 for seven, the compounded frailties of the season were apparent and a third-day finish was not being ruled out.

Sussex were a bowler short because Robin Martin-Jenkins was troubled with sore shins; this disadvantage was cancelled out by Johnson's knee injury. When he batted he needed his captain Justin Langer to do the running for him. Johnson may have limped but there was nothing seriously wrong with his approach. He played for a long time with a pronounced dead bat: the unwavering bit actor found on his cues while leaving the acclaimed lead to get on proficiently with the bigger speeches. Together, a genuine complementary alliance, that kept Middlesex in the game.

There were no pyrotechnics in the batting. Ramprakash hit only eight boundaries although they were, in terms of co-ordination, all worth coming to see. The cricket from him was contemplatively calm as he kept an eye on the board, analysing what he had to do.

Johnson put Bevan away into the trees for a straight six and he collected nine fours before being taken at the wicket. His runner waited to pat his back as he came off. Ramprakash soon followed, superbly held at extra cover by Tony Cottey.

But Middlesex, with increased muscle at the end, had got to an unlikely 283. Kirtley and Rashid, in their different ways, each took four wickets. Sussex may have played an extra spinner, Justin Bates, but he was given surprisingly few overs and these in truth proved expensive.

webTitle: A single Test, a century for two

fields.headline: A single Test, a century for two
fields.standfirst: Mike Selvey  salutes Atherton and Stewart, partners playing their 100th Tests this week
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey salutes Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart, partners playing their 100th Tests this week.
fields.body:
Chalk and cheese: they seem to have been around for ever, these two very individual individuals. Yin and yang; the regimental sergeant major with get-your-bleedin'-'air-cut standards and creases you could shave with and the lippy, know-all, stuff-it squaddie; Savile Row and an explosion in an Oxfam shop; school leaver and Cambridge graduate; Stan Laurel and Thomas Hardy; the Gaffer and Captain Grumpy; Alec Stewart and Mike Atherton.

Almost 11 years ago Atherton, at the age of 21, made his debut for England against Australia at Trent Bridge, watched Geoff Marsh and Mark Taylor bat through the first day and then, when finally it was his turn, at No3, made nought. He made 47 in the second innings but England lost by an innings and plenty. It had been a harsh start.

One hundred and ninety eight days after Atherton's first appearance Stewart made his own debut, at Sabina Park in Kingston ("they'd sent Athers off for a quiet time on the A tour"), and, also batting at three, hit his first ball to the boundary, scored 13 before Ian Bishop got him and had just come to the crease in the second innings when Wayne Larkins hit the runs that completed a nine-wicket win.

Chalk and cheese, separate and yet together and about to join an exclusive club of England cricketers - Graham Gooch, David Gower, Colin Cowdrey, Geoff Boycott and Ian Botham - who have played 100 Test matches. One or, more likely, both will surely go on to pass Gooch at 118 and one of them become the highest capped Englishman of them all.

Their careers have followed remarkably parallel courses. Atherton has played 182 innings, 167 as opener, and scored 6,713 runs at an average of 38.14 with 14 hundreds. Pakistan and Sri Lanka alone are missing from his set of centuries and there is an opportunity to rectify that this winter. Stewart, for his part, has three fewer innings, 77 as opener, and scored 20 more runs at an average of 40.56. He has one fewer century, missing out only against India, for whom he will have to wait until the winter after next.

Each has captained England, Atherton for a record 52 times, surviving the dirt-in-the-pocket controversy on the way, and Stewart on 14 occasions, two of them abroad during the winter of 1992-93, an 11-match stint following Atherton's resignation until a duff World Cup did for him last year, and the last as stand-in for Nasser Hussain at Lord's recently.

Chalk and cheese: Stewart and Atherton have complemented one another in the same way that unlike polarity attracts but have competed against each other as well, which, says Atherton, is only healthy. Only once, in Bombay seven years ago when, says Atherton, "he called yes and I said no" and Stewart was run out, have they fallen out and that only briefly. Their mutual respect is fulsome.

Atherton is remembered best for his toughness, technique, concentration and ability to raise his game. One is constantly reminded of his confrontations with the great fast bowlers: Allan Donald at Trent Bridge, Courtney Walsh in Jamaica and Curtly Ambrose just about everywhere they opposed each other.

Along with Steve Waugh this has been perhaps the most single-minded batsman of his generation. Stewart is the contrast, a bat-twirling boulevardier, brisk and dapper, with timing courtesy of Swiss watchmakers. He is recalled for the perky exuberance of his back-foot stroke play and the way that in adversity, when the runs have dried up, he has had the courage to stick to what he knows.

Perfect foil

Between them they have provided the spine of the England side, a constant throughout a tough decade where the cricket world has moved on leaving England behind. The first time they opened the batting together, at Sabina Park once again in February 1994, they put on 121 and there have been five more century partnerships at the top of the order from a further 49 opening excursions with an average partnership of almost 40.

"I like to think we were a good team," says Stewart. "Our styles have complemented each other. He is good defensively and less flamboyant than me. When we have opened together, it has been an England strength because he blunts and I take them on. It's like Taylor and Michael Slater were. It is a pity that this particular strength has been weakened by me moving down the order but in doing so we have actually strengthened a different weakness, so it is a question of balance.

"Athers' concentration is just fantastic. I have played with or against no one quite with his ability to block everything out except the job in hand. And the way he has managed to carry on playing with his back problems is an object lesson, for he just got on with it where others would not."

Stewart pinpoints two Atherton innings as exemplifying his qualities. "Johannesburg five years ago obviously just for the concentration and technique required to bat for the period of time to save the game." Atherton spent more than 10 hours at the crease in making his highest score of 185 not out to ensure that a match that seemed doomed was resurrected. "But I look then at his unbeaten 98 at Trent Bridge two years ago because it was a match-winning innings."

Chasing 247 to win the fourth Test and level the series against South Africa, Atherton batted himself to a standstill, enduring and surviving on the way the classic duel with Donald, before Stewart took charge and put the game out of its misery by plastering the ball all round the field. "That was a great way for Alec to finish the match," Atherton points out, "because it was so emphatic, making a statement to take into the final match."

Generally Atherton has been England's insurance policy against defeat: 12 of his centuries have come in the first innings, and, if only twice - his 101 against New Zealand at Trent Bridge in 1994 and his 118 in the second innings at Christchurch 3 years ago - his hundreds have resulted in a victory, then just once, at Georgetown in 1994, has he made a hundred and lost.

Stewart's fine record might have been better still had he not been a victim of his own versatility for, if he has been one of the world's finest opening batsmen for a decade, then for much of that time he has also been its very best allrounder, his wicketkeeping of the highest order and too valuable an asset to ignore in the wider scheme of things. As a result, no other contemporary England player, apart perhaps from Graeme Hick, has stimulated quite the discussion he has. But even someone as willing to be all things to everyone was unable to sustain the triple role of opening batsman-wicketkeeper-captain. His life has been a compromise but one to England's if not his own advantage.

Stewart's fondest memories are of making his debut at Sabina - "a dream, and to play in a winning side too" - and in particular of his historic twin centuries in Bridgetown four years later. "I've played better innings than these but never better throughout a match. Particularly it was on the back of the humiliation in Trinidad, when we were bowled out for 46. From a team perspective, winning the series against South Africa at Headingley was a highlight as I was captain. And there was the time that I carried my bat for 69 out of 175 against Pakistan at Lord's in 1992. I thought I played well there."

Atherton recognises Bridgetown as the benchmark but also cites this latter innings along with Stewart's 190 at Edgbaston in the preceding match (in neither of which he himself played) as representing his partner at his very best.

One other Stewart innings sticks in the mind, though. Three years ago at Sabina Park yet again, on a sadistic surface the like of which had never been seen in a Test, Stewart batted skilfully but above all courageously, taking numerous knocks in making nine before the match was abandoned. "That was 54 minutes of hell," he remembers. "We can look back on it and laugh but it was not funny at the time. You were just trying to avoid getting hurt. The thing is that Athers, who was out, wanted the match scrubbed from the record but I was keen for it to be kept because I was not out. But, yes, I played well there. You can mention that one."

webTitle: Rebekah Wade's first campaign as editor of the News of the World assessed

fields.headline: Vigilance and vigilantes
fields.standfirst:
Rebekah Wade's first campaign as editor of the News of the World assessed

More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Rebekah Wade's first campaign as editor of the News of the World assessed
fields.body:
A week is a very long time in journalism. Because the nature of the job is instantaneous, we who practise it tend to rush to judgment. Within minutes of newspapers arriving at the headquarters of the seemingly infinite number of television and radio outlets that now exist, the pundits' phones are ringing.

Knee-jerk liberal is sought to do battle with knee-jerk rightwinger, or serious, thoughtful broadsheet journalist is matched against trivial, thoughtless tabloid journalist. The script is written before the opponents have a chance to think. Rushing from their red and blue corners, they swap punches at the urging of an "impartial" referee anxious to promote as dirty a fight as possible.

The lower the blow the better the broadcast. Controversy is good because it stimulates the viewers and listeners to take sides too. So it was following last Sunday's surprise issue of the News of the World which named and shamed a number of alleged paedophiles.

According to a host of liberal commentators and, interestingly, the Daily Telegraph, the issue was clear: it was a vile and despicable act. It would lead inevitably to vigilante misbehaviour and might also prove counter-productive, driving the named offenders further underground. I said roughly that, and with some passion, on radio on Monday, describing it as a foolish initiative. I pointed to that day's Daily Mail story about a man mistakenly identified as one of the pictured sex offenders. He had been abused and a brick had been thrown through his window. He could have been killed.

Even though the News of the World had urged people not to engage in vigilante action, it was bound to happen. If children are given a box of matches and told not to light a fire, do we blame the child for burning the house down or the person who supplied the kid with the matches?

Asked to rehearse the same views a couple of days later on Irish radio, I took a similar line. On both occasions, though, I baulked at the suggestion that the News of the World's new editor, Rebekah Wade, had come up with the idea either to make her mark or as a cynical attempt to boost sales. It seemed too far-fetched. I had listened carefully to broadcast interviews with two of the paper's experienced senior executives, Bob Warren and Stuart Kuttner, and detected that they were not simply following the corporate line out of a sense of duty. Their support was whole-hearted.

As for the idea of it being a circulation gimmick, my researches indicate that the charge is well wide of the mark. In fact, Wade was so certain that a paper which led on a campaign rather than a titillating sex scandal would lose sales that - on her advice - the print run was reduced by some 80,000 copies.

Instead, sales took off. Early, unaudited figures suggest a rise of about 95,000 to a total of 4,065,000, with returns so low as to be negligible. Word of mouth and TV publicity undoubtedly helped. Some newsagents were still selling News of the Worlds on Monday morning.

Then it was suggested that Wade was unable or unwilling to face her critics. According to the Daily Telegraph, "the feeling that the campaign was misjudged - and that Wade is coming to realise the fact - has been reinforced by her refusal to defend it publicly". The trade weekly, Press Gazette, also referred to her "curious silence", as if she was embarrassed by what she had done.

I think we can discount that particular claim. Wade has adopted the philosophy expounded by the successful Mirror editor of the 1960s, Lee Howard, who said: "I believe in the anonymity of editors. I think their papers should speak for them."

Anyway, Wade showed yesterday that she certainly isn't running away from the issue. She devoted no fewer than 10 pages to the naming and shaming issue, vigorously defending her campaign. The front page was dominated by a cut-out petition to send to home secretary Jack Straw. A further 50 offenders were named, and four pages of letters from readers were published in a pull-out. The paper has received 5,000 letters, of which only 15 were critical. Of some 2,000 emails, only a handful thought the paper wrong. Most of the week the newsdesk was inundated with callers offering the paper their support.

One of the most surprising supporters was the misidentified man, posing with the petition and saying: "What are a few stones thrown against my window when a child's life might be saved?"

To show how serious she is, Wade flew in from the US the parents of a child who was killed by a paedophile and who secured the passing of legislation which ensures that people must be told when freed sex offenders return to their neighbourhood. Named after their child, it is a form of "Megan's law" that Wade (and the Mirror, in a somewhat supportive leader) wants the British government to introduce.

Straw, whose officials have evidently looked at Megan's law, has rejected the idea and is known to have been appalled by the News of the World's campaign. There are rumours that he told Wade so in an edgy phone conversation last week.

One of Straw's objections to the name-and-shame list, which I share, is its indiscriminate nature. Why should a woman who engaged in consensual sex with an under-age youth be named alongside a man who forced himself on a tiny child? Is a person who downloads computer porn, no matter how disgusting, as much a threat to the public as a convicted rapist?

I understand that the only proper complaint to the press complaints commission so far has come from a woman contesting the accuracy of the description of her offences, arguing that her inclusion was therefore invalid. The PCC did have a preliminary discussion about the whole affair on Wednesday, but reached no conclusion. Doubtless an investigation will follow.

So have I changed my mind after my initial knee-jerk response? Up to a point, yes. I remain worried about the possibility of "lynch law" outrages, despite Wade's leader yesterday urging vigilance rather than vigilantism. I think the definition of who appears on any list requires very careful monitoring and if the paper makes mistakes it should be required by the PCC to publish corrections. Complaints should therefore be dealt with as fast as possible.

I am also unsure whether it helps people to understand the awful truth of most attacks on children: they happen within the home and are usually committed by someone known to the child. Attacks by strangers are mercifully rare.

But I take on board the argument that there is a policy vacuum in which the authorities appear uncertain how to deal with the phenomenon of paedophiles who reoffend. In that sense, the News of the World has attempted to perform a public service.

I am certain that Wade has not acted from base commercial motives. She clearly believes she has done right by her readers. Her fear - our fear - must be that an innocent will suffer. The fact that the first victim has given the campaign his blessing should not blind us to the possibility of a far worse mistake in future. Wade, an editor for barely two months, has taken an enormous risk.

The PCC did have a preliminary discussion about the whole affair on Wednesday, but reached no conclusion. Doubtless an investigation will follow. So have I changed my mind after my initial knee-jerk response? Up to a point, yes. I remain worried about the possibility of "lynch law" outrages, despite Wade's leader yesterday urging vigilance rather than vigilantism. I think the definition of who appears on any list requires very careful monitoring and if the paper makes mistakes it should be required by the PCC to publish corrections. Complaints should therefore be dealt with as fast as possible. I am also unsure whether it helps people to understand the awful truth of most attacks on children: they happen within the home and are usually committed by someone known to the child. Attacks by strangers are mercifully rare. But I take on board the argument that there is a policy vacuum in which the authorities appear uncertain how to deal with the phenomenon of paedophiles who reoffend. In that sense, the News of the World has attempted to perform a public service. I am certain that Wade has not acted from base commercial motives. She clearly believes she has done right by her readers. Her fear - our fear - must be that an innocent will suffer. The fact that the first victim has given the campaign his blessing should not blind us to the possibility of a far worse mistake in future. Wade, an editor for barely two months, has taken an enormous risk.

webTitle: Supermarket pricing report due, as shops feel squeeze

fields.headline: Supermarket pricing report due, as shops feel squeeze
fields.body:
The competition commission is due to deliver its long-awaited report on supermarket pricing to the government today, but the demands it will make of the UK's leading chains come on the heels of increasing pressures on the industry fuelled by overseas competition.

According to new retail analysis also published today, three of the five major chains could shut down over the next five years. Wal-Mart's UK arrival this month has led to a programme of cost-cutting that has disturbed the grocery retailing industry.

The competition commission's findings will remain confidential for another eight to 10 weeks, but the report is not expected to be strongly critical of the industry, despite months of claims that UK shoppers pay more for their groceries than consumers in other EU countries.

Over the last 18 months the inquiry into the £60bn-a-year market occupied by the big five - Tesco, Asda, Sainsbury's, Morrisons and Safeway - investigated the effect of possible supermarket monopolies on the public interest.

The commission has already said it has found "only limited evidence of excessive profitability", and that grocery prices in the UK are lower than in some comparable EU countries.

The report is expected to focus on two areas of concern: goods pricing and supermarkets' use of suppliers. Supermarket chains could be told to stop abusing their buying power to squeeze prices when dealing with farmers and other suppliers.

The commission could also recommend the closure of stores in areas where one chain has an unfair market share, and will say prices should be no higher in areas where one supermarket corners the market than in areas where shoppers have a choice of three or four different chains.

The commission is expected to recommend that supermarkets post prices on their websites to enable consumers to "shop around". The commission may also press the government to set up a system whereby the big supermarkets send detailed accounts of their profit margins to competition watchdogs every six months.

Supermarket heads have described the internet idea as unworkable, as it would mean posting tens of thousands of product prices on a daily basis. The proposals to reveal their profit details are equally unrealistic, they say, as stores would be required to deliver both cost price and retail price details for every single product line.

The inquiry has received more than 200 submissions, questioned 400 suppliers and 50 local authorities, and held 35 hearings in London, Birmingham and Belfast. Tesco, Asda, Sainsbury's, Morrisons and Safeway were also called to make submissions earlier this year.

Meanwhile, a study published today by retail analyst Verdict Research said heightened price competition among UK supermarkets could shut down three of the UK's top five supermarket chains within the next five years.

According to Verdict, price competition, now incorporating petrol, is set to reach new levels with both Tesco and Asda (backed by US giant Wal-Mart) raising the tempo in the supermarket price war.

Both Safeway and Somerfield, which is struggling under the burden of ailing discount chain Kwik Save, are potential takeover targets. Sainsbury's, struggling against Asda to hold on to the number two slot, was another possible candidate for acquisition, Verdict suggested.
