webTitle: Tell us what to watch, wise ones

fields.headline: Tell us what to watch, wise ones
fields.trailText: Now, spot the deliberate mistake: "The other thing that irks me about Badger is that it isn't nearly as bad as I had hoped. Kieran Prendiville's script is serviceable; Robson Greene's hero is personable . . ."
fields.body:
Now, spot the deliberate mistake: "The other thing that irks me about Badger is that it isn't nearly as bad as I had hoped. Kieran Prendiville's script is serviceable; Robson Greene's hero is personable . . ."

Students of television trivia will know that Robson Green's surname does not have an "e" on the end. Perhaps the television reviewer had confused Robson with Richard Greene, the legendary Robin Hood.

Unfortunately, that is only the beginning. This distinguished television critic had not only failed on his spell-check but clearly can't tell his Robson from his Jerome. The BBC drama series Badger, of course, stars Jerome Flynn not Robson Green.

Such errors are not as rare as sightings of the Great Auk. Comedy writers Laurence Marks and Maurice Gran were recently flattered and angered in equal measure when they were credited in one broadsheet review as the authors of Till Death Do Us Part. I presume the same critic thought Johnny Speight wrote Birds of a Feather.

Television producers have a love-hate relationship with critics. You love them when they like your programmes and hate them when they don't. We are all vain enough to be pleased with a good review or to blame the messenger when we don't get it right.

Television needs intelligent informed criticism. Critics should encourage the good, champion the innovative and help winnow out the bad. Producers will accept criticism when it is fair.

One newspaper recently claimed that Michael Barrymore's Bob Martin had been recommissioned despite low ratings because of one good review in the Spectator. Apparently, this impressed advertisers in search of the elusive upmarket viewer. Most time-buyers are more likely to be impressed by a good review in Loaded or FHM, but the story shows the power, real or imagined, of television criticism.

Most newspapers think anyone can write about TV, whether or not they have any understanding or passion for the medium, that there is no specialist knowledge required. Some newspapers take the same approach to food. Indeed, television writers often pop up as restaurant reviewers as well. As Marks and Gran put it: "Anyone with a pen and a pot of bile to dip it in is allowed to strut his stuff on the TV Page."

Newspapers do not treat opera or dance or architecture so casually. It is hard to remember who is the number-one critic on the Times: or understand why the Observer hires a different preview writer for every day, thus confusing the reader.

We measure our own tastes against those of critics whose perspective we have grown to understand. If we like Waldemar Januszczak's approach to art, and he recommends an exhibition, then it's probably worth a visit. Developing that kind of cultural understanding for the work of a television critic is almost impossible.

There are, of course, notable exceptions. Victor Lewis-Smith is a distinctive presence in the London Evening Standard, but as he possesses more venom than the entire snake population of Africa, his brilliant writing is more often destructive than constructive. Jaci Stephen in the Mail on Sunday writes with a passion for television that is lacking elsewhere. The occasional column by the best of them all, the eternally perceptive and witty Nancy Banks-Smith in the Guardian, is a treat.

Perhaps criticism is like television itself; there is so much of it that there are bound to be only a few high spots. Sitting at home watching the programmes on cassettes biked round from the press offices of broadcasters is an unreal way of reviewing an art form. The theatre or opera critic at least sees the performance with an audience.

So what is it that makes so many critics hate television? AA Gill, an entertaining reviewer himself, revealingly said last year: "I don't know of any other cultural form where the perpetrators have such a low opinion of their audience, except perhaps strip clubs . . . television people regularly say, 'I'm making a load of crap for the BBC'."

My own experience is exactly the opposite. However low the budget, whatever the genre, television production teams invariably work with a commitment and professionalism which is very striking. Gill's comment tells us more about jaundiced reviewing than jaundiced television production.

As television choice widens and as electronic programme guides and personal video recorders increasingly shape our viewing, both producers and viewers will need skilled television criticism more than ever.

In this vast sea of channels, we need writers who will highlight the surprising, understand the different and, amidst the confusion of choice, point us towards what is best. In the multi-channel world newspapers will serve their readers better if they take television more seriously.

 John Willis is chief executive, United Productions

fields.headline: Crippled Barak limps on
fields.standfirst: A double blow by Israeli MPs has left the prime minister badly weakened, writes former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Monday, 7pm: A double blow by Israeli MPs has left the prime minister badly weakened, writes former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Prime minister Ehud Barak has been dealt a colossal double blow by the Israeli parliament, narrowly surviving an opposition motion of no confidence after seeing his ally and elder statesman Shimon Peres stunningly defeated in his bid for the national presidency.

Although Mr Barak scraped through this afternoon's no confidence motion he was humiliatingly unable to secure even a simple majority in the Knesset (chamber of deputies). Members voted 50-50 on the confidence motion, which thus failed to attract the 61 votes needed to force Mr Barak from office. There were eight abstentions and a number of MPs absent from the session. The result was an ominous signal to the Labour prime minister that his parliamentary base has crumbled.

Earlier today, MPs choosing a president to replace Ezer Weizman snubbed Mr Peres, a former Labour prime minister and Nobel laureate, voting instead for Moshe Katsav, a lightweight supporter of the rightwing Likud faction.

Both votes are hugely damaging to Mr Barak's ambition to lead the nation into a permanent peace settlement with the Palestinians and with Israel's Arab neighbours.

The prime minister had hoped to conclude a draft peace treaty with Palestinian president Yasser Arafat before September 13, the somewhat notional deadline for a final deal.

Today the Israeli leader was forced to admit that he no longer had the backing of the Knesset to negotiate a settlement. He said he was confident that public opinion would rally behind the peace process, and force a shift in parliamentary attitudes. But Mr Barak's ship of state has been badly holed below the waterline, and may yet sink long before he can reach a deal with Mr Arafat.

The two men left Washington last week after a two-week summit which made steady progress on the huge outstanding issues, but which foundered on the biggest one of all: future control of Jerusalem.

When Mr Arafat returned home, he was given a hero's welcome for his tough stand over the city, which he insists must be the capital of a future Palestinian state. Mr Barak, by contrast, flew back into a storm of rightwing criticism of his willingness even to contemplate conceding more land - and a role in Jerusalem - to the Palestinians.

That anger has now erupted in the Knesset, which even in placid times is a nest of vituperative intrigue. Several former Barak allies have defected to the opposition, reducing his effective strength in the 120-member chamber to just 42.

The beleaguered former army chief now has two remaining major assets. One is that he was directly elected by the people in May last year, and thus has a popular and democratic mandate to stay on, even with a parliamentary minority. The other is that today's votes came at the end of the Knesset session. The parliament will not reassemble until October, which at least gives Mr Barak a chance to make running repairs to his battered administration.

fields.headline: Money can keep British science in the race
fields.standfirst: Special report: road to the manifesto
fields.trailText: Forget about the euro. Think about the erg. The true currency of survival is measured in units of energy.
fields.body:
Forget about the euro. Think about the erg. The true currency of survival is measured in units of energy.

All living things depend on the sun. The wealth of the 20th century was powered by sunshine stored in the form of coal and oil: millions of years of sunshine squandered in a mere century. To return all that stored carbon to the atmosphere in such a hurry was asking for trouble. Man-made global warming is almost certainly on the way. Demand for oil will one day outstrip supply.

Three things - a population explosion, climate change and an energy crisis - will set the agenda for the 21st century. They are notes from the planetary bank manager, warning of capital overdrawn. They raise huge political problems, but they present a clear challenge for science.

Here is the problem. The human population explosion from 1bn to 6bn in 200 years has been paid for by the loss of life - other life. Between a third and a half of the land surface has been transformed by human action. Carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased by 30%. Vast tracts of the world are rapidly growing short of water, which means huge areas will go short of food.

One species controls the globe and is obliterating thousands - perhaps tens of thousands - of other species a year.

In this context, Britain's future is inseparable from the rest of humanity's. It was British science - Jenner's vaccine, Lister's hygiene, Brunel's ships and railroads, Rutherford's atom, Fleming's antibiotics - that accelerated the 20th century revolution. It could be British science that finds better ways to handle energy, devises new ways to save the natural world, manipulates crops for more nourishment, outwits disease and extends healthy lifespans.

Only very lately, however, has there been any sign that a British government might put more resources into science - resources that really would make for a better world, or at least forestall a worse one.

Step one is to confront the energy crisis. In the next term, the Department of Trade and Industry should fund more initiatives to save and recycle wasted energy, to fashion machines that need less energy, to construct power supplies that use renewable energy and do not pollute the atmosphere.

A community that does these things must then share the technology: the potential poverty of billions can be alleviated only by clean and reliable sources of energy. Through foreign aid programmes Britain should make sure the know-how gets shared. It is an investment. A developing world with energy to spare is a market for more trade, and more ingenuity, which will create more wealth.

The second step is to put increasing sums of money into the government's natural environment research council, the Natural History Museum, the Royal Botanic Gardens and other world-class institutions dedicated to understanding the planet, from the magnetosphere to the deepest ocean trench, and to making an inventory of the life on it.

The habitats of the forests, savannahs, swamps, reefs and river estuaries are being destroyed, and with them creatures fashioned by millions of years of evolution. Nobody can make a sensible guess as to the number of species on the planet, but half could vanish in the next century. If taxonomists do not take to the field now, the world will not even know what it has lost.

And it will be a loss. The wealth of the pharmaceutical industry, a key part of the British economy, is based on natural genetic material: medicines from plants, antibiotics from bacteria, drugs from slugs and sponges. So the third step is to focus on the genetic machinery of life and learn from it. The medical, biotechnology and biological sciences research councils have begun the basic research, but the prizes will go to the groups with the best backing. Here, too, a second-term government can play its part.

Tomorrow's industry will be a marriage of computing power and biological information, as science begins to understand how genes make proteins, and how proteins assemble themselves into living things. Animals and crops will become genetically engineered: animals will make human proteins, crops will grow human vaccines. The divide between flesh and automata will begin to blur. Life will be understood as software, and disease as a software glitch.

Tissues will be engineered, artificial limbs will be hooked up to nervous systems. The "biochip" will assess the DNA of the patient, and the DNA of the pathogen, and expert systems will offer diagnoses.

These things will start to happen in the lifetime of the next government, and the richest pickings will go to those who get there first. Labour can keep British science in the race by using the country's considerable wealth. This is one of the few problems that really can be solved by throwing money at it.

But who benefits? Just the rich? Or everybody? How wisely, how safely, how effectively these things happen will depend on political will. Science needs the informed consent of voters and taxpayers. Politicians won't pay attention until the people do. So the most important step is to educate a nation in the challenges of tomorrow. It will take skills to cure ills - and that means a government boost to the teaching of science in schools and colleges.

This alchemy will be competitive, but it will also be international. It will be done entirely in the units of the metre, the kilogram, the second. On second thoughts, the erg has no place in it. The unit of currency that will matter most will be not the British erg but its rival measure of energy, the EU's joule. But fear not, Eurosceptics: James Prescott Joule came from Salford.

Pledges

1. More for satellite observation and disaster warning

2. More for conservation in species-rich but cash-poor nations

3. More research into non-polluting energy sources

4. Cheap technology to spread medical benefits to the poor

5. Research into GM crops that genuinely help the poor and hungry

fields.headline: Man re-arrested over Sarah Payne murder
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the murder of Sarah Payne today arrested a man for a second time.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the murder of Sarah Payne today arrested a man for a second time.

Roy Whiting, 41, was originally quizzed by Sussex police about Sarah's suspected abduction soon after she went missing on July 1.

"We can confirm that this is the same man who was originally arrested on the evening of Sunday July 2 in connection with her suspected abduction, and who was subsequently released on police bail pending further inquiries."

The handyman has been in custody since last Sunday, when he was charged with theft, assault and aggravated vehicle-taking following a high-speed car chase.

Eight-year-old Sarah is believed to have been abducted from a field near her grandparents' home near East Preston, West Sussex, on July 1. Her naked body was found dumped in a field beside the A29 near Pulborough two weeks ago.

Detective superintendent Peter Kennet, who is now leading the inquiry, said that police had fresh evidence in the Sarah Payne murder hunt.

He refused to say if the new evidence was forensic of a new witness, but added: "There is fresh evidence that is being followed up, but I couldn't go into the ins and outs of it."

He said police would not confirm the name of the arrested man.

Police now have up to 96 hours to question the man before he must be charged or released.

Mr Kennet said: "Just because someone's arrested it doesn't mean to say that they will be charged."

It is understood that the decision to arrest the man was taken two days ago and Sarah's parents Michael and Sara have been told of the arrest.

webTitle: Petrol giants join the price war

fields.headline: Petrol giants join the price war
fields.standfirst: As national 'dump the pump' protest by motorists draws near, big oil firms and supermarkets cut the cost of fuel
fields.trailText: The petrol wars escalated yesterday as two of the big oil companies joined in price cutting, on the eve of a national boycott of filling stations in protest at fuel duty.
fields.body:
The petrol wars escalated yesterday as two of the big oil companies joined in price cutting, on the eve of a national boycott of filling stations in protest at fuel duty.

The announcements by Esso and Texaco come in the wake of price cuts of up to 4p per litre by supermarkets Morrisons and Sainsbury's. Tesco joined the battle at the weekend, matching the price tag of 79.9p a litre. Asda has said it is offering petrol at 79.5p per litre at some sites.

The retailers and oil companies will be hoping the fall in prices can offset the effects of the "dump the pump" protest, which organisers hope will leave forecourts across the country deserted tomorrow.

Esso said it would look to make further cuts on top of the 2p cut it made earlier this month. A spokesman said that it was company policy to monitor 10,000 rival stations and ensure that its own prices were among the lowest.

"We have already seen prices come down to due to competitive pressures but we will continue to keep competitive."

Texaco said it had noted the move by supermarkets and would not risk losing customers. "Our pricing policy is to remain competitive," said a spokeswoman.

BP Amoco, which lowered its average price for unleaded petrol by 1p last Monday, said it would reflect further falls in price at the pumps.

A combination of increased taxation and a nine-year high in oil prices has led British motorists to pay the dearest petrol prices in Europe, at rates approaching 90p a litre. Earlier this summer the price of petrol was a key factor in pushing inflation to a two-year high.

The oil companies insist that pricing is based on a range of issues including crude and finished petroleum product costs, storage and transportation. They point out that the strong pound has also pushed up prices as petroleum products are in US dollars.

Big oil companies are also aware they make easy targets for politicians anxious to take the heat off their own taxation policies. The large salaries enjoyed by the oilmen leave them open to attack.

Oil prices have been coming down in recent weeks after Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest producer, decided it was time to pump out more supply to bring down crude from a level of more than $30 (£20) a barrel to a target of around $25. Petrol prices should naturally follow, but they are also subject to their own refinery demand-and-supply pressures.

Regardless of prices it is the government that provides the focus for motorists' ire according to Garry Russell, an IT consultant turned petrol activist who is coordinating the boycott of service station forecourts. The protest, supported by the Road Haulage Association and tabloid newspapers, starts tomorrow and will be repeated every Monday thereafter.

"We're picking up an awful lot of anti-government feeling on this issue. People would rather pay an extra penny on income tax than petrol tax," he said.

"If we sit back and do nothing then before too long we will have the £5 gallon. If we paid as much tax on certain items as we do on petrol then a first-class stamp would cost £1.13, a cinema ticket would be nearly £22 and a loaf of bread would be £1.58.

"This is a solidarity issue, a chance for the motorist's voice to be heard. If we can turn the forecourts into ghost towns tomorrow that will have been achieved.

"The impression we get through the website is that there's a great awareness now of how the price of a litre of petrol is made up," he said.

Every litre of petrol or diesel sold is subject to a fixed sum of 48.82p in duty. On a litre of unleaded petrol retailing at 85p, VAT takes the amount of duty paid to 61.5p, or 72% of the total price. The remaining share of income is split between supply costs and a profit of around 3.5p for the oil companies.

The government has defended the rates of duty by pointing out that 16p of the 18p rise in prices in the last year was due to the price of oil.

In the last budget the fuel price escalator was removed in favour of an inflation-only rise in duty. Future price adjustments will be set on a budget-to-budget basis.

Treasury officials stress that a 2p cut in fuel duty would cost £1bn, money that would have to be raised by other forms of taxation. They also point out that high duty is intended to encourage greater awareness of the environmental cost of car use.

The opposition parties moved yesterday to increase pressure on the government over the issue. The Conservative party declared last Saturday national fuel day in 325 constituencies and collected an unknown number of signatures for a petition demanding a lowering of fuel duty.

"I have never found it so easy to get people to sign a petition. People were storming up to us to sign," said the shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, after campaigning in Colchester, Essex.

The Liberal Democrats demanded a five-year freeze in petrol tax rises and called for a link between carbon-dioxide emission and tax. The SNP, meanwhile, claimed that high motoring costs were a major factor in the 10% drop in tourist numbers.

Petrol companies and the government could be heartened by a new survey showing that fewer than one in 10 motorists would ditch the car even if the price of petrol more than doubled to £2 a litre.

Two in five would not part with their vehicle for anything, according to the survey for Churchill Insurance, which also found that more than three in four motorists use their cars every day.

Motorists queue up as 'dearest place in Wiltshire' slashes prices

Reg and Doreen Giddings dread the day when soaring petrol prices finally prevent them from tending their son's grave.

For years they have made a weekly pilgrimage to the resting place of the child they lost in a road accident when he was 29, struggling to make sure that the 20-mile trip remains a permanent feature in their lives.

The couple, both in their 70s and on state pensions, feel the pain of high petrol costs acutely. Mr Giddings said: "The combination of a very poor pension and petrol prices as they are make it very difficult for us to maintain a good standard of living. We go every week to Swindon to tend our son's grave. The price of petrol is threatening it. It would be a very serious blow to us if the cost of running the car became unbearable."

The couple's difficulties are increased by their proximity to one of the country's most expensive petrol stations, Bridge Garage, in Marlborough, Wiltshire.

Until 10 days ago the cost of a litre of unleaded petrol at Bridge Garage was 91.9p.

Like millions of Britons angry at the high price of fuel, the focus of tomorrow's Dump the Pump protest, Mr Giddings is forced to shop around. He fears that the couple's rural location and a lack of public transport mean that if they are forced to give up the car they will lose "their lifeline to the world".

But yesterday, like many, they were lured back to Bridge Garage by the offer of a 10p-a-litre discount on unleaded petrol to cash buyers. Marlborough residents who for months have ventured further afield to get cheaper fuel appear to have returned en masse.

Sam Bennet, 23, admitted she felt she was being ripped off by the cost of petrol and was "helpless to do much about it". The accounts clerk, who had been avoiding Bridge Garage despite having to travel several miles to find another service station, said: "In the past if I ever had to come here I would put under £5 in the tank and then go to another garage. This one is so renowned. Everybody knows it and avoids it. This is the busiest I have seen it in a long time."

Ms Barnett said she was in favour of the boycott of petrol stations tomorrow but, like many people, was doubtful such action would have a serious impact on government policy.

Claire Barnett, the manager of Bridge Garage, said the fuel issue was a highly controversial topic that needed to be dealt with sensibly by the government. She said there had been many occasions when motorists had come in without buying petrol to hurl abuse and complain about the prices.

She dismissed the Dump the Pump campaign: "People still need to go to work so they'll just get it a day before or after. We aren't bothered. It seems like an empty gesture. I think people are quite fired up about it at the moment. The government needs to do something about this. People are just paying through the nose all the time."

Fifteen miles away drivers were queuing at Sainsbury's in Swindon for an even cheaper deal. Most of those fighting for access to the 15 pumps admitted they had chosen the supermarket because of the price - unleaded petrol was reduced to 79.9p a litre on Saturday - and many believed shopping around was the only way to soften the impact of petrol costs.

Morley Pennington, 54, from Crediton, Devon, summed that feeling up: "What is really going to stop people driving their cars at the end of the day? Nothing. And the government know that. They know they have people in the palm of their hands. One day of protest won't make a blind bit of difference."

fields.headline: Ssssh! Don't mention GM
fields.standfirst: The US government is trying to bully the EU into a ban on labelling GM food because they know people won't buy it, reports Joanna Griffiths
fields.trailText: Monday, 5.45pm: The US government is trying to bully the EU into a ban on labelling GM food because they know people won't buy it, reports Joanna Griffiths.
fields.body:
News came from Washington today that the US government is considering making a formal complaint to the World Trade Organisation in Geneva on the grounds that labelling GM foods is a restraint of trade. The US has said it will ask the WTO to impose sanctions on EU exports if GM labels are not removed from US food exports.

A spokeswoman for the US food and drug administration (FDA) called the labelling of GM foods "economic fraud". She continued: "We would not have allowed these products on the market if they were not safe, they are the same as non-GM food, so they do not require a label." Any labelling of GM foods as GM foods is, she suggested, "trade discrimination and therefore wrong".

This is quite extraordinary behaviour. The purpose of labelling is to inform the public of the ingredients of the food they eat. The FDA claims such information is "fraud". Their system - to deliberately neglect to inform the public - is, by their terms, "not fraud".

The FDA has accused the EU of "discriminating" against GM foods by labelling them as GM foods. This is particularly unfair, their spokeswoman suggests, because GM foods are the "same" as non-GM food. But, GM foods are not "the same" as non-GM foods. GM foods are made by altering the properties of plants by direct scientific intervention in the make-up of their DNA. Non-GM foods are not made in this way.

The US government and FDA demands are also extraordinary business practice. They are trying to boost the sales of an unpopular US export by asking trading countries to treat it in 'the same' way as other products which sell better. This makes it starkly obvious that GM manufacturers and promoters in the USA believe the European public perceives no positive benefit in GM food manufacture.

They do not believe that advertising campaigns, however backed by billions, will persuade this public that there are any positive reasons - any positive benefits of health, or cost, or distribution, or resource-use - for eating GM foods. Instead, the best US GM companies can hope for is that European consumers can be conned into buying GM foods without realising.

The FDA is an organisation given to creative use of labelling for GM foods. In 1997, they produced a staggering ruling that GM foods could be labelled as "organic". And the recent statement from Washington is merely the latest stage in a long line of US to Europe pressure over food practice.

In talks at Downing Street in 1998, Clinton was briefed to warn Blair of the huge cost to US corporations of current EU approval processes for GM foods. At the same summit, US representatives also expressed disapproval at the labelling of GM foods.

The EU ban on the use of hormones in beef has led to a 12 year embargo on US beef. In response, the US has imposed 100% tariffs on French cheese and truffles and German and French mustards. Britain has nominated itself in support of the US, while being bound by EU legislation.

There is a danger that the US bullying will work. Two weeks ago the European commission stated that it would mount a proposal to reverse the current European moratorium on the introduction of new types of GM food.

Eighteen GM food products have already been passed for commercial use in the EU. Proposals such as this latest one fly in the face of popular opinion - which remains vehemently opposed. A recent EU poll found that 66% of Europeans saw GM foods as a health hazard.

The USA, a country which thrives on free market competition, has conceded that it cannot compete with the organic trade. It needs special dispensation. It needs GM foods to be sold as if they are something other than GM foods. It needs the public to be lied to.

webTitle: Precocious schoolboys have a head start on Bill Gates with portal for teenagers

fields.headline: Precocious schoolboys have a head start on Bill Gates with portal for teenagers
fields.trailText: The internet has apparently made bucketloads of clever young people into millionaires. We hope a Rools partnership with a couple of teenage entrepreneurs, Nick Bell and Robbie Hodgekiss at Teenfront.com, will lead them to riches. We can exclusively reveal that Rools has completed an investment in a portal for teenagers that has been developed by Nick and Robbie, both aged 16.
fields.body:
The internet has apparently made bucketloads of clever young people into millionaires. We hope a Rools partnership with a couple of teenage entrepreneurs, Nick Bell and Robbie Hodgekiss at Teenfront.com, will lead them to riches. We can exclusively reveal that Rools has completed an investment in a portal for teenagers that has been developed by Nick and Robbie, both aged 16.

The site was launched in 1998 and for two years acted as a low-key bulletin board, providing links to other sites and cheat information for video games. It is now a fairly comprehensive portal and looks as professional as many sites where large sums of money have been spent on development, offering a range of services from an advice column to product reviews and horoscopes. It has also developed links to leading online services.

Until now, it has not actively pursued revenue streams, but has attracted the attention of several advertisers wishing to target the youth market.

And all this has been achieved on a budget of hundreds of pounds rather than thousands and with relatively limited time. All of the work has been done after school, at weekends or during the holidays. The individuals behind it are impressive - one started his first internet site when he was 12 - and they have a great understanding of the internet and powerful business brains.

The market for online services for teenagers is frenzied, with the launch of a number of big players such as MyKindaPlace, Wowgo and Swizzle. Drawing from the existing business to business and business to consumer abbreviations, the sector has developed its own acronym - B2T for business to teenagers.

The sector is crowded, but lacks a reasonable sized player that is for teenagers by teenagers (T2T perhaps). We came across Teenfront during some market research on teenage portals. The site appeared well designed and well organised, but what attracted us most was the network of regular teenage contributors. It demonstrates a natural understanding of the teenage market - although we're not convinced that all young people are as keen on Dire Straits as Nick and Robbie are.

The site's closeness to its audience is the most important element of the partnership. Teenfront gives us a direct insight into teenagers and helps us develop a service that is most relevant to them - after all, none of us is as young as we used to be. Nick and Robbie face the challenge of developing the site and translating a serious hobby into a larger enterprise. They plan to continue working on Teenfront while studying for A-levels and, after that, at university. Bill Gates started Microsoft as a university student, so these guys have a head start.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools.com a service that enables teenagers to buy online without a credit card.

fields.headline: Walk on the wild side
fields.standfirst: While the government's transport plans are to be applauded, pedestrians, cyclists and local travel needs risk being sidelined
fields.trailText: Transport was always going to be a big winner in the spending review and the chancellor did not disappoint. Investment worth £180bn is being made available to improve roads, bridges and railways - a third of it coming from the private sector. A third will go to railways, £25bn to London and £21bn on major roads. Some £59bn is earmarked for "local transport" including £30bn to cover the backlog of road maintenance.
fields.body:
Transport was always going to be a big winner in the spending review and the chancellor did not disappoint. Investment worth £180bn is being made available to improve roads, bridges and railways - a third of it coming from the private sector. A third will go to railways, £25bn to London and £21bn on major roads. Some £59bn is earmarked for "local transport" including £30bn to cover the backlog of road maintenance.

John Prescott deserved his plaudits. This is serious money and the plan marks a move away from the short-term thinking that has dogged transport policy for decades.

But questions remain. The government has abandoned any attempt to reduce traffic growth. Congestion is the new enemy and drivers will get 40 major road schemes, 100 new bypasses and so on. Most of the non-road money has obvious political appeal. It shows the government doing something to provide alternatives to the car and create opportunities for ministers and mayors to snip ribbons before the cameras.

The plan's aim is a 50% increase in rail passenger journeys over the next decade. Rail travel accounts for less than 1% of the trips we make annually. So the government will invest £60bn to increase rail travel from 1% to 1.5% of trips. Hardly a bargain.

What about urban tram networks, costing up to £350m each? For the price of seven of 25 such schemes, safe walking and cycling routes could be provided for all 25,000 schools in the country.

The problem is that fixed investment does not relate to people's travel needs. Most travel is local. Some 70% of all trips and 56% of car trips are less than five miles; drivers use their cars to travel door-to-door and often visit several destinations in a single journey. Outside cities people need diffuse and flexible travel options.

This is not to argue against major public transport investment. We do, however, need to compare it with cheaper, more cost-effective alternatives - walking, cycling and making roads safer. Mayer Hillman, a long-standing critic of unquestioning support for public transport investment, analysed travel habits in the Netherlands. Despite enjoying superb public transport, the Dutch walk and cycle rather than take the bus, tram or train for all but the longest trips. Walking and cycling account for seven times as many trips in the Netherlands as public transport. They are flexible and door-to-door. In the UK, walking accounts for three times as many journeys as public transport.

New pedestrian crossings, wider pavements and safe cycle tracks would meet travel needs. They would also be popular. A Mori poll for the commission for integrated transport found 88% of the public supported improved conditions for pedestrians, second only to better road maintenance at 91%. Some 77% wanted better conditions for cyclists. And 81% of those asked wanted better railway services and only 44% wanted new tram systems.

Improved walking and cycling conditions would also be far more equitable than investment in long-distance road or rail travel. People on high incomes make three times as many journeys by car or van, over four times as many journeys by train and travel more than three times further overall than those on low incomes.

There is also the question of speed of delivery. However much the government accelerates the planning process, road and rail schemes will take years. They are also likely to prove controversial. People's support for bypasses and railways tends to evaporate when they see the route coming through their allotments. By contrast, improving the quality and safety of the streets could begin at once. It would be a much more tangible use of public funds and it would involve no destruction of cherished landscapes and natural habitats. Above all, it would support the effort to regenerate city centres along the lines suggested by Richard Rogers' urban task force.

Pedestrians and cyclists will get extra money from the Prescott plan. The £30bn for road maintenance should reduce the number of potholes and cracked flagstones. A further £20bn, 11% of the total, will be channelled through local transport plans, five-year transport investment strategies being prepared by councils. But this needs to pay for everything local authorities want to do, including local road building. And councils' record on planning for small-scale transport improvements is not good. Having spent the past 30 years building roads and bypasses, most lack the data, skills and experience needed to plan systematically for walking and cycling. Little wonder light rail and trams seem an attractive option.

Budgets applauded on the day can look less impressive in hindsight. To avoid a similar fate for the Prescott plan, the government should set clear targets for improving the quality and safety of local streets. These might include creating safe routes to every school and providing traffic calming to every community that wants it. Investment in local transport plans needs to be increased, perhaps to a quarter or a third of the £180bn total. A major programme of recruitment and professional development is needed in local authorities, to enable them to invest these additional funds creatively. The Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions will need to increase its staff and deploy more senior civil servants on the so-called "soft modes" of travel.

 Ben Plowden is director of the Pedestrians Association
ben@pedestrians.org.uk

fields.headline: Israeli PM survives no-confidence vote
fields.trailText: Israel's beleaguered prime minister Ehud Barak has narrowly survived a no-confidence motion in parliament over  his willingness to make land concessions to the Palestinians.
fields.body:
Israel's beleaguered prime minister Ehud Barak has narrowly survived a no-confidence motion in parliament over his willingness to make land concessions to the Palestinians.

The 50-50 vote fell short of the 61 votes needed in the 120-seat Knesset (lower house) to topple the government. There were eight abstentions and some deputies did not attend the session.

Although the vote was unsuccessful, it represents another blow to Mr Barak's prestige after his failure to secure a peace deal with the Palestinians in two weeks of talks hosted by US President Bill Clinton at Camp David.

Three parties have already resigned from Mr Barak's government in protest at his apparent willingness to make concessions to the Palestinians, particularly over the sovereignty of Jerusalem, in the interests of reaching an accord. Earlier this month the prime minister survived another no-confidence motion, also called in protest at his attempts to secure a peace deal with the Palestinians.

This afternoon's vote came on the last day of the summer session of the Knesset. Mr Barak will not face another serious parliamentary challenge until October when the house reconvenes.

fields.headline: Award-winning magazine seeks editor
fields.trailText: Tim de Lisle (Special Interest Magazine Editor of the Year) is leaving Wisden Cricket Monthly to concentrate on running Wisden's web operations, so John Wisden & Co require a new editor to drive the magazine onwards.
fields.body:
Tim de Lisle (Special Interest Magazine Editor of the Year) is leaving Wisden Cricket Monthly to concentrate on running Wisden's web operations, so John Wisden & Co require a new editor to drive the magazine onwards.

We need an experienced and committed person of any age and either sex who has a passion for cricket. They must also have a flair for words, pictures and dealing with people.

Experience of cricket journalism and/or magazines in general is a big plus, but lack of either would not necessarily be a bar to an outstanding candidate looking to do something different.

The job is based in west London. Small company, unstuffy atmosphere; salary package by negotiation.

Please apply in writing to Christopher Lane, Managing Director, Wisden, 25 Down Road, Merrow, Guildford, Surrey GU1 2PY, or e-mail wisden@ndirect.co.uk.

To read Wisden's press release on the subject, click here

fields.headline: Wisden's press release
fields.trailText: Tim de Lisle, the award-winning editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly, is leaving the magazine to run an expanded version of the company's website,Wisden.com.
fields.body:
Tim de Lisle, the award-winning editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly, is leaving the magazine to run an expanded version of the company's website,Wisden.com.

Only the second editor in WCM's history, de Lisle succeeded David Frith in April 1996 with a brief to modernise the magazine. At the same time, Matthew Engel of The Guardian became editor-in-chief of John Wisden & Co.

de Lisle, a former cricket correspondent and arts editor on broadsheet newspapers, attracted leading cricket writers such as Scyld Berry and Alan Lee, hired star coach Bob Woolmer as a columnist, and oversaw a full redesign, while maintaining the services that Wisden readers expected, such as news, book reviews, obituaries, Test reports and generous helpings of statistics.

The magazine switched from Guildford to London, from spot colour to full colour, from 44-48 pages to 64-72, and from cow-gum to Apple Macs. It introduced a picture section, TV listings, calendar wallcharts, the Reality Cricket game, an Anglo-Asian column and a guide to the web.

The magazine campaigned successfully for women to be admitted to MCC, culminating in a special Women's Issue in October 1998, which attracted international news coverage by featuring a woman on the cover for the first time.

In November 1999, Wisden Cricket Monthly became the first cricket title to win a British Society of Magazine Editors award when Tim de Lisle was named Editor of the Year (Special Interest Magazines).

Sales, which had been sliding gradually since 1987 with the fortunes of the England team, bottomed out at 16,000 early in 1997 and have since risen to an average of 19,313 (ABC Jan-Dec 1999). Subscriptions have gone up by 55 per cent and market share has grown from 33pc to 40pc.

"Tim has done an absolutely brilliant job at a time when the failures of the England team have made it incredibly difficult to sell cricket magazines in the UK," said Matthew Engel.

Since August 1999, de Lisle has also been editing Wisden.com, a cricket comment service, updated every weekday, which runs its own material as well as tasters from the magazine and the Wisden Almanack. Wisden has spent this year examining all its internet options and is now working on plans for a significantly expanded service.

"Editing the magazine is a great job," de Lisle said. "I am very grateful for the help I have had from Matthew and the rest of an enlightened management committee, as well as the editorial staff, which is small but high-quality, and our excellent publishing team at John Brown.

"It has now become impossible to combine the two roles, and I am excited to be concentrating on the web, which is the biggest opportunity for Wisden since the founding of the Almanack in 1864. Cricket sites are reaching a huge market but as yet there is little sign of editorial quality or independence - the two things Wisden is famous for. We have the best-known brand in cricket publishing and the web gives us a wonderful chance to bring our brand values to a wider audience."

John Wisden & Co is now advertising for a new editor for the magazine.

A major announcement follows shortly about Wisden.com.

fields.headline: Peres pipped for the presidency
fields.standfirst: Today's decision by Israeli MPs to block Shimon Peres's bid for the presidency will do little to ease tensions in the Middle East, warns Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Today's decision by Israeli MPs to block Shimon Peres's bid for the presidency will do little to ease tensions in the Middle East, warns Derek Brown.
fields.body:
One of Israel's most experienced politicians, Shimon Peres, today lost his bid for the presidency in a stunning defeat which could fatally undermine the fragile coalition government headed by his ally, Ehud Barak.

Mr Peres, a former prime minister and Nobel peace laureate, was beaten by 63 votes to 57 in the parliamentary vote by the relatively unknown Moshe Katsav of the rightwing Likud party.

Later today, the Knesset, the Israeli parliament, will vote again on a motion of no confidence in the Barak government.

The Likud opposition, bolstered by its spectacular victory in the presidential vote, will be bidding hard to bring down the coalition and replace it with a new rightwing administration.

A number of Knesset members have defected to the opposition in recent weeks, over Mr Barak's willingness to concede land to the Palestinians.

Rightwingers were especially incensed by the prime minister's apparent offer of shared sovereignty in Jerusalem.

Tensions are running high in the occupied West Bank, partially controlled by the Palestinian National Authority, led by Yasser Arafat. The territory, seized by Israel in the six-day war of 1967, is home to more than 1m Palestinian Arabs, most of whom live in abject poverty.

It is also home to more than 150,000 Jewish settlers, many of them with strong religious beliefs, who have pledged to resist any Israeli withdrawal to the pre-1967 boundaries.

Jerusalem, also captured in 1967, is an even greater source of friction inside Israel, as well as between Israel and the Palestinians.

At the failed Camp David summit earlier this month, Mr Barak stuck to the standard Israeli line that the city will remain its undivided capital. But he offered the Palestinians limited authority over some of the Islamic holy places in the old walled city, and also suggested that a new Palestinian capital could be established in Abu Dis, in the eastern suburbs.

Mr Arafat, who insists that Israel must give up all the territory captured in 1967, rejected Mr Barak's "compromise". He returned from the summit to a hero's welcome, while Mr Barak returned to a storm of rightwing protest.

That storm shows no sign of abating, and some observers believe that the prime minister is now fighting for political survival.

Mr Barak became prime minister last year, with a handsome majority over the incumbent Likudnik, Binyamin Netanyahu. But under Israel's fiendishly complex electoral system, the prime ministerial and parliamentary elections are simultaneous but separate. Although they overwhelmingly endorsed Mr Barak's pro-peace policies, the voters withheld support from his One Nation faction, the successor to the Israeli Labour party.

As a result, Mr Barak became prime minister without a Knesset majority. At present, only 42 members out of 120 in the Knesset support him, and even they are much given to internal feuds and bickering.

The opposition is also deeply divided between secular factions such as Likud and a variety of religious parties.

For Mr Peres, today's presidential poll was a personal and political calamity. He has been at the vortex of Israel's tumultuous politics since before the foundation of the state in 1948. He served three terms as prime minister, and played a key role in the secret negotiations which led to the Israeli-Palestinian outline peace accord of 1993.

He is admired by many Israelis for his mastery of the political black arts - and deeply distrusted by many more, for exactly the same reason.

webTitle: Probation chiefs warn News of the World as paedophiles go into hiding

fields.headline: 'Name and shame' court threat
fields.standfirst:
Probation chiefs warn News of the World as paedophiles go into hiding

More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Probation chiefs are considering legal action against the News of the World if the newspaper does not halt its campaign to "name and shame" sex offenders, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Probation chiefs are considering legal action against the News of the World if the newspaper does not halt its campaign to "name and shame" sex offenders, it emerged yesterday.

The Association of Chief Officers of Probation (Acop) said it might have to explore ways of stopping the campaign through the courts. Its threat came amid growing evidence that many offenders are being driven underground by the campaign, launched in the wake of eight-year-old Sarah Payne's murder.

Yesterday the paper printed the photographs and details of 34 sex offenders, after naming 49 last Sunday. It also called on readers to sign a petition calling on the home secretary, Jack Straw, to introduce legislation giving the public the right to see a register of convicted paedophiles.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, questioned the paper's methods. "It is a noble motive to want to ensure the issue of paedophiles is more widely discussed and children are properly protected," he told BBC 1's Breakfast With Frost.

"But I fear that this is not the right way of going about doing it and I feel it would be wise for the News of the World to listen to the advice of the police."

The Home Office minister Paul Boateng, writing in the Observer, said the decision to name offenders should be taken only by the police and probation services.

Child protection and offenders' organisations are to meet News of the World executives tomorrow to argue that the campaign should be stopped.

Among the bodies expected to be represented are the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, the Association of Chief Police Officers and Acop.

Acop has compiled a report on the impact of the campaign and has written to the News of the World and the press complaints commission spelling out its concerns.

Yesterday a spokesman confirmed that Acop would seek legal advice if the paper did not back down, arguing that the campaign was impinging on its ability to carry out its statutory duty. Taking the paper to court, said the spokesman, was "a route we have got to explore".

Acop said: "Offenders under probation are talking to probation staff about moving away from their home area, changing identity/appearance and breaking contact with the services - effectively going underground. Treatment and assessment programmes are being disrupted and compliance is threatened."

Cases cited include a man who committed a sex offence at the age of 19 - 33 years ago - and is considered unlikely to reoffend. He is said to be suicidal over fears of being identified in the paper.

Meanwhile, some prisoners on the south coast have said they are reluctant to participate in treatment programmes, saying they cannot see the point if they are going to be "outed" on their release.

The newspaper publicity has been blamed for a series of vigilante attacks on innocent people. On Friday night a group of around 60 people waving banners and shouting abuse threw paint at a house in Plymouth which they had wrongly identified as home to a paedophile.

In the Midlands, vigilante groups have told police that they intend to use violence to drive out sex offenders.

Probation officers have reported "high levels of anxiety" from wives and children of sex offenders - and from victims.

One officer in Yorkshire told of an adult victim who came to him angry and drunk, threatening to kill the man who abused him. "Prior to this he had been dwelling less on the past and his drinking was more controlled. This has set him back," said the officer.

Probation officers are worried that, because many victims are related to their abusers, there is a risk that they could be identified.

Leading children's charities have said the government should launch a major public education campaign offering practical advice on how to protect children.

The News of the World was last night sticking by its campaign. Referring to tomorrow's meeting, a spokesman said: "We are ready and very willing to meet these important organisations. We will of course listen with the greatest care to everything they have to say. At the same time, we will clearly explain our position and restate if necessary our defined objectives."

 Police last night prepared to clear away the final toys, cards, letters and mementoes from the site where Sarah Payne's body was found 14 days ago.

Yesterday a spokesman confirmed that Acop would seek legal advice if the paper did not back down, arguing that the campaign was impinging on its ability to carry out its statutory duty. Taking the paper to court, said the spokesman, was "a route we have got to explore". Acop said: "Offenders under probation are talking to probation staff about moving away from their home area, changing identity/appearance and breaking contact with the services - effectively going underground. Treatment and assessment programmes are being disrupted and compliance is threatened." Cases cited include a man who committed a sex offence at the age of 19 - 33 years ago - and is considered unlikely to reoffend. He is said to be suicidal over fears of being identified in the paper. Meanwhile, some prisoners on the south coast have said they are reluctant to participate in treatment programmes, saying they cannot see the point if they are going to be "outed" on their release. The newspaper publicity has been blamed for a series of vigilante attacks on innocent people. On Friday night a group of around 60 people waving banners and shouting abuse threw paint at a house in Plymouth which they had wrongly identified as home to a paedophile. In the Midlands, vigilante groups have told police that they intend to use violence to drive out sex offenders. Probation officers have reported "high levels of anxiety" from wives and children of sex offenders - and from victims. One officer in Yorkshire told of an adult victim who came to him angry and drunk, threatening to kill the man who abused him. "Prior to this he had been dwelling less on the past and his drinking was more controlled. This has set him back," said the officer. Probation officers are worried that, because many victims are related to their abusers, there is a risk that they could be identified. Leading children's charities have said the government should launch a major public education campaign offering practical advice on how to protect children. The News of the World was last night sticking by its campaign. Referring to tomorrow's meeting, a spokesman said: "We are ready and very willing to meet these important organisations. We will of course listen with the greatest care to everything they have to say. At the same time, we will clearly explain our position and restate if necessary our defined objectives."  Police last night prepared to clear away the final toys, cards, letters and mementoes from the site where Sarah Payne's body was found 14 days ago.

fields.headline: Wings, Stings and Jings
fields.trailText: WINGING IT
fields.body:
WINGING IT

So did David Ginola join Villa willingly or was he pushed? Agent Fox Fiver smells a conspiracy, and he wants answers. And it's going to take more than matching his 'n' hers Mercedes cars, £40,000 a week and a six-bedroom house to persuade him that the Gallic dribbler actually wanted to join John Gregory's increasingly splintered side. Or live in Birmingham.

According to David's view of events, he was happily enjoying his summer holiday, "and looking forward to another season at White Hart Lane, when my agent called to tell me Spurs were selling me. It totally ruined my summer. I never asked to leave." So who was the villain who pushed him towards Villa? "I was surprised to hear George Graham saying in the papers that he didn't want me to go," David admitted, heroically flicking his hair out of his eyes. "If that was the case, he had the power to tell Alan Sugar not to accept Villa's offer."

So why didn't he? Because according to Herr Commandant Graham, it was Ginola's decision. "It was his decision to go, not mine," he said, smiling. "If he had wanted to stay, that would have been fine by me. At his age, however, it was a great offer that was put in front of him and I don't blame him for wanting to accept it." All of which all leaves the Fiver very confused. Perhaps Ginola pushed himself?

But just as we were about to join the unruly mob descending on White Hart Lane, Graham cannily let it slip that he wasn't going to dwell on Ginola's departure, concentrating instead on targeting Boudewijn Zenden as the Frenchman's replacement. "Zenden is certainly a player that I admire," admitted George slyly. Luckily for Spurs, Zenden was about to join Lazio for £8m last week but the move fell through and, for all we know, the winger is currently resting in Amsterdam. Which sounds like a case for director of football David Pleat.

BORO'S BIG BLOWOUT

Bryan Robson, who cannot escape these pages at the moment, promised the fans of Middlesbrough that he was only looking to bring "Christian Zieges" to the Riverside. Club chairman Steve Gibson also boasted that he and Robbo were preparing a transfer move that would "shake the foundations of football". So, this afternoon, Boro are on the verge of signing Noel Whelan from Coventry and fellow forward Joseph Desire Job from Lens for a combined fee of £5m.

Whelan needs no introduction. Actually that's not quite true, as while Noel's window smashing and refuelling habits were once as legendary as his Gallagher namesake, they are now obscured by images of the less-than-streamlined forward sitting on the Cov bench. Gordon Strachan used to claim that his greatest challenge at Highfield Road was getting Whelan into the England side. It appears to be a challenge he has now given up on, and if Strachan failed then what can we expect from Robbo, the players' pal? "I will miss him [Strachan] shouting at me at the morning," said Whelan today. "But I am sure Bryan [Robbo] will do that." Yep.

Job meanwhile is waiting on a medical after completing his fortnight-long trial at the Riverside. A regular Cameroonian international, Job has hardly set the French first division alight - scoring only four league goals in his one season with RC Lens. Meanwhile it looks like Boro's bid to land Dani has ran aground, while Steve McManaman has called the very idea of his transferring to Boro as "barmy". As for Christian Ziege, Robbo is becoming less and less bullish by the day. "Obviously I don't want him to go, but it's his decision," he said this morning. And, let's face it, if Robbo does sell one Ziege, he won't really be expected to buy any more.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"One of the things we are trying to engender at Leeds is that if you grow the talent through your youth system there is a certain amount of loyalty and belonging. I am in the game of making sure that we build this club for the long term, because that's when the supporters and the shareholders get the benefits" - Peter Ridsdale outlines his plan to end the money madness. It's enough to make you sick.

BHOSNICH THE BHOY

Poor old Mark Bosnich. He's spent the last year flinging his portly torso around the Old Trafford goalmouth with reckless abandon. And for what? OK, he's got a Premiership medal to show for his troubles. And his bank balance is probably much healthier. But have his brave exploits established him as United's number one number one? Does he get showered with unconditional love from a grateful manager? Well, the Imperial Lord Ferg has agreed to loan him to Celtic for the whole of the 2000/01 season, let's put it that way.

It had been suggested that the Bhoy Bhosnich would join up with the Glasgow giants today, replacing Jonathan Gould, who had a jittery start against Dundee United yesterday. But Bhos's representative Steve 'say my surname carefully' Kutner announced this morning that this wasn't the case. "As things stand Celtic made an inquiry and Mark will now meet with Martin O'Neill later on in the week. I'm not sure what is going to happen at this moment in time but I have spoken to Alex Ferguson and we'll have to wait and see now what happens."

Given that Fergie has effectively told Bhosnich he is now third in line at United behind £7.8m Fabien Barthez and understudy supreme Raimond Van Der Gouw, it looks like the rotund Aussie will be miskicking balls towards the feet of grateful Motherwell forwards come Saturday. The Fiver can't help feeling slightly sorry for the way Bhos has been treated at Old Trafford - you've got to find some sympathy for a keeper who was once second choice to Massimo Taibi. So if he does move to Celtic only to find himself warming the bench while a rejuvenated Stuart Kerr enjoys an extended run in the first team, we won't be laughing. No, we definitely won't.

THE RUMOUR MILL

The Spanish press are reporting that Arsenal have made an £18m bid for Steve McManaman.

The money from Robbie Keane's transfer to Internazionale is likely to end up in the pocket of Gordon Strachan, according to Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson. "The Keane fee is at Gordon's disposal so he can do what is necessary to make us as strong as possible for the new Premiership season," he said today. Names on Strachan's list reportedly include West Brom striker Lee Hughes, Wimbledon's Jason Euell, and Rod Wallace and Neil McCann from Rangers. Coventry are already in negotiations with Liverpool over the possible transfer of England U-21 winger David Thompson.

Juninho is expected to return to Brazil with Flamengo rather than remain in Spain with Atletico Madrid.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Charlton have completed the signing of Finnish international Jonatan Johansson from Rangers in a £3.75m deal.

Former Newcastle chief executive Freddie Fletcher has informed the board he is standing down as a non-executive director with immediate effect. A statement released by United today revealed that Fletcher "wishes to pursue a range of business interests and does not feel that he will be able to commit adequate time to fulfil his obligations to the club".

Newcastle midfielder Christian Bassedas will miss the start of the season after x-rays revealed he has cracked a bone in his foot. The 27-year-old Argentinian picked up the injury in his club's 2-2 draw with Columbus Crew in Ohio last week.

Birmingham left-back David Burrows will miss the start of the new season with a torn hamstring.

Newcastle goalkeeper Lionel Perez has joined Cambridge United.

Spanish Primera League side Racing Santander are warming up for the new season nicely, after scoring 59 goals in two friendlies. In two encounters with Dutch side Smilde G4, Santander won 33-0 and 26-0. Norwegian striker Sigurd Rushfeldt was the top scorer in the two games, scoring 16 times.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 5: Major League Soccer (4am, 5.30am)

Dallas Ann Widdecombe v Los Angeles Colonel Gadaffi.

Sky Sports 1: International Football (2am)

The official film of the 1974 World Cup, mit Franz Beckenbauer und Johan Cryuff.

Sky Sports 2: World Football Show (6.30pm, 10.15pm SS1)

The very latest news from the last six weeks or so.

Sky Sports 3: World Corporate Games (6pm, 1am SS2)

Flabby businessmen take part in disciplines including football, golf and whoring.

webTitle: General Colin Powell's speech to the Republican party convention

fields.headline: General Colin Powell's speech to the Republican party convention
fields.trailText: President and Mrs Bush, a special good evening. I am honoured and pleased to again have the privilege of addressing a Republican national convention.
fields.body:
President and Mrs Bush, a special good evening. I am honoured and pleased to again have the privilege of addressing a Republican national convention.

In San Diego in 1996, I followed former first lady Nancy Reagan to the lectern after her moving tribute to President Reagan. I am delighted this time to follow Mrs Laura Bush, a lady of passion, dedication and grace. She will be a great first lady. Don't you think?

During the almost seven years since I left the army, I've traveled all across America. I've seen people hard at work providing for their families, giving of themselves, caring for each other.

I've seen them creating wealth for the nation. I've seen an economy transforming itself to seize the promise of the information revolution. I've met so many of our fellow citizens who believe in America to the depth of their hearts and who are doing everything they can in their communities to make our nation that more perfect union spoken of in our constitution.

I've been moved yet again to stand in awe of the American dream which was given birth in this city over 200 years ago. A dream I have been privileged to live. I've met so many young people who believe in the dream. They are on a road to success. They are being raised in strong families, going to good schools, filling the finest universities, graduating and going on to find their place and fortune in this land.

Even the youngest of them, still in elementary school are getting ready for the future -- using computers, logging onto the internet -- while still enjoying the magic of childhood by curling up with a Harry Potter book. There is so much that is good and right in America!

Yet I cannot ignore that in my travels I've also seen poverty, failing communities, people who've lost hope. Tragically, I've seen too many young Americans who are overwhelmed by the daily struggle just to survive. I've seen kids destroying themselves with drugs. Kids who see violence and crime as the answer to their hopelessness. Kids who no longer believe in themselves and who don't see a reason to believe in America. I've seen kids in utter despair. I've visited kids in jail doing adult time for crimes they've committed.

They are part of a growing population of over 2m Americans behind bars. Two million convicts, not consumers. Two million Americans who, while paying for their crimes, are not paying taxes, are not there for their children and are not raising families. Most of them are men and the majority of those men are minorities. The issue of race still casts a shadow over our society, despite the impressive progress we have made over the last 40 years to overcome the legacy of our troubled past.

So, with all the success we have enjoyed and with all the wealth we have created, we have much more work to do and a long way to go to bring the promise of America to every American. And with all we have to do on our national agenda, I am convinced that to deliver on that promise, we must begin with our children. So many of the problems we worry about go back to how we raise our children. We either build our children or we build more jails.

Time to stop building jails. And listen -- our children are not the problem, they are our future. They are America's promise. The problem is us if we fail to give them what they need to be successful in life.

That mission has become the passion of my life. Because if you want to solve our drug problem, you won't do it by trying to cut off the supply and arresting street pushers alone.

It will only be solved when we place into the heart of every child growing up in America the moral strength never to fall for the destructive lure of drugs --- the strength to just say "no, not me. I won't do it! I've got too much to live for."

If you want to solve the problem of violence and crime on our streets, it begins with us teaching children to value life, their own and others, and to have respect for themselves and respect for others. If you want young people to become contributing citizens and not convicts, then early in life we must give them the character and the competence they need to succeed in this exciting new world.

It begins in the home with caring, loving parents and family members who pass on the virtues of past generations, who live good lives which serve as models for their children.

And where the family is broken or not up to the task, the rest of us must step in to help as mentors, tutors, foster parents, friends to kids who desperately need responsible adults to show them the way. Tens of thousands of our neighbours have stepped forward. Tens of thousands who realize that children are a gift from God not only to their parents, but to their community. They belong to us all.

We need to provide safe places for those kids to learn and to grow. More clubs and after-school programs to protect them from the dangers in our society and to surround them with more adults who will keep them in play. We are obliged to make sure that every child gets a healthy start in life. With all our wealth and capacity, we just can't stand by idly. We must make sure that every child has health care.

As we are giving these necessities, and others, to our children, let's ask them to also give back to the community of which they are a part. Early in life help them to learn of the joy that comes from giving to others through community service. Let youngsters be part of the solution.

With character in their hearts, and nurturing adults in their lives, our youngsters will be ready for the schooling that will give them the education needed to win those jobs of the future.

There's work for all of us to do -- parents, aunts, uncles, teachers, the government at all levels, the private sector, our great non-profits, our houses of worship, all joining in the crusade to point kids in the right direction in life.

Tonight we focus on education. Governor Bush has rightly made children and education the centrepiece of his campaign for president. You just heard him say it - we can't leave any child behind. Every child deserves and must receive a quality education. Give a quality education to a child who believes in himself or herself and even with the bleakest beginning in life that child can make it and break the cycle of poverty and failure for that family forever.

So many of our public schools are doing a fine job preparing our youngsters. I have been given no greater honour than to have had four public schools named after me - an honour greater than medals. In those schools and so many others I've visited, you've never seen better facilities, more dedicated teachers and more involved parents. It makes your heart pound with pride.

But I have also seen too many schools that are failing. They are trapped in fossilised bureaucracies. Bureaucracies that have low expectations for children and consequently set low standards for them. These schools are leaving our children behind and they must be fixed.

If we believe they are all our children, then all of us must be willing to spend more to repair our schools and to pay our teachers better. We must also be open to new ideas. Let's not be afraid of standardised testing for students, testing of teachers, charter schools, private scholarship funding to give poor parents a choice, or home schooling.

Let's experiment prudently with school voucher programs to see if they help. Let's use innovation and competition to help give our children the best education possible.

We invite skilled workers to come to America from all over the world to fill the good obs that are waiting here. I think that's great. Immigration is our life's blood. I am the son of immigrants. But I also want our kids educated and trained for those jobs. We owe it to them!

Governor Bush has shown in Texas in just a few short years, what can be done for education. As Governor, he ended social promotions. He increased state funding for education by $8bn. He put new textbooks in every school. He strengthened standardised testing in all Texas public schools, he insisted on teacher competency, and he expanded the charter school movement.

Seventeen thousand Texas kids are now in charter schools. Seventy-eight percent of those kids are minorities - their parents had a choice and what they decided was best for their kids. The results in Texas have been dramatic. The number of students passing all parts of the Texas standardised tests since 1994 has increased by 51%. Even more exciting, the number of minority students passing the tests has increased by 89%.

Also, to insure a diverse college population with the loss of affirmative action, Governor Bush has guaranteed acceptance at public universities for the top 10% of every high school graduating class in the state. And above all, he insisted on accountability for results.

It works. It all comes together. Governor Bush doesn't just talk about reform, he reforms. He now offers that leadership to the nation.

In pursuing educational reform, as well as in all other parts of his agenda for Texas, Governor Bush has reached out to all Texans-- white, black, Latino, Asian, native American.

He has been successful in bringing more and more minorities into the tent by responding to their deepest needs. Some call it compassionate conservatism. To me, it's just about caring for people.

He can do the same thing as President. He will bring to the White House that same passion for inclusion. I know he can help bridge our racial divides.

Recently, Governor Bush addressed the annual meeting of the NAACP. He spoke to the delegates about his plans for housing, health and educational programs to help all Americans. He also spoke the truth to the delegates when he said that "the party of Lincoln has not always carried the mantle of Lincoln."

I talked with him again today and I know that, with all his heart, Governor Bush welcomes the challenge. He wants the Republican party to wear that mantle again. But he knows it will take hard work. He knows it will not be handed over, that it will have to be earned.

The party must follow Governor Bush's lead and reach out to minority communities and particularly the African-American community - and not just during an election year campaign. It must be a sustained effort. It must be every day. It must be for real.

The party must listen to and speak with all leaders of the black community, regardless of political affiliation or philosophy. We must understand the cynicism that exists in the black community. The kind of cynicism that is created when, for example, some in our party miss no opportunity to roundly and loudly condemn affirmative action that helped a few thousand Black kids get an education, but hardly a whimper is heard from them over affirmative action for lobbyists who load our federal tax codes with preferences for special interests.

Overcoming the cynicism and mistrust that exist and raising up that mantle of Lincoln is about more than just winning votes. It is about giving all minorities a competitive choice. We deserve one! It will be good for our party and it will be good for America.

Good for America -- that must be the measure for all that we do. I believe that's the measure that Governor Bush will use to guide his actions as president. Whether it's economic policy or military strategy or seeing what we can do to make our American family more inclusive, he will always try to do what is good and right for America.

Ladies and gentlemen, we stand at an historic turning point in world history. For the first time in almost a century, America does not face an enemy fueled by an ideology claiming to be superior to our beloved system of democracy, free enterprise and the rights of men and women to pursue their individual destinies.

We defeated communism and fascism on the field of battle and on the field of ideas. The sick nations that still pursue the 'fools gold' of tyranny and weapons of mass destruction will soon find themselves left behind in the dust bin of history. They are investing in their own demise as surely as the Soviet Union did by investing in the Red Army.

Today, we are the most powerful nation on earth - militarily, economically, by any measure. We are that rarity in history - a trusted nation whose power is tempered by compassion, whose leadership is earned by example and whose foreign affairs will be guided by common interests and common sense.

The world is watching to see if all this power and wealth is just for the well-to-do, the comfortable, the privileged. Or are we a nation that can make our dream real for all Americans, so that all share in what we have been given by a generous God? We must show to the rest of the world the beauty and potential of democracy.

Our greatest strength is the power of our example -- to be that shining city on the hill that Ronald Reagan spoke of and that the world looks up to. To continue to be that place, we must all work together, we must reach down, back and across, all of us coming together to show the world what our American family can do.

That is the challenge. This is the time. And in Governor George Bush we have the leader.
