Tragically, I've seen too many young Americans who are overwhelmed by the daily struggle just to survive. I've seen kids destroying themselves with drugs. Kids who see violence and crime as the answer to their hopelessness. Kids who no longer believe in themselves and who don't see a reason to believe in America. I've seen kids in utter despair. I've visited kids in jail doing adult time for crimes they've committed. They are part of a growing population of over 2m Americans behind bars. Two million convicts, not consumers. Two million Americans who, while paying for their crimes, are not paying taxes, are not there for their children and are not raising families. Most of them are men and the majority of those men are minorities. The issue of race still casts a shadow over our society, despite the impressive progress we have made over the last 40 years to overcome the legacy of our troubled past. So, with all the success we have enjoyed and with all the wealth we have created, we have much more work to do and a long way to go to bring the promise of America to every American. And with all we have to do on our national agenda, I am convinced that to deliver on that promise, we must begin with our children. So many of the problems we worry about go back to how we raise our children. We either build our children or we build more jails. Time to stop building jails. And listen -- our children are not the problem, they are our future. They are America's promise. The problem is us if we fail to give them what they need to be successful in life. That mission has become the passion of my life. Because if you want to solve our drug problem, you won't do it by trying to cut off the supply and arresting street pushers alone. It will only be solved when we place into the heart of every child growing up in America the moral strength never to fall for the destructive lure of drugs --- the strength to just say "no, not me. I won't do it! I've got too much to live for." If you want to solve the problem of violence and crime on our streets, it begins with us teaching children to value life, their own and others, and to have respect for themselves and respect for others. If you want young people to become contributing citizens and not convicts, then early in life we must give them the character and the competence they need to succeed in this exciting new world. It begins in the home with caring, loving parents and family members who pass on the virtues of past generations, who live good lives which serve as models for their children. And where the family is broken or not up to the task, the rest of us must step in to help as mentors, tutors, foster parents, friends to kids who desperately need responsible adults to show them the way. Tens of thousands of our neighbours have stepped forward. Tens of thousands who realize that children are a gift from God not only to their parents, but to their community. They belong to us all. We need to provide safe places for those kids to learn and to grow. More clubs and after-school programs to protect them from the dangers in our society and to surround them with more adults who will keep them in play. We are obliged to make sure that every child gets a healthy start in life. With all our wealth and capacity, we just can't stand by idly. We must make sure that every child has health care. As we are giving these necessities, and others, to our children, let's ask them to also give back to the community of which they are a part. Early in life help them to learn of the joy that comes from giving to others through community service. Let youngsters be part of the solution. With character in their hearts, and nurturing adults in their lives, our youngsters will be ready for the schooling that will give them the education needed to win those jobs of the future. There's work for all of us to do -- parents, aunts, uncles, teachers, the government at all levels, the private sector, our great non-profits, our houses of worship, all joining in the crusade to point kids in the right direction in life. Tonight we focus on education. Governor Bush has rightly made children and education the centrepiece of his campaign for president. You just heard him say it - we can't leave any child behind. Every child deserves and must receive a quality education. Give a quality education to a child who believes in himself or herself and even with the bleakest beginning in life that child can make it and break the cycle of poverty and failure for that family forever. So many of our public schools are doing a fine job preparing our youngsters. I have been given no greater honour than to have had four public schools named after me - an honour greater than medals. In those schools and so many others I've visited, you've never seen better facilities, more dedicated teachers and more involved parents. It makes your heart pound with pride. But I have also seen too many schools that are failing. They are trapped in fossilised bureaucracies. Bureaucracies that have low expectations for children and consequently set low standards for them. These schools are leaving our children behind and they must be fixed. If we believe they are all our children, then all of us must be willing to spend more to repair our schools and to pay our teachers better. We must also be open to new ideas. Let's not be afraid of standardised testing for students, testing of teachers, charter schools, private scholarship funding to give poor parents a choice, or home schooling. Let's experiment prudently with school voucher programs to see if they help. Let's use innovation and competition to help give our children the best education possible. We invite skilled workers to come to America from all over the world to fill the good obs that are waiting here. I think that's great. Immigration is our life's blood. I am the son of immigrants. But I also want our kids educated and trained for those jobs. We owe it to them! Governor Bush has shown in Texas in just a few short years, what can be done for education. As Governor, he ended social promotions. He increased state funding for education by $8bn. He put new textbooks in every school. He strengthened standardised testing in all Texas public schools, he insisted on teacher competency, and he expanded the charter school movement. Seventeen thousand Texas kids are now in charter schools. Seventy-eight percent of those kids are minorities - their parents had a choice and what they decided was best for their kids. The results in Texas have been dramatic. The number of students passing all parts of the Texas standardised tests since 1994 has increased by 51%. Even more exciting, the number of minority students passing the tests has increased by 89%. Also, to insure a diverse college population with the loss of affirmative action, Governor Bush has guaranteed acceptance at public universities for the top 10% of every high school graduating class in the state. And above all, he insisted on accountability for results. It works. It all comes together. Governor Bush doesn't just talk about reform, he reforms. He now offers that leadership to the nation. In pursuing educational reform, as well as in all other parts of his agenda for Texas, Governor Bush has reached out to all Texans-- white, black, Latino, Asian, native American. He has been successful in bringing more and more minorities into the tent by responding to their deepest needs. Some call it compassionate conservatism. To me, it's just about caring for people. He can do the same thing as President. He will bring to the White House that same passion for inclusion. I know he can help bridge our racial divides. Recently, Governor Bush addressed the annual meeting of the NAACP. He spoke to the delegates about his plans for housing, health and educational programs to help all Americans. He also spoke the truth to the delegates when he said that "the party of Lincoln has not always carried the mantle of Lincoln." I talked with him again today and I know that, with all his heart, Governor Bush welcomes the challenge. He wants the Republican party to wear that mantle again. But he knows it will take hard work. He knows it will not be handed over, that it will have to be earned. The party must follow Governor Bush's lead and reach out to minority communities and particularly the African-American community - and not just during an election year campaign. It must be a sustained effort. It must be every day. It must be for real. The party must listen to and speak with all leaders of the black community, regardless of political affiliation or philosophy. We must understand the cynicism that exists in the black community. It will be good for our party and it will be good for America. Good for America -- that must be the measure for all that we do. I believe that's the measure that Governor Bush will use to guide his actions as president. The sick nations that still pursue the 'fools gold' of tyranny and weapons of mass destruction will soon find themselves left behind in the dust bin of history. They are investing in their own demise as surely as the Soviet Union did by investing in the Red Army. Today, we are the most powerful nation on earth - militarily, economically, by any measure. We are that rarity in history - a trusted nation whose power is tempered by compassion, whose leadership is earned by example and whose foreign affairs will be guided by common interests and common sense. The world is watching to see if all this power and wealth is just for the well-to-do, the comfortable, the privileged. Or are we a nation that can make our dream real for all Americans, so that all share in what we have been given by a generous God? We must show to the rest of the world the beauty and potential of democracy. Our greatest strength is the power of our example -- to be that shining city on the hill that Ronald Reagan spoke of and that the world looks up to. To continue to be that place, we must all work together, we must reach down, back and across, all of us coming together to show the world what our American family can do. That is the challenge. This is the time. And in Governor George Bush we have the leader.

webTitle: Hague denounces 'fraudulent left' on trip to Republican convention

fields.headline: Hague denounces 'fraudulent left' on trip to Republican convention
fields.trailText: Tory leader William Hague today took his 'common sense revolution' to the United States where he launched an attack on the parties of the left claiming they had defrauded the public.
fields.body:
Tory leader William Hague today took his 'common sense revolution' to the United States where he launched an attack on the parties of the left claiming they had defrauded the public.

Mr Hague was speaking at the beginning of the Republican Party Convention in Philadelphia, where Senator George W Bush is expected to be endorsed as the party's Presidential candidate. The Tory leader was speaking to members of the International Democrat Union, a gathering of centre-right leaders from around the world.

Mr Hague said that while it was time to lay down their arms in the fight against Communism, parties of the centre-right faced a new challenge. While they had exposed the bankruptcy of socialism, too many of the centre-right parties had lost battles in their own backyards, he said.

Although he did not mention Tony Blair or Bill Clinton by name his speech was seen as a clear attack on the Labour Party and the US Democrats. "Perhaps because our victory over the old left was so complete, we allowed ourselves to become complacent," he told delegates. "We were slow to see that the left was re-inventing itself. They disowned their roots, repackaged themselves and chose new political leaders.

"They made a systematic attempt to occupy the centre ground of politics by imitating our language, adopting our issues and pretending to be parties of the right. Our Republican Party hosts know all too well who pioneered this."

Mr Hague denounced this left wing "repackaging" as a fraud, stating that their actions rarely matched their rhetoric.

fields.headline: Licence to make money?
fields.standfirst: Its rivals are baying for a sell-off. What does the BBC do with the net? David Teather reports.
fields.trailText: Its rivals are baying for a sell-off. What does the BBC do with the net? David Teather reports.
fields.body:
The old adage goes that in times of crisis the nation turns to the BBC. And so it proved last week - although not in any sense that would have been recognised by whoever originally coined the phrase. In the hours after the horrific crash of an Air France Concorde just outside Paris, around 5.2m people turned to BBC News Online to find out what had happened. The number of hits was a black-rimmed record for the service which broke the 100m barrier during June.

That the success of News Online, which launched in November 1997, is underpinning a wave of new internet services from the BBC should be cause for celebration at a time when the corporation is lauded for little else.

Questions of funding, however, and the conspicuous expansion of the BBC's online presence are beginning to prompt a series of uneasy questions. Greg Dyke, BBC director-general, recently announced an £8m increase in the funds for the web, taking the budget to £40m. Dyke is clearly an advocate of new media and in his inaugural list of promises to licence fee payers he vowed to expand the BBC's presence on the net.

The expansion is already under way. A dedicated sports service with an annual budget of £5m was launched last month. New sites are being planned for the arts and A-level students as well as a "lifestyle" service. Sites already in existance are linked to programming and education. There is also online shopping at Beeb.com, plus content for mobile phone networks and internet portals. The BBC's commitment to building its presence in the internet as a third leg to television and radio was underscored at the end of last week with the appointment of its first new media supremo. Ashley Highfield, 34, who will join the corporation from pay TV group Flextech, will sit on the new 18-strong executive committee.

Other agreements are understood to be under negotiation including an online service which would be adapted for the ONdigital pay television platform.

For some, the presence of a public service broadcaster on the internet at all is questionable. The British Internet Publishers Alliance argues loudly that the BBC has no place on the web, which it says is already a well served commercial marketplace.

The mushrooming of the BBC's internet services in more recent months has started to prompt wider concerns about what the corporation's role in new media should be and whether any boundaries should be set. Culture secretary Chris Smith has stated that any new television services from the BBC would need his approval and he has even ruled out certain channels such as a publicly funded sports station. Smith's ambivalence about the BBC's internet ambitions has not gone unnoticed and Julie Kirkbride MP, a member of the culture, media and sport commons select committee, has tabled a series of as yet unanswered questions to get a clearer picture.

"I would like to know what is and what isn't in the BBC's remit," she says. "At the moment it seems to be about how the governors feel on the day when they wake up and whatever Chris Smith decides to act on - both of which are indeterminate. They just haven't thought these issues through. "What we have is this old thing called the BBC which sits very uneasily amidst the changes in the media."

Much of the recent criticism has been levelled at arrangements struck between the BBC and commercial operators including Yahoo! and the leading mobile phone networks to provide content free of charge. ITN had threatened to complain to the office of fair trading about six month trials with Vodafone, One2One and BT Cellnet which are due to end next month. In this case the BBC governors were alive to the growing controversy and told the corporation last week that it could no longer provide the licence fee-funded services free of charge. The BBC defends itself by saying it is not aiming to edge anyone else out of the online market. It also contends reasonably that it is making better use of the vast wealth of content that would otherwise go unused from its bank of bureaux, sports reporters and news stringers around the world.

Professor Ian Hargreaves from Cardiff University, who has written on the future of the corporation, says: "The BBC's place on the internet is incontestable. The BBC has to be there just as it had to move from radio to television. But the BBC in its history has tended to monopolise a new medium in its early days, and the private sector companies are right to be concerned about the BBC's might."

The other dilemma facing the BBC's development of new internet services is also writ large in the rest of the corporation. Funding. As the least mature service, attracting private backing for the internet division could be the least politically sensitive way of getting outside money into the BBC.

Insiders say that Dyke views the core news online service as a sacred cow but that everything else is up for debate. He is said to enthuse over the commercial opportunities available from exploiting the web.

A model may be Beeb.com, which sits under BBC Worldwide. For the past 12 months or so a wide range of options have been considered including a partial stock market flotation of the retailing site.

The preferred option is selling a minority stake to a private investor. Cable companies NTL and Telewest both held protracted talks but have since left the negotiating table although the BBC is understood to be close to agreeing a deal with another unnamed partner. "Beeb.com is pretty much opening the door," says one BBC insider. "It's difficult to say what the BBC will look in a few years' time - although it is committed to a public internet service."

The other option that has been mooted is some kind of mutual structure which would leave the BBC owned by the licence fee payers - but better able to raid the capital markets for funding.

Hargreaves adds that the answer to both funding and the issue of how far the BBC should be allowed to go will come down to more effective regulation. "They are not separate questions," he says. "The way to deal with issues of competition is by having a competent regulatory regime but the regulator also has to have a view on far the BBC will be able to raise money in a commercial fashion."

The issues facing the BBC are similar to those troubling most others in the new media environment. There is one certainty however - that in the short term the blurring of lines between commercial operations and the public service will at the very least cause structural headaches of the kind Dyke is keen to expunge.

Other agreements are understood to be under negotiation including an online service which would be adapted for the ONdigital pay television platform. For some, the presence of a public service broadcaster on the internet at all is questionable. The British Internet Publishers Alliance argues loudly that the BBC has no place on the web, which it says is already a well served commercial marketplace. The mushrooming of the BBC's internet services in more recent months has started to prompt wider concerns about what the corporation's role in new media should be and whether any boundaries should be set. Culture secretary Chris Smith has stated that any new television services from the BBC would need his approval and he has even ruled out certain channels such as a publicly funded sports station. Smith's ambivalence about the BBC's internet ambitions has not gone unnoticed and Julie Kirkbride MP, a member of the culture, media and sport commons select committee, has tabled a series of as yet unanswered questions to get a clearer picture. "I would like to know what is and what isn't in the BBC's remit," she says. "At the moment it seems to be about how the governors feel on the day when they wake up and whatever Chris Smith decides to act on - both of which are indeterminate. They just haven't thought these issues through. "What we have is this old thing called the BBC which sits very uneasily amidst the changes in the media." Much of the recent criticism has been levelled at arrangements struck between the BBC and commercial operators including Yahoo! and the leading mobile phone networks to provide content free of charge. ITN had threatened to complain to the office of fair trading about six month trials with Vodafone, One2One and BT Cellnet which are due to end next month. In this case the BBC governors were alive to the growing controversy and told the corporation last week that it could no longer provide the licence fee-funded services free of charge. The BBC defends itself by saying it is not aiming to edge anyone else out of the online market. It also contends reasonably that it is making better use of the vast wealth of content that would otherwise go unused from its bank of bureaux, sports reporters and news stringers around the world. Professor Ian Hargreaves from Cardiff University, who has written on the future of the corporation, says: "The BBC's place on the internet is incontestable. The BBC has to be there just as it had to move from radio to television. But the BBC in its history has tended to monopolise a new medium in its early days, and the private sector companies are right to be concerned about the BBC's might." The other dilemma facing the BBC's development of new internet services is also writ large in the rest of the corporation. Funding. As the least mature service, attracting private backing for the internet division could be the least politically sensitive way of getting outside money into the BBC. Insiders say that Dyke views the core news online service as a sacred cow but that everything else is up for debate. He is said to enthuse over the commercial opportunities available from exploiting the web. A model may be Beeb.com, which sits under BBC Worldwide. The preferred option is selling a minority stake to a private investor. "Beeb.com is pretty much opening the door," says one BBC insider. "It's difficult to say what the BBC will look in a few years' time - although it is committed to a public internet service." The other option that has been mooted is some kind of mutual structure which would leave the BBC owned by the licence fee payers - but better able to raid the capital markets for funding. Hargreaves adds that the answer to both funding and the issue of how far the BBC should be allowed to go will come down to more effective regulation. "They are not separate questions," he says. The issues facing the BBC are similar to those troubling most others in the new media environment. There is one certainty however - that in the short term the blurring of lines between commercial operations and the public service will at the very least cause structural headaches of the kind Dyke is keen to expunge.

fields.headline: Lords' bills under threat
fields.standfirst: Delays in the House of Lords have left the government's legislative programme in disarray. Julian Glover looks at the bills in question
fields.trailText: Delays in the House of Lords have left the government's legislative programme in disarray. Julian Glover looks at the bills in question
fields.body:
Parliamentary tradition calls for legislation to be passed within one parliamentary year. Any bills which have not completed all their stages in both the House of Lords and the Commons by the time parliament is prorogued ahead of the Queen's speech fail automatically.

This year, a newly enlivened House of Lords and a heavy and controversial government programme have combined to leave the government's parliamentary business managers in a bind. With its big majority, the government has no problem passing legislation in the Commons, but without a majority in the Lords, it needs to tread more gently to win the support of peers. Many bills have yet to reach the upper house and though it will return in October - a month earlier than usual - peers doubt that all the bills due for consideration will be passed before the Queen's speech, due in November.

Since a general election is likely to interrupt parliament early next year, any bills left unfinished this autumn are unlikely to become law before the country goes to the polls. That would be embarrassing for the government, since some of the bills involve commitments made in Labour's 1997 manifesto.

One way of getting round the problem might be to delay the Queen's speech into December, but this would be a propaganda coup for the Tories. Another more likely option would be to drop some bills, or accept opposition amendments to them to speed their passage. Doing either would be embarrassing and would upset lobby groups.

Legislation under threat includes:

The freedom of information bill: A favourite of Labour's more liberal supporters and of some members of the government, this bill is a watered-down version of the government's original proposals, but still has the potential to revolutionise the way Britain is run. It was given a second reading in the Commons in April, but has been on the backburner since then. Abandoning it would enrage the Liberal Democrats, whose support in the House of Lords is much valued by the government, and lead to charges that new Labour has abandoned its radical edge.

 Chances of survival: touch and go.

The football (disorder) bill: Now law after it completed its passage last week, this piece of legislation, hurried through in the wake of the Euro 2000 riots, has held up work on other issues. The government, like its predecessor with the unworkable Dangerous Dogs Act, may come to regret introducing such emergency legislation.

 Chances of survival: now law.

The countryside bill: This bill gives the public a general right to roam over the English and Welsh countryside and as such is likely to find its passage through the Lords a tricky one. Even with the abolition of the automatic right of hereditary peers to sit in the upper house, the chamber is strongly influenced by rural interests opposed to countryside access. As a manifesto commitment, the Lords is bound by convention not to vote against the legislation in its entirety, but peers will try to sabotage it with unworkable amendments. Some sources in the government have hinted that the bill will be dropped to allow time for other legislation.

 Chances of survival: likely to become law, but with some amendments

The police (Northern Ireland) bill: A controversial piece of legislation reforming the way Northern Ireland is policed. Unionists object in particular to its renaming of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. The government will not let this bill fail, but it has yet to pass its Lords third reading.

 Chances of survival: good, but expect it to make headlines

The political parties, elections and referendums bill: Boring but important, this low-profile bill will bring changes to the way political parties are funded in Britain and to the conduct of referendums. With the general election and a possible referendum on the euro looming, the bill's demise would have a significant impact. So far, it has had little parliamentary consideration.

 Chances of survival: not good

The regulation of investigatory powers bill: This controversial bill extending police powers to spy on internet use has now received royal assent. Its passage ahead of other legislation promised in Labour's election manifesto will lead to protests if delays lead to the abandonment of other bills.

 Chances of survival: now law

The criminal justice (mode of trial) (No 2) bill: The obscure title of this bill hides an important change in the way the law courts work. The bill removes the right of defendants to choose a jury trial in a crown court instead of appearing before a magistrate. Civil liberties groups and some lawyers object to this, but the Home Office argues it will lead to better justice. The Lords rejected an earlier bill on the same subject.

 Chances of survival: good, but will prove a tough battle

fields.headline: 'I arrest you for emailing'
fields.standfirst:
The RIP Act, passed last week, means nothing you write in an email will ever be private

Special report: privacy on the net
fields.trailText: August 07 2000 The RIP Act, passed last week, means nothing you write in an email will ever be private. By Roy Greenslade
fields.body:
On Friday the Queen graciously gave her assent to the Regulation of Investigatory Powers bill after it was fast-tracked through parliament with the agreement of the two main parties. So the RIP bill is now the RIP Act, yet another piece of legislation which will prevent journalists from operating freely in the public interest.

On the face of it, the act was proposed for the best of reasons: to ensure that the formidable array of the authorities' investigatory powers accord with human rights. Unless there is good reason, our communications cannot be monitored.

But what amounts to a good reason? Terrorism, drug-dealing, serious crime, tax evasion and that greatest of catch-alls: the national interest. There lies the problem. What the government and its various authorities - whether police, customs and excise or security services - regard as the national interest is all too often about the state's interest rather than the public good.

I'll come back to that. Let's consider the main threat faced by newspapers from the draconian powers of this act. Emails, now the most used form of communication between journalists, and between them and their contacts and sources, are no longer safe.

From this day on, without our knowledge, the authorities can intercept our messages. They will know who said what to whom about what well before the information can be published. Indeed, by having that knowledge in advance they may well be able to take measures to prevent its publication.

This isn't far-fetched. A good example occurred recently when the renegade MI5 officer David Shayler emailed the Observer and the Guardian. When the police - claiming to be acting in the national interest - tried to compel the papers to hand over the emails, the request was refused.

A judge ordered the papers to comply, a ruling that was overturned by the court of appeal in a masterly judgment by Lord Justice Judge which stressed the rights of a free press to investigate matters on behalf of the public without compromising its informants.

If the RIP Act had been on the statute book at the time, that case would never have reached court because the police would have used the act's powers to obtain the emails secretly regardless of such rights.

It wouldn't have helped if the emails had been encrypted. Under the new act, the authorities can demand the key to any encrypted message.

In other words, the RIP Act makes all traffic over the internet in Britain available to the state if a body, however flimsy its suspicion, decides to apply for the right to intercept emails.

Nor will the authorities need a legal warrant to do so. Interception will require only the home secretary's approval while the monitoring of traffic can be "self-authorised" by whoever decides it is necessary. Demands for someone to provide an encryption key can be authorised by a customs and excise official, a chief constable, a magistrate, a judge or the home secretary.

The passing of the RIP Act denies everyone the freedom, and the privacy, we thought the internet had provided. It robs journalists and their sources - including that most potent and essential of tipsters, the whistle-blower - of their rights and, quite possibly, threatens their liberty.

Despite significant concessions made during the passage of the bill, it is still badly conceived and may well prove counter-productive. Internet experts believe that users will soon employ a range of esoteric "privacy tools", enabling them to camouflage emails and hide files, to avoid compliance.

In what appears to have been panic at the growth of the internet and the freedom enjoyed by its users, the British government has accorded itself powers which no other western country has dared to take.

Yet this, remember, is the government that came to power crowing about its commitment to end secrecy.

Instead its record has been a disgrace. Jack Straw last week finally announced that the Home Office will consult media bodies to ensure that future legislation which does "impact on press and media reporting" does not create "unintended restrictions".

What a cheek. The sound of the stable door being closed long after the horses have bolted is deafening. So far we have seen a milksop freedom of information proposal, a worrying data protection act, a thoughtless youth and criminal evidence act, a potentially harmful terrorism act and a restrictive local government act.

Now comes the RIP Act. Consultation is supposed to happen before, Mr Straw, not afterwards.

The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act (RIP)

What is it? Originated by Jack Straw, RIP sets out the government's plans to allow official surveillance of internet traffic. Published in February 2000, it passed through the Lords in July and becomes law in October.

The government line? RIP gives police and security services new powers to monitor and intercept emails and websites, channels through which online criminals, terrorists, paedophiles and pornographers have traditionally been able to communicate.

Some data on computers, such as child pornography, is often encrypted. The bill makes it illegal to refuse a police request to decrypt data.

All security service warrants for data interception will require prior government approval, bringing the UK into line with other EU surveillance measures.

The anti-government line? The cost and maintenance of necessary surveillance equipment will be passed on to the internet user, threatening e-commerce in Britain and billions in lost business.

Every UK internet service provider will be responsible for the installation of remote-controlled black boxes relaying all data passing through its computers to a special monitoring centre in MI5's HQ, the Government Technical Assistance Centre.

Unlike telephone tapping, which can be specified, RIP allows the government to monitor all UK internet traffic - sites downloaded, address books, emails, discussion groups and chat rooms - without a warrant, which could be considered a contravention of the privacy requirements of the European convention on human rights. There are two-year sentences for forgetting passwords, and for failing to surrender or losing keys used to encrypt communications data. The burden of proof is reversed from the prosecution to the defence.

Then there are five-year sentences for telling anyone that you have been served with an order to surrender encryption keys or hand over encrypted material in "plaintext" form. The RIP bill can justifiably be called a total infringement of civil liberties. From October, no one in the UK will be able to feel free from government surveillance.

International precedents? Only Russia, Singapore and Malaysia have similar laws. There is nothing comparable in the US. A recent Irish law makes it illegal for government to access commercial encryption keys. France has relaxed controls on domestic encryption, while Germany is opposed to restrictions on citizens' use of encryption.

webTitle: In Kosovo, newspaper exposes of war criminals led to murder

fields.headline: In Kosovo, newspaper exposes of war criminals led to murder
fields.trailText: Earlier this summer the Kosovan daily Dita ran an exclusive story about a 25-year-old Serb working in Pristina for the UN. The article, "When Petar becomes Peter", accused him of committing war crimes during Nato's bombing campaign in Yugoslavia last year.
fields.body:
Earlier this summer the Kosovan daily Dita ran an exclusive story about a 25-year-old Serb working in Pristina for the UN. The article, "When Petar becomes Peter", accused him of committing war crimes during Nato's bombing campaign in Yugoslavia last year.

"His name is Petar Topoljski," ran the article. "He and his father were paramilitary. They robbed, looted, beat and forced their Albanian neighbours from their homes. Now Petar is working in the UN administration in Pristina and is known as Peter." His address was also provided.

Three weeks after publication, Petar Topoljski went missing. Ten days later, he was found stabbed to death in a village on the outskirts of Pristina.

The article was far from the first to have appeared in the Kosovo Albanian press attempting to "expose" war criminals. Numerous similar features have appeared over the last few months. But the "naming and shaming", and subsequent death of a UN employee, have jolted the UN into action and sparked an intense debate in the province about the regulation of the media.

Dita was seen as having a significant role in Petar Topoljski's death. Bernard Kouchner, head of the UN mission in Kosovo, ordered the paper to close for eight days in the immediate aftermath of his death.

New rules have since been introduced that can see newspapers fined up to 100,000 German marks (£31,500), or closed down permanently. The rules are being enforced by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), part of the UN administration in Kosovo. Its ambassador, Daan Everts, is hoping the new rules will put an end to the publication of articles that he describes as "death warrants".

"We have seen some very bad articles where individuals are being condemned to death, because they are being identified," he says. "Their workplace is being given out, and people are basically saying, 'There they are. Do whatever you want to them.' This is unacceptable."

So far the rules have had a limited effect. At the beginning of this month, the bi-monthly magazine Kosovarja published Nightmare Butchers, an article accusing Kosovo's Roma community en masse of being guilty of war crimes.

"Sources of information from all battlefields support the reactions of Albanian public opinion proving with facts and names the participation of Roma in the ethnic cleansing campaign against Albanians," the article stated. With scant evidence that they had committed any crimes, it listed 11 men involved in "local actions".

Dita has continued to print articles revealing the whereabouts of paramilitaries and even Kosovo's best selling and most widely respected daily, Koha Ditore, has printed the name of an Albanian student in the Kosovo police school with alleged connections to the Serbian police.

There seems to be very little middle ground between newspaper editors and the UN, which has taken on the task of regulation. Few newspapers accept that what they put into print can have potentially fatal consequences. Editors instead see the articles as part of a quest for the truth. Behlul Beqaj, the editor of Dita, argued in a recent editorial that "it is the task and obligation of every Albanian citizen to reveal war criminals. If we do not do so now the forthcoming generations will never forgive us".

The articles, Beqaj claimed, are also a quest for justice: "Do not ask Albanians to forgive before justice has been done. Ethnic tolerance cannot be created by asking Albanians to turn a blind eye... You who came to Kosovo to establish justice should stop the crime and criminals and not the press that publishes facts about them."

Dita's complaint is a common one. Kosovo's judicial system has been notoriously slow to get started and very few Serbs have stood trial for war crimes.

Llazar Semini, a writer for the Institute of War and Peace Reporting, which monitors news coverage in Kosovo, suggests that much of the problem is due to a perception among Kosovo Albanians that the courts are not effective.

"They are not seeing any alleged Serb war criminal being sentenced. They think this is morally right at a time when they are not feeling the results of good governance by the international community."

In the meantime there has been strong criticism of tighter media regulation from local editors and international press organisations alike. Groups such as Article 19, the World Press Freedom Committee and the International Federation of Journalists have criticised the wide-ranging powers of the new OSCE press commissioner as a threat to the freedom of speech.

A code of conduct is currently being discussed with local editors, but the media commissioner already has the power to warn, fine, or even close down a newspaper. Ardian Arifaj, managing editor of Koha Ditore, sees this as an unwelcome reminder of the past.

"It's definitely a step in the wrong direction - any kind of suppression of freedom of speech and expression is a step backwards. It would definitely be a reminder of the environment I grew up in and started working as a journalist in. And it's a reminder of an environment I would not like to go back to."

The division between Kosovo's media and the UN regulators looks likely to intensify for the moment. At the end of last week the OSCE took the decision to close Dita. The paper was refusing to pay a fine of 25,000 German marks for publishing the names and photos of several Serb paramilitaries. Dita's editor described the fine as "25,000 blows for Kosovo and democracy".

But the media commissioner, Douglas Davidson, an American diplomat working with the OSCE, defends the regulatory measures.

"People argue that this [the new media law] limits press freedom, saying everyone should be free to pronounce whoever is a war criminal. I'm not sure that is a very healthy tendency if you are trying to bring a society together. It is a pretty effective means of keeping people whipped up with hatred against other ethnic groups."

He admits that this latest crackdown may not have initially had the desired effect. "I've boosted Dita's circulation from nothing." The paper is now planning demonstrations against its closure. But Davidson says he won't let up.

"We wouldn't be doing this if the press could regulate itself. If you are trying to build a stable, secure, democratic and multi-ethnic Kosovo, it seems to me you might want to curb the tendency of people to take justice into their own hands, whether on the pages of the newspaper, or directly for the benefit of society."

At the beginning of this month, the bi-monthly magazine Kosovarja published Nightmare Butchers, an article accusing Kosovo's Roma community en masse of being guilty of war crimes. "Sources of information from all battlefields support the reactions of Albanian public opinion proving with facts and names the participation of Roma in the ethnic cleansing campaign against Albanians," the article stated. With scant evidence that they had committed any crimes, it listed 11 men involved in "local actions". Dita has continued to print articles revealing the whereabouts of paramilitaries and even Kosovo's best selling and most widely respected daily, Koha Ditore, has printed the name of an Albanian student in the Kosovo police school with alleged connections to the Serbian police. There seems to be very little middle ground between newspaper editors and the UN, which has taken on the task of regulation. Few newspapers accept that what they put into print can have potentially fatal consequences. Editors instead see the articles as part of a quest for the truth. Behlul Beqaj, the editor of Dita, argued in a recent editorial that "it is the task and obligation of every Albanian citizen to reveal war criminals. If we do not do so now the forthcoming generations will never forgive us". The articles, Beqaj claimed, are also a quest for justice: "Do not ask Albanians to forgive before justice has been done. Ethnic tolerance cannot be created by asking Albanians to turn a blind eye... You who came to Kosovo to establish justice should stop the crime and criminals and not the press that publishes facts about them." Dita's complaint is a common one. Kosovo's judicial system has been notoriously slow to get started and very few Serbs have stood trial for war crimes. Llazar Semini, a writer for the Institute of War and Peace Reporting, which monitors news coverage in Kosovo, suggests that much of the problem is due to a perception among Kosovo Albanians that the courts are not effective. "They are not seeing any alleged Serb war criminal being sentenced. They think this is morally right at a time when they are not feeling the results of good governance by the international community." In the meantime there has been strong criticism of tighter media regulation from local editors and international press organisations alike. Groups such as Article 19, the World Press Freedom Committee and the International Federation of Journalists have criticised the wide-ranging powers of the new OSCE press commissioner as a threat to the freedom of speech. A code of conduct is currently being discussed with local editors, but the media commissioner already has the power to warn, fine, or even close down a newspaper. Ardian Arifaj, managing editor of Koha Ditore, sees this as an unwelcome reminder of the past. "It's definitely a step in the wrong direction - any kind of suppression of freedom of speech and expression is a step backwards. It would definitely be a reminder of the environment I grew up in and started working as a journalist in. And it's a reminder of an environment I would not like to go back to." The division between Kosovo's media and the UN regulators looks likely to intensify for the moment. At the end of last week the OSCE took the decision to close Dita. The paper was refusing to pay a fine of 25,000 German marks for publishing the names and photos of several Serb paramilitaries. Dita's editor described the fine as "25,000 blows for Kosovo and democracy". But the media commissioner, Douglas Davidson, an American diplomat working with the OSCE, defends the regulatory measures. "People argue that this [the new media law] limits press freedom, saying everyone should be free to pronounce whoever is a war criminal. I'm not sure that is a very healthy tendency if you are trying to bring a society together. It is a pretty effective means of keeping people whipped up with hatred against other ethnic groups." He admits that this latest crackdown may not have initially had the desired effect. "I've boosted Dita's circulation from nothing." The paper is now planning demonstrations against its closure. But Davidson says he won't let up. "We wouldn't be doing this if the press could regulate itself. If you are trying to build a stable, secure, democratic and multi-ethnic Kosovo, it seems to me you might want to curb the tendency of people to take justice into their own hands, whether on the pages of the newspaper, or directly for the benefit of society."

webTitle: Two recent endorsements of press and broadcasting freedom

fields.headline: Free to report
fields.standfirst: Rod Liddle celebrates two recent decisions handed down to the media by the courts
fields.trailText: Rod Liddle celebrates two recent decisions handed down to the media by the courts
fields.body:
Twice in the space of a week, British courts did an unusual thing and delivered ringing endorsements of press and broadcasting freedom.

You know all about the first one - the appeal court victory for the Guardian and the Observer in the Shayler case was a front-page lead story in this newspaper on July 22. It upheld the right of journalists to publish allegations by whistleblowers without then having that material seized by the authorities. The publication of "inconvenient or embarrassing revelations" was, the court seemed to accept, necessary and in the public good. It should therefore not be discouraged or stifled.

A similar principle was at work the following Tuesday, two floors up in the family division of the high court. The BBC sought to remove an injunction placed on an interview Today had carried out with Bobby Kelly, the 16-year-old boy who left home suddenly to join an obscure religious sect. We had pursued the sect, Jesus Christians, for several days, asking to talk to Bobby. Eventually he rang the programme and an interview with our reporter, Zubeida Malik, was recorded. Bobby had been made a ward of court after his "abduction", as some people had called it. When we rang his family to let them know Bobby would be on air the next morning, the injunction was served, supported by his grandmother and by his legal guardian, the official solicitor.

This was an odd state of affairs. After making Bobby a ward of court, the authorities had called for media assistance in tracking the boy down. They named him, and a photograph was published. None of this attention would, so far as the court was concerned, do the boy any damage. But, having invited the press in, they shut the door.

Not only was our interview injuncted, but henceforth there would be no interviews, anywhere, with Jesus Christians. This was, in our view, an extreme case of censorship. While Jesus Christians were allegedly in contempt of court for not having disclosed the whereabouts of Bobby Kelly, the organisation was not illegal nor a force for evil deserving a restriction of its members' civil rights. Why should they be deprived of free speech? The answers were a little vague.

The official solicitor argued that to broadcast the interview would harm Bobby. No direct evidence was offered as to what that damage would be; publicity in itself was seen as damaging. In other words, it was a circular argument. Further, interviews with members of the cult would provide Jesus Christians with - here comes that ill-judged phrase again - the oxygen of publicity. It seemed that the authorities, in the same way as in the Shayler case, regarded the media as an unpaid servant of the judiciary.

In lifting the injunction, Justice Munby challenged this head on. Just as Lord Justice Judge in the appeal court the previous Friday had recognised the public interest served by free and independent media, so Judge Munby acknowledged that newspapers and radio programmes were not factotums of the court and that restrictions on their reporting rights served to chip away at freedom of speech.

Further, the suggestion that in every such case the child's welfare would take precedence over press freedom, was rejected: hard evidence, said Munby, must be provided to support allegations of likely harm. This is crucial. In future, courts may be less likely to view the wishes of the media as trivial when compared to the welfare of a single individual; the overriding concern must be free speech.

What happened in court is immensely useful . In future, there might, after this very long, detailed and powerful judgment, be fewer injunctions, and a greater realisation that the media assist the courts - and the public - to the fullest when given as much freedom and independence as possible.

Rod Liddle is editor of Radio 4's Today programme

fields.headline: Dawn rises quickly
fields.trailText: 1984 Graduates from Cambridge and joins Central TV as trainee, eventually rising to scheduling role as controller of planning: "It was a baptism of fire: most other controllers were men in their mid-40s, who felt rather undermined that Central had the audacity to put a 26-year-old unknown woman in as a controller." Acquires "Zulu Dawn" nickname.
fields.body:
1984 Graduates from Cambridge and joins Central TV as trainee, eventually rising to scheduling role as controller of planning: "It was a baptism of fire: most other controllers were men in their mid-40s, who felt rather undermined that Central had the audacity to put a 26-year-old unknown woman in as a controller." Acquires "Zulu Dawn" nickname.

1993 Part of first ITV Network Centre team under Marcus Plantin, commissioning children's and daytime programmes (including Supermarket Sweep). Output for kids criticised by BBC counterpart Anna Home for over-reliance on cartoons, but boasts "every show won its time-slot. No one else at Network Centre can say that."

1994 Poached by Channel 4 as controller of arts and entertainment. Seen as leading the channel's populist tendency, favouring an expansion of entertainment output at the expense of worthy "remit" programmes, during 18-month stint which saw launch of Hollyoaks.

1995 Accepts approach from Pearson TV's Greg Dyke to be director of programmes in Channel 5 bid headed by him: "I'm a deeply commercial and competitive animal, and I'd always wanted the chance to run my own channel." When Dyke's consortium wins, Michael Grade tells her: "I hope Channel 5 goes down the pan, but you end up smelling of roses."

1996 David Elstein joins Channel 5 pre-launch from BSkyB as chief executive, leading industry commentators to question whether cerebral "Two Brains" (who's a BBC2 man) and fun-loving Zulu Dawn will be compatible.

1997 Channel 5 launches with icons of girl power - the Spice Girls, Kirsty Young, Xena: Warrior Princess - mirroring Airey's own image. Turns down approach from Elisabeth Murdoch to join BSkyB, despite viewing her dad as a "demigod".

1998 Airey forecasts Channel 5 - now achieving 5% audience share in best weeks - will overtake BBC2 and Channel 4 as "third channel" within three years. Sent to Harvard Business School on course previously taken by Dyke, suggesting grooming for future chief executive role.

1999 Relaunch of Channel 5's soap Family Affairs with massacre of original family. Airey tells Guardian her channel specialises in "films, fucking and football", but "bosoms, balls and brutality" are also "part of the mix".

2000 Home and Away acquired when dropped by ITV. Screening of nude gameshow The Naked Jungle, presented by Keith Chegwin, adds to mounting press criticism, but Elstein takes the brunt of Daily Mail's attacks rather than Airey.

webTitle: The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act (RIP)

fields.headline: The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act (RIP)
fields.trailText: The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act (RIP)
fields.body:
The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act (RIP)

What is it? Originated by Jack Straw, RIP sets out the government's plans to allow official surveillance of internet traffic. Published in February 2000, it passed through the Lords in July and becomes law in October.

The government line? RIP gives police and security services new powers to monitor and intercept emails and websites, channels through which online criminals, terrorists, paedophiles and pornographers have traditionally been able to communicate.

Some data on computers, such as child pornography, is often encrypted. The bill makes it illegal to refuse a police request to decrypt data.

All security service warrants for data interception will require prior government approval, bringing the UK into line with other EU surveillance measures.

The anti-government line? The cost and maintenance of necessary surveillance equipment will be passed on to the internet user, threatening e-commerce in Britain and billions in lost business.

Every UK internet service provider will be responsible for the installation of remote-controlled black boxes relaying all data passing through its computers to a special monitoring centre in MI5's HQ, the Government Technical Assistance Centre.

Unlike telephone tapping, which can be specified, RIP allows the government to monitor all UK internet traffic - sites downloaded, address books, emails, discussion groups and chat rooms - without a warrant, which could be considered a contra vention of the privacy requirements of the European convention on human rights. There are two-year sentences for forgetting passwords, and for failing to surrender or losing keys used to encrypt communications data. The burden of proof is reversed from the prosecution to the defence.

Then there are five-year sentences for telling anyone that you have been served with an order to surrender encryption keys or hand over encrypted material in "plaintext" form. The RIP bill can justifiably be called a total infringement of civil liberties. From October, no one in the UK will be able to feel free from government surveillance.

International precedents? Only Russia, Singapore and Malaysia have similar laws. There is nothing comparable in the US. A recent Irish law makes it illegal for government to access commercial encryption keys. France has relaxed controls on domestic encryption, while Germany is opposed to restrictions on citizens' use of encryption.

fields.headline: Need to know: Roy Tuvey
fields.trailText:
Age?
24.
fields.body:
Age?
24.

Who is he?
Co-MD and co-founder of mailround.com (launched this month), a two-brother email marketing service. Former banker.

What's the clever idea?
"A technology that enables consumers to use email in a slightly different way. They can send and receive email and add 'stamps' to their mail - clickable ads, offers or pieces of content that we've produced in-house that are visually quite interesting and liven up email. It's a way of rewarding users for doing something they do every day."

What's the thinking behind it?
"It enhances people's email experience. Email is a brilliant communication tool, but it can sometimes be boring. For the consumer it's quite interesting to get things within your regular email that you are interested in, without having to go surfing round the net to find them. We generate revenues from advertisers who pay us to market their products online using email. Then we pass on a percentage of that to our 'Mailrounders'."

How does it work?
"You register with Mailround and provide us with your name, email address and things you are interested in. Then you press the 'download' button and install our 'mailman' software, which works with existing email systems. And that's it. When you receive mail, you'll see stamps on it. When you send mail, mailman will ask you whether you want to add stamps or not. At the end of each month you'll get an email which is either bronze, silver, gold or, for the lucky few, platinum. It represents the reward you've earned for that month. The more stamps and emails you send and receive, the more rewards you earn, which you can redeem at leading retailers or donate to charity. And the value of the reward each month really depends on how successful we are in generating revenues - anywhere between £50 and £2.50."

Possible shortcomings?
"The major challenge is to communicate what we are doing as clearly as possible, because it is not obvious. But once users and advertisers understand what it is, then it should work really well. It's got a lot of advantages, particularly from the advertisers' point of view."

What's next?
"We're very focused on the UK launch and improving the concept here. Then we'll expand very quickly, probably into France and Germany first."

fields.headline: The watchdog who caught rabies
fields.standfirst:
Steve Brill was the man dedicated to embarrassing journalists into acting with 'integrity, honesty, fairness and accuracy'. But then he and a few corporate friends started a content website which seems to be using writers' work without their permission. Sean Dodson reports
Net news
fields.trailText: Steve Brill was the man dedicated to embarrassing journalists into acting with 'integrity, honesty, fairness and accuracy'. But then he and a few corporate friends started a content website which seems to be using writers' work without their permission. Sean Dodson reports
fields.body:
He is the self-appointed watchdog of the US media, the man who Bob Woodward once called, "the foremost serious journalistic entrepreneur of our times". His name is Steve Brill, he is the founder and former editor of Brill's Content - one-time scourge of corporate media - and now he is a fully-fledged media owner in his own right.

Last month, Brill started what many new media commentators regard as one of the most exciting e-commerce launches in the US this year. Contentville.com is a massive e-publisher, selling content culled from books, magazines, transcripts and legal documents. It even claims every dissertation written for a PhD degree in the US since 1861.

The site is a pay-to-download electronic archive. Magazine articles are sold for $2.95 (£2), while a dissertation (in electronic form) costs around $50 (£33). The site sells books too, selected by a string of carefully chosen bookshops and by a weighty editorial team which includes such luminaries as Harold Bloom and the playwright Wendy Wasserman.

But only a week into its launch the $120m (£80m) company found itself embroiled in a bitter dispute. And for once, Brill found himself up against thousands of disgruntled freelance writers rather than the media higher-ups that he usually tackles in his magazine Brill's Content.

The writers are complaining that their work is being sold on his new site without their prior consent. What rubs salt in the wound is that Brill has always sold himself as a guardian of the little fella. And besides, all he had to do was ask.

Brill launched Brill's Content in 1998 and it rapidly gathered a reputation for being a brash magazine that prided itself on whistle-blowing its way through the US media. Brill had cut his teeth 20 years earlier as founder of the first court TV service in the US, before moving on to found the magazines American Lawyer and Consumer Reports.

So when he announced, back in February, that he was to form a partnership with some of the biggest names in the US media, many pundits reacted with surprise and even scorn. How could a media watchdog be of any use if it was in the lap of the corporations it was set to guard against?

Brill's partners include NBC, CBS (who gained 35% equity in Contentville in return for $40m (£26m) worth of advertising and promotions over a three-year period) and Ebsco, a company which provides magazine subscription services and databases of archive content. In other words, the very companies that Brill's Content is famous for monitoring. It was as if Private Eye had cut a deal with Rupert Murdoch and begun selling edited highlights of Hansard at a couple of pounds a throw.

As Matt Welch of the Online Journalism Review points out: "He [Brill] will benefit materially from every positive book or magazine review he publishes, and his right to cover one of the most important media issues of the day... is hopelessly compromised."

Immediately, Brill announced that he was stepping down as as editor-in-chief of the magazine, turning those duties over to David Kuhn, who had joined the company last autumn from Talk magazine. Kuhn will edit both sites and Brill will remain as chairman and CEO of Brill Media Holdings - the company which oversees Brill's Content and Contentville. But he has insisted he will keep the two entities separate.

Writing in Media Life magazine, Jeff Bercovici noted: "It's almost as though, by appointing a single editor-in-chief for both ventures and announcing plans to share staffs and stories, he's intentionally stirring up controversy."

But the trouble really started in the week after the launch. A number of online writing lists began to receive complaints from disgruntled freelancers claiming that they had found their articles available on Contentville. One writer, Catherine Dold, discovered that an article she had written in 1993 was for sale on the site. She believes that she retains copyright and has said that she was never contacted by Contentville or the article's original publishers.

Dold immediately posted a warning on the online-writers list at content-exchange.com. She said: "Big surprise. Several articles I wrote for Discover are being offered for sale on Contentville. I hold the copyright to these, no question... I suggest everyone do a search on your name at this site."

She quickly found out she was not alone. Freelance writers across the US began complaining to the National Writers Union (NWU) that their work was available on the website without prior permission being granted. The authors claim that they still own the copyright to the material and have contracts to prove it. What's more, a number of the writers claim to have contacted the website and informed them of the infringement. None has received an initial reply and none of the work has been removed.

The NWU immediately posted an email alert, warning its members that: "There could literally be thousands whose work is being used illegally" on Brill's new site.

Then, a letter addressed to Steve Brill, by NWU president Jonathan Tasini, claimed that several of its members who retain copyright reported to Contentville that their work was being used without permission.

Contentville responded by stating that more than a million articles are offered on its site legitimately, under a contract with the magazine archive company Ebsco.

Contentville's website states that: "Except for materials in the public domain, all of the content of Contentville.com is the property of Contentville.com or its content suppliers and is protected by copyright laws..." The site also claims that it "will block access to and/or remove any material that it believes in good faith to be copyrighted".

Obviously embarrassed by the criticism, Brill responded on the Poynter Institute's media news website (www.poynter.org/medianews/letters.htm) claiming that his company had bought the articles in good faith and was "keeping exact records of each article that we sell so that we can pay whoever the appropriate copyright owner is".

He added: "I don't think we should be cast as the bad guy here for trying to create a market for this stuff - and for getting that process started by going to those who are promising that they own it."

But the mess was not confined to small-time freelances either, it was reported last week that Associated Press is investigating after one of its business writers found AP stories in the Contentville archives. The New York newspaper the Village Voice has also complained that its own archive material is being sold on the site.

Some analysts have suggested that what Brill wants to do is ditch Brill's Content, a magazine that has never made a profit, and concentrate on the e-publishers. Both Brill and Kuhn have denied this. But the kind of publicity generated by the ugly mess over writers' copyright will hardly inspire confidence in an ailing magazine.

The NWU is confident that the row can be resolved and cites a similar recent dispute with another pay-to-download site, www.mercurycenter.com. Also, the union offers a similar service of its own - the Publication Rights Clearing House - which it is urging sites like Contentville to adopt.

But David Wallis, a New York-based writer who is planning to launch an elite freelancers' agency, told the Village Voice that he sees Brill's attempt at reconciliation with the NWU as a "dodge," and a reaction to the "terrible publicity and backlash" of last week. Wallis says: "As a media watchdog, Steve Brill has rabies."

It is perhaps worth remembering what Brill's Content was meant to be about. In what amounts to a mission statement on the original Brill's Content website, Brill wrote: "It's time to hold journalists accountable. It's time we embarrass them into doing their jobs the way they're supposed to - with integrity, honesty, fairness and accuracy." Catherine Dold and the freelancers on the online discussion list might well be musing on those words and wondering, while they patiently wait for their cheques to arrive, just what happened to Steve Brill?
fields.bodyText: He is the self-appointed watchdog of the US media, the man who Bob Woodward once called, "the foremost serious journalistic entrepreneur of our times". His name is Steve Brill, he is the founder and former editor of Brill's Content - one-time scourge of corporate media - and now he is a fully-fledged media owner in his own right. Last month, Brill started what many new media commentators regard as one of the most exciting e-commerce launches in the US this year. Contentville.com is a massive e-publisher, selling content culled from books, magazines, transcripts and legal documents. It even claims every dissertation written for a PhD degree in the US since 1861. The site is a pay-to-download electronic archive. Magazine articles are sold for $2.95 (£2), while a dissertation (in electronic form) costs around $50 (£33). The site sells books too, selected by a string of carefully chosen bookshops and by a weighty editorial team which includes such luminaries as Harold Bloom and the playwright Wendy Wasserman. But only a week into its launch the $120m (£80m) company found itself embroiled in a bitter dispute. And for once, Brill found himself up against thousands of disgruntled freelance writers rather than the media higher-ups that he usually tackles in his magazine Brill's Content. The writers are complaining that their work is being sold on his new site without their prior consent. What rubs salt in the wound is that Brill has always sold himself as a guardian of the little fella. And besides, all he had to do was ask. Brill launched Brill's Content in 1998 and it rapidly gathered a reputation for being a brash magazine that prided itself on whistle-blowing its way through the US media. Brill had cut his teeth 20 years earlier as founder of the first court TV service in the US, before moving on to found the magazines American Lawyer and Consumer Reports. So when he announced, back in February, that he was to form a partnership with some of the biggest names in the US media, many pundits reacted with surprise and even scorn. How could a media watchdog be of any use if it was in the lap of the corporations it was set to guard against? Brill's partners include NBC, CBS (who gained 35% equity in Contentville in return for $40m (£26m) worth of advertising and promotions over a three-year period) and Ebsco, a company which provides magazine subscription services and databases of archive content. In other words, the very companies that Brill's Content is famous for monitoring. It was as if Private Eye had cut a deal with Rupert Murdoch and begun selling edited highlights of Hansard at a couple of pounds a throw. As Matt Welch of the Online Journalism Review points out: "He [Brill] will benefit materially from every positive book or magazine review he publishes, and his right to cover one of the most important media issues of the day... is hopelessly compromised." Immediately, Brill announced that he was stepping down as as editor-in-chief of the magazine, turning those duties over to David Kuhn, who had joined the company last autumn from Talk magazine. Kuhn will edit both sites and Brill will remain as chairman and CEO of Brill Media Holdings - the company which oversees Brill's Content and Contentville. But he has insisted he will keep the two entities separate. Writing in Media Life magazine, Jeff Bercovici noted: "It's almost as though, by appointing a single editor-in-chief for both ventures and announcing plans to share staffs and stories, he's intentionally stirring up controversy." But the trouble really started in the week after the launch. A number of online writing lists began to receive complaints from disgruntled freelancers claiming that they had found their articles available on Contentville. One writer, Catherine Dold, discovered that an article she had written in 1993 was for sale on the site. She believes that she retains copyright and has said that she was never contacted by Contentville or the article's original publishers. Dold immediately posted a warning on the online-writers list at content-exchange.com. She said: "Big surprise. Several articles I wrote for Discover are being offered for sale on Contentville. I hold the copyright to these, no question... I suggest everyone do a search on your name at this site." She quickly found out she was not alone. Freelance writers across the US began complaining to the National Writers Union (NWU) that their work was available on the website without prior permission being granted. The authors claim that they still own the copyright to the material and have contracts to prove it. What's more, a number of the writers claim to have contacted the website and informed them of the infringement. None has received an initial reply and none of the work has been removed. The NWU immediately posted an email alert, warning its members that: "There could literally be thousands whose work is being used illegally" on Brill's new site. Then, a letter addressed to Steve Brill, by NWU president Jonathan Tasini, claimed that several of its members who retain copyright reported to Contentville that their work was being used without permission. Contentville responded by stating that more than a million articles are offered on its site legitimately, under a contract with the magazine archive company Ebsco. Contentville's website states that: "Except for materials in the public domain, all of the content of Contentville.com is the property of Contentville.com or its content suppliers and is protected by copyright laws..." The site also claims that it "will block access to and/or remove any material that it believes in good faith to be copyrighted". Obviously embarrassed by the criticism, Brill responded on the Poynter Institute's media news website (www.poynter.org/medianews/letters.htm) claiming that his company had bought the articles in good faith and was "keeping exact records of each article that we sell so that we can pay whoever the appropriate copyright owner is". He added: "I don't think we should be cast as the bad guy here for trying to create a market for this stuff - and for getting that process started by going to those who are promising that they own it." But the mess was not confined to small-time freelances either, it was reported last week that Associated Press is investigating after one of its business writers found AP stories in the Contentville archives. The New York newspaper the Village Voice has also complained that its own archive material is being sold on the site. Some analysts have suggested that what Brill wants to do is ditch Brill's Content, a magazine that has never made a profit, and concentrate on the e-publishers. Both Brill and Kuhn have denied this. But the kind of publicity generated by the ugly mess over writers' copyright will hardly inspire confidence in an ailing magazine. The NWU is confident that the row can be resolved and cites a similar recent dispute with another pay-to-download site, www.mercurycenter.com. Also, the union offers a similar service of its own - the Publication Rights Clearing House - which it is urging sites like Contentville to adopt. But David Wallis, a New York-based writer who is planning to launch an elite freelancers' agency, told the Village Voice that he sees Brill's attempt at reconciliation with the NWU as a "dodge," and a reaction to the "terrible publicity and backlash" of last week. Wallis says: "As a media watchdog, Steve Brill has rabies." It is perhaps worth remembering what Brill's Content was meant to be about. In what amounts to a mission statement on the original Brill's Content website, Brill wrote: "It's time to hold journalists accountable. It's time we embarrass them into doing their jobs the way they're supposed to - with integrity, honesty, fairness and accuracy." Catherine Dold and the freelancers on the online discussion list might well be musing on those words and wondering, while they patiently wait for their cheques to arrive, just what happened to Steve Brill?

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.body:
 News International is having a hard time keeping up the pretence that everything is running tickety-boo in its new media lab, especially now it has laid off 30 members of staff, including marketing director Tony Hall. The restructuring, which focuses on the auction event site FiredUp.com, follows attempts in the past two months to re-boot (but NI spinners prefer the term "hard launch" ) the shaky service. Recruitment site Revolver.com, which launched last month, will also be affected. No one at News Networks would comment on rumours that the sites are in for a radical review, but MD Alasdair MacLeod insists that they will "continue operations as usual". Perhaps NI should stick to what it knows best - Page3.com goes from strength to strength.

 The death knell has sounded for dozens of UK ISPs. Last week the RIP bill was passed in the Commons, making Britain the only G7 state which permits government access to encryption keys on the net. ISPs such as Claranet and Easynet, which have infrastructure overseas, will move their email and web storage there. Claranet says that many of its financial services customers are concerned by the security implications. Others without overseas set-ups, such as Poptel and GreenNet, which host protest groups and political sites, are probably panicking.

 Hats off to Colin Robinson, the former teacher who won Channel 4's E-Millionaire show. He has made the wise decision to sell the paper concept for schoolsforschools.com, his B2B education site, to a bigger fish called Schoolmaster.net, thereby avoiding the headache of running his own start-up. Nabil Shabka, Schoolmaster's CEO, has implied it will be using the TV publicity the site generated to launch an e-commerce arm later this year. Robinson could not be contacted last week - he may be house-hunting in the Bahamas.

 ITV Sport has just closed a deal with Two Way TV to develop an enhanced live, interactive sports service. The move has fuelled rumours that ITV, which has been lagging behind the BBC in the online rat race, may be planning a portal or central web network.

 Freeserve, which seemingly increasingly fancies itself as a rival to Channel 5, is launching a celebrity chat show on its entertainment channel, to be fronted by Tiffany Jones, formerly of Carlton TV. Last week whiskery Teletext also announced it was moving into digital TV and wireless technology. The 25-year-old service has a user base that most ISPs would die for.

 More new media jargon: if you don't know what Vip or Hip are, you may as well go back to making smoke signals. Vehicle internet protocol (think intelligent mopeds which tell you when to turn left ) and home internet protocol (smart fridges which talk to your dietician) are going to be huge, mate (honest).
