fields.headline: Media diary
fields.body:
 Scotsman supremo Andrew Neil was rallying the troops at Holyrood last week. It was unfortunate that his speech ("Truly inspiring," says our man in a kilt) was scheduled just hours after the Concorde crash in Paris on Tuesday, resulting in a depleted audience. But it was nothing short of incompetent that no one at the Hootsmon thought to pull a full-page ad in Press Gazette later that week, which showed a mock-up of the Scotsman with the splash headline: "Win a fabulous trip to New York by Concorde."

 The Daily Mail's hostility to asylum-seekers is well known. But its recent cartoon by Mahood showing refugees leaving Dover in the back of a lorry loaded with boxes of tomatoes, telling each other that Mo Mowlam was moving the Queen out of Buckingham Palace to make room for them, was breathtaking in its timing - just a few days after 58 had suffocated to death in similar circumstances.

Distressed representatives of the Refugee Council fired off a letter to editor Paul Dacre in protest, pointing out how appalling it was to make a joke of the tragedy. Naturally, the letter was not printed, but executive managing editor Robin Esser replied (and we quote in full): "I think it is not always appreciated that cartoons are not jokes. They are satirical comment."

Readers of the Mail will doubtless be looking forward to the biting cartoon satire about German holiday-makers on Concorde telling each other "This is the trip of a lifetime!", or similar.

 Benny is on his way back, it seems, as the race to win the commission for ITV's teatime soap hots up. Carlton's Crossroads bid is a top tip - and not just because it is being scripted by Lucy "Peak Practice" Gannon, the doyenne of ITV popular drama.

So desperate is Carlton to wake its elephantine Nottingham studios from slumber that it has seriously undercut its rivals and, we hear, is offering some big stars in key roles. Will the motel room-rate rise accordingly, we wonder?

 It seems that cash-rich Channel 4 is so financially secure it can afford to throw away its best ideas. The broadcaster held the rights to the Wanted reality game show format, which it broadcast with limited success a few years before Big Brother fever. Recently, the rights reverted to the show's creator, the independent Hewland International. Yes, the same Hewland International that has just raked in a tidy sum selling the idea to the Fox network in the US.

 Cold Feet star and drinking chum of the diary James Nesbitt is no fan of trashy TV magazines, even deriding his publicist recently for not securing him an interview in the Guardian ("All he ever gets me is face of the fortnight in Inside Soap").

So it was with some surprise that our man in a spangly jacket saw him huddled in the corner at C5's champagne-fuelled Family Affairs relaunch party last week, giving extensive in-depth interviews to, you've guessed it, trashy TV magazines. We feel Mr Nesbitt needs more broadsheet exposure - how about doing My Media, Jimmy?

 Hats off to Melanie "friend of the family" Phillips. In an article last week, Mel P accused Cherie Blair of making a speech to the American Bar Association that was largely "highly ideological: tendentious, selective, contradictory or just plain wrong". The publication she wrote in was, of course, the ideologically neutral, impartial, exhaustive, consistent and always accurate Spectator.

 There is disappointment among correspondents at the BBC over its decision to reverse a publicly announced intention to chase Israel through the international justice system over the death at the hands of an Israeli tank crew of a BBC driver/fixer, Abed Takkous, in South Lebanon in late May.

The BBC had said it planned to prosecute the soldiers and officer responsible for war crimes. Head of news Tony Hall has apparently now decided to sue the Israeli defence forces through the civilian justice system inside Israel.

 What do actress Leslie Ash, pop group Steps and TV presenter Clive Anderson have in common? They were all worth £15 to Benji the Binman. On top of his News International income, an invoice for last July shows professional muckraker Benjamin Pell pocketed a decent whack from the Mirror Group.

He made £50 out of Rik Mayall, £80 from Paul McCartney and £350 from the divorced Jaggers. His biggest earners, at £400 each, were Elton John and Geri Halliwell. Where there's muck, there really is brass.

 Still at least the Mirror has paid Mr Pell. Last week, poor Benji was disconsolate at being blanked by the Times diary. It seems the team no longer have time for their old friends, following orders from on high. Pell's close friend and adviser (Uncle) Max Clifford had typically shrewd advice: "Don't get upset, this is typical. What's outstanding?" To which the reply was nine (count 'em) invoices.

fields.headline: My media: Robin Oakley
fields.trailText: Newspapers: I'm a complete news junkie. All the heavies: Times, Guardian, Telegraph, FT, Independent, plus the Mail. Can't afford to miss Peter Riddell, Don Macintyre, Philip Stevens, Hugo Young. Always make sure I read the Sun. You can't cover politics without it. Sundays: pretty well the lot. Horseracing being my other great interest, my other daily reading is the Racing Post.
fields.body:
Newspapers: I'm a complete news junkie. All the heavies: Times, Guardian, Telegraph, FT, Independent, plus the Mail. Can't afford to miss Peter Riddell, Don Macintyre, Philip Stevens, Hugo Young. Always make sure I read the Sun. You can't cover politics without it. Sundays: pretty well the lot. Horseracing being my other great interest, my other daily reading is the Racing Post.

Magazines: Spectator, New Statesman, Economist. There's no time for anything lighter, except Private Eye.

Books: I like Robert B Parker's Boston-based crime novels. Always enjoy political biographies. Haven't read much recently because I've been writing a book myself. My favourite book title is jockey Jack Leach's Sods I Have Cut on the Turf.

Film: This is where I realise what a terribly boring person I've become. I only occasionally get to the cinema. Saw East Is East a while ago. Loved it. And The Talented Mr Ripley. My favourite of all time is a film of the Newport Jazz Festival in the 1970s: Jazz on a Summer's Day. It's the most wonderful, evocative piece of filming.

Television: For eight years I've worked 12-15 hour days, so I watch remarkably little. I love contemporary history series like the Poisoned Chalice, about Britain's relations with Europe, or Michael Cockerell's political biographies. I'm looking forward to watching Newsnight a lot more.

Radio: The Today programme of course. Love News Quiz, World at One, and PM. I'm a fan of 5 Live - its breakfast show is good.

Ads: Absolutely do not register with me at all. Occasionally there's an eye-catching one and I think, "What the hell is that all about?", but there's nothing that sticks very much in my mind.

Multimedia: I'm not an internet man. I keep an old-fashioned diary and journal.

fields.headline: Charles in charge
fields.standfirst: The would-be ITV media moguls have been battling for months and on Friday Charles Allen won. Not bad for an 'upstart caterer', says David Teather
fields.trailText: The would-be ITV media moguls have been battling for months and on Friday Charles Allen won. Not bad for an 'upstart caterer', says David Teather.
fields.body:
When Gerry Robinson took the reigns of Granada as chief executive in 1991 and installed his right hand man Charles Allen as managing director they were greeted with howls of derision.

The pair had been managers in Granada's hospitality division and comedian John Cleese, aka Basil Fawlty, famously dismissed them as "upstart caterers" who had been miscast at the head of Britain's best loved television franchise. Allen in turn was also sniffily referred to as a "Scottish accountant" with all the stereotyped husbandry that entails.

Almost a decade on it is Robinson and Allen who have had the last laugh. A succession of deals starting with the hostile takeover of LWT in 1994 has built Granada to the point where it has become the single largest player in ITV.

But as Robinson settles into a consultancy role with the catering side of Granada and a £1m a year stipend it will be Allen, 43, that will adopt the mantle of the most powerful man in ITV.

At the end of last week, Granada agreed a deal to acquire the Meridian, Anglia and HTV licences from Lord Hollick's United News & Media for £1.75bn. Granada will need to sell HTV on, most likely to Carlton, but will still be left as the dominant player on the ITV map.

Allen characterised the agreement as a defining moment. "This is a transforming deal for Granada and for ITV, which moves from a federal structure to a partnership between us and Carlton," he said.

The deal was the first time Allen has emerged fully from the shadow of Robinson and he did so with disappointing good grace given the egocentricity of your average media mogul.

Twice during the press conference announcing the acquisition of the United franchises on Friday he was asked whether the deal put him in prime position to assume control of ITV when legislation allows - attempts to elicit at least a certain amount of triumphalism.

The questions were deftly avoided; this was a great deal for shareholders, he said, he was looking forward to working with Michael Green of Carlton and Lord Hollick had achieved an "elegant exit" from television (also doing well for his shareholders).

Only one of Allen's advisers confided afterwards that the week had been full of phone calls, machinations and no one trusting anyone.

Allen is a genial, well liked figure in television. He tucks his limbs up under him as he sits and talks passionately about the business, remembers details of former conversations and assiduously remarks that "you have made a good point".

Behind the smiles though he is also the veteran of two ugly hostile takeovers and is clearly not afraid of a bloodied nose. Allen tore through hotels group Forte after the hostile takeover battle of the mid-90s with hundreds of job losses and faced down fierce tensions when he took over the Granada television business.

It's of little surprise that Carlton and United took the threat of a hostile assault on either seriously and that Michael Green stepped quietly back after his own plans for expansion were frustrated.

"I think Green will be relieved to still have a company today," a Granada adviser said on Friday. "Next week he will start wondering where it went wrong."

Allen, an intensely private figure, was born in Lanark in Scotland the youngest of three children. His father, a hairdresser, died when he was only 14 and his mother became the breadwinner by working in catering. He won a place at Strathclyde university but felt compelled instead to find work and support the family taking a job as a management trainee with British Steel for £18 a week.

That time, he says, made an impression that would go on to inform his later business life. The local pub was known as the P45 Arms, where steelworkers would gather to drown their sorrows after being made redundant during a long stream of job losses. It is better, Allen says now, to deal with bad news swiftly rather than leave people lingering and uncertain of their futures.

Allen's career spanned steel - and even microbiology for a brief stint - before he moved into catering where he worked at Grand Metropolitan and Compass among others. He adopts an avuncular air when he claims to have enjoyed catering and television equally before the business was split in two earlier his year. "Both were people businesses," he says.

But he has found his metier in broadcasting. At a briefing several weeks ago in his St James' office Allen hamfistedly poured coffee into the tea pot instead of hot water, despite each being clearly marked with a yellow sticker. "You can see why I chose television," he said.

When Robinson took over at Granada he gave Allen a year to turn the ITV franchise around or else sell it. He endured a series of critical headlines accusing him of sacrificing quality television in the pursuit of profit and became embroiled in spectacular fall outs - such as the dismissal of the respected executive David Plowright.

The received wisdom in television at the time - that Channel 4 would forever need financial support, that BSkyB would never succeed and that the ITV companies had no place in programme making - was almost entirely "utterly wrong" he says.

"One of the things that has fascinated me about this industry is that people speak so knowledgably from a position of not knowing a great deal," he commented.

"When I took over at Granada Television one of the early decisions I made was to turn programming from a cost centre into a business which was seen as heresy and the second decision was that we would start selling our programmes to other broadcasters which was also seen as crazy," he says. "Granada was seen as a dinosaur because it made programming. Content at the end of the day is the thing that will really matter but that wasn't the way it was viewed ten years ago."

The use of the word content is a ready clue to Allen's enthusiasm for the potential of new media for Granada and ITV. "We want to try and create new types of content," he says. "We get tens of thousands of applications for Stars in their Eyes - we could put those online and people could vote on it. Here are the 20 contestants we got today and so you have heats. You start opening your mind to innovative, creative ideas. We have a cult show with 15m viewers why not take it back a stage?"

One of the bonuses of ITV being run in large part by two companies he says is the easier ability to make the big strategic decisions that affect the network and the Channel 3 brand. Granada and Carlton are already partners in ONdigital Allen points out although in a relaxed moment he confides that working in the same company with either Hollick or Green "would have been challenging".

Plans on the agenda include the development of ITV.co.uk, which has lost a huge march on the BBC and the launch of a family of ITV channels for digital. These will be grouped around themes or particular segments of the audience and, Allen promised last week, will finally be available on Sky Digital.

His other focus now is on mainland Europe which Allen compares to ITV five years ago - each media company sitting on its own sovereignty and eyeing each other warily before inevitable consolidation. Most of the deal with United is in Granada shares which means the company is still sitting on a war chest of £1.5bn. "We have the firepower to move forward," he says.

Perhaps the lack of obvious ego or triumphalism though is in part to do with Allen's awareness of how far there is to go. Though the dominant player in ITV, with a value of £10bn, Granada would still be considered something of a minnow by many of its rivals in Europe. Having bested Michael Green and Clive Hollick, Allen must now compare his growing empire to that of Vivendi's Jean-Marie Messier.
fields.bodyText: When Gerry Robinson took the reigns of Granada as chief executive in 1991 and installed his right hand man Charles Allen as managing director they were greeted with howls of derision. The pair had been managers in Granada's hospitality division and comedian John Cleese, aka Basil Fawlty, famously dismissed them as "upstart caterers" who had been miscast at the head of Britain's best loved television franchise. Allen in turn was also sniffily referred to as a "Scottish accountant" with all the stereotyped husbandry that entails. Almost a decade on it is Robinson and Allen who have had the last laugh. A succession of deals starting with the hostile takeover of LWT in 1994 has built Granada to the point where it has become the single largest player in ITV. But as Robinson settles into a consultancy role with the catering side of Granada and a £1m a year stipend it will be Allen, 43, that will adopt the mantle of the most powerful man in ITV. At the end of last week, Granada agreed a deal to acquire the Meridian, Anglia and HTV licences from Lord Hollick's United News & Media for £1.75bn. Granada will need to sell HTV on, most likely to Carlton, but will still be left as the dominant player on the ITV map. Allen characterised the agreement as a defining moment. "This is a transforming deal for Granada and for ITV, which moves from a federal structure to a partnership between us and Carlton," he said. The deal was the first time Allen has emerged fully from the shadow of Robinson and he did so with disappointing good grace given the egocentricity of your average media mogul. Twice during the press conference announcing the acquisition of the United franchises on Friday he was asked whether the deal put him in prime position to assume control of ITV when legislation allows - attempts to elicit at least a certain amount of triumphalism. The questions were deftly avoided; this was a great deal for shareholders, he said, he was looking forward to working with Michael Green of Carlton and Lord Hollick had achieved an "elegant exit" from television (also doing well for his shareholders). Only one of Allen's advisers confided afterwards that the week had been full of phone calls, machinations and no one trusting anyone. Allen is a genial, well liked figure in television. He tucks his limbs up under him as he sits and talks passionately about the business, remembers details of former conversations and assiduously remarks that "you have made a good point". Behind the smiles though he is also the veteran of two ugly hostile takeovers and is clearly not afraid of a bloodied nose. Allen tore through hotels group Forte after the hostile takeover battle of the mid-90s with hundreds of job losses and faced down fierce tensions when he took over the Granada television business. It's of little surprise that Carlton and United took the threat of a hostile assault on either seriously and that Michael Green stepped quietly back after his own plans for expansion were frustrated. "I think Green will be relieved to still have a company today," a Granada adviser said on Friday. "Next week he will start wondering where it went wrong." Allen, an intensely private figure, was born in Lanark in Scotland the youngest of three children. His father, a hairdresser, died when he was only 14 and his mother became the breadwinner by working in catering. He won a place at Strathclyde university but felt compelled instead to find work and support the family taking a job as a management trainee with British Steel for £18 a week. That time, he says, made an impression that would go on to inform his later business life. The local pub was known as the P45 Arms, where steelworkers would gather to drown their sorrows after being made redundant during a long stream of job losses. It is better, Allen says now, to deal with bad news swiftly rather than leave people lingering and uncertain of their futures. Allen's career spanned steel - and even microbiology for a brief stint - before he moved into catering where he worked at Grand Metropolitan and Compass among others. He adopts an avuncular air when he claims to have enjoyed catering and television equally before the business was split in two earlier his year. "Both were people businesses," he says. But he has found his metier in broadcasting. At a briefing several weeks ago in his St James' office Allen hamfistedly poured coffee into the tea pot instead of hot water, despite each being clearly marked with a yellow sticker. "You can see why I chose television," he said. When Robinson took over at Granada he gave Allen a year to turn the ITV franchise around or else sell it. He endured a series of critical headlines accusing him of sacrificing quality television in the pursuit of profit and became embroiled in spectacular fall outs - such as the dismissal of the respected executive David Plowright. The received wisdom in television at the time - that Channel 4 would forever need financial support, that BSkyB would never succeed and that the ITV companies had no place in programme making - was almost entirely "utterly wrong" he says. "One of the things that has fascinated me about this industry is that people speak so knowledgably from a position of not knowing a great deal," he commented. "When I took over at Granada Television one of the early decisions I made was to turn programming from a cost centre into a business which was seen as heresy and the second decision was that we would start selling our programmes to other broadcasters which was also seen as crazy," he says. "Granada was seen as a dinosaur because it made programming. Content at the end of the day is the thing that will really matter but that wasn't the way it was viewed ten years ago." The use of the word content is a ready clue to Allen's enthusiasm for the potential of new media for Granada and ITV. "We want to try and create new types of content," he says. "We get tens of thousands of applications for Stars in their Eyes - we could put those online and people could vote on it. Here are the 20 contestants we got today and so you have heats. You start opening your mind to innovative, creative ideas. We have a cult show with 15m viewers why not take it back a stage?" One of the bonuses of ITV being run in large part by two companies he says is the easier ability to make the big strategic decisions that affect the network and the Channel 3 brand. webTitle: 'I don't care what the Mail says'

fields.headline: 'I don't care what the Mail says'
fields.standfirst: Famous for her frankness, lambasted by the Mail, Dawn Airey says Channel 5 is 'as good as the others'. The chair of this year's Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival tells  Matt Wells  what's going to be hot this summer
fields.trailText: Famous for her frankness, lambasted by the Mail, Dawn Airey says Channel 5 is 'as good as the others'. The chair of this year's Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival tells Matt Wells what's going to be hot this summer
fields.body:
Keith Chegwin's naughty bits notwithstanding, Channel 5 likes its beautiful people. With the hunky antipodean himbo on security and the meticulously made-up receptionist, a visitor's first impression is that its Long Acre headquarters in London must be populated by jobbing magazine models who happen to run a TV channel in their spare time.

It's all part of the F-factor - that's F for feelgood, before you ask - that has delivered an impressive set of audience figures to the station recently. It may be derided as Channel Filth by executives at the Daily Mail (who probably drool over Sex and Shopping in private) but the David and Dawn show is delivering the goods, which is why the paper's increasingly personal attacks on chief executive David Elstein and director of programmes Dawn Airey are beginning to grate.

There was a time when Channel 5 could take a joke, but headlines bemoaning the "sad and degrading" programmes and the "dirty lies" of its executives are in danger of robbing the channel of its sense of humour.

"We put on our full metal jacket and we don't care what the Daily Mail is saying because we know it is not true," says Airey, a few minutes after poring over another rant. "We know, and our viewers know, that this is a polarised view of a very, very small part of the schedule. There is excellence and depth in vast areas of our schedule."

It is certainly true that the channel is beginning to get a name for itself. Its daily soap, Family Affairs, is showing a slow but steady improvement in ratings. Night Fever, the Saturday night karaoke show starring the former Madness frontman Suggs, has a cult following and has been recommissioned for a fourth series. And The People versus Jerry Sadowitz shows that the channel is committed to cutting-edge comedy. Audience share in recent weeks has neared 6%.

Later this year it will screen two new "reality" gameshows that may deliver not just "talked-about television", something of which C5 has plenty, but also a set of ratings that will really raise its game. One is as yet undisclosed, but the other, The Mole, a Belgian format that walked away with the Golden Rose at the Montreux television festival earlier this year, sounds a winner. The idea is that a group of 10 contestants compete to solve a challenge - and discover a mole in their midst who is tasked with sabotaging their every move.

Despite her bullish mood, Airey concedes that the attacks are getting under her skin. "It really upsets me, and everyone at Channel 5. We all want to make Channel 5 a huge success and we know that we are significantly better than when we launched three and a half years ago. Now, we are at least as good as the other broadcasters."

It's a typically brash claim from the woman who once said that C5 was about "films, fucking and football". It is a style which she has brought to her role as advisory chair for the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival - she describes her position as "agent provocateur", and promises a festival line-up that is "relevant, revelatory and raucous".

Traditionally the festival is the industry's annual opportunity for navel-gazing, and an increased number of discussion sessions this year means there will be more self-evaluation than ever before. Topics up for discussion include reality TV, the future of television news, regulation in the digital age and - since Greg Dyke is delivering the keynote MacTaggart lecture, the first person in the history of the festival to perform the role twice - the future of the BBC.

Airey appears nervous about publicising her views on the last topic, since dissing her star speaker would not exactly be a politic move. But she suggests that Dyke's lecture may draw back from what his chief lieutenant, director of television Mark Thompson, outlined in his recent speech in Canada. "It's quite clear that the government is not thrilled by what Mark said. I think the BBC is just throwing up lots of ideas and just testing the water. I personally would be surprised if the BBC went quite so far down the polarising route it was proposing."

She is charitable about Dyke's first months at the corporation - "People are discovering that they have a pulse again" - but she likens the director-general's job to wading through treacle. It will take some time, she predicts, before Dyke's reforms filter through to what appears on screen.

"From people I know there, I just get the sense that it's not as empowering or as fast or as dynamic as it should be. For an organisation that has such a huge sum of money to spend on programmes, at its most simple, the BBC should be about commissioning the best ideas from the best sources - because it's got an awful lot of money to do so. It also has such a great legacy and attracts such great talent, but why isn't the range and quality of programming appearing on screen? I think it's probably a structural issue, and, as I say, that's what Greg is trying to address at the moment."

The biggest challenge for the BBC, Airey suggests, is to maintain its long-term justification for its unique and increasingly controversial method of funding - the licence fee. As digital viewing expands, the audience share for all traditional broadcasters will fall. Ratings will be the key to the BBC's future: "I think they have to be of a certain size in terms of audience share to justify the licence fee. If the BBC doesn't connect with most of the population on a relatively frequent basis then obviously there has to be a question mark over its long-term future funding."

The key test will not be the rate at which the BBC's share falls, but how that share compares with the ratings of its commercial competitors. If the gap between BBC1 and ITV widens to more than 5% - at the moment, thanks to ITV's poor performance this year, they are about neck and neck - it will become impossible for the corporation to justify a tax on every viewer. At that stage, she suggests, the BBC could only justify a future without advertising by going down the subscription route.

On regulation, there is no case for the BBC to remain outside a reformed system. Joining the almost universal calls for abolition or at least radical reform of the BBC governors, she argues that the corporation should be brought under the wing of one "Ofcom" regulator. The argument is simple, she suggests: "Why should one sector of the broadcasting industry be regulated under different rules to another?" Because of its unique system of funding, you might think. "But it still has to reflect the mood of the population in terms of content. You can't have a BBC doing one thing and commercial broadcasters doing another."

It is a statement of the obvious to say that the BBC needs more big hits, but there are few signs of any jackpots in the corporation's current crop of ideas. Airey is delighted to have beaten BBC1 controller Peter Salmon to The Mole - it sat on his desk for a year before he realised its potential, and when the BBC came calling on the day it won the Golden Rose at Montreux, it was too late. ITV is to snap up Survivor, the Charlie Parsons format that is a runaway success in the US (think Castaway 2000 crossed with Big Brother). With only a few more Castaway instalments planned before the survival experiment ends, the BBC has some catching up to do in the reality TV game.

Clearly, the Big Brother phenomenon will be the talk of Edinburgh (it's the subject of a Guardian-sponsored debate), since the run will be halfway through at the time of the festival. "We all love to talk about each other, we all love to gossip about each other and the way you've got people whose lives are being broadcast into the nation's homes, you can form a view about them. With Big Brother, while the viewing figures aren't spectacular, it's certainly a talking point with a certain demographic group. It has captured the imagination."

High ratings are not the defining factor, although Big Brother's figures are climbing steadily and last Thursday the show attracted almost a quarter of the available audience at 11pm, says Airey. If your show is the talk of the steamie, that's good enough. And Big Brother is certainly "talked-about television".

Not surprisingly, Airey does not agree with the doom-mongers that surveillance television spells the end of authored documentary; she says it is simply an evolution of the genre - clearly, what is shown on screen in Big Brother is heavily edited and packaged. And, however much Paul Watson protests, Big Brother is firmly rooted in the Sylvania Waters tradition. "It shows that ordinary people can be infinitely fascinating."

There will be a strong US contingent at Edinburgh, including the executive from ABC who commissioned Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? - another example of how "ordinary people" can deliver extraordinary audiences for broadcasters. Britain is clearly leading the field in the genre, and the US cannot get enough of it. "We do experiment more with form and type here," she says. "The stakes are less high."

Chairing the Edinburgh TV festival has something of a job application feel about it - previous incumbents have included Jane Root and Mark Thompson. Share options, however, lock her in to Channel 5 for the foreseeable future, and given that her boss, Elstein, is not going anywhere soon, it looks as if she is there to stay. Indeed, she insists that the only task which she is anticipating after the festival is preparing for a five-week break in Australia - perhaps she could recruit a few more security guards while she's there.

Dawn rises quickly

1984 Graduates from Cambridge and joins Central TV as trainee, eventually rising to scheduling role as controller of planning: "It was a baptism of fire: most other controllers were men in their mid-40s, who felt rather undermined that Central had the audacity to put a 26-year-old unknown woman in as a controller." Acquires "Zulu Dawn" nickname.

1993 Part of first ITV Network Centre team under Marcus Plantin, commissioning children's and daytime programmes (including Supermarket Sweep). Output for kids criticised by BBC counterpart Anna Home for over-reliance on cartoons, but boasts "every show won its time-slot. No one else at Network Centre can say that."

1994 Poached by Channel 4 as controller of arts and entertainment. Seen as leading the channel's populist tendency, favouring an expansion of entertainment output at the expense of worthy "remit" programmes, during 18-month stint which saw launch of Hollyoaks.

1995 Accepts approach from Pearson TV's Greg Dyke to be director of programmes in Channel 5 bid headed by him: "I'm a deeply commercial and competitive animal, and I'd always wanted the chance to run my own channel." When Dyke's consortium wins, Michael Grade tells her: "I hope Channel 5 goes down the pan, but you end up smelling of roses."

1996 David Elstein joins Channel 5 pre-launch from BSkyB as chief executive, leading industry commentators to question whether cerebral "Two Brains" (who's a BBC2 man) and fun-loving Zulu Dawn will be compatible.

1997 Channel 5 launches with icons of girl power - the Spice Girls, Kirsty Young, Xena: Warrior Princess - mirroring Airey's own image. Turns down approach from Elisabeth Murdoch to join BSkyB, despite viewing her dad as a "demigod".

1998 Airey forecasts Channel 5 - now achieving 5% audience share in best weeks - will overtake BBC2 and Channel 4 as "third channel" within three years. Sent to Harvard Business School on course previously taken by Dyke, suggesting grooming for future chief executive role.

1999 Relaunch of Channel 5's soap Family Affairs with massacre of original family. Airey tells Guardian her channel specialises in "films, fucking and football", but "bosoms, balls and brutality" are also "part of the mix".

2000 Home and Away acquired when dropped by ITV. Screening of nude gameshow The Naked Jungle, presented by Keith Chegwin, adds to mounting press criticism, but Elstein takes the brunt of Daily Mail's attacks rather than Airey.

fields.headline: A bird in the hand
fields.standfirst: A feathered fugitive, unusual livestock, gnome conspiracy and the phantom school
fields.trailText: A feathered fugitive, unusual livestock, gnome conspiracy and the phantom school.
fields.body:
Rhea fear
A thrilling chase through the streets of Pinehurst, Wiltshire, was triggered after a rhea which two brothers had bought as a gift for their parents panicked and escaped.

The Sawyer brothers - Nigel, 39, and Neil, 37 - had purchased two of the ostrich-like birds while their parents were on holiday.

Unfortunately one of the rheas, Victor, was ill-at-ease in his new surroundings - despite the company of a peacock, two peahens, three dogs, a parrot, two cats, goldfish and a pot-bellied pig called OJ - and jumped over the gate.

After a frantic chase on foot, Nigel Sawyer jumped into his car and managed to corner the bird in a cul-de-sac, where the pair overpowered the reluctant bird.

Electrician Neil said: "Me and Nigel got a good kicking ­ they have really powerful legs.
Swindon Evening Advertiser

Doing bird
Feathered gifts caused more trouble for a Bradford man, whose attempts to discard an unwanted bird landed him in court after an RSPCA observer recognised it as a protected species.

Sattar Mohammed pleaded guilty to possessing a live bird of prey, transporting it and offering it for sale at a livestock auction in Clitheroe.

Mr Mohammed told Blackburn magistrates that he had been given a sparrowhawk by a man in the street. While he had tried to feed it on chapattis and nuts, the ungrateful hawk proved a difficult addition to the Mohammed household, eating half a pound of raw meat a day, scratching his new owner on the hand and trying to bite him.
East Lancashire Online

Gnome man's land
The North Devon Express has launched a gnome hotline in attempt to put an end to an unexpected garden pest - a burgeoning population of gnomes in the garden of a Lynton homeowner.

John Hoyles, a former mayor of Lynton and Lynmouth, claims to have no idea where the gnomes are coming from. While he admits to having introduced the first gnome to his front garden, since then nine further gnomes have appeared.

Mr Hoyles said: "I don't know where they come from and I never see anyone put them there. But in the morning when I get up there is another one out there."

In a sinister development, Mr Hoyles has also received a demand for a £20,000 payment from an anonymous source. He said: "They say if I don't pay up, the gnomes will get it."
North Devon Express
 Gnome hotline: 01271-347420

School's out
A Leeds parent has denounced her local council as having "something drastically wrong with the education department" after an official recommended that her 11-year-old son attend a non-existent school.

Unfortunately Benjamin Gott high school closed four years ago, and has since been demolished.

A fuming Mrs Averil Stevens said: "I've got a good mind to apply for that school and then see what they do."

The council said: "There was clearly an administrative error in this case."
Yorkshire Evening Post

Letter of the week
Your "mystery shopper" evidently hasn't been shopping in Ilfracombe for a few years, otherwise she would have known there is no branch of Woolworth's there. More's the pity.
Mrs T Chapple, Slade Valley Road, Ilfracombe

The Sawyer brothers - Nigel, 39, and Neil, 37 - had purchased two of the ostrich-like birds while their parents were on holiday. Unfortunately one of the rheas, Victor, was ill-at-ease in his new surroundings - despite the company of a peacock, two peahens, three dogs, a parrot, two cats, goldfish and a pot-bellied pig called OJ - and jumped over the gate. After a frantic chase on foot, Nigel Sawyer jumped into his car and managed to corner the bird in a cul-de-sac, where the pair overpowered the reluctant bird. Electrician Neil said: "Me and Nigel got a good kicking they have really powerful legs. webTitle: Spurs look bland without French dressing

fields.headline: Spurs look bland without French dressing
fields.trailText: Last year, David Ginola waltzed to both player of the year awards ahead of Beckham, Yorke, Keane and the rest of Manchester United's treble-winning team. Today he is picking up his P45.
fields.body:
Last year, David Ginola waltzed to both player of the year awards ahead of Beckham, Yorke, Keane and the rest of Manchester United's treble-winning team. Today he is picking up his P45.

That's some comedown. So it was hardly surprising that the man who was once Tottenham's totemic figure, the fulcrum of all their good attacking intentions, the player who made Spurs tick, sounded hurt and bewildered as he broke the news of his move to Villa on his website yesterday.

And all he got for his three years service was a terse statement from Sir Alan Sugar, saying: "When we sell first-team or senior players we do so because their services are no longer required. David Ginola has done a good job for the club but time moves on."

No wonder Spurs fans are angry. No wonder they are carping about their club's lack of ambition. One of the more measured responses came from the Spurs online fanzine The Yids: "Daveed, good luck and thanks. It's our loss, and Villa's gain." But other fans weren't so restrained, and again they are asking questions about Alan Sugar and George Graham.

And while the rest of the world probably considers it canny business to pocket £3m for a 33-year-old whose talents are fading, who doesn't track back, and who barely performs away from home, I'm not so sure.

For a start, Spurs without Ginola don't exactly ooze creativity or width. Anderton enjoys coming into the centre, and Leonhardsen is hardly the type of winger who can beat people on the outside. A lot now rests on Rebrov, and if the Ukrainian gets injured, expect Spurs to bludgeon and battle their way through teams rather than bewitch them with the beautiful game.

Another problem Graham faces is who will replace the French winger. As Fran Jones, a Spurs season-ticket holder, put it: "If we can bring in somebody like Boudewijn Zenden it will be OK, but at the moment Korsten's out for a month and Ethrington is raw as a cow's hide." With that in mind, surely Graham would have been smarter to keep Ginola onside for just one more year, while youngsters like Ethrington picked up more experience?

Spurs fans aren't even convinced of the economics of it all either, especially in today's inflated transfer market. "£3m for a 33-year-old may make good business sense - but does it make good football sense?" asks Rob Veling. "Where are we going to get another world-class left winger from at a reasonable price? Again, it's shows up Spurs' lack of ambition."

But the biggest problem Sugar and Graham face is that Ginola was a portent symbol of the way Tottenham Hotspur approach the game - the latest in a long line of White Hart Lane geniuses which includes the likes of White, Peters, Hoddle, Ardiles, Waddle and Gascoigne. Without him, free-flowing Tottenham have the defensive imprint of George Graham all over them.

Of course, a lot now depends on the next few weeks. If a world-class replacement is found - and there are rumours linking the club with Zenden - and Spurs make a strong start to the season, their fans will soon forgive the Tottenham board for letting Ginola go. But if the team struggles to break through the Ipswich defence on the opening day of the season, the fans will soon let Sugar - and Graham for that matter - know exactly what they think.

sean.ingle@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Three-ton Ramps, four-ton Bevan
fields.standfirst: This week we're departing from the norm. Thanks to unanswerable cases from two batsmen, both on the fringes of their national Test sides, Good Form, Bad Form becomes Good Form, Even Better Form. We're sure you'll understand why
fields.trailText: GOOD FORM
fields.body:
GOOD FORM

Mark Ramprakash Middlesex

Ramprakash has been dropped twice in the past month. First from the England team, then down the Middlesex order. No sooner was he restored to his favoured position at No. 4 for his county than he found the runs flowing again. Three Championship centuries in five innings - all at Southgate - suggest that England's strategy to open with him in the Tests was misplaced. And the runs haven't been easy either. The 101 against Worcestershire was made against Glenn McGrath, the 83 at Southgate v Glamorgan came out of a total of 164, while the twin centuries in the losing cause v Sussex made up 43.53% of Middlesex's aggregate. Ramps has reverted to what he loves being: a prolific middle-order batsman. Which is just what England need really.

At a glance

42; 101; 83 and 40; 20; 46; 8; 110* and 112

In detail

42 v Somerset, Southgate, NatWest, July 5
101 v Worcs, Southgate, Ch'ship Div 2, July 7-10
83 and 40 v Glam, Southgate, Ch'ship Div 2, July 12-15
20 v Durham, Southgate, NCL Div 2, July 16
46v Hants, Portsmouth, NCL Div 2, July 23
8 v Hants, Lord's, NatWest, July 25
110* and 112 v Sussex, Southgate, Ch'ship Div 2, July 28-31

First-class runs since July 5 446 at 111.50
One-day runs since July 5 116 at 29
All runs since July 5 562 at 70.25

EVEN BETTER FORM

Michael Bevan Sussex

The world's best one-day batsman is currently in the sort of purple patch that turns other purple patches green with envy. Since making a duck against Essex, Bevan has been unstoppable, belting four 150s in five first-class knocks, plus 89* in the National League win over his former county, Yorkshire. His 173* in the victory charge against Ramprakash's Middlesex made him the first man to pass 1000 Championship runs this season in either division. Bradman wouldn't have been satisfied with a tally of 783 in seven innings. He'd have been over the moon.

At a glance

0 and 151*; 89*; 166 and 174; 30 and 173*

In detail

0 and 151* v Essex, Arundel, Ch'ship Div 2, July 12-15
89* v Yorks, Arundel, NCL Div 2, July 16
166 and 174 v Notts, Ch'ship Div 2, July 19-22
30 and 173* v Middx, Ch'ship Div 2, July 28-31

Runs since July 12 783 at 195.75

Note First-class scores in bold, one-day scores in italics

fields.headline: Don't go, Mo
fields.standfirst: Chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour laments the way the talents of the government's most popular politician are being wasted at the Cabinet Office
fields.trailText: Chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour laments the way the talents of the government's most popular politician are being wasted at the Cabinet Office.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, the government's most popular minister, has landed herself - or has been landed - in hot water again.

She has admitted to the Mirror that she would like one day to go back to Northern Ireland to help integrate education in the province.

Most recognise that discrimination and prejudice start at birth. In the long term the only solution to ending the sectarianism which has plagued Northern Ireland will be integrated education, which will hopefully break down the rigid divisions between the Catholic and Protestant communities. Ms Mowlam would like to play a role in encouraging such a transformation.

But her wistful remark that she might like to devote herself to this task once she leaves government has been taken as a signal that she plans to leave the government after the election. Downing Street today hotly denied that the Cabinet Office minister intended to quit.

It is possible that Ms Mowlam gave that indication off the record to her interviewer. It is possible that she feels the reporter has put two and two together and made a little more than five.

It is possible it was a cry for help. Whatever the explanation, the attention is back on Ms Molwam as a personality and on her apparent unstable grip on office. The interview has fuelled doubts about her commitment to Tony Blair's government, rumours which started when she was asked to leave the Northern Ireland Office to be replaced by Peter Mandelson.

In private, Ms Mowlam admits she needed a long adjustment to her new job as Cabinet Office minister. It is a strange brief. She has responsibility for the future of the civil service, the machinery of government, drugs coordination and GM technology.

It is a mixed bag, to which was added social exclusion by Mr Blair when he tried to persuade her to take the brief and wrench herself away from Northern Ireland.

It sounds like a massive and demanding portfolio. But in fact Ms Mowlam's is not really in charge of these areas. Her role is all responsibility and no power. She wears the epaulettes, but does not carry much ammunition.

In reality, the government's policy on drugs is run by the Home Office, the police and the drugs tsar, Keith Halliwell. GM technology is largely the responsibility of science minister Lord Sainsbury and the Department of Environment. Mr Blair takes a close interest in the machinery of government and has strengthened its control from Downing Street. The Treasury sets the individual departmental targets. Social exclusion is the responsibility of almost every government department, from environment to social security - and ultimately the Treasury.

It leaves Ms Mowlam with a lot to coordinate, but precious little to enforce, let alone decide. She might increase her influence if she possessed the kind of mind that becomes enlivened by detail, numbers and policy options. But she does not.

She has huge social charm, an acute political brain, and understands people better than anyone else in government. Doubtless, she can and does use her charm to reduce interdepartmental turf wars. She is not one of nature's policy wonks.

As a result, she is probably in the wrong post and deserves another brief. Ms Mowlam and Mr Mandelson have spoken little since he took on the post; the smallest pleasantries seem too much for them. But perhaps after the election, Mr Mandelson will move to higher office, and she can return to Northern Ireland.

The tragedy would be that if she is lost to politics altogether. There are too few humans - and too few women - in government for politics to lose her.

webTitle: Cronje enlists services of Max Clifford

fields.headline: Cronje enlists services of Max Clifford
fields.standfirst: Our day-by-day diary of the scandal that shocked the cricket world
fields.trailText:
Saturday July 1
CBI officials question Ali Irani, former physiotherapist of the Indian cricket team, for over three hours. This follows an alleged videotaped conversation between Irani and Manoj Prabhakar regarding match-fixing.
fields.body:
Saturday July 1
CBI officials question Ali Irani, former physiotherapist of the Indian cricket team, for over three hours. This follows an alleged videotaped conversation between Irani and Manoj Prabhakar regarding match-fixing.

Ali Bacher says that he has passed "credible information" to the ICC that Pakistan's matches against India and Bangladesh in the 1999 World Cup were fixed.

Sunday July 2
The Sunday Telegraph reports that Hansie Cronje is looking for a lucrative publishing deal to give his version of his demise. Clive Rice, the Nottinghamshire coach and former South African all-rounder, is to broker a book deal with a British publisher.

In the News of the World Cronje is said to have recruited Max Clifford, the PR guru, in an attempt to improve his image.

Monday July 3
A court in New Delhi issues a warrant for the arrest of Sanjay Chawla, the Indian bookmaker who is alleged to have instigated much of Cronje's wrongdoing.

Mohammad Nasir, the manager of the Pakistan team currently touring Sri Lanka, blames India for the current match-fixing scandal. "All the bookies are from India," he says. "They are the ones who are bringing the bad name to the game."

The South Africans arrive in Sri Lanka for their first tour since the allegations broke. New captain Shaun Pollock rejects suggestions that the scandal will affect his team.

Tuesday July 4
In New Delhi Manoj Prabhakar is questioned for nearly three hours by the special crime branch of the CBI. He is questioned about videotapes he submitted to the agency with conversations about match-fixing between players and administrators.

Wednesday July 5
Ricky Ponting reveals that he was approached by a bookmaker three years ago. He says that he immediately informed ACB officials and "that was as far as it went." When asked if the bookmaker was Indian, Ponting shakes his head.

The CBI plan to question former Indian captain and TV commentator Ravi Shastri. Shastri had corroborated Manoj Prabhakar's claim that Kapil Dev attempted to bribe him to underperform in a Singer Cup match in 1994.

Thursday July 6
Director of Operations Yawar Saeed says that the Pakistan Cricket Board is waiting to receive an ICC report on umpire Javed Akhtar, who was accused by Ali Bacher of match-fixing. "When Akhtar officiated in the Leeds Test in 1998, he was representing the ICC and we can only hold an inquiry if we get the match referee's report from that particular Test. There is nothing against Akhtar and since he is a Pakistani, we have to clear the matter," says Saeed.

Friday July 7
The Board of Control for Cricket in India fax a letter of complaint to the PCB's Yawer Saeed, in response to comments from Mohammad Nasir, the manager of the Pakistan team in Sri Lanka. Nasir had blamed India and Indian bookmakers for the current match-fixing scandal.

Saturday July 8
PCB chairman Tauqir Zia phones Mohammad Nasir to express his "unhappiness, anger and disappointment" over Nasir's remarks.

Nasir accuses the BCCI of overreacting: "Doesn't everybody know that there are numerous bookies in India? What is the need to overreact like this? After all, isn't India the place where Cronje's conversations were recorded and the whole Pandora's box was opened?"

Sunday July 9
Rashid Latif is reported in The Sunday Telegraph as saying that he rejected an offer of £15,000 to ensure his side were dismissed for under 300 in the first innings of the Lord's Test of 1996. Latif was unbeaten at the close of the first day, when he received the proposition, with his side 290-9. They made 340. He also asserts his belief that England's last game in Sharjah before the 1999 World Cup was fixed. It was England's only victory of the tournament, in which they dismissed Pakistan for 144.

Sunday July 9
Syed Kirmani, the former Indian wicket-keeper, says that various match-fixing enquiries are taking too long. "They should see that the entire muck is cleaned and the sooner the better," he says.

Satirical playwright Aldrin Naidu begins auditions for an actor to play Hansie Cronje in his play "Vak-Hansie." Naidu says his play "will lampoon the underworld of cricket."

Monday July 10
The Guardian reports that Hansie Cronje is to be invited as an unpaid guest lecturer in sports ethics at Pretoria University. A spokeswoman says that "Mr Cronje could, as a community service, share his experience of temptation and corruption with students."

Wednesday July 12
Salim Malik says that he is "fed up" with match-fixing allegations against him. He demands that the PCB take action against Rashid Latif for his "immature and childish" statements, which are "destroying" him. Latif had told The Sunday Telegraph that Malik offered him 100,000 rupees to throw a one-day match in Christchurch in December 1995.

Kapil Dev meets Indian Sports Minister S S Dhindsa in New Delhi. The Indian coach urges Dhindsa to bring the match-fixing probe to its "logical conclusion" as quickly as possible, saying that the delay was troubling his players.

Thursday July 13
Christopher Doig, chief executive of the New Zealand Cricket Board, reveals plans to prepare players to handle approaches from "disreputable people."

Friday July 14
KC Mittal, an Indian government prosecutor involved in the Cronje case, is given special police protection after receiving death threats. After receiving a call saying he would be attacked in his chamber, Mittal is under 24-hour guard.

Steve Waugh calls for next month's Australia-South Africa ODI series to act as a fresh start for the game: "I think people want some positive stuff out of cricket - they are always talking about bookmakers and bribery and have associated that with cricket."

In a minor demonstration in Calcutta cricket fans praise Cronje's honesty. Up to 200 fans shout "Hansie, we hate your actions but praise your confessions" outside Eden Gardens. They also castigate "Indian culprits" who put forward "false and fabricated counter-allegations."

Saturday July 15
General Tauqir Zia, chairman of the PCB, again criticises Mohammad Nasir, manager of the Pakistan team in Sri Lanka, for blaming India for the current match-fixing scandal. "It was not in his domain to comment on India's state of affairs. They have conducted a judicial investigation and Pakistan accepts it", says Zia.

Sunday July 16
Hansie Cronje tells Channel 9's Sixty Minutes that Shane Warne and Mark Waugh were guilty of the same offence as him. "They basically confessed to taking money from bookmakers...and it's exactly what I did in a lot of my dealings and it is wrong."

Cronje also reveals that he considered suicide. "I honestly struggled to eat and sleep...I could not find a building high enough to jump from but I really felt bad about what I did and I supposed that was the chicken way of getting away with it, to kill yourself."

Ajay Jadeja is questioned by the CBI's Special Crime Branch for over two hours. He denies any match-fixing links.

Monday July 17
The BCCI drafts a code of conduct, under which any cricketer or umpire found guilty of match-fixing will be banned for life.

Tuesday July 18
The ACB hosts an anti-corruption meeting in Melbourne. "If we can find common ground to fight the problem, that will benefit all sports, not just cricket," says ACB chief executive Malcolm Speed.

Wednesday July 19
Hansie Cronje puts off a planned visit to Britain, fearing extradition by Indian police. Cronje was due to have discussions with Max Clifford.

London publishers Collins Willow have apparently asked for a synopsis from Cronje, detailing any revelations he plans to come out with in his book. Cronje is said to have asked for a £250,000 advance.

A PCB meeting decides that all its players should sign an undertaking that they will not take part in any match-fixing or gambling.

Thursday July 20
Indian income-tax officials raid the homes of various players and officials across the country, including Mohammad Azharuddin and Kapil Dev. "We are looking for wealth or assets which have not been disclosed," said K.V.M. Pai, chief commissioner for income tax in Bombay.

Thursday July 20
Former ICC President Jagmohan Dalmiya warns against a witch hunt following the tax raids in India. "If the raids are part of an effort to cleanse cricket, then I welcome it wholeheartedly. But if it means witch hunting, then it is very regettable."

Friday July 21
The income-tax raids are completed in India. Officials say that they have evidence of undisclosed income against Mohammad Azharuddin, Ajay Jadeja and Kapil Dev. They are also said to have made findings implicating a number of bookmakers.

Manoj Prabhakar welcomes the raids as an attempt to "sincerely clean the system" and says that he has "nothing to hide. Nothing to declare."

Indian Sports Minister SS Dhindsa warns the BCCI that they "should not think that the government cannot interfere in its working even if it commits mistakes."

The King Commission is to resume on October 2, it is announced in South Africa. An interim report will be submitted to president Thabo Mbeki on August 11.

Saturday July 22
Dhananjaya Kumar, Indian Minister of State for Finance, reveals "cogent evidence to prove the nexus in match-fixing for amassing this kind of wealth." He says it will take two months to complete proceedings.

fields.headline: When loyalty breeds contempt
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Simon Rogers: View from here
fields.body:
I come from a Guardian house. My parents have read the Guardian six days a week - resting only on Sundays to pick up the Observer - for at least 20 years. It's always been a loyalty based on familiarity and the feeling that ownership of their paper is worth more than the money paid for it.

At first glance, net users seem the exact opposite. It's the rule of publishing online: users are promiscuous. If they can't find what they want with you, they'll look elsewhere. And, unlike newspapers, it's spectacularly easy to do that - they're only one click away from the opposition. So, if you can't get them to come back regularly, the chances are that someone else will. It takes quite a lot to get someone to change their daily paper. It only takes one missed story or a slow download to get fed up with a favourite site.

That's down to the nature of the web. If ever there was a medium which instilled an "everything now" attitude, it's the internet. Justifiably, users get resentful if a site they've taken the trouble to go to has a page which is slow to download or is missing something they want. But, just as cars encourage people to cram more journeys into their day, the faster the net, the more people want - immediately.

Size matters, too. A research paper published last week by searchenginewatch.com, a Dakota-based site, found that the web is around 500 times larger than the maps provided by the best and most popular search engines. There are now more than 550bn documents stored on the web. Incidentally, that is also the best indication of the growth of the web - Lycos only indexed 54,000 pages in mid-1994.

According to the report, all the net search engines combined only index about 1bn pages, which means that if you're a user looking for a very specific page, you're increasingly likely to go to a bookmarked site where you know you're most likely to find what you want. So, creating a site where users feel comfortably at home is vital.

That feeling of being at home was reflected in a strange phone conversation I had recently. The call was from a user asking permission to alter the topic of a talk thread on our site.

This was strange only because the talk areas are the one part of our site where users are most in charge. They control the context and the conversations within certain limits, ie no racism, sexism, homophobia or abuse. Simply working on a site gives you no more power than the average user - and you become a party host, rather than a performer. And any power that exists in the ability to delete or alter a conversation is tempered by the fact that if there's one thing that annoys the hell out of net users it's the idea of censorship. Maybe it's just plain easier than writing a letter - while the Guardian newspaper receives about 1,000 letters a week, the Guardian Unlimited site talkboards get more than 10,000 postings.

And that self-policing works. Just as you wouldn't walk into a party of like-minded people and shout abuse at them, talk users generally don't, either. Who wants to be embarrassed in front of people you're trying to impress?

It's a strange sort of ownership that the web brings. When home secretary Jack Straw went online for an hour, we had more than 500 questions, many from people who would be too embarrassed to stand up and ask something at a public meeting. But, because users had mailed their questions in, they expected them to be answered - with none of the cynicism that might be expected from the net generation, they displayed a touching faith in the simple democracy of the medium. If you bother to send in a message, then someone has to reply, don't they?

However, there's a big difference between knowing who makes up your audience and wildly aiming a site at a pre-existing community and hoping you can get it online.

A survey I like quoting comes from California research firm Cheskin Research, which looked at the burgeoning numbers of Hispanic Americans going online. Now the marketing people who come up with dodgy business plans would probably have us believe that Hispanic Americans want their own sites and special portals such as Quepasa.com.

But the report found that, actually, Hispanic users are just like everyone else. They would rather use the big-name sites such as Yahoo! or Alta Vista to find specific things, such as movies or news.

Which just illustrates the madness of trying to create sites that appeal to a particular community. Why, for example, would a woman go to a specific women's site rather than a site where she could just get what she wanted?

People hate being told what they want to do, after all.

 Simon Rogers is deputy editor of Guardian Unlimited

fields.headline: Ehud Barak
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Israel's embattled prime minister
fields.trailText: All you need to know about Israel's embattled prime minister.
fields.body:
1. Yesterday was the hottest day in Jerusalem for 122 years. But the political temperature is rising too. There are two crucial votes today in the Knesset, Israel's parliament, and the fragile government headed by prime minister Ehud Barak depends on the outcome.

2. In the first vote, Shimon Peres, a Barak ally, former prime minister and the wily old fox of Israeli politics, was expected to become the eighth president of the state, a largely ceremonial role. But outsider Moshe Katsav was elected instead in a result which took everyone by surprise.

3. The second vote, on a motion of no confidence in the government, is much more problematic. It could lead to the fall of the "soldier-prime minister", whose fragile coalition commands just 42 votes out of 120 in the Knesset.

4. The main issue, as ever, is security. The Israeli right was shocked by the concessions Barak offered during this month's Camp David summit with Palestinian president Yasser Arafat, including a measure of shared sovereignty in Jerusalem, and the abandonment of at least some Jewish settlements on the occupied West Bank.

5. David Levy, the perpetually petulant foreign minister, has threatened to resign unless Barak broadens his government to include the rightwing Likud faction.

6. Groomed for high office by Yitzhak Rabin, the prime minister who was assassinated for making peace with the Palestinians, Barak is a former army chief who believes passionately in the peace process, but is equally passionate about the security of the state. Indeed, nobody is quite sure whether he is a hawk or a dove.

7. In his military days, Barak was something of an action man. He is also fond of music and chess.

8. Barak became prime minister in May last year, on a promise of reinvigorating the peace process, which had stagnated under the three-year prime ministership of hardline Likudnik Binyamin Netanyahu. "Bibi", as he is universally known, is now manoeuvring to make a comeback.

9. In Israel's fiendishly complex political system, the prime minister is directly elected at the same time as the Knesset, and is always doomed to command a minority of deputies. How it works is something of a mystery, even to insiders.

10. Politics is the nation's favourite sport. Israel is probably the only country in the world where hourly news bulletins are relayed on bus radios, and listened to with rapt attention by passengers. Newspapers like the rightwing Jerusalem Post and the liberal Ha'aretz daily also thrive on politics, as does the splendid fortnightly news magazine Jerusalem Report.

fields.headline: Bruce Douglas-Mann
fields.standfirst: 'Exemplary man in politics': Labour MP who crossed the floor to the Social Democrats
fields.trailText: 'Exemplary man in politics': Labour MP who crossed the floor to the Social Democrats.
fields.body:
Bruce Douglas-Mann, who has died aged 73, was, as both lawyer and MP, a startling combination of a tough, super-competent man of business and a disinterested idealist.

The last time I saw him was a month ago at an open air opera performance in Holland Park: he had had a delightful evening, captivated by Mascagni's L'Amico Fritz. Although he had suffered from cancer of the throat, he had continued valiantly in his formidable practice as a solicitor. This stubborn resolution was entirely in character. The old doorstep moan, "Politicians? They're all in it for what they can get out of it!" never applied to him.

Bruce Douglas-Mann was the son of another solicitor, Leslie Douglas-Mann. He was educated at the Upper Canada School in Toronto and - after national service as a leading seaman in the navy - at Jesus College, Oxford 1948-51.

He became a solicitor in 1954, and married Helen Tucker in 1955. For Labour, he unsuccessfully contested St Albans, 1964, Maldon, 1966 and was a councillor in Kensington and Chelsea 1962-68, before being elected at North Kensington in 1970. He was Labour's MP for Mitcham and Morden from 1974-82, and for the Social Democrats from January-May 1982.

Had he chosen to apply his lucid grasp of finance and his unfoxable resolution in negotiations to the pursuit of money in those areas of the law profitable for that sort of thing, he could have strung millions on a thread. He chose instead to be a trade union lawyer, superbly on top of industrial accident and injury legislation and case law, a specialist in everything relating to housing and (a later development which amused him) in obscenity. Bruce briefed the barrister, John Mortimer, in the case over the film, Last Tango in Paris: that, together with the cases against D H Lawrence's Lady Chatterley's Lover, and the magazine Oz, sent the censor into muttering retreat.

But he was happiest as solicitor to injured workmen. In any struggle with the solicitors of a company's insurers, to which he would be directed by a union (for an action nominally between victim and company), he was patient, and quite implacable. He was the first solicitor, in a period of mounting inflation, to have damages proofed against the retail price index, and he refused any solution which might diminish the client's settlement, persuading union and client that proper damages were won by meticulous trench warfare.

He was always up to the last supplementary date on Kemp & Kemp, the ever-adjusted bible of personal injury tariffs, and ready to stare out the opposition to the gates of the court; he set himself to grind the faces of the insurers. I was his inept clerk for 18 months and saw him in action, burning up vast amounts of work without fuss during a long day which usually ended with housing association or council or candidate's constituency work; he inspired admiration, and we started a friendship which lasted until his death.

His chief weakness as a lawyer was that he had no great powers of advocacy. He was diffident, unflashy, but not fluent, and he never enjoyed court. And this carried over into his political career. He knew more about housing than all but a couple of MPs. He had worked strenuously with housing associations and knew inside-out the renting and enforcing hell hole of North Kensington. But politically, he was a first-rate product which never advertised. So though he had been elected for North Kensington in 1970, he was made minister of state for housing only in 1974.

He was a hesitant, apologetic speaker but he knew the subject backwards. He served as chairman of the parliamentary party's housing and construction group throughout the second Wilson and Callaghan governments. When Norman St John-Stevas introduced select committees, he served as vice chairman of the one on the environment which took in housing.

He could be a dangerous backbencher, and the famous George Cunningham amendment, which effectively blocked Scottish devolution in the late 70s, was an adaptation of his earlier work.

The end of Douglas-Mann's political career was at one with his stubbornness and idealism. Depressed by the state into which the Labour party had got itself by the time of the Tony Benn challenge to Denis Healey for the deputy leadership, on the last day of the Brighton conference he brought back to his Sussex home for lunch the MPs John Grant and George Cunningham, and myself. Over a long, dark, edge-of-the-cliff conversation he was almost ready to join the others in signing up with the emerging Social Democrats. However, the SDP were overwhelmingly pro-European and Bruce had his reservations on that subject.

He did cross the floor in January 1982, but insisted (to the acute embarrassment of his new leaders) that he must renew his mandate from the voters of Mitcham and Morden, who had elected him on the Labour ticket. The SDP should have done this out of self-interest on its own early high tide. But it was Bruce's bad luck to make this stand of principle at the time of Margaret Thatcher's triumphalism over the Falklands. He lost to Angela Rumbold and was much smirked over. He fought the general election of 1983, but gave up parliamentary ambitions, though he continued in SDP, then Liberal Democratic, politics.

A well read man, an admirer of Bernard Shaw and Thomas Hardy, he served for 16 years from 1981 on the Arts Council committee for special funds, was an active member of Shelter (on its board since 1974) and was, above all, still the senior partner in the firm which he had founded.

He was very fond of sailing and as a young man had been close to selection for the British Olympic canoeing team.

Happy in marriage to Helen, who survives him with one son and a daughter, he overcame his vicissitudes by doing the worthwhile, interesting things he had always done. He was an exemplary man in politics and if he was not given the scope to use those talents, the loss was to government.

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.standfirst: Christopher Walken says no to Star Wars, MPA says Bacon in colour is too much, South Korea rejects North Korean cinema, and Sean Penn takes on the Vikings
fields.trailText: Christopher Walken says no to Star Wars, MPA says Bacon in colour is too much, South Korea rejects North Korean cinema, and Sean Penn takes on the Vikings
fields.body:
 Christopher Walken has denied widespread reports that he's to star, as Sith lord Darth Bane, in the new Star Wars movie. "People have been telling me for six months and really it's very interesting. I even asked. I said maybe I am in it and they're just saving it for a surprise. But I'm not in that movie. Never was. I don't know how that happened. Maybe somebody put it on the internet. I tell you frankly that the only place I've ever heard that is by way of rumour."

 The Motion Picture Association of America - the US's censors - has vetoed the use of a colour photograph of Kevin Bacon to market his new film, but allowed instead the publication of its black-and-white counterpart. The picture, from the imminent release Hollow Man, shows Bacon without skin. The newspaper USA Today tried to pin MPAA president Jack Valenti down on which rule the colour image transcended. But, says Valenti, "when I started here, I threw out the book on do's and don'ts. These are subjective decisions." Well, that's cleared that up then.

 At a time of unprecedented rapprochement between the hitherto hostile North and South Korean, a North Korean version of Godzilla has failed to further salve the decades-long rupture between the two states. Pulgasari ('Starfish') was released last week in South Korea - the first film from the communist North to exhibit across the border. But the movie attracted only 1,000 people during its first week, five-cinema run. "My children are not interested," one father was reported as saying, and it's hardly a surprise: South Korean audiences are used to Hollywood fare. The country had allowed a local distributor to screen Pulgasari as part of a drive to foster cultural links with the North.

 Sean Penn is at work on a film based on legendary Irish chieftain Brian Boru. Casting for the movie is reported to be underway in LA. Boru is remembered principally as the warrior who ejected the Vikings from Ireland.

fields.headline: The role of Israel's president
fields.trailText: Moshe Katzav, a former transport minister from the rightwing Likud party, today beat Nobel peace laureate and former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres to become the country's new president.
fields.body:
Moshe Katzav, a former transport minister from the rightwing Likud party, today beat Nobel peace laureate and former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres to become the country's new president.

Mr Katzav is Israel's eighth president. He succeeds Ezer Weizman.

The job is largely ceremonial, although some presidents have used it as a platform for mobilising public support for everything from peace moves to preventing traffic accidents.

The president serves a seven-year term and cannot be re-elected.

Parliament elects a president at a special session. The successful candidate must be elected by at least 61 politicians in the 120-seat parliament. If no candidate receives 61 votes in the first round, then more rounds are held until a candidate receives the required majority.

If more than three rounds are held, then the candidate who receives the lowest number of votes in each round is disqualified.

The president is the head of state and represents the state of Israel abroad and at home.

The president's most important function is the ability to grant pardons and reduce the sentences of convicted criminals.

He or she also receives diplomatic credentials, swears in judges and signs laws.

webTitle: Blow for Barak as Likud man wins presidency

fields.headline: Blow for Barak as Likud man wins presidency
fields.standfirst: Moshe Katsav profiled
fields.trailText: A relatively obscure member of the opposition Likud party today was elected president of Israel, humiliating the much better-known Shimon Peres, a former prime minister and Nobel peace prize laureate.
fields.body:
A relatively obscure member of the opposition Likud party today was elected president of Israel, humiliating the much better-known Shimon Peres, a former prime minister and Nobel peace prize laureate.

Moshe Katsav's surprise victory marked an ignominious end to Mr Peres' political career and dealt another blow to prime minister Ehud Barak in his quest for a peace with the Palestinians.

Mr Katsav is one of the leading members of the rightist Likud party, which has taken a harder line than Mr Barak in peace talks with the Palestinians. Mr Barak had backed Peres in the presidential election.

The presidency is largely ceremonial, but the incumbent, Ezer Weizman, used the prestige of the post in support of Middle East peace. Mr Peres, who led Israel to negotiations with the Palestinians in 1993, had been expected to turn the presidency into a platform for the latest peace efforts.

Mr Katsav started his career as Israel's youngest mayor in the 1969, when he was 24. He was elected to the parliament in 1977 and rose to tourism minister and deputy prime minister. Born in Iran, he presented himself as the representative of Israelis of Middle East origin.

Mr Katsav won 63-57 in a second round of voting in Israel's 120-member parliament. In the first round, neither candidate received the required 61 votes. Mr Peres had counted on the support of many of the 22 religious lawmakers. When he was prime minister, his governments were consistently generous to the ultra-Orthodox, a chronically impoverished sector of Israel's society; in addition, Mr Peres' wife, Sonya, is herself Orthodox.

But the ultra-Orthodox are more in line with the Likud's foreign policy in recent years, and many see Mr Katsav - who himself is religiously observant - as the more sympathetic candidate.

Mr Peres has held nearly all of Israel's top jobs over the years, but also lost four out of five elections for prime minister. He served as prime minister three times, twice succeeding his longtime political rival, Yitzhak Rabin, and once in a rotation agreement after a deadlocked election. In 1993, Mr Peres was the driving force behind Israel's breakthrough agreement of mutual recognition with the PLO, and he negotiated subsequent interim peace agreements. But today's defeat will cement Mr Peres' reputation as a perennial also-ran in Israeli politics.

Later today, Ehud Barak faces a no-confidence vote after accusations that he had been prepared to make too many concessions in the failed Camp David talks.

The Knesset was due to start debating the no-confidence motion as soon as it had chosen Israel's new president.

No-confidence votes are becoming a way of life for Mr Barak, who survived a similar vote just before the Camp David summit. He is widely expected to win today's vote despite losing three parties from his coalition.

If he survives, Mr, Barak will win a three-month reprieve to pursue a peace process that has angered the right and members of his cabinet.

The talks have a target date of September 13 to reach a final deal that would resolve the issues of borders, Palestinian refugees, Jewish settlers and - the most difficult of all - the status of Jerusalem.
