webTitle: Prisoner loses court fight to father a baby

fields.headline: Prisoner loses court fight to father a baby
fields.trailText: A jailed murderer today lost a high court battle for the legal right to donate sperm for his wife to become pregnant by artificial insemination.
fields.body:
A jailed murderer today lost a high court battle for the legal right to donate sperm for his wife to become pregnant by artificial insemination.

The bid by Gavin Mellor, 29, was resisted by the home secretary, Jack Straw, whose lawyers argued a ruling in the prisoner's favour could lead to others, including child abusers, claiming the right to father children.

Mr Justice Forbes, sitting in London, ruled Mr Straw's decision not to allow Mellor to donate sperm was rational and reasonable.

Mellor had met his wife while he was in prison and the judge said: "It was reasonable for the secretary of state to take into account the fact that Mr and Mrs Mellor's relationship has not been tested in normal conditions, and that its durability is thus uncertain."

In the first case of its kind, David Pannick QC, appearing for Mellor, had argued the home office decision to deny the prisoner's request was "unjustifiably paternalistic".

He said: "The home secretary has many onerous responsibilities, but whether Mr and Mrs Mellor should bring a child into the world is a matter for them and not him."

Mellor was given a mandatory life sentence in February 1995 for the killing of 71-year-old grandfather George Sims. He had been attacked as he walked home from a working men's club in Crewe, Cheshire.

He met his wife, Tracey McColl, 25, while she was working as an administration officer at Gartree Prison in Leicestershire in January 1997.

They fell in love and Ms McColl later told a newspaper how she and Mellor, now at Nottingham Prison and the father of a child from a previous relationship, had regularly made love during their courtship in jail.

Ms McColl resigned from the prison service so the couple could marry in July 1997.

The judge said that, given the age of Mrs Mellor, the evidence about the couple's health and dates for temporary leave and the expiry of Mellor's tariff in 2006, there was no reason to believe that the refusal of artificial insemination would prevent them having a child.

Should problems develop, the matter would then be reconsidered.

Mr Pannick had argued the home office's approach meant "a substantial detriment to Mrs Mellor, who undoubtedly retains all of her civil rights".

Mellor had written to the prison authorities claiming a right to have a child under Article 12 of the European convention on human rights, which guaranteed the right to found a family.

Mr Pannick had told the judge: "To deny the prisoner the right to participate in the artificial insemination of his wife is no more lawful than to deny him the right to receive any other medical treatment."

But Ms Dinah Rose, for the home secretary, said part of the punishment involved in imprisonment was the loss of freedom to associate with family members.

fields.headline: Israel's new president: Moshe Katsav
fields.trailText: Moshe Katsav, who today became Israel's new president, is the first Israeli of truly humble origins to hold the country's highest office.
fields.body:
Moshe Katsav, who today became Israel's new president, is the first Israeli of truly humble origins to hold the country's highest office.

Mr Katsav, 55, confounded all the pundits by defeating the better-known Shimon Peres, a former prime minister and a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, in secret balloting in the Israeli parliament, the Knesset.

Born in Iran, Mr Katsav is the first president to represent the "second Israel," the wave of Sephardic Jews from Arab and Islamic countries who immigrated in the early years of the state and formed the bulk of the country's underprivileged.

Mr Katsav's family lived in one of the rudimentary "transit camps" which were set up for immigrants after the 1948 war. He grew up in Kiryat Malachi, one of the new towns on Israel's periphery which were populated mainly by immigrants and plagued by unemployment, social problems and government neglect.

In his election campaign, he denied he was an "ethnic" candidate and said his aim was to heal rifts between Israelis of all origins and political or religious views. But he stressed that he was proud call Kiryat Malachi home.

His supporters said it was time the country had a president who did not come from the European, or Ashkenazi, elite. An earlier president, Yitzhak Navon, was Sephardic but was perceived as belonging to the Ashkenazi establishment. Mr Katsav's achievements are modest when compared with those of Mr Peres, a statesman who played a major role in the creation of Israel's military power, including its nuclear deterrent. Mr Peres was also an architect of the Oslo agreement with the Palestinians.

Public opinion was overwhelmingly behind Mr Peres in the presidential race. But in Israel, the president is elected by the 120 members of parliament, and the Knesset, with its political infighting, has often been at odds with the popular will.

Mr Katsav began his public career at the age of 24, when he was elected mayor of Kiryat Malachi. He was the youngest mayor in the country.

He was elected to parliament in 1977 for the rightwing Likud party and served in a number of cabinet posts after the Likud came to power. The most senior position he held was that of transport minister.

Mr Katsav has vowed that unlike his predecessor, Ezer Weizman, a supporter of the peace process, he will eschew politics and concentrate on trying to forge unity between left and rightwing Israelis, between Ashkenazi and Sephardic Jews, between religious and secular Jews and between Jews and Arabs.

Like the rest of his Likud party, Mr Katsav saw the Oslo accord as a mistake and a tragedy for Israel.

Mr Katsav began his public career at the age of 24, when he was elected mayor of Kiryat Malachi. He was the youngest mayor in the country. He was elected to parliament in 1977 for the rightwing Likud party and served in a number of cabinet posts after the Likud came to power. The most senior position he held was that of transport minister. Mr Katsav has vowed that unlike his predecessor, Ezer Weizman, a supporter of the peace process, he will eschew politics and concentrate on trying to forge unity between left and rightwing Israelis, between Ashkenazi and Sephardic Jews, between religious and secular Jews and between Jews and Arabs. Like the rest of his Likud party, Mr Katsav saw the Oslo accord as a mistake and a tragedy for Israel.

webTitle: Super Mario KOs Brown in identity stakes

fields.headline: Super Mario KOs Brown in identity stakes
fields.trailText: Video game star Super Mario is four-times more recognisable to young people than Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown, a survey revealed today.
fields.body:
Video game star Super Mario is four-times more recognisable to young people than Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown, a survey revealed today.

The character from the Donkey Kong games was correctly spotted by 96% of 16 to 21-year-olds, while only 24% identified the politician.

Prime Minister Tony Blair fared better in the poll for online retailer Amazon.co.uk after being spotted by 91%, although he was 2% behind Pokemon character Pikachu.

The firm asked 560 people to identify politicians and video game stars to tie in with the launch of its new PC and games store. Lara Croft, the heroine of the Tomb Raider games, was spotted by 80% of those surveyed while the least recognised on 67% was Donkey Kong itself, although that was still 25% higher than any Cabinet member other than Mr Blair.

Foreign Secretary Robin Cook was known by 42% while Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson was spotted by just 18%. Under a third of the young people (29%) said Mr Blair was not important to their lives.

Open University psychologist Adam Joinson said: "The survey findings show just how relevant video games are to the majority of UK teenagers - they also demonstrate how new technology is blurring our notions of celebrity and fame. Games characters are now icons in their own right."

fields.headline: Stone conspires another presidential plot
fields.trailText: Oliver Stone is adapting another political conspiracy for the screen. The JFK and Nixon director is at work on a screenplay about a plot by rich Republicans to oust President Franklin Roosevelt in 1933
fields.body:
Oliver Stone (pictured) is adapting another political conspiracy for the screen. New York's Daily News reports that the JFK and Nixon director is at work on a screenplay about a plot by rich Republicans to oust President Franklin Roosevelt in 1933.

"The coup d'etat planned against President Roosevelt," writes Stone in a new book about his paranoid perspectives on history, "has amazingly disappeared from the history books. You don't have to wonder why when you understand the power of the conspirators or the incredible ability of the media, which were then as now basically controlled by the establishment of this country, to vaporize the incident into the black hole of ridicule."

The conspiracy allegedly involved a group of wealthy fat cats seeking to pay angry war veterans to march on Capitol Hill and oust the President from office. After a superficial investigation - the like of which Stone-watchers may recognise from JFK - a committee concluded that there wasn't enough evidence to support the charges. "The incident was buried," Stone concludes, "largely because Roosevelt himself was weathering a major storm and feared a revolution if these events were revealed."

webTitle: Venice festival scales down Hollywood fare

fields.headline: Venice festival scales down Hollywood fare
fields.trailText: The line-up for the Venice Film Festival 2000 has been announced, and - like Cannes before it - it features a scaled-down Hollywood presence and a focus on Asian as well as European cinema
fields.body:
The line-up for the Venice Film Festival 2000 has been announced, and - like Cannes before it - it features a scaled-down Hollywood presence and a focus on Asian as well as European cinema. Only two American films feature in competition: former Golden Lion-winner Robert Altman's Dr T and the Women (pictured), starring Richard Gere, and Julian Schnabel's Before Night Falls.

Britain will be represented by Stephen Frears' Liam (more poverty in Ireland, to be sure) and by Sally Potter's Johnny Depp-starring 1930s melodrama The Man Who Cried. Depp, with co-stars Christina Ricci and Cate Blanchett, is expected to attend the festival.

Announcing the line-up for the 57th Venice Festival, director Alberto Barbera said, "This year's festival will be authoritative, luminous and carefree. Authoritative because of the number of important names and prestigious auteurs in the selection; luminous because of the presence of so many major stars, who have always played a significant role in the festival's success; and carefree because of the number of parties throughout the festival."

Barbera ascribed the absence of US films at the festival to a rethinking of marketing and distribution strategies in the internet era: Hollywood blockbusters now tend to be released in Europe much earlier after their American openings.

Other highlights on Venice's Lido include Tony Gatlif's Vengo; Raoul Ruiz's Fils de Deux Meres, starring Isabelle Huppert; Tom Tykwer's The Princess and the Warrior; and new films from Brit director Christopher Nolan and the Swedish wunderkind Lukas Moodyson. Venice will also see the European premieres of the likes of Woody Allen's Small Time Crooks and the Harrison Ford spooker What Lies Beneath.

 The festival opens on 30 August.

fields.headline: The outsiders
fields.standfirst: How do you teach English to asylum seekers and refugees?
fields.trailText: One of the biggest problems for the thousands of refugees and asylum seekers that come to Britain and Ireland every year is language. Many are from countries where English is neither spoken nor taught. However, success in their new lives - interviews for residence, social-service applications, housing - will depend on them speaking and writing English well. A priority, then, on arrival is to find classes and a good teacher.
fields.body:
One of the biggest problems for the thousands of refugees and asylum seekers that come to Britain and Ireland every year is language. Many are from countries where English is neither spoken nor taught. However, success in their new lives - interviews for residence, social-service applications, housing - will depend on them speaking and writing English well. A priority, then, on arrival is to find classes and a good teacher.

Teaching refugees or asylum seekers is one of the greatest challenges that a TEFL teacher can take on. It needs dedication, lots of patience and gives little or no financial reward. Yet, every year a large number of teachers ignore these difficulties and get involved, most by making contact with a local body that organises courses.

The quality of courses varies greatly. In the worst case scenario a teacher is given half a room, a large, poorly-graded class and paper to write on instead of a blackboard. In better-funded associations a teacher might expect to teach a well-balanced group in a comfortable classroom. Some organisations also provide 'outreach' programmes; here teachers visit the houses of refugees or asylum seekers to help them with their English on a one-to-one basis.

Anne is typical of many that teach in the sector. She works in a language school in the day with mainly Western European students, and then teaches asylum seekers as a volunteer in the evening. Asked about the contrast she shakes her head. They are, she says, "different worlds". Most importantly, her asylum-seeker classes tend to have students from far more varied backgrounds. A class that she is teaching now includes two Angolans, a Nigerian, two students from Zaire, four East Europeans (ethnic Russians from Lithuania and Estonia), two Algerians, a Palestinian and an Iranian. The professional background of students also varies greatly. One teacher I met taught a class that included farmers, soldiers, doctors, construction workers, university teachers and an ex-government minister.

This diversity causes problems at different levels. But most importantly it means that students are used to different styles of learning. Many refugees or asylum seekers have had poor or zero schooling. Others, especially from Eastern Europe, have a level of schooling that would put lots of Britons to shame. The first group favours a communicative approach with practical examples and role-plays. The second group demands systematic grammatical explanations. It can be very difficult to balance these needs.

Refugee or asylum-seeker classes also tend to have far more students with special requirements than normal language-school classes. Sometimes these requirements are physical: a war-crippled Bosnian, for example, who cannot climb a set of stairs to get into the classroom. Sometimes they are psychological, the result of a difficult past.

However, at other times these requirements relate specifically to language. For example, a student whose mother tongue is a Creole English that is almost unintelligible to a Briton, or another student who has never learnt to read, as her native language has no written form. Problems like these present real difficulties for teacher and student alike, and often the only way to deal with them is to spend extra time together before or after the lesson.

Given the spectrum of backgrounds and needs found in an immigrant class, conventional textbooks are almost useless. They can be mined for exercises. But as the basis for a course they are definitely lacking. (Articles on buying a car, throwing a party or going on a honeymoon can leave students cold and bewildered.) It is often left to the teacher to produce his or her own material.

So how do you go about designing a course? "I believe in teaching them what they tell me they need," says Sally from Dublin. In her view the student's experience should determine the syllabus. For example, students say that they have to look for housing, to deal with abuse or to apply for jobs. The teacher can then recreate these circumstances in class or find exercises that relate to them.

The average student responds very well to this approach, as his or her life is full of these kinds of problems. But, the word 'problems' points to another of the dimensions of working with refugees or asylum seekers. The teacher is often one of the few friendly figures in the life of a student that speaks English. As a result teachers can easily find themselves drawn into the refugee's world, writing letters to officialdom, visiting landlords and negotiating with the Social Services. It can be a rewarding, frustrating and extremely time-consuming experience.

Most institutions offer few guidelines about teaching asylum seekers or refugees. One unspoken rule is that teachers should not ask too much about the past. Many students have come from extremely difficult situations in their own country that they might not want to discuss in a lesson. There is also the added need to be sensitive about potential conflicts within the class. I once asked two Romanians to describe their homeland only to find that one belonged to Transylvania's long-suffering Hungarian minority. They seemed to be talking (or at times shouting) about two very different countries. These kinds of problems are especially acute when a teacher has students from different ethnic communities in the Balkans and Central Africa.

There are paid and voluntary jobs teaching asylum seekers and refugees. In Britain the Refugee Council or local education authorities and Learning and Skills Councils can all be contacted. In Ireland the main co-ordinator is the Irish Refugee Council. Even TEFL teachers based on the Continent can work in the sector. The high status of English there means that asylum seekers and refugees in Italy, France, Spain and other European countries are keen to learn English too.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the transfer talk forced off the track at the first bend
fields.trailText: Harry Redknapp has denied receiving a £16m bid from Barcelona for Rio Ferdinand - but the West Ham manager says he won't stand in Ferdinand's way if an offer is made. Redknapp said: "There are certain clubs - Barcelona, Juventus, Inter, people like that - who fire the imagination of all youngsters playing the game and you could never stand in anybody's way if they had the chance of going there. But I must say that I have had no contact whatsoever from anybody at Barcelona about Rio."
fields.body:
Harry Redknapp has denied receiving a £16m bid from Barcelona for Rio Ferdinand - but the West Ham manager says he won't stand in Ferdinand's way if an offer is made. Redknapp said: "There are certain clubs - Barcelona, Juventus, Inter, people like that - who fire the imagination of all youngsters playing the game and you could never stand in anybody's way if they had the chance of going there. But I must say that I have had no contact whatsoever from anybody at Barcelona about Rio."

However, Paulo Wanchope may be allowed to leave Upton Park - and he could be off to Celtic, reports Planet Football. "I need to let someone go to balance the books and Paulo is a possibility," admits Redknapp, "and Martin has tried to buy him before."

Another player who could be moving to Parkhead is Mark Bosnich. According to the Mirror, the United keeper will join Celtic in a 12-month loan deal later today.

Liverpool have accepted a £2.5m bid from Coventry for David Thompson, reports the Daily Express. Sky Blues boss Gordon Strachan will have talks with Thompson today, and he hopes to complete the deal in the next 48 hours.

Another Liverpool player possibly on the move is Dominic Matteo. The Sun reports that Blackburn manager Graeme Souness has offered £3m for the versatile defender - but the paper reckons he may have to increase his bid to £4m to get his man.

And Titi Camara could also be on his way out of Anfield. Manchester City have registered an interest, reports Teamtalk - but they think Joe Royle won't be able to afford his £30,000-a-week wages.

But it's not all bad news, Liverpool fans - at least Christian Ziege looks like he's on his way. Bryan Robson will make a last ditch attempt to persuade the German defender to stay at Middlesbrough later today, but the Express says Ziege is likely to sign in a £9m deal - not the £5.5m that has been widely reported - later this week.

Meanwhile, Steve McManaman has laughed off suggestions he's about to move to Middlesbrough. "It's barmy," claimed McManaman. "I'm not taking these reports seriously and I hope nobody else is. I'm very, very happy at Real Madrid. I love the club and the city, and I have a great contract. Why anyone would think I'd swap that for Middlesbrough I don't know."

Charlton will sign Rangers' Finnish striker Jonatan Johansson in a £3.5m deal later today. "I see a figure of £2.5m has been reported," said Rangers manager Dick Advocaat. "Actually, it is £1m more."

Crystal Palace manager Steve Coppell wants to tempt Ian Wright out of retirement, according to the Sun. After suffering a 6-0 defeat at Millwall, Coppell said: "The players have lost the will to fight. Wrighty is 36, but he loves playing. Having him around can only be a benefit."

fields.headline: The DoubleClick dilemma
fields.standfirst: As data about consumers increases in value with the expansion of e-commerce, Mark Tran examines how best to protect the privacy of the individual
fields.trailText: As data about consumers increases in value with the expansion of e-commerce, Mark Tran examines how best to protect the privacy of the individual.
fields.body:
Within the next few weeks, DoubleClick, the American online advertising company, will appoint a chief privacy officer for Europe. The firm hopes to assure consumers that it takes privacy issues seriously after its actions provoked widespread criticism in the United States.

In March, DoubleClick merged with a company called Abacus. In the absence of industry guidelines, it agreed not to merge Abacus's off-line customer specific data with its on-line anonymous data. In the face of public protest, it backed off from such a move, which would have enabled it to produce individual profiles which it could then have sold to advertisers.

DoubleClick officials in Europe admit that March episode was a wake-up call for the company. The timing was especially embarrassing, as only a few weeks earlier, DoubleClick had trumpeted the claim that it had the strongest privacy policy in the internet advertising industry.

As DoubleClick expands operations into Europe it is determined to avoid similar pitfalls. "In Europe, we want to move towards standards that go beyond the law," said Chris Kuner, who has been working with DoubleClick to create a European network.

Call it the DoubleClick dilemma. As online business gathers momentum, data about individuals will increasingly assume the status of a valuable currency. The more information that companies gather about individuals, the more they can target their goods and services towards those customers.

But there is a fine line between gathering data about people and violating their privacy. Data mining has been around for years. One of the driving forces behind the series of mergers that gave rise to Citigroup, the US financial giant, was the possibility of cross-selling a whole series of financial products, from insurance to banking services, to the same person.

But the technology to glean information about individuals is becoming increasingly sophisticated. Internet service providers can keep track of the sites you visit and the software you download. Websites use "cookies" - bits of data that can be stored in PCs - to keep a record of visitors. Software now exists that plants itself in a hard drive and then starts digging up information about your net activities, such as monitoring the advertisements you click on.

Such information is particularly valuable in e-commerce. The value of advertising and e-commerce increases in relation to the number of users of the site and the level of detail which can be amassed about them.

So businesses could become more efficient as they know more about their customers. But there is growing concern about the implications of the collection and use of such personal data, which threatens to disrupt the development of data as currency.

Other companies besides DoubleClick have run into privacy problems in the US. Earlier this month, 39 states asked a federal court to stop a bankrupt online toy retailer from selling personal information about its customers. Toysmart.com declared bankruptcy in June and asked a federal bankruptcy court for permission to put all its assets, including its customer records, such as names, addresses and credit card numbers, up for sale - despite a privacy policy that assured customers that such information would remain private.

Europe, by contrast, has more stringent privacy laws. In 1995, the European Commission drafted the Data Protection Directive, designed to "protect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, and in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data". The directive came into effect in 1998.

Britain has the Data Protection Act, which tightened existing law. In force since March, the act's key provisions include new rights to know who holds information on you, being told the identity of the person in a business nominated as responsible for data protection issues and greater rights to object to anyone holding personal data.

But grey areas still exist, which is why companies such as DoubleClick are keen to get involved discussions on industry-wide standards. "It is in our interest to educate our customers," said Gavin Lennox, managing director of DoubleClick's technical arm in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

Mr Lennox believes that the future of the booming email-marketing sector lies in "opt-in" procedures. In an opt-in system, a person must expressly agree to data being used; "opt-out" allows the data to be used unless the person explicitly requests otherwise.

Email is the fastest growing marketing medium and will reach 135m users by 2002. By 2004 the US is expected to spend more than £3bn on email marketing, compared with £200m in 1999.

"This is the wave of the future of online marketing, and DoubleClick is putting a lot of resources behind it," Mr Lennox said. "We are very conscious not to create spam [junk email] so we have decided on the opt-in. All email will be consent-based, with any unsolicited third party email offer requiring an opt-in from the user."

The Department of Trade and Industry has also been exploring the tensions between e-commerce and privacy. An unpublished interim report from a DTI taskforce suggested four steps for adequate data protection.

The report recommended that sites display a prominent privacy policy; that users be allowed to choose what happens to information they supply; that sensitive information should be opt-in only; that users are able to see and correct data which is held about them; and the Data Protection Registrar should conduct regular audits of companies to ensure compliance.

The taskforce believes it is crucial to resolve the tension between commercial pressures and the desire for privacy. "If users are unwilling to develop working and consumption practices online because of concerns over data privacy, then the UK economy at both a micro and a macro level will suffer," its report said.

Alex Barnett, sales and marketing director of Blue Wave, a web design company, predicts a consumer backlash against intrusive marketing techniques. He posits the intriguing idea of a "privacy maintenance company" or an honest broker between vendors and consumers. Such a company will hold up-to-date information about you and will approach vendors with goods and services of possible interest to you.

"The privacy maintenance company will be a trusted party acting on your behalf, so that vendors don't even know your identity," Mr Barnett said. "These companies don't exist yet, but they are inevitable in an information economy." He believes that the real money-makers will be those companies offering anonymous purchasing and promising to retain the privacy of customers.

fields.bodyText: Within the next few weeks, DoubleClick, the American online advertising company, will appoint a chief privacy officer for Europe. fields.headline: A diesel in disguise
fields.standfirst: Racing driver Jenson Button got nabbed for doing a whopping 143mph in the new BMW 330d.  Giles Smith  tries his utmost to act a bit more responsibly
fields.trailText: Racing driver Jenson Button got nabbed for doing a whopping 143mph in the new BMW 330d. Giles Smith tries his utmost to act a bit more responsibly
fields.body:
Last May, on a motorway near Montpellier, at the wheel of a BMW 330d, the Formula One racing driver Jenson Button was stopped by police for travelling at 143mph in a 70mph zone. It is not recorded whether the officers in question greeted Button - as once a British policeman greeted the late Ayrton Senna when he was caught speeding in Oxfordshire - with the line: "Who do you think you are? Nigel Mansell?" It is known, however, that Button was given a £500 fine and, after enjoying a cup of coffee in the company of his arresting officers and signing a few autographs, was allowed on his way.

Was this the first sign that a young sporting talent, exposed so early to the trappings of fame and success in a rich and glamorous sport, had begun to spend itself tragically in an orgy of wild living? More importantly, how did he get a diesel car to go that fast?

Diesel is not, by anyone's reckoning, a glamour fuel. It is the stuff of lorries and taxis. Depress the accelerator in a diesel car and the car responds at some point in the middle of next week. Normally by slowing down.

Reckless impetuosity is not diesel's thing. Diesel is all about ecologically sound decisions, such as decreased fuel consumption and reduced exhaust emissions. Driving at more than twice the speed limit is not supposed to occur in a diesel car.

Indeed, the reason Button was driving a diesel in France is that, when he is abroad, his license permits him to drive nothing but diesels until he reaches the age of 21. Diesel is the Tizer to petrol's alcohol and was supposed to impose a restraint upon his youthful tendencies. The authorities reckoned without BMW.

These days, in a small tribute to Jenson, perhaps, but also to the car's extraordinary powers, press models of the 330d come with a stern note attached, reminding you of your personal responsibility for any offences committed while in charge of the vehicle. This is because offences are more likely in a car that gets up to 60 while you are still fiddling with the CD player. Actually, though it's no slouch, acceleration from standing is not the 330d's strongest suit. Its best trick is accelerating at high speed - the extra power it allows you quick access to at, say, 70mph, when, with a little squeeze, you can burst past that iffy-looking lorry or leave that tiresome tail-gater receding in your mirror. This is a miracle: additional power at speed is no more of a feature of diesel motoring than wings are.

How close I came to emulating Button's speed is, I feel, a matter between me, my conscience and the traffic cameras on the M25 between the M11 and A12 intersections. I would like to stress, however, that I did NOT take the car up as far as 143mph and if this leads to accusations of timidity, then I would point out that it's not open to all of us to placate policemen by offering to sign a few hats for their kids.

The remarkable thing about the 330d is that it's a diesel which sounds and behaves like no diesel on earth. It is the world's first diesel in disguise. True, when you turn the key there is some hint of that familiar, rattling diesel tick-over, reminiscent of Hoppa buses and black cabs. But then you drive off and all is forgotten, the engine noise reduced to a low, petrol-like thrum.

It's a great car - luxurious but also tightly sprung and sporty, so not remotely spongey. In the long- running BMW v Audi debate, I have tended to stand unflinchingly behind Audi, believing its cars to have more elegant shapes and fewer pimp overtones. The 330d threatens to spoil the argument. The low skirts and skimpy tyres seem to be aimed at the boy racer, upon whom BMW have always looked very kindly, but the boot and bonnet shapes come from somewhere much more cool and poised.

In black it would be inestimably smart. Unfortunately, the car I drove came in a colour which BMW calls Arizona Sun Metallic, but which you know better as Terry's All Gold. It would be hard to imagine a worse colour for a car - maximum objectionableness and maximum profile in the same eye-watering package. The attempt to reflect the colour in the wooden trim of the interior - yielding a shade matching the contents of certain nappies - is misguided.

Amazingly, it would cost you nearly £1,000 extra to have the car painted this way, Arizona Sun Metallic being what BMW rightly calls an "individual paint colour". The world is upside-down. You should get danger money to drive that paintwork around.

The daft paint was just part of a £4,000 package of extras, some dispensable (the rear side airbags, for instance, and the radio navigation system), and some completely essential, like the multi-function sports wheel, which enables you to skip CD tracks with your thumb while you steer, and the six-CD-changer, which gives you something to skip through. What you would definitely stick with is the diesel engine. Sexy stuff, diesel: so fast, so smooth, so economical.

The lowdown

BMW 330d SE

Price on the road: £26,995
Top speed: 141mph
0-62 mph: 7.8 seconds
Fuel consumption: 41.5mpg
On the stereo: The Corrs
At the wheel: Jenson Button
En route for: Monaco; court

webTitle: One in six crimes 'missing from official figures'

fields.headline: One in six crimes 'missing from official figures'
fields.trailText: Police forces will be urged today to improve the way they record offences after a report found that true crime levels could be at least 20% higher than official figures suggest.
fields.body:
Police forces will be urged today to improve the way they record offences after a report found that true crime levels could be at least 20% higher than official figures suggest.

An HM Inspectorate of Constabulary study of the way crime is recorded by police forces in England and Wales found that thousands of offences, including assaults and burglaries are being left out of official statistics.

The report, which comes a fortnight after the government reported a 3.8% increase in the official crime rate last year, says inconsistencies and bureaucracy are the main causes of the inaccuracy.

The official figures showed that a total of 5.3m offences were reported to police in the 12 months to March, compared with 5.1m in the previous year.

There was a 16% increase in violent crimes, with the number of robberies rising 26.1% and the most serious cases of violence up 12.6%.

The suggestion that actual crime levels are 20% higher than the official figures will add to the pressure on the home secretary, Jack Straw.

The authors of the new report found that in too many instances, decisions on whether a crime had taken place were left to individual officers. They also said that there were too many differences between forces on the categories under which offences should be recorded.

After the report by HM Inspectorate of Constabulary was leaked earlier this month, police chiefs and ministers said they were committed to producing as accurate a picture of crime levels as possible.

A consultation paper aimed at increasing consistency between forces will accompany the report when it is officially published today.

Home Office minister Charles Clarke said that the different ways of recording violent crime across the 43 police forces were "completely dotty". Changes needed to be made to define the various kinds of crime and to increase the recording and reporting of crime, he said.

"The level of comparability is very poor right across the country." He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "There are important categories of violent crime - for example, domestic violence, racial violence, sexual violence - where there is significant under-reporting of crime, because people haven't been confident that there problems will be sorted out directly."

The chief constable of Gloucestershire police, Tony Butler, said that the system of recording crime figures was unhelpful and needed to be "simplified". He told the Today programme that the Association of Chief Police Officers would work with the Home Office on the issue.

fields.headline: Leewards grudge match in Leeds
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com goes behind the scenes to get the  lowdown on one of  the performances of the week. Today we talk to Yorkshire's Caribbean-born  fast-medium bowler Lesroy Weekes.
fields.trailText: Lesroy Weekes was born in Monserrat in 1971 and played cricket for the Leeward Islands. He now lives in England and plays in the Huddersfield League. He will qualify for England in January 2001. Last week he took 6-56 against the West Indian tourists at Headingley - the highlight for Yorkshire in their 10-wicket defeat.
fields.body:
Lesroy Weekes was born in Monserrat in 1971 and played cricket for the Leeward Islands. He now lives in England and plays in the Huddersfield League. He will qualify for England in January 2001. Last week he took 6-56 against the West Indian tourists at Headingley - the highlight for Yorkshire in their 10-wicket defeat.

"In some ways I was surprised to be picked. When Martyn Moxon [Yorkshire's director of cricket] rang to ask if I was OK to play I said yes in a shaky sort of way.

"I gave up playing at home to come here because my chances of making it there were so steep - I was playing in such a strong team, what with [Curtly] Ambrose and the Benjamins [Kenny and Winston]. So to get a phone call on the Friday asking me to play against the West Indies was a dream come true. It was a grudge match really for me - a chance to prove myself against these guys.

"Martyn Moxon said to me before the innings began that [Adrian] Griffith falls over when he's batting, and I said yeah - I thought I could get him lbw. And that was my first wicket - it nipped back and he was leg-before. I felt really good after that, when for the first couple of overs I'd been really nervous. The one to [Chris] Gayle was a similar delivery, he played all around it and it hit off-stump. [Sherwin] Campbell, the right-hander, was bowled by an out-swinger that also took off-stump.

"There was a long spell between gettting the third and fourth wickets, because [Jimmy] Adams and [Ramnaresh] Sarwan batted well, and then we went off for bad light. Sarwan was out in the second over of the next day [caught Middlebrook for 32]. Then [Mahendra] Nagamootoo was caught behind and [Corey] Collymore was lbw. The one that got Sarwan was probably my best delivery of the game. Courtney Walsh bowled it short that day, but he's tall. We couldn't afford to bowl short because we've not got his pace. I've been watching Goughie at Headingley and I've learnt a lot from watching him bowl, pitching it up and getting wickets.

"My qualification should come through in January - I'm keeping my fingers crossed and trying to speed things up. Really my future is in the hands of Yorkshire County Cricket Club. They've been kind to me, playing me for the Cricket Board, and they've worked hard with me in the nets.

"I think Yorkshire will do well in the Championship. We've always done well in the first half of the season, and then the back-up bowlers get injured and we suffer. At the start of the season you'd have said we'd got a great side, with seven top-class bowlers. Now Ryan Sidebottom, Gavin Hamilton and Paul Hutchison are injured, and Darren Gough and Matthew Hoggard are away with England. But I think we'll make a top-five finish."

Lesroy Weekes was talking to Claire Daniel. To read last week's My Day in the Sun, in which Surrey's Martin Bicknell tells us about his record-breaking feats against Leicestershire, click here

webTitle: BBC web must not be boundless

fields.headline: BBC web must not be boundless
fields.standfirst:
Net news

Special report: the future of the BBC

Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The BBC's free rein to offer services over the internet is being challenged by a member of the select committee on culture, media and sport.
fields.body:
The BBC's free rein to offer services over the internet is being challenged by a member of the select committee on culture, media and sport.

Julie Kirkbride MP has tabled a series of questions for culture secretary Chris Smith, asking him to state whether boundaries exist to limit the BBC's online ventures. She is particularly concerned about the effect on commercial operators competing against the corporation.

"I would like to know what is and what isn't in the BBC's remit," she said. "At the moment it seems to be about how the governors feel on the day when they wake up and whatever Chris Smith decides to act on - both of which are indeterminate. They just haven't thought these issues through.

"What we have is this old thing called the BBC which sits very uneasily amid the changes in the media and no one has really thought what role it should now have. It is a very grey area."

The challenge comes at a time when the BBC has begun ramping up its involvement in the internet, encouraged by the huge success of its award winning News Online site.

Last month it launched a dedicated sports website and has plans for arts, lifestyle and local city and county sites.

It has received stiff criticism from the private sector which claims the BBC brand is stifling competition.

A decision by the BBC governors has, however, called a halt to the corporation giving away free content to mobile phone networks after intense lobbying by rival news provider ITN. "I'm extremely concerned that the BBC is seeking to operate like a business with the taxpayers' money," Miss Kirkbride added. "They are spending the licence fee on the internet and giving content away free to commercial operators often without the cognisance of the public."

A BBC spokesman said the corporation is "pretty much four square behind the idea that there is room for a public service broadcaster to be on the internet."

Four questions were tabled by Miss Kirkbride last week. However, they have yet to be answered.

She has asked for a 1998 agreement struck between Mr Smith and BBC Online on its activities to be published, whether that agreement permits the distribution of content to commercial operators free of charge and at what date his department was informed of the mobile phone plans. She also asks when he will begin a review of BBC Online.

A BBC spokesman said the corporation is "pretty much four square behind the idea that there is room for a public service broadcaster to be on the internet." Four questions were tabled by Miss Kirkbride last week. However, they have yet to be answered. She has asked for a 1998 agreement struck between Mr Smith and BBC Online on its activities to be published, whether that agreement permits the distribution of content to commercial operators free of charge and at what date his department was informed of the mobile phone plans. She also asks when he will begin a review of BBC Online.

fields.headline: Flawed genius
fields.standfirst: At 15, Benjamin Lebert started to write Crazy. Three years on, his semi-autobiographical novel about a partially paralysed adolescent is a bestseller in Germany.  Simon Hattenstone meets him
fields.trailText: At 15, Benjamin Lebert started to write Crazy. Three years on, his semi-autobiographical novel about a partially paralysed adolescent is a bestseller in Germany. Simon Hattenstone meets him
fields.body:
I'm looking for a beautiful boy with a distant look and a heavy limp. I stare hopefully at someone who could be Benjamin Lebert - he looks like him and doesn't look like him. Slightly too spotty, and imperfect. He limps up to me and shakes my hand.

Benjamin Lebert is a bestselling author. At 15, he started writing Crazy during weekends at home from boarding school. By the time he was 16 it had been published and today, at 18, he has sold more than 300,000 copies in Germany alone. Crazy is autobiographical. The lead character is called Benjamin Lebert, it is set in a boarding school outside Munich and tells the story of a 15-year-old boy paralysed down half his body. At the same time, it is a novel - the Benjamin Lebert of the book, like the photograph on the front, is both recognisable and different. His school friends are composites of different people, many of the incidents are made up.

Crazy is a beautiful book about someone grasping freedom for the first time.

Benjamin, the character, revels in his adolescent discovery - girls, drink, cigarettes. The book also captures a boy who is part of the world but always separate, forever marked out by his disability.

Like Holden Caulfield in Catcher in the Rye, the fictional Benjamin asks the biggest existential questions in the tiniest words. He decides life is pointless unless you're brave, unless you can face up to your daily demons.

But he's still never sure what bravery actually is. At times, his school friends mock his tedious philosophical questing. "Where did you come up with all this shit?" they ask him.

We're walking to a restaurant. Lebert is struggling a few paces behind me. In Crazy, he is always struggling a few paces behind his friends. He is talking about the ways in which the character is different from himself. "He's braver. Some girls have an idea that I'm a powerful boy and I'm not powerful, I'm weak."

After the book was published, many girls wrote to Lebert and poured their heart out. Some said they loved him, some said they wanted to sleep with him, show him a good time like Marie had done in the book. In Crazy, Benjamin's disability is almost envied by friends, it makes him different, and so cool. He says this was true of his year at boarding school, but at no other point in his life.

Lebert was born with his umbilical cord around his neck. It starved him of oxygen, hence the paralysis. He ended up in boarding school because he'd flunked all the exams at all the other schools. "I was a loser," he says. It was also part of his rehabilitation into the real world.

"Because I was disabled my mother always tried to protect me and hide me from the world." He knew it wasn't good for him, but he enjoyed hiding behind his doctor mother. Much of his childhood was painful - at earlier schools he had been teased, ridiculed. "Cripple!" his fellow pupils shrieked at him. Or, even worse, he was ignored.

The last few years have been so much better, he says, but even now he has periods where he feels he's the unluckiest person in the world.

"Sometimes I feel very good and I say I'm different. Sometimes I like it, it's a part of me. But sometimes I say, 'Oh I'm so poor and I'm so different.' I feel sorry for myself."

I order drinks and am surprised when he opts for a Coke. I offer him a cigarette and he refuses. "I don't smoke." I was sure you smoked, I say.

No, that is the Benjamin of the book. If Lebert doesn't eat and drink wisely his health will rapidly deteriorate. His phone rings. He flips it open with a deft flick of his teeth. He says you adapt, gain new strengths.

Lebert started writing when he was nine or 10 - monster stories. The longer he wrote the simpler the words and sentences and stories became. Before long he found he was writing about himself and his experiences and losing himself in his fictive universe. "You can invent your own world. There's a kind of purity . . . you have to be very honest and very close to yourself."

I ask him what his favourite bit of the book is, and without hesitation he mentions the scene in the toilet when he loses his virginity. "It was terrific fun to write," he says with a squeaky giggle. A drunk girl, Marie, takes him off to the toilet. She silently lifts off her dress, places herself on top and rides him to a convulsive ecstacy. She dresses and walks off without a word.

I was amazed that a 16-year- old could write so tenderly and so erotically, and tell him I phoned the publisher Hamish Hamilton to ask if Crazy was a hoax.

Lebert says many people in Germany have suggested that the book was actually written by his journalist father. "That made me angry," he says. "I mean really angry. People are always so sceptical, I don't like it." He's a wonderful mix of excessive politeness ("How is your pizza?" "To your health") and seething impatience, doe-eyed idealism and street-wise cynicism.

Lebert says he adapted the sex scene from life. Did she really walk off like that? Pretty much, so he says. I say that's sad. "Yes, but also kind of beautiful," he says. More perfect? He shudders and says he hates the word perfect, hates the very concept of perfection. Suddenly, he's talking about the politics of cloning and there's no stopping him. "They try to make everything perfect, especially with the cloning and stuff. There will be a brave new world, and I'm really frightened of it." He says what scares him most is the idea that you could choose your body like you choose a computer program.

And that's not the way the world or nature was meant to work. "Human beings are different. Some have big noses, some have big ears, and some have big breasts, and that's life. I hate MTV. When I look at MTV I get really upset because everybody seems so happy, and everyone seems so beautiful, dancing, but it's just sick, and no one seems to recognise it. It's going in the same direction as the Nazi thing that there must be a beautiful race . . ."

If gene therapy could have stopped him being paralysed . . . He interrupts my question. "I wouldn't have done it, you know, because it's me."

He asks me how my pizza is, and thanks me for taking him out to lunch. He says there are so many beautiful things in the world, why would people ever be mad enough to strive for perfection.

Have his boarding school friends enjoyed his success? "No, they are very angry." Why? "Some are angry because of what is not true, some are angry because of what is true." He says they cannot accept that Crazy is a novel based on experience. "I'm not friends with them any more, but they are not exactly like they are in the book." Characters such as Florian aka Girl and his hero, Janosch, are hand-crafted, the type of friends all of us would like.

A while ago documentary-makers returned to Lebert's old school and asked the teachers about him. Did they say that they always knew he had it in him to be a successful writer? "No. They said I was a loser. I was a loser." He smiles, and thinks about it. "But I feel in some way everyone is not a loser. Everyone is brave in some way."

And he limps back to his chauffeur-driven Mercedes.

 Crazy, published by Hamish Hamilton, priced £9.99.

webTitle: Why the press breaks its own code

fields.headline: Why the press breaks its own code
fields.standfirst: The Blairs' family life is proving a difficult temptation for newspapers to resist, says media correspondent Matt Wells
fields.trailText: The Blairs' family life is proving a difficult temptation for newspapers to resist, says media correspondent Matt Wells.
fields.body:
It is a busy time for the press complaints commission. This week it will have to respond to Downing Street's concerns over the publication of pictures of young Leo Blair, and it is also facing calls to intervene in the News of the World's name-and-shame paedophile campaign. If it puts a foot wrong, it risks raising the thorny issue of press self-regulation once again.

The PCC code of conduct is perfectly clear: photographs of children under 16 may not be published without their parents' consent. Downing Street had made it clear the Blairs did not want publicity at Saturday's ceremony, so the action of most Sunday newspapers in printing the images of Leo Blair and his family outside a christening service on Saturday was a deliberate decision to break the rules.

Given that the PCC code was drawn up by newspaper editors, it stands or falls on their decision to uphold it. So why did half of Fleet Street decide that it was worth the candle to flout it in such a flagrant fashion?

Newspaper editors did, in fact, respect the privacy of the Blairs during the service and at the reception afterwards. But seeing Tony and Cherie pressing the flesh and even posing for pictures afterwards, it must have seemed perfectly harmless to print cute pictures of a happy family.

Not so. The Blairs were furious, and have called in the PCC to clarify the rules. Inevitably, it has raised the hackles of editors, who are furious that the PM is happy to pose for pictures when he wants to, but not on other occasions. They also feel there ought to have been an element of payback over the restraint shown when Mr Blair's son, Euan, 16, was cautioned for drunken behaviour in Leicester Square, London.

We are in uncharted waters. Never in recent history has a serving prime minister brought up a young family in Downing Street. The Blairs, naturally, are keen to ensure their children have as normal a family life as possible; the press and public are keen to show images of the prime minister as a family man, simply because they are so unusual.

It is a delicate balance, and Lord Wakeham will have to tread carefully. He has shown remarkable tact in mediating between press and palace over the Prince of Wales's sons, and he will have to show similar diplomacy here.

The NoW campaign is a different matter altogether. Its campaign to out paedophiles has been roundly criticised - yet, surely, it is the role of newspapers to campaign in whatever method they see fit, whether we agree with it or not. A meeting tomorrow with experts in the field and News of the World executives may herald a softening in the newspaper's line. Tighter regulation would not have stopped the paper from raising the issue: a sustained campaign by leading experts might.

webTitle: Concorde in three new safety scares

fields.headline: Concorde in three new safety scares
fields.trailText:
British Airways was today under increasing pressure to ground its Concorde fleet after a third safety scare to hit the supersonic airliner in just two days. 
Last night 57 passengers were grounded at Gander, Newfoundland, when their New York-bound BA flight was forced to divert after the captain smelled fuel as the aircraft neared the US.
fields.body:
British Airways was today under increasing pressure to ground its Concorde fleet after a third safety scare to hit the supersonic airliner in just two days. Last night 57 passengers were grounded at Gander, Newfoundland, when their New York-bound BA flight was forced to divert after the captain smelled fuel as the aircraft neared the US.

News of the incidents came as experts from Britain's Civil Aviation Authority today prepared to meet their French counterparts to discuss safety measures for Concorde flights.

They were joining officials from Air France and the British and French transport ministries in trying to agree a new system of safety checks to allow the airline to resume flights of its Concorde fleet.

All passengers - including musicians Tony Bennett and George Benson - were put on a 737 to New York around 1am BST and are expected to arrive in America later today.

British Airways engineers from New York were being flown to inspect the aircraft. A BA spokeswoman said future Concorde flights were still under review in the wake of the new incidents and last week's Paris crash in which an Air France jet crashed killing 114 people.

She said passenger safety was never at risk in any of the incidents, which were treated with strong "precautionary action".

The first scare came on Saturday as a BA Concorde flight with 18 passengers on board bound for Heathrow from New York suffered a mixture of fuel and air in the engine which led to fire engines and ambulances being put on standby beside the runway as it landed.

The drama caused a loud bang inside the jet, which was "something like an engine backfiring", the BA spokeswoman said. In the second incident a refuelling problem prevented a BA Concorde bound for New York from taking off on Sunday morning, the airline said.

This forced BA to switch 51 passengers to another Concorde, delaying their flight for more than an hour. Norwegian businessman Jostein Svenson, who was on board last night's flight which was diverted to Newfoundland said passengers became upset and nervous when they were told about the hitch. "Tony Bennett was quite concerned, but he's a seasoned flyer," said Mr Svenson, who lives in London. Speaking on BBC Radio Five Live's Up All Night programme, Mr Svenson added: "Considering the Paris crash of course quite a lot of passengers got quite nervous and quite upset. "But it wasn't full panic, as you may expect."

Passengers first became aware of a problem when the aircraft slowed down above the Atlantic, when they were still a long way from New York. "Then it was announced that a strange smell had been noticed towards the back of the plane, and just to be cautious they had decided to divert the plane." Air France's five Concordes were grounded after last week's crash at Gonesse near Paris. But British Airways resumed flights of its seven-strong supersonic fleet the day after the crash. The French transport ministry had said it would await the findings of an air accident report, due at the end of August, before allowing the Air France fleet off the ground.

webTitle: Commission urges 10% devaluation to enter euro

fields.headline: Commission urges 10% devaluation to enter euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Britain would be able to join the euro safely only if it devalued sterling by at least 10% and held a referendum within 18 months of an election, an independent commission has concluded.
fields.body:
Britain would be able to join the euro safely only if it devalued sterling by at least 10% and held a referendum within 18 months of an election, an independent commission has concluded.

The commission includes former members of the Treasury, IMF and the Bank of England monetary policy committee. It suggests a series of parallel steps be taken before the referendum, including opening talks with European finance ministers on sterling's exchange rate - recommending entry at between 1.25 and 1.45 euros to the pound.

The study is due to be published next month at the start of the party conference season, and will put fresh pressure on Tony Blair to set out his plans for the euro at the election.

Ministers have agreed a pact not to discuss the economic case for the euro until after the election, promising simply to make an assessment on whether Britain has sustainably converged with the European economies. That position was criticised yesterday by Lord Haskins, the businessman and Labour peer, for showing a lack of leadership.

The study, now in its final draft, is the most detailed attempt yet to set out a timetable to get Britain ready to join the euro and prevent destabilising speculation in the markets.

It concludes that a referendum must be held by the autumn of 2002, assuming a May 2001 election, to ensure British membership is completed and irreversible by the time of the subsequent election.

The study warns that the markets would not respond well, or cooperate in the necessary gradual devaluation of sterling, if a realistic political chance remained of the Conservatives going into the subsequent election on a ticket of "the last chance to save sterling".

The study has been commissioned by the Liberal Democrats and was chaired by Chris Huhne, the economist and Liberal Democrat MEP.

However, the quality and independence of the commission's membership will take its conclusions above the level of party politics. Members include Marcus Miller, on the Treasury's academic panel, Lionel Price, former head of the international division at the Bank of England, and David Peretz, a senior adviser at the World Bank and formerly deputy director of inter national finance at the Treasury. Other members include the monetary policy committee member Willem Buiter, exchange rate specialist John Williamson, and Martin Weale, a director of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

The group concludes that convergence will be "well nigh perfect soon after the election" since the amount of spare capacities in the British and European economies will be very similar. It argues that, before a referendum, ministers will need to open negotiations with the European Central Bank on the terms of sterling's entry into the euro, including the likely exchange rate and prospects for getting ECB intervention in the markets to ease entry. The study further says that it might be possible for Britain to win formal dispensation from the treaty requirement to join the European exchange rate mechanism for two years; however, it suggests, if Britain did choose not to join, it might have to pay a negotiating price.

Before the referendum, the study recommends, the Treasury should publish a new draft transitional mandate for the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, so that it no longer followed merely a domestically set inflation target. The Bank of England, to conform with the law inside the euro zone, would also need to change its legal status to be made more independent of the government. At present the chancellor retains the power to override the committee, including its membership and terms of reference.

The single biggest step the government could take to bring about convergence with the euro, says the study, is to bring down the exchange rate by lowering sterling against the Deutschmark, which would also increase British competitiveness.

The study concludes that the lowering of sterling would be best achieved by politicians making it clear to the markets that they were seriously determined to join the euro. Opening negotiations with Brussels to agree on a rate would be a key step. "The greater the likelihood of EMU membership injected into the public domain before a decision, the easier it will be to get the exchange rate down," a member of the study team said.

Previous academic assessments have suggested a rate of DM2.10 to DM2.78. The study will propose a rate below DM2.80 and above DM2.40. The current rate is DM3.17.
fields.bodyText: Britain would be able to join the euro safely only if it devalued sterling by at least 10% and held a referendum within 18 months of an election, an independent commission has concluded. The commission includes former members of the Treasury, IMF and the Bank of England monetary policy committee. It suggests a series of parallel steps be taken before the referendum, including opening talks with European finance ministers on sterling's exchange rate - recommending entry at between 1.25 and 1.45 euros to the pound. The study is due to be published next month at the start of the party conference season, and will put fresh pressure on Tony Blair to set out his plans for the euro at the election. Ministers have agreed a pact not to discuss the economic case for the euro until after the election, promising simply to make an assessment on whether Britain has sustainably converged with the European economies. That position was criticised yesterday by Lord Haskins, the businessman and Labour peer, for showing a lack of leadership. The study, now in its final draft, is the most detailed attempt yet to set out a timetable to get Britain ready to join the euro and prevent destabilising speculation in the markets. It concludes that a referendum must be held by the autumn of 2002, assuming a May 2001 election, to ensure British membership is completed and irreversible by the time of the subsequent election. The study warns that the markets would not respond well, or cooperate in the necessary gradual devaluation of sterling, if a realistic political chance remained of the Conservatives going into the subsequent election on a ticket of "the last chance to save sterling". The study has been commissioned by the Liberal Democrats and was chaired by Chris Huhne, the economist and Liberal Democrat MEP. However, the quality and independence of the commission's membership will take its conclusions above the level of party politics. Members include Marcus Miller, on the Treasury's academic panel, Lionel Price, former head of the international division at the Bank of England, and David Peretz, a senior adviser at the World Bank and formerly deputy director of inter national finance at the Treasury. Other members include the monetary policy committee member Willem Buiter, exchange rate specialist John Williamson, and Martin Weale, a director of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research. The group concludes that convergence will be "well nigh perfect soon after the election" since the amount of spare capacities in the British and European economies will be very similar. It argues that, before a referendum, ministers will need to open negotiations with the European Central Bank on the terms of sterling's entry into the euro, including the likely exchange rate and prospects for getting ECB intervention in the markets to ease entry. The study further says that it might be possible for Britain to win formal dispensation from the treaty requirement to join the European exchange rate mechanism for two years; however, it suggests, if Britain did choose not to join, it might have to pay a negotiating price. Before the referendum, the study recommends, the Treasury should publish a new draft transitional mandate for the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, so that it no longer followed merely a domestically set inflation target. The Bank of England, to conform with the law inside the euro zone, would also need to change its legal status to be made more independent of the government. At present the chancellor retains the power to override the committee, including its membership and terms of reference. The single biggest step the government could take to bring about convergence with the euro, says the study, is to bring down the exchange rate by lowering sterling against the Deutschmark, which would also increase British competitiveness. The study concludes that the lowering of sterling would be best achieved by politicians making it clear to the markets that they were seriously determined to join the euro. Opening negotiations with Brussels to agree on a rate would be a key step. "The greater the likelihood of EMU membership injected into the public domain before a decision, the easier it will be to get the exchange rate down," a member of the study team said. Previous academic assessments have suggested a rate of DM2.10 to DM2.78. The study will propose a rate below DM2.80 and above DM2.40. The current rate is DM3.17.

fields.headline: A convert to scepticism
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: It seems weird to have joined the ranks of the eurosceptics. After so long as a true believer, finding a more complex position and writing a pamphlet for New Europe - a body which supports Europe but is against the euro - has been a demanding exercise.
fields.body:
It seems weird to have joined the ranks of the eurosceptics. After so long as a true believer, finding a more complex position and writing a pamphlet for New Europe - a body which supports Europe but is against the euro - has been a demanding exercise.

My faith in a single currency had roots in my attempts to escape the reactionary and narrow form of patriotism with which I was brought up. Europe, the single market and a single currency stood for a more liberal way of thinking and larger market and business opportunities.

But now it seems anything but progressive. The Europe envisaged by the proponents of the single currency is not the Europe to which I thought we were committed. Far from being a land of opportunity, it is a zone in which control is rampant and bureaucrats decide which opportunities each of us should be allowed.

Joining the euro under these circumstances will mean that the potential advantages of the single currency cannot in practice be grasped and will further embed a system of rule making that is to the disadvantage of Europe as a whole and of Britain in particular.

I used to think that to deal with the EU's limitations we had to get in there and tackle them. Now I believe we can only join the euro when there is unmistakable evidence that the system has changed.

The EU is a handicapper, framing ever more complicated rules to ensure everyone in the race hits the tape at the same time. Excellence is stifled and competition is seen as harmful. The euro is simply another element of this rule-making capacity.

The pressure for harmonisation of everything is increasing to ensure the euro works in the face of the real and inevitable lack of convergence.

In the past Britain has wallowed in the mire of over-management. Eventually, we began to walk away. It is crazy to start a rerun now, especially when we look at the rest of the world. Outside parochial Europe the world is becoming a freer place. The internet and global communications are changing trading patterns and making it easier to enter markets. They are undermining the ability to tax business but making it possible for developing countries to leapfrog some of the constraints they used to suffer.

Modern day Colonel Blimps hate this world. They can no longer wear tweeds and drink a gin and tonic at sundown, bewailing the loss of Empire.

But now they sit in Brussels, where they believe that they can solve all problems and set all agendas. Ironically, they are the intellectual heirs of the central planners of the Soviet Union. They are building a European empire of cosy, inward-looking elites.

I can no longer see that entry to the euro helps achieve any of the aims that I formulated in my teens. I cannot see how it will, in the medium term, create jobs, alleviate poverty or enable us to reap the benefits of innovation. All of these gains which are possible in theory will be restricted and prevented by the handicappers of Brussels. We should say now that we do not intend to join until there are clear reforms of the rule-making process. Only then will it be worth reconsidering entry.

The following are alternative or additional tests to those the chancellor has set out:

 evidence of reduced pressure for fiscal harmonisation;

 evidence that pension and labour market reform is being taken seriously;

 evidence that the commission has cleaned up its act;

 evidence centralism is not as important as democracy.

Bridget Rosewell is chairman of Volterra Consulting and a former adviser to Kenneth Clarke

brosewell@volterrra.co.uk

webTitle: The problems of imposing economic sanctions

fields.headline: An enemy to the innocent, best friend to dictators
fields.standfirst:
Even the people who impose sanctions know they don't work
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Stand on the last red, rocky outcrop of Pakistan territory at the end of the Khyber Pass: look down the winding road into Afghanistan. And what do you see on the plain below? A gigantic goods depot. Lorries by the hundred, parked for offloading. You see the imbecility of sanctions.
fields.body:
Stand on the last red, rocky outcrop of Pakistan territory at the end of the Khyber Pass: look down the winding road into Afghanistan. And what do you see on the plain below? A gigantic goods depot. Lorries by the hundred, parked for offloading. You see the imbecility of sanctions.

There was a predictable flurry a few weeks ago when Robin Cook abandoned his (inevitably ethical) arms embargo against General Pervez Musharraf's fledgling regime. Here we were, after a handful of months, abandoning our righteous condemnation of the soldiery who had, yet again, crushed Pakistan democracy. Here we were, giving in. But this ban - more even than most such exercises - had been a charade of diplomacy.

The stark fact is that General Musharraf's men can never, will never, run short of guns. They have guns extruding from every arsenal: weapons showered on them by Uncle Sam through the long years of Afghan war, weapons by the million collected from the refugees and dealers of that war, weapons shipped by lorry down the highways from central Asia where the indigent former republics of the Soviet empire have leftover kit to sell, weapons trucked from China or across Iran from the factories of eastern Europe. An arms embargo? The MoD could take Gordon Brown's new billions and blow them overnight in the gun supermarkets of Khybermart.

Go out and make a futile gesture? Brother, this de funct embargo was the emperor of redundant gestures. It was a bad, sad joke. And yet, as it is lifted, we still wriggle with indignation. How can you relax sanctions when the cause of those sanctions remains unaddressed (and, indeed, Pakistan's elected prime minister begins a clutch of life sentences)? What kind of signal does that send? What does it tell the "world community" about our resolve?

These weren't questions on the agenda at Okinawa. TB doesn't even seem to have written one of his memos about them. Yet facing and answering them becomes imperative. Do sanctions "work"? Perhaps, very occasionally. They were one factor among many in South Africa's lurch to a better future. But do the sanctions currently imposed around the world show any such sign of working? To the contrary: they merely make some lousy scenes worse.

President Slobodan Milosevic is thinking of standing early for re-election this autumn. He wouldn't be thinking about that test - euro-referendum style - if he wasn't sure of winning. The early opposition rallies which followed the Kosovan war have faded into squabbling impotence. Milosevic is closing radio stations and locking up dissident journalists with all his old elan.

I have, at second hand, many contacts across the swathe of the president's critics inside Serbia, the men and women from all walks of life who hope one day to offer their country a better future. There are dozens of them. Not one - not a single one - believes that the west's continuing sanctions have any useful effect. Exactly the opposite. They all believe that these sanctions prolong Milosevic's rule. They oppress, depress and divide the forces of possible resistance - and turn ordinary people against them. They make life a barren struggle in which only acquiescence and despair grow. And, crucially, they hand the power of survival - access to food, goods and permits - to Milosevic's cronies.

Sanctions create a corrupt crony state. Sanctions undermine any residual rule of law. Sanctions breed fear and resignation in precisely the quarters they are meant to succour. We shouldn't be surprised about that. It is the abiding lesson of Saddam's Iraq a decade on. The old gangster may - just may - be dying of cancer, his sons preparing to stage their own succession revels; but the dictatorship lives and flourishes as usual, untouched by any liberalising breeze of change. The only change of a wasted, deluded decade has been the changings of the guard at UN mercy missions within Iraq as its commanders have departed in disgust at the starvation and death of innocent peasants and innocent children which sanctions have brought in train.

The miserable truth about such reflections, though, is not that they are the treacherous mutterings of some minority - but exactly the reverse. Everybody in polite political and diplomatic circles is prepared to shrug and write off sanctions in private. Wasn't that the rub for Milosevic: that he'd be left to languish in isolated autocracy while the countries of freedom near to him, the Bulgarias and Romanias, would prosper? But just go to the empty Danube and look at the blight that sanctions spread. Whatever happened to examples?

The moral difficulty now, the real problem of ethics, is that the imposers and maintainers of sanctions have no faith in them either. They recognise that these tools of the trade haven't undermined Saddam or Slobodan, but have kept them in place. We've done them a good turn, these formally designated war criminals; we've given them no choice but to hang on, then ensured that they can gather their cronies together and keep the lid on society jammed tight.

Good news for the Kurds or the marsh dwellers of Iraq? Good news for the millions of Serbs who want to be human again? Of course not. But - and here even the sagest diplomats gaze at their boots - what else is there to be done? This policy of "strength and resolve" can't be abandoned. We can't admit in public what we all acknowledge in private. That would be "weakness".

And so the old nostrums emerge almost of their own accord. Don't like Burma? Then chuck in more sanctions. Don't like Fiji? Here we go again. That doesn't mean that all sanctions, in all circumstances, are a waste of time. General Musharraf wouldn't take a ban on diplomatic travel lightly - nor yet a ban on Pakistan officers past and present visiting their European and American villas and watering holes for the summer. That would soon have the yelps starting. But meaningless sanctions, imposed by rote and continued long after their failure is manifest, are different. They are the embattled dictator's friend and the enemy of the innocent.

Dichotomy time. We preach freedom's catharsis through the freedom of the market - but we jettison that freedom when we try to confront autocracy. We put our trust in the people - except when they need our trust. In terms of hardship and futility, we ought to be rethinking sanctions now. We know that they are killing children by the hundreds of thousands in Iraq, but we daren't admit it. We know that they are the tyrant's best friend, but will not say so. Perhaps Philip Gould could see what one of his focus groups thinks. Then at least we might get sanctions on the agenda.

peter.preston@theguardian.com
