fields.headline: Mossad drops cloak and dagger
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Mossad, the agency that once boasted a bug in the office of every Arab leader, has been forced to advertise openly for would-be spies in the Israeli press and on the internet.
fields.body:
Mossad, the agency that once boasted a bug in the office of every Arab leader, has been forced to advertise openly for would-be spies in the Israeli press and on the internet.

In an era when cappuccino-swigging twentysomething techies have replaced horny-handed desert farmers as the new heros of Zionism, the agency is finding it can no longer replenish its ranks.

Its reputation for toughness and panache badly shaken by a series of bungles, Mossad can no longer make do with making discreet approaches to likely candidates or placing vaguely worded advertisements through front companies. The agency said yesterday that it was launching its first public recruitment campaign, offering graduates aged 25-35 the chance of a "thrilling career" while serving the nation.

"Only you, in your heart of hearts, know that you are capable of much more, to think differently, to do more than you thought you could," says the advertisement, which was posted on the Hebrew version of the website for the prime minister's office yesterday.

"We offer you a future and a horizon of service in a field in which you will be able to contribute to what is dear to all of us."

Candidates are invited to fax a freephone number with their curriculum vitae and Israeli identity-card number.

Mossad's reputation was boosted in 1960 when it kidnapped Adolf Eichmann, the Nazi who masterminded the annihilation of Europe's Jews, from his hideout in Buenos Aires and brought him to Israel to stand trial.

In 1986 the agency staged another coup when a blonde agent identified only as Cindy lured nuclear technician Mordechai Vanunu away from London to Italy for a holiday. He was drugged and returned to Israel to be tried for exposing the country's secret nuclear programme to the Sunday Times.

The advertisements are intended to counter the hi-tech boom that is siphoning off the best of a new generation, more concerned with material success than Zionist idealism. Mossad also plans to scour the ranks of graduates and send out postal solicitations to those it considers suitable.

Applicants for the dozens of field intelligence officer posts on offer should be independent, creative, highly motivated and intelligent, and demonstrate resourcefulness and an ability to perform well under pressure, the ad says, warning: "Mossad is opening - but not for everyone."

The new recruitment method, which brings Mossad into line with the more open approach of the CIA and MI5, is a result of serious manpower shortages in all areas.

"We have more need of secret agents than ever, because of the dangers that threaten us," an ex-Mossad chief, Yitzhak Hofi, said. "But we face relentless competition from the world of hi-tech."

The malaise is also affecting Israel's army, which has seen a drop in teenagers seeking to perform their compulsory military duty in elite army units, and a rise in the number of reservists seeking to wriggle out of their annual stint of service.

Instead, high school students are lining up to perform their compulsory military duty in the army's data processing unit, whose graduates can command incomes four times the average starting salary.

Meanwhile, the downside to a Mossad career has never been so apparent. Recently an agent received a one-year suspended sentence from a Swiss court after police caught him trying to put a wiretap on a Lebanese car dealer.

webTitle: Pressure grows for tobacco firm inquiry

fields.headline: Pressure grows for tobacco firm inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Pressure is intensifying on Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, to order an investigation into British American Tobacco, with the publication today of internal documents detailing how the company exploited smuggling in Africa.
fields.body:
Pressure is intensifying on Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, to order an investigation into British American Tobacco, with the publication today of internal documents detailing how the company exploited smuggling in Africa.

The London-based corporation's memos disclose how it benefited from black marketeering in a concerted drive to boost sales.

One note records discussions over a proposed deal with a businessman who "would disguise the cigarette importations by calling the shipment something else, eg matches" to beat restrictions in Niger.

Another intermediary, targeting north Cameroon and Chad, was sold 300 cartons which was all his truck could carry "taking into account the other merchandise which will 'hide' the cigarettes".

The BAT letters dating up to the mid-1990s were obtained by the Action on Smoking and Health (Ash) anti-tobacco campaign after a trawl of the firm's Guildford archive, opened to the public as part of a settlement last year to a health lawsuit in the US.

Evidence of BAT's activities in Africa will trigger further demands for Mr Byers to approve an official Whitehall inquiry into the company.

The all-party Commons health committee unanimously called for an investigation last month after the Guardian revealed how BAT exploited smuggling in South America and Asia.

The European commission announced last week that it would act against unnamed tobacco companies to recover tax losses from smuggling.

Yussuf Saloojee, of the South Africa-based National Council Against Smoking, said last night: "We are pressing African governments to launch criminal investigations into BAT and its involvement in cigarette smoking.

"The days when they can march in with their colonial arrogance and treat Africa like some lawless frontier are over.

"Africa has enough problems without multinational corporations undermining the stability of our governments and national policies."

Mr Byers is known to favour a British inquiry but some Department of Trade and Industry officials are believed to be warning that a formal inspection could prove expensive and lengthy. Lawyers in London and New York have also been appointed by BAT to prepare possible defences, and an internal inquiry was launched.

A company spokeswoman yesterday declined to discuss specific allegations raised by the latest memos. "We do not condone or collude with smugglers," she said.

The BAT memo on Niger referred to a meeting in the firm's Woking offices on July 1987; the translated north Cameroon-Chad note was dated February 1988.

Others uncovered by Ash include accounts of so-called "umbrella operations" under which advertising is used to promote limited legal sales and cover much bigger smuggling operations.

Complaints that smugglers preferred to handle a rival's products because they were cheaper are also aired in one of the documents.

Clive Bates, director of Ash, said: "Every week that goes by, the evidence is piling up higher."

Jenny Tonge, the Liberal Democrat spokeswoman on international development, said last night: "We need an inquiry to get to the bottom of what has been going on."

The London-based corporation's memos disclose how it benefited from black marketeering in a concerted drive to boost sales. One note records discussions over a proposed deal with a businessman who "would disguise the cigarette importations by calling the shipment something else, eg matches" to beat restrictions in Niger. Another intermediary, targeting north Cameroon and Chad, was sold 300 cartons which was all his truck could carry "taking into account the other merchandise which will 'hide' the cigarettes". The BAT letters dating up to the mid-1990s were obtained by the Action on Smoking and Health (Ash) anti-tobacco campaign after a trawl of the firm's Guildford archive, opened to the public as part of a settlement last year to a health lawsuit in the US. Evidence of BAT's activities in Africa will trigger further demands for Mr Byers to approve an official Whitehall inquiry into the company. The all-party Commons health committee unanimously called for an investigation last month after the Guardian revealed how BAT exploited smuggling in South America and Asia. The European commission announced last week that it would act against unnamed tobacco companies to recover tax losses from smuggling. Yussuf Saloojee, of the South Africa-based National Council Against Smoking, said last night: "We are pressing African governments to launch criminal investigations into BAT and its involvement in cigarette smoking. "The days when they can march in with their colonial arrogance and treat Africa like some lawless frontier are over. "Africa has enough problems without multinational corporations undermining the stability of our governments and national policies." Mr Byers is known to favour a British inquiry but some Department of Trade and Industry officials are believed to be warning that a formal inspection could prove expensive and lengthy. Lawyers in London and New York have also been appointed by BAT to prepare possible defences, and an internal inquiry was launched. A company spokeswoman yesterday declined to discuss specific allegations raised by the latest memos. "We do not condone or collude with smugglers," she said. The BAT memo on Niger referred to a meeting in the firm's Woking offices on July 1987; the translated north Cameroon-Chad note was dated February 1988. Others uncovered by Ash include accounts of so-called "umbrella operations" under which advertising is used to promote limited legal sales and cover much bigger smuggling operations. Complaints that smugglers preferred to handle a rival's products because they were cheaper are also aired in one of the documents. Jenny Tonge, the Liberal Democrat spokeswoman on international development, said last night: "We need an inquiry to get to the bottom of what has been going on."

webTitle: At last Blair is scoring some goals

fields.headline: At last Blair is scoring some goals
fields.standfirst:
Let's hope the next two years make the last three worthwhile
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Let's hope the next two years make the last three worthwhile
fields.body:
A couple of weeks ago, I received one of those postcards which are designed to raise a weak-minded laugh rather than create a feeling of wonder, envy or nostalgia.

Instead of being decorated with a sepia picture of Brighton pier on a pre-war bank holiday, or a full-colour photograph of Blackpool illuminations at midnight, it was embellished with what passed for a humorous criticism of the government. The "joke" was built on an advertisement for margarine and read: "New Labour. I can't believe it isn't better."

Today I feel vindicated in my decision not to pin the postcard on my noticeboard. Things are getting better. Even the quality of the leaks is improving. Last week's revelation that Tony Blair's private view on entry into the European single currency cannot be distinguished from his public statements was the sort of unauthorised disclosure of which Alastair Campbell must dream - or perhaps dreams of organising. But I put all unworthy thoughts out of my mind. Labour is back on course. At least I think it is.

You are right, cynical reader, to suspect that I want to believe politics is a game of two halves. It is goals which count and the goals in which I believe seem likely to be achieved (at least in part) by the time the final whistle is blown on this parliament. My football metaphor is dedicated to Margaret Hodge, the junior minister who only slightly tarnished the government's suddenly glittering achievements by insisting on a work-permit policy which will further depress the quality of the British game. But Ms Hodge aside, I am ready to be delighted. I only wish that the prime minister was not so determined to convince me that - whatever the evidence to the contrary - he is firmly opposed to anything that looks or sounds like socialism.

He was at it again during his statement on health service reforms when he dismissed opposition to the public use of private hospital beds as "ideological". I share his view that, when patients are waiting for surgery, the refusal to hire available space in private wards would be indefensible. It would also be callous, doctrinaire and stupid. But, unlike those adjectives, ideological is not a term of abuse. Ideology is what the prime minister is, or ought to be, about. He is at his best (and I am at my happiest) when he fulfils that obligation.

Ideological disputes are no more or less than arguments about the nature of the good society. Tony Blair rightly emphasised the distinction between a Tory health service, which would include a compulsory element of private insurance, and the Labour alternative, which would not. The gulf which divides the two schemes is ideological. Each of the parties objects to the other's idea of medical care for reasons which - although they may be dressed up as common sense or compassion - have no other origin. It is foolish to pretend otherwise.

My fear, for the years between now and polling day, is that the more genuine socialism the government practises, the more it will denounce socialism and all that it stands for. I would be perfectly happy for the prime minister to behave in that mildly dishonest manner if I thought it would secure the deserved objective of a second term with both a substantial majority and the enthusiastic support that is essential to the success of a radical programme.

1997 was the triumph of ecumenicism. It cannot happen a second time. That simple truth is illustrated and confirmed every day - most recently, in my direct experience, during last Friday's Any Questions. One of the participants was Nicholas Coleridge, the boss of Condé Nast - a company which produces glossy magazines. Mr Coleridge was introduced as a man who, before the last election, totally identified with Tony Blair. But glad confident morning did not last. During the broadcast, he was eloquent in his support for a privately funded element within the health service, the policy which his erstwhile hero had rightly dismissed with contempt a couple of days earlier.

As I listened to Mr Coleridge expressing his doubts about the policies and personalities of the government, I grew close to feeling sorry for the true begetters of the New Labour project. I imagined how a half-word of support or sympathy from Mr Coleridge had driven them into frenzies of pleasure at the thought that another smartly dressed businessman had been converted to their cause. They cannot believe that now. And, assuming they have any grasp of reality, they will not be able to convince themselves he can be won back.

But here we are, me and thousands of Labour supporters like me, standing ready - perhaps too ready - to believe that the next two years will make the last three worthwhile. Tony Blair cannot convince both Mr Coleridge and us that he is on our side. If (as the last fortnight has encouraged me to hope) he really does support us, it will be sensible of him to say so.

webTitle: Illegal immigrants found in lorry after 60-mile chase

fields.headline: Illegal immigrants found in lorry after 60-mile chase
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A supermarket worker was yesterday charged with smuggling 28 illegal immigrants into Britain in the back of a lorry after a 60-mile chase.
fields.body:
A supermarket worker was yesterday charged with smuggling 28 illegal immigrants into Britain in the back of a lorry after a 60-mile chase.

Julian Lee, 26, allegedly failed to stop when asked to do so by immigration officers as his truck rolled off a cross-Channel ferry at Dover on Saturday.

The lorry was pursued up the M20 towards London before it turned onto the A228 at Cuxton and ended up in a ditch. Thirty men were allegedly found inside.

A police officer was taken to hospital with a back injury and two police cars were damaged in the chase. Eight were involved in all. Mr Lee, of Romford, Essex, was taken to hospital with a suspected broken arm.

A police spokesman said: "Thirty men were taken into custody and have now been handed over to immigration officials." Mr Lee had been charged in connection with 28 of them. "The issue of the other two is one we will be resolving," police said.

A Home Office spokesman said only one of the 30 was claiming political asylum.

The men, believed to be from Bangladesh, were aged between their late teens and mid-40s. The spokesman said six had left Britain yesterday and 23 were to be taken to France tomorrow.

"None of the men was injured in the incident and they were all taken straight to police stations," he added. "The main thing is they are on their way back."

Last month 58 Chinese nationals were found dead in a lorry at the ferry port in Dover. An inquest heard that the dead had suffocated, and that a vent that might have saved their lives was closed. Seven Dutch nationals were charged with manslaughter.

Mr Lee was charged with 28 counts of facilitation - illegally bringing people into the country - and was bailed to appear before Folkestone magistrates on Friday.

webTitle: New trade war looms over GM labelling

fields.headline: New trade war looms over GM labelling
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Europe and the United States are on a collision course over the issue of the labelling of genetically modified food which threatens to spark a trade war.
fields.body:
Europe and the United States are on a collision course over the issue of the labelling of genetically modified food which threatens to spark a trade war.

Washington has warned the EU that it is considering making a formal complaint to the World Trade Organisation in Geneva on the grounds that labelling GM products is unfair discrimination against US goods and therefore a restraint of trade. The US says it will ask the WTO to impose sanctions against EU exports if GM labels are not removed from supermarket shelves.

The row comes at a time when trade relations with the US are tense over other disputes.

A spokeswoman for the US food and drug administration, which insists that only nutritional information should be on the label, said: "This is getting extremely serious. We regard requiring GM labelling as economic fraud. Our view is that we would not have allowed these products on the market if they were not safe, they are the same as non-GM food, so they do not require a label. In fact, to label them is trade discrimination and therefore wrong."

The agency confirmed there had been discussions with the European commission over labelling and the restraint of trade issue, but the two sides were "as far apart as ever".

Among those urging the US to take action is Senator Christopher Bond, a Republican from Missouri and a leading advocate of US bio-technology. He told the Guardian that the EU's insistence on labelling was designed to lower consumer confidence in US goods and was a barrier to trade. "I will be pushing for trade sanctions over this hysteria," he said. "We are on a collision course, and our government must go to the WTO if the EU does not give way."

In Brussels, Beate Kminde, speaking for the commission, said the EU was aware of US threats but no formal complaint had been made. "We are aware of our trade obligations but we also believe in consumer choice so we require GM foods to be labelled. The Americans will not accept this but we are determined. We will have to see what they do."

Unless the row is resolved, there could be a trade war that would make present disputes seem very small.

The British government is already braced for heavy job losses in the Scottish cashmere industry as a result of US retaliation in the long-running US-EU banana dispute. US officials complain that Caribbean producers in former colonies of EU members are getting preferential treatment.

Britain has so far escaped sanctions in the row over the EU ban on the use of hormones in beef, which has led to 12-year embargo on US beef. Goods including French cheese and truffles and German and French mustards have faced 100% US tariffs in tit-for-tat action but Britain's support for the US position, even though it cannot opt out of the EU ban, has meant British goods have not been targeted.

The EU meanwhile has complained about US export subsidies to huge corporations such as Boeing, Exxon, Ford and Monsanto.

Regulators on opposite sides of the Atlantic disagree about the purpose of food labels and the EU stance on consumer choice is regarded as fundamentally wrong in Washington. The FDA believes that GM foods are safe and the nutritional value is the same as non-GM foods, so there should be no mention on the label of the "process" by which the food was grown.

In Washington, Tom O'Connor, director of technical services for the national grain and feed association, said the EU labelling system would "kill GM technology in Europe".

"It looks like a warning, like putting a skull and crossbones on the packet, a kiss of death in marketing terms," he said.

The FDA and other regulators decided in May to look again at the issue after US organic and other food producers began to label food GM-free. No final decision has been made but officials believe that to conform with regulations the food would have to be 100% non-GM, a difficult feat in a country where almost all processed food contains some GM maize or soya.

fields.headline: Countryside bill at risk
fields.standfirst:
Prescott and Meacher lead fight to avoid Lords sacrifice of key manifesto pledge

Special report: countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Ministers are bracing themselves to abandon their countryside bill, designed to protect threatened wildlife and the rights of ramblers.
fields.body:
Ministers are bracing themselves to abandon their countryside bill, designed to protect threatened wildlife and the rights of ramblers.

Senior ministers have been told it is increasingly likely they will be not be able to clear the massive backlog of legislation through the Lords this session and that a major bill looks likely to be sacrificed.

The countryside bill is already the subject of more than 300 amendments from Conservative peers and landowners who are determined to restrict access.

Some ministers now believe a fight with landowners could be the right issue to revive the electorate's appetite for further reform of the Lords.

They are preparing to mount a pre-election campaign attacking the continuing dominance of the landowning classes in an only partially reformed House of Lords.

But both the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the environment minister, Michael Meacher, are strongly opposed to sacrificing the legislation, which contains key manifesto commitments.

It is known that Lady Young of Old Scone, the chairman of English Nature, is increasingly worried the bill might be lost due to pressure of time.

Lady Young warned last week that the bill "must not become a battleground for wider matters of town versus country, or simply spoiling tactics which jeopardise the bill's passage and risk sinking the first decent wildlife legislation for 20 years".

Friends of the Earth also warned last night that the bill was in jeopardy. Matt Phillips of FoE said environmental groups would be mounting a sustained campaign through the summer to persuade the government not to jettison the bill.

Mr Phillips stressed that wildlife groups with more than 6m supporters were determined to see the highly complex bill on to the statute book.

He said there was every sign that some Tory backwoodsmen were planning to wreck the bill by tabling nonsensical amendments such as a ban on glue-sniffing on the land.

More serious amendments have been tabled, designed to restrict the kinds of land available to ramblers, as well as prevent rambling by night. Some peers have already described the bill as a criminal's charter.

Landowners are also seeking requirements on ramblers to keep dogs permanently on leads, and rights to compensation for landowners.

Planned detailed consideration of the bill has been delayed until after the summer recess due to the pressure of business, including the suddenly announced football hooligan bill.

In a bruising final day before the summer recess, ministers were forced to make repeated concessions to keep the government's legislative timetable vaguely on course.

Ministers recognise that even with the early return of the Lords on September 27, it will be extremely difficult to steer through more than five major bills still in the upper house in time for the Queen's speech and the opening in November of what could turn out to be this government's final parliamentary session.

The government feels it cannot afford to jettison other bills such as the political parties and elections and referendums bill, which will set a campaign limit on election spending by parties. The Freedom of Information Act is also seen as indispensable, even if it is subject to a growing list of amendments from Tories and Liberal Democrats.

The government also cannot afford to lose the police Northern Ireland bill, a key part of the Good Friday agreement. The transport bill introducing congestion charges for motorists is also seen as indispensable by the Department of the Environment. Time is also being found for two controversial Home Office bills - the criminal justice (mode of trial) bill, restricting trial by jury, and the criminal justice court services bill.

The government has no overall majority in the Lords and has to rely on the Liberal Democrats and crossbenchers to win key votes. Although ministers have promised to modernise the procedures of the Lords, they do not have the same control over timetabling bills, or the length of debates.

Ministers have already set aside three committee stages for the countryside bill in early October timed to coincide with the party conference season and increase the political pressure on the Lords not to defy the public.

Mr Prescott has even said he is willing to invoke the Parliament Act in the next session if the countryside bill is scuppered so that it will be on the statute book in time for the election.

webTitle: The medical benefits of stem cell research

fields.headline: Don't stop science
fields.standfirst:
The government's eagerly awaited response on embryonic cell research is a matter of life and death
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Speculation is growing about the official response to the chief medical officer's forthcoming report on research using cells from embryos. A wise government will understand that although such work might upset a few members of the public, many lives might almost certainly be saved.
fields.body:
Speculation is growing about the official response to the chief medical officer's forthcoming report on research using cells from embryos. A wise government will understand that although such work might upset a few members of the public, many lives might almost certainly be saved.

Every decade or so, developments in a particular scientific field have profound importance for health. Such is "stem cell" technology. Whilst biologists have known of the existence of stem cells for years, recent research into their potential now offers immense medical benefits. These cells are the "ancestors" of all adult cells. From the earliest stages, the cells of the embryo start to differentiate into more specialised tissues. Their property of forming new tissues and organs offers extraordinary opportunities. If caught and cultured very early, embryonic cells should be capable of becoming any of the 216 cell types that make an adult human.

Later in existence, any stem cells that are collected have a much more limited potential. It is true that primitive blood cells, harvested from adults, can be used for treating some blood disorders. It is also possible that stem cells from the blood may occasionally be capable of being turned into another cell type, such as liver cells. These were the exciting results just published from the Imperial Cancer Research Fund and Hammersmith Hospital.

Why stem cells turn into a particular type is unclear. Scientists are trying to unravel the chemical messages which, if given to them, persuade them to develop into a specific tissue. This research is complex and will take many years.

But a short cut is possible, and one that could save lives. It is wrongly called "therapeutic cloning". It involves transplanting the control centre, the nucleus, from a differentiated cell of an adult into one of these primitive cells. This could have the advantage of producing tissue of precisely the desired type. Moreover, it would be immunologically compatible with the person who donated the nucleus and would not suffer rejection. In short, an injured or sick patient, could have one of his own nuclei transferred into a spare embryonic cell from which the nucleus had been removed.

Cells derived from an embryo four or five days after fertilisation offer the most hope for creating new human tissues artificially. They are the most "plastic". Cells from a fetus, a few weeks old, are much more limited. Controversial treatment of Parkinson's disease sufferers has had partial success using fetal brain cells.

These were injected into the brain of adult patients and it is probable that neural stem cells from the fetal tissue were the key to the dramatic recovery that a few of these largely paralysed and very crippled patients experienced.

There are a vast number of possible applications using stem cell treatments. Given further research, they could help repair various damaged organs. Heart attack victims should benefit from them; stem cell injection into the heart muscle is an exciting prospect. Stem cells are likely to be valuable in treating strokes, or possibly to repair the spinal cord in paraplegics. Thousands of people suffer from diabetes - stem cells could probably be used to regrow their insulin-producing pancreatic cells. And horrendous burns or severe arthritis might be treated by replacement cells generated in the laboratory.

Professor Peter Andrews recently described his work at Sheffield University. He grew various tissues from stem cells. His pioneering work, if used in patients, could save many lives. Much of his research used stem cells taken from testicular and rather rarer cancers which oddly contain primitive embryonic cells. There is little difficulty to get ethical approval for this, because nobody worries too much about using cells from a cancer. But tissues derived from tumours are almost certainly too dangerous to use for actual treatments. There must be a risk that these cells are already genetically damaged and might revert to cancer if implanted into a person.

There is a plentiful and ideal supply of suitable cells that could be used. Embryos just a few hours old are lost naturally or by contraception every day. Treatments such as IVF produce spare embryos that are literally left to perish. Hardly any infertile patient would have any problem if their embryos were used for this research. But this kind of work has, until recently, been held up in the United Kingdom.

In 1990, there was a massive majority in both houses of parliament for the use of human embryos, derived from IVF treatments, for research into infertility, congenital disease, the causes of miscarriage and effective methods of contraception. This research continues in a regulated fashion. People find it ironic that we led the world in reproductive research because of this liberal and humane legislation, but now there are chances to actually save lives, other countries are overtaking us. We need to recognise that it would be unethical not to use this new information for the alleviation of fatal diseases.

Robert Winston, a Labour peer, is professor of fertility studies at London University.

webTitle: merchant@florence wrote it first 500 years ago

fields.headline: merchant@florence wrote it first 500 years ago
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The ubiquitous symbol of internet era communications, the @ sign used in email addresses, is actually a 500 year old invention of Italian merchants, a Rome academic has revealed.
fields.body:
The ubiquitous symbol of internet era communications, the @ sign used in email addresses, is actually a 500 year old invention of Italian merchants, a Rome academic has revealed.

Giorgio Stabile, a professor of the history of science at La Sapienza University, claims to have stumbled on the earliest known example of the symbol's use, as an indication of a measure of weight or volume.

He said the @ sign represented an amphora, a measure of capacity based on the terracotta jars used to transport grain and liquid in the ancient Mediterranean world.

The first known instance of its use, he said, occurred in a letter written by a Florentine merchant on May 4, 1536.

Sent from Seville to Rome by a trader called Francesco Lapi, the document describes the arrival in Spain of three ships bearing treasure from Latin America.

"There, an amphora of wine, which is one thirtieth of a barrel, is worth 70 or 80 ducats," Mr Lapi informs his correspondent, representing the amphora with the now familiar symbol of an "a" wrapped in its own tail.

The Spanish word for the @ sign, arroba , also indicates a weight or measure, which was equivalent, at the end of the 16th century, to 11.3kg (25 lb) or 22.7 litres (six gallons).

"Until now no one knew that the @ sign derived from this symbol, which was developed by Italian traders in a mercantile script they created between the middle ages and the renaissance," Prof Stabile said. "The loop around the 'a' is typical of that merchant script."

The professor unearthed the ancient symbol in the course of research for a visual history of the 20th century, to be published by the Treccani Encyclopedia.

He said the sign, known to modern Italian cybernauts as la chiocciola (the snail), had made its way along trade routes to northern Europe where it took on its contemporary accountancy meaning: "at the price of".

Having hopped on to English typewriter keyboards in the early 20th century, it was selected as a rarely used symbol to separate user names from domain addresses by the American internet engineer Ray Tomlinson.

Prof Stabile believes that Italian banks may possess even earlier documents bearing the symbol lying forgotten in their archives.

"The oldest example could be of great value. It could be used for publicity purposes and to enhance the prestige of the institution that owned it," he said.

Internet users of various tongues have adopted metaphors ranging from an elephant's trunk to a monkey's tail and even a cinnamon roll to describe the now ubiquitous squiggle.

The inventors of the "snail" would doubtless be proud to learn that they were the progenitors of such a successful sign, also known, somewhat unromantically in English, as "commercial at".

"No symbol is born of chance. This one has represented the entire history of navigation on the oceans and has now come to typify travel in cyberspace," Prof Stabile said.

"Venice is the maritime city that continued to use the amphora weight unit the longest, but Florence is the foremost city of banking. The race is on to see who has the oldest document."

fields.headline: Mugabe steps up farm seizures
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean government announced last night that it will step up its land seizures to take possession of 3,000 white-owned farms immediately, a move that will add to the country's growing tensions.
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean government announced last night that it will step up its land seizures to take possession of 3,000 white-owned farms immediately, a move that will add to the country's growing tensions.

President Robert Mugabe is raising the stakes by directing his government to seize such a large number of farms so quickly. Three thousand farms represent three-quarters of the country's 4,200 large-scale commercial farms that are mostly owned by whites.

In recent weeks the Mugabe government has taken legal steps to confiscate 804 farms, but last night it stated that a new, larger list of 3,000 farms would be published.

Although Mr Mugabe and other top officials said last month that poor blacks would be immediately resettled on white-owned farms, that has not yet happened.

More than 1,400 farms are currently illegally occupied by veterans of the war against Rhodesian rule and other supporters of Mr Mugabe. In the past two weeks the squatters have increased their death threats, violence and thefts against white farmers and their labour. Mr Mugabe's order that police should take no action against the farm invaders has promoted a breakdown of the rule of law.

Mr Mugabe's new threat of massive land seizures is a response to the three-day anti-government national strike that is to take place from Wednesday to Friday. The strike was initiated by a group of white farmers to protest against the lack of law and order in the country.

The strike has received crucial backing from the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) and the opposition party the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC). All commercial and industrial activity is expected to shut down.

With its announcement of increased land seizures, the Mugabe government indicated last night that it will hit out at the coalition of forces opposed to it.

"We have reached a point where enough is enough," said Jonathan Moyo, the new minister of information, last night. "The MDC and the ZCTU have become the unacceptable face of disorder in this country."

fields.headline: Clickmango founders seek new ventures
fields.standfirst:
Setback fails to deter young entrepreneurs

Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Toby Rowland and Robert Norton, the founders of clickmango, are in discussions with venture capital firm Atlas Ventures to manage new internet investments despite the winding down of their natural health products e-tailer.
fields.body:
Toby Rowland and Robert Norton, the founders of clickmango, are in discussions with venture capital firm Atlas Ventures to manage new internet investments despite the winding down of their natural health products e-tailer.

Mr Rowland, son of the late tycoon Tiny Rowland, and Mr Norton, announced plans to close clickmango this month after it failed to secure a second round of funding.

Clickmango was seeking bridging finance of £300,000 for the company to continue operation into the autumn. Both entrepreneurs said the decision to wind up clickmango was made while the company had enough cash to pay creditors and its 20 employees. The funding for dotcom companies has dried up with market scepticism about the ability of fledgling dotcoms to deliver returns.

Analysts have cited an oversupply of e-tailers and the lack of clear revenue projections as reasons for the collapse of companies like up-market fashion retailer Boo.com. Even long-established internet bookseller Amazon.com has watched its share price crash from $100 to near $30 recently, reflecting the disillusionment among investors.

Lastminute.com, the online travel retailer and financial services company Interactive Investor International have also watched their stock prices plunge since listing.

Mr Rowland, 31, said that clickmango was in discussions with several "white knights" to take over the company's operation. Clickmango stunned the City last September when it secured £3m in funding in a record eight days.

The rapid speed with which the internet start-up was able to raise funds was attributed to the experience of Mr Norton, former business development director at America Online, and Mr Rowland's background.

Clickmango was trading in a competitive market with several other natural health care websites, including large rival ThinkNatural.com, which is backed by venture capitalist Amadeus, and recently recruited retail group Kingfisher as an investor.

Clickmango was selling about £2,000 in health care products a week since the website was launched in April. It never released details of its customer numbers. "We decided the right course of action was to wind the business up in an orderly fashion without jeopardising outstanding creditors," Mr Norton, 28, said.

"We've some options with Atlas who have offered to back us in future ventures but right now it's a period of reflection and to recharge our batteries."

Mr Rowland added: "I think we want to get the next venture trading for longer than three months."

Joanna Lumley, who played Patsy Stone in the television series Absolutely Fabulous, was one of the high profile shareholders in clickmango. Ms Lumley is understood to have owned some 2% of the company after she agreed to become its figurehead.

A variety of experts, including a holistic veterinarian, were also on the clickmango website while other stars were going to provide "insights" into alternative and holistic medicine.

Ms Lumley's contract with clickmango was a two-year deal with a break clause after one year and a share of the company.

Lord Rothschild's private family trust was another investor in the group. clickmango sells products ranging from herbal teas, vitamins and natural health remedies.

fields.headline: Starting up
fields.standfirst:
Precocious schoolboys have a head start on Bill Gates with portal for teenagers

Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The internet has apparently made bucketloads of clever young people into millionaires. We hope a Rools partnership with a couple of teenage entrepreneurs, Nick Bell and Robbie Hodgekiss at Teenfront.com, will lead them to riches.
fields.body:
The internet has apparently made bucketloads of clever young people into millionaires. We hope a Rools partnership with a couple of teenage entrepreneurs, Nick Bell and Robbie Hodgekiss at Teenfront.com, will lead them to riches. We can exclusively reveal that Rools has completed an investment in a portal for teenagers that has been developed by Nick and Robbie, both aged 16.

The site was launched in 1998 and for two years acted as a low-key bulletin board, providing links to other sites and cheat information for video games. It is now a fairly comprehensive portal and looks as professional as many sites where large sums of money have been spent on development, offering a range of services from an advice column to product reviews and horoscopes. It has also developed links to leading online services.

Until now, it has not actively pursued revenue streams, but has attracted the attention of several advertisers wishing to target the youth market.

And all this has been achieved on a budget of hundreds of pounds rather than thousands and with relatively limited time. All of the work has been done after school, at weekends or during the holidays. The individuals behind it are impressive - one started his first internet site when he was 12 - and they have a great understanding of the internet and powerful business brains.

The market for online services for teenagers is frenzied, with the launch of a number of big players such as MyKindaPlace, Wowgo and Swizzle. Drawing from the existing business to business and business to consumer abbreviations, the sector has developed its own acronym - B2T for business to teenagers.

The sector is crowded, but lacks a reasonable sized player that is for teenagers by teenagers (T2T perhaps). We came across Teenfront during some market research on teenage portals. The site appeared well designed and well organised, but what attracted us most was the net work of regular teenage contributors. It demonstrates a natural understanding of the teenage market - although we're not convinced that all young people are as keen on Dire Straits as Nick and Robbie are.

The site's closeness to its audience is the most important element of the partnership. Teenfront gives us a direct insight into teenagers and helps us develop a service that is most relevant to them - after all, none of us is as young as we used to be. Nick and Robbie face the challenge of developing the site and translating a serious hobby into a larger enterprise. They plan to continue working on Teenfront while studying for A-levels and, after that, at university. Bill Gates started Microsoft as a university student, so these guys have a head start.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools.com a service that enables teenagers to buy online without a credit card.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Co-op rebrands travel shops
fields.body:
Co-op rebrands travel shops

The Co-op is to spend £20m on rebranding 300 branches of Co-op Travel care and launching a marketing campaign. New-look stores will be rolled out next month along with the launch of stores in five locations offering more private seating where people can discuss holiday plans. A new £1m call centre will aim to increase direct holiday sales from £13m last year to £30m by 2002.

Threat to stores

Three of Britain's top five supermarkets could disappear in the next five years as overseas rivals muscle in on the food retailing sector, a study by retail analyst Verdict Research reveals today.

Murdoch move

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp is expected to pay several hundred million marks for a small stake in German commercial television company Kirch Media KGaA, reports the Süddeutsche Zeitung paper, which said the two sides were near the completion of talks.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

The Consumers' Association is demanding that Gordon Brown hold a summit with the insurance industry to investigate the way in which firms hand out windfall profits, known as orphan assets - which are estimated to be worth £20bn. The CA's demand has been provoked by the plan from insurer AXA for distribution of its orphan funds, worth £1.7bn.

Claranet, the UK's largest independent ISP, is poised to move parts of its telecoms infrastructure abroad to protect its blue chip clients from potential vetting by the security services.

Britain's leading out-of- town shopping centres are planning to open for longer on Sundays in a move that could lead to a clash with union Usdaw.

Sunday Times

After a collapse in its share price, falling sales, a cut in the dividend and poorly received new collections, board members say Marks & Spencer's chief Peter Salsbury is to be axed.

The Treasury is concerned about the prospects of a rise in interest rates when the monetary policy committee meets this week, according to the newspaper.

A power struggle to dominate the transport sector is about to break out, with SNCF, the state-owned French transport group, in talks to pay more than £100m for FirstGroup's London bus operations.

Sunday Telegraph

Innogy, the renamed UK arm of National Power, is in talks with Warren Buffett about a £1bn bid for Northern Electric and Gas, the power group owned by Berkshire Hathaway, his investment vehicle. Northern, which has 1.5m customers, is also being eyed by Scottish & Southern Energy and TXU, the US company which owns Energy Group.

M&S has ordered its clothing suppliers to cut prices by 2% immediately in an effort to shore up its low profits and shrinking margins.

The competition commission is to urge the government to force the largest supermarkets to reveal their prices on the net.

Sunday Business

Michael Green, chairman of Carlton Communications, is trying to buy Scottish Media Group's television assets. He hopes for an agreed deal but has not ruled out a hostile bid. Mr Green is keen to snap up the remaining commercial television franchises available after Granada Media's acquisition of United News & Media's ITV assets last week.

Cadbury Schweppes is considering a bid for Keebler, the second largest American biscuit maker.

Mail on Sunday

SmithKline Beecham faces a backlash from American shareholders who have objected to a share option package worth up to £15m being approved for chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier. Investors will vote on directors' pay packages at the meeting today called to approve the merger with Glaxo Wellcome.

IoS

Sir Alan Sugar has received an offer to buy most of his 40% stake in Tottenham Hotspur football club from investment group Enic, led by Joe Lewis, the Bahamas-based billionaire. Enic is understood to be offering 80p a share for a 29.9% stake in the listed Premier League group.

The Royal Mint, which produces all the coins used in UK, has suffered an enormous slump in its profits for the 1999-2000 tax year - seeing it massively underperform targets set by the Treasury. Profits at the Royal Mint fell from almost £6.3m in 1998-99 to a mere £668,000 last year.

webTitle: Barak braces for latest no-confidence vote

fields.headline: Barak braces for latest no-confidence vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: After failing to make peace with the Palestinians, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, started yesterday the even more daunting task of trying to make peace with his own people before a crucial parliamentary vote.
fields.body:
After failing to make peace with the Palestinians, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, started yesterday the even more daunting task of trying to make peace with his own people before a crucial parliamentary vote.

He made some headway when his foreign minister, David Levy, retreated from his threat to vote against the government in today's no-confidence vote, and agreed to defer his resignation until later in the week.

Mr Levy's concession tips the odds in favour of the Israeli prime minister in today's vote. But it can not begin to compensate for the fact that Mr Barak has no government; three parties quit his coalition on the eve of his departure for the Camp David summit.

Mr Levy's threat to resign is a further sign of rightwing anger with Mr Barak's conduct during the peace process.

Although the Camp David summit broke up after 15 days with no agreement, the right has been unable to stomach the concessions he was willing to make for peace. The most contentious of these was Mr Barak's readiness to share control of Jerusalem, with the Palestinians being granted sovereignty of far-flung neighbourhoods in the north and east of the city, occupied by Israel since 1967.

However, because the offer fell far short of the Palestinian demand for control of the al-Aqsa mosque, the third-holiest shrine in Islam, Yasser Arafat turned it down.

His refusal allowed Mr Barak to be portrayed as the hero of the failed peace talks - with Mr Arafat once again cast in the familiar role of villain. That characterisation - offered by Mr Clinton last week - was reinforced at the weekend when the US president appeared on Israeli television to heap fulsome praise on Mr Barak.

However, Mr Clinton's remarks badly backfired. Israeli commentators yesterday accused Mr Clinton of setting back the peace process. They say his threat to review Washington's relationship with the Palestinians should Mr Arafat declare a state later this year has compromised Mr Clinton's ability to broker a future agreement.

"It could be they told Clinton that Channel 1 is a closed-circuit television, and the Palestinians can't see it. Otherwise it would be hard to understand the tone and music of the president," Hemi Shalev wrote in the Ma'ariv newspaper yesterday. He called Mr Clinton's remarks "a huge step for Ehud Barak, but a very small step for the peace process - backwards."

Dismay at Mr Clinton's remarks, which included an oblique reference to moving the American embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem and a threat to withhold $400m (£266m) in US aid, continued to spread throughout the region yesterday.

The Palestinian spokeswoman, Hanan Ashrawi said Washington could no longer be considered an honest broker. "America has come out of the closet," she said. "Palestinians see these statements as the true face of the US, and that the so-called even-handed sponsor of the talks is very blatantly one-sided and biased."

She accused Mr Clinton of pandering to US domestic opinion, ahead of this year's presidential elections, and Hillary Rodham Clinton's race for the New York Senate.

webTitle: Vodafone adviser poached as firm targets Europe

fields.headline: Vodafone adviser poached as firm targets Europe
fields.trailText: Providence Equity Partners has poached the highly rated co-leader of Morgan Stanley's European telecoms group as part of a plan to invest up to $1bn in British and Continental start-ups.
fields.body:
Providence Equity Partners has poached the highly rated co-leader of Morgan Stanley's European telecoms group as part of a plan to invest up to $1bn in British and Continental start-ups.

John Hahn, who advised on some of Europe's largest telecoms deals, including the $160bn Vodafone/Mannesmann merger, becomes managing director of the private equity group. Hahn has brought with him Biswajit Subramanian from Morgan Stanley, plus Anne Farlow, a telecoms and technology expert drafted in from Electra Partners, another private equity firm.

Hahn said he was excited by the prospect of working with a company that had a "sterling US [investment] performance" to develop a European telecoms market worth some $100bn to new entrants.

US-based Providence Equity has begun to build a name over here through its involvement with First Telecom which merged with Atlantic Telecom and VoiceStream Wireless, just bought by Deutsche Telekom.

Paul Salem, mastermind of Providence Equity's advance into Europe, says the $1bn will be spent over three to five years on telecoms and internet-infrastructure ventures.

He said: "The telecommunications market in Europe is experiencing dramatic growth and we see tremendous investment opportunities. We have achieved annual returns of 145% over the last decade and have warned investors we cannot keep that up. But with John [Hahn] we now have the best telecoms team in Europe."

Providence Equity, which first opened an office in London last year, is one of dozens of private equity and venture capital groups lured across the Atlantic by privatisation and liberalisation, but is one of few to specialise in technology, particularly telecoms.

Salem says Providence Equity will focus on start-up businesses where the main challenge is to find human, not financial capital. "John will play a key role here because he knows everyone in the industry," Salem said.

Providence Equity claims to have been successful in all but one of the 52 companies in which it has invested more than $2bn since it opened for business in the early 1990s.

 Germany's telecoms regulator expects only four bidders to win third generation mobile phone licences at the end of the German auction starting today, according to German newspaper reported.

"It's quite possible that we'll have four bidders in the end taking over three blocks of frequency each," Klaus-Dieter Scheurle was quoted as saying.

webTitle: Nomura makes knockout bid for control of Hyder

fields.headline: Nomura makes knockout bid for control of Hyder
fields.trailText: Nomura, the Japanese bank that is to run the Dome, is poised to deliver a knockout blow in its battle for control of Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, by raising its bid well above the controversial £464m offer from American competitor Western Power Distribution.
fields.body:
Nomura, the Japanese bank that is to run the Dome, is poised to deliver a knockout blow in its battle for control of Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, by raising its bid well above the controversial £464m offer from American competitor Western Power Distribution.

The board of Hyder, which owns Welsh Water and Swalec, the south Wales electricity distributor, meets later today to consider an informal approach on Friday from Nomura indicating it is prepared to raise its initial 260p a share offer to nearer 320p.

That would force WPD, which still awaits clearance from the UK competition authorities for its 300p bid, to rethink its tactics in the absence of a signal from Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, over whether he approves its complicated offer.

The long-running battle for Hyder, which has debts of £1.9bn, is seen as critical to the prospects for further consolidation in the UK utilities industry, in which water companies are seeking greater competition by splitting assets from day to day operations and several electricity companies are up for sale.

Mr Byers is due to decide within the next few days, possibly as early as today, whether to refer WPD's bid - which has already been cleared by the European Union - to the competition commission.

But Mr Byers, about to relaunch the DTI as a government centre for promoting risk-taking entrepreneurship, has let the timetable for the Hyder bid process slip so far that the Nomura bid could lapse on Wednesday.

It is understood that the City's takeover panel has indicated to Nomura, whose venture arm is run by Guy Hands, architect of the successful Dome bid, that its £403m offer cannot be extended beyond the Wednesday deadline.

The bank, worried by this potential outcome if Mr Byers further delays his decision on referral, told the Hyder board on Friday that it could raise its bid. Hyder originally backed Nomura's bid but recently decided to opt for break-up strategy, selling off the water and power businesses separately.

"The danger is that if Stephen Byers is working to his own timetable the two bids could fall this week," an industry insider said.

"Nomura might not be able to extend its original bid beyond Wednesday, the WPD offer might be referred and the Hyder board could revert to the minority position in favour of a break-up."

Wales-based unions fear that any break-up could lead to further job losses than the 1,000 now being implemented by Hyder. They - and the national assembly for Wales - have backed the Nomura bid because the Japanese ban will keep Hyder intact.

WPD, which already owns South-West Electricity, has courted controversy in its bid by tabling plans for the day-to-day running of Welsh Water to be handed over to partner United Utilities, and for its assets to be parked in a mutual.

fields.headline: 'Caring' Bush uncovers iron fist
fields.standfirst:
Republican militants are gagged as 2,100 delegates and 15,000 journalists gather for Philadelphia convention

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush has promised to use "iron fist rule" to ensure that this week's Republican national convention is free from the hard-edged conservatism and political culture wars which marked the party's aggressive style in the 1990s.
fields.body:
George W Bush has promised to use "iron fist rule" to ensure that this week's Republican national convention is free from the hard-edged conservatism and political culture wars which marked the party's aggressive style in the 1990s.

After two shattering defeats at the hands of Bill Clinton in 1992 and 1996 - the first of which ousted Mr Bush's father from the White House - the Texas governor has made it clear that he intends to leave nothing to chance this week. He plans to use the convention to highlight a Republican party apparently united behind his "compassionate conservative" agenda as it seeks to reclaim the US presidency.

The principal Republican aim in Philadelphia will be to choreograph four solid days of political stagecraft, with minimal spontaneity, all in the cause of replacing the party's divisive image with a friendlier, more inclusive message.

More than 45,000 people including 15,000 journalists, are attending the convention. There are only 2,100 delegates. The Democrats hold their convention in Los Angeles in two weeks' time.

Mr Bush will use his acceptance speech in Philadelphia on Thursday night to reach out to independent and Democratic voters with a series of carefully crafted broad messages. But the week's emphasis on a new Republican "inclusivity" will not extend to allowing delegates or television viewers to see and hear from the party's diehard conservatives, pro-abortion militants or the congressional hawks who tried to impeach Bill Clinton.

The emphasis on keeping the party on message was a "an indication of the Republican party's desire to win," Mr Bush said as he campaigned in Ohio yesterday. He was determined, he said, to avoid a repetition of the 1992 Houston Republican convention, which is remembered for the militant speeches from the platform by rightwingers Pat Buchanan and Pat Robertson, rather than for President George Bush's re-election effort.

"A lot of people said the '92 convention set a negative tone, and that it sent a divisive message for the country," he said. There were "no slights intended" in the decision to keep conservative militants off the platform this week, but "this is a different time, a different approach."

Mr Bush's determination to promote the Republicans as a "big tent" party will be underscored tonight when General Colin Powell, the former head of the US armed forces in the Gulf war, is given the prime-time television slot in the evening session. Tomorrow, in one of the few decisions that have been left to risk this week, the slot will be filled by John McCain, another of the handful of Republicans with mass non-partisan appeal.

Mr McCain has arrived early in Philadelphia, where yesterday he gave Mr Bush his qualified endorsement at a so-called "alternative convention" at the University of Pennsylvania. The Arizona senator said it was "no secret" that he disagreed with Mr Bush on campaign finance reform, but the two men agreed on far more things than divided them.

As part of his effort to promote himself as a candidate with electoral appeal beyond his own party, Mr Bush said yesterday that he would use Thursday's speech to "send a broadened message". He underlined that aim by ensuring that his lieutenants beat off a last-minute attempt by party conservatives to change the draft election platform by pledging to abolish the federal department of education, an obsession of rightwingers.

He has also sent out a message to delegates that he does not want them to use their speeches to mount personal attacks on Hillary Clinton or to concentrate on attacking the Democrats. "I will needle my opponent, but we don't have a 'let's-tear-down night' or a 'slash-and-burn night' or a night that subjects the other side to ridicule," he said of the week's agenda.

While Mr Bush focused his efforts on trying to appear new, open and conciliatory, he provided fresh ammunition to those who charge that he is a surrogate for his father in a grudge rematch with the Clinton-Gore Democrats.

"I'm proud to be George Bush's son. And people are going to hear at the convention how proud I am," he said.

webTitle: Nissan cuts put jobs at risk

fields.headline: Nissan cuts put jobs at risk
fields.standfirst: Car maker plans to spend £200m less a year on British components because of strong pound
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest car manufacturer, Nissan, warned last night that it planned to spend over £200m less a year on British components in a move which could endanger thousands of jobs.
fields.byline: Terry Macalister  and  Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo
fields.body:
Britain's biggest car manufacturer, Nissan, warned last night that it planned to spend over £200m less a year on British components in a move which could endanger thousands of jobs.

The decision comes as Carlos Ghosn, president of the Japanese-owned company which will build 240,000 cars this year in Sunderland, meets the prime minister today for crisis talks on the strength of the pound. Nissan is already threatening to take production of a new Micra model abroad with the loss of 1,000 north-east jobs unless the government stumps up £50m in aid.

Mr Blair is believed to be ready to look at measures which could offset the impact of the strength of the pound, but a Downing Street spokesman declined to comment ahead of the meeting.

Toyota and other British car makers have already cut their UK contribution. Toyota will take 30% of the parts for its Derby plant from mainland Europe, up from 20%. Honda's Swindon plant will receive 35% of its parts from euroland, up from 25%.

However Nissan's will hurt most because this year it expects to build more cars than its rivals and had traditionally sourced more materials locally.

A Nissan spokesman said: "Until now we have bought 70% of our components in Britain. But as part of our plans to reduce overall costs by 30% to combat the strong pound we will significantly reduce this."

The car manufacturer declined to say what the new level would be but insiders believed it would be about 20% less in future, in monetary terms over £200m.

Component manufacturers are desperately dependent on individual car companies for their business. The 5,000 jobs at Sunderland are said effectively to create another 15,000 jobs around the rest of the economy.

Nissan is under tremendous pressure to cut its costs because it exports three quarters of the cars it produces and has a tough president keen to rebuild profitability.

Sourcing components from abroad is part of a wider plan to cut 30% off Nissan's British cost base in an effort to counter further the impact of a strong pound. The car group also plans to squeeze more productivity out of its high performing workforce and is in discussions with union leaders about changing shift patterns.

Mr Blair and industry secretary Stephen Byers will be tackled on their position over the euro. Mr Ghosn believes a lack of action over the currency is making a difficult position worse.

The strength of sterling, which has gained more than 10% against the euro since 1998, is hurting Japanese manufacturers with bases in Britain. The European operations of Nissan, Toyota and Honda all fell into the red last year, largely because of the currency inbalance with euroland.

Although few firms are willing to upset consumer opinion by openly backing the euro, leading inward investors have urged Mr Blair to clarify the government's position and many are already quietly trimming their presence in Britain.

Other companies have decided to quit all together. Sumitomo Electric Wiring announced earlier this month that it will halt operations at its Sunderland plant, which have been hurt by the strong pound. Leading electronics manfucturers have also indicated that exchange rates will play a substantial role in deciding where they produce the next generation of digital televisions.

Britain ought to be the obvious choice for such manufacturing operations as it will be among the first countries in Europe to start digital broadcasts, but the strong pound could outweigh other factors.

"It's simple business logic that you don't make new investments in an area where the strong currency means you are likely to make a loss," said a senior executive at a top Japanese electronics firm.

webTitle: Little Irish comedy that is wowing LA's finest

fields.headline: Little Irish comedy that is wowing LA's finest
fields.standfirst: How two actors with a cracking script turned a no-budget provincial production into a West End sell-out
fields.trailText: If someone had told actors Conleth Hill and Sean Campion when they were resting six months ago that Tom Hanks would soon be queuing at the stage door for their autographs, they would have told them to "go away and boil your head".
fields.body:
If someone had told actors Conleth Hill and Sean Campion when they were resting six months ago that Tom Hanks would soon be queuing at the stage door for their autographs, they would have told them to "go away and boil your head".

But in the past few giddy months since the no-budget little Irish comedy Stones in His Pockets opened without fanfare in the West End, a procession of Hollywood's finest have beaten a path to their dressing room door at the New Ambassadors theatre.

Hanks was followed by Dustin Hoffman, Calista Flockhart, Tracey Ullman, Roger Moore and, in the past few days, by Mel Brooks and Anne Bancroft. When Kevin Spacey arrived in London last week, he declared: "I've got to see these guys, everybody is talking about them."

Stones in His Pockets is the sort of play that actors dream of - the one that will catapult them from provincial obscurity to fame - the single bravura performance that can make a career but which rarely happens these days in a West End dominated by the bankable and the bland. It is also theatre at its purest and best - two actors alone on a bare stage with nothing but a box of tricks and a cracking script.

Between them Hill and Campion play everyone on the set of a Hollywood film being shot in Ireland, from their "own" characters - two down-on-their-luck chancers - to Ol' Micky, the last surviving extra from The Quiet Man and the movie's American star, not dissimilar to Julia Roberts. It is these lightning shifts of character combined with writer Marie Jones's warm, scabrous wit which make the play such a charmer.

On word of mouth alone it has become London's most profitable show, selling out every night, and will transfer at the end of the month to the larger Duke of York's theatre round the corner. Co-producer Adam Kenwright, a nephew of impresario Bill, joked that the costs of moving it will be huge. "We'll have to hire an estate car," he said.

Now it is also heading to Broadway, where it will open next year on St Patrick's Day. And with such a fertile line in filmic in-jokes Hollywood is beckoning too.

Its appeal is not, however, confined to dewy-eyed Americans. In the 18 months since it first opened at the Lyric theatre in Belfast, and then transferred to the Tricycle in Kilburn, north London, Stones in His Pockets has been translated into French, German, Spanish, Portuguese and Italian. Jones returned last weekend from Stockholm after seeing the Swedish version. "I just smiled and nodded and told them the jokes were much better in Swedish," she said.

Being an actor herself - she plays George Best's alcoholic mother in the new film about the errant soccer star - Jones wanted to write something that would be fun to be in.

"But the real reason I've got them playing 15 parts between them was that we were skint," she said. We hadn't a bob to put it on at the Lyric, that's why Ian McElhinney [the director] did it with no real set or anything other than a line of old shoes. That was a stroke of genius."

A fortysomething mother-of-three born in the shadow of Belfast's shipyard, Jones has become one of Ireland's favourite playwrights the hard way. A champion of community theatre - through which she rose - her last play, Women on the Verge of HRT, was a huge hit in the regions and in Scotland but did not do so well in London, where references to Daniel O'Donnell, the country and western singer its two middle-aged protagonists lust after, went way over metropolitan heads.

Jones's idea for Stones came from a documentary she made about the shooting of Shane Connaughton's film, The Playboys, starring Albert Finney and Robyn Wright-Penn, and its impact on his tiny home village of Redhills, in Co Cavan.

"Redhills is just a few houses round a little green," she said. "It's not so much sleepy as comatose, and into this tiny wee place a Hollywood circus descended, with stars in caravans bigger than houses. The locals' lives were turned upside down."

While the play is set in the more touristy Kerry, and has closer parallels with the Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman epic, Far and Away, Jones wanted to show how the rural communities these films celebrate are being pushed rapidly towards extinction.

Hill, who was named Irish actor of the year for his performance, said Jones's down-to-earth attitude was the key to the play's phenomenal success.

"You couldn't work with better, more unpretentious people. It was just great crack putting it together. We have something really special and I just want it to go on and on. Sometimes things change as they get bigger, but hopefully it won't be ruined."

webTitle: BSkyB plans to snatch ITN contract

fields.headline: BSkyB plans to snatch ITN contract
fields.trailText: BSkyB announced yesterday that it intends to snatch the lucrative contract to supply ITV's news programmes from ITN, just two days before its rival is due to launch a 24-hour news channel.
fields.body:
BSkyB announced yesterday that it intends to snatch the lucrative contract to supply ITV's news programmes from ITN, just two days before its rival is due to launch a 24-hour news channel.

Sky News, whose round-the-clock operation is 11 years old, said it could provide a far better service than ITN, which has made ITV's news programmes since the channel began. ITN accused Sky of "running scared" of the ITN venture, which starts tomorrow, complete with a resurrected News at Ten.

BSkyB, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, went on the offensive yesterday with a story in Sunday Business revealing it is to seek approval by the independent television commission (ITC) as a "nominated news provider", a prerequisite to pitch for the ITV news contract.

The broadcaster then issued a statement by the head of Sky News, Nick Pollard, saying it would pose a serious challenge to ITN. "Sky News has built up a fantastic reputation for the quality of its journalism and the speed and breadth of its coverage," he said. "We feel we could offer a very attractive proposition to ITV and are sure our record as a TV news broadcaster provides the strongest evidence in support of our application."

ITN was not surprised by the revelation: Sky News has bid for every major terrestrial news contract in Britain when they have come up over the past 10 years. "We are launching a news channel on Tuesday which will seriously undermine the economics of Sky News, so it's not surprising that they are 'revealing' their interest in the ITV news contract at this stage," said an ITN spokesman.

The news came a few days after ITV announced it was taking the ITC to court over the regulator's demand that it bring forward the 11pm news which, along with Sir Trevor McDonald's 6.30pm bulletin, replaced the long-running News at Ten last year. That institution returns on ITN's 24-hour news channel tomorrow, but will be seen only by cable and digital television viewers.

While Sky is probably better placed now to win a terrestrial news contract - it has recently won a clutch of industry awards - its track record in previous bids suggests it would be unlikely to grab the ITV prize from ITN, in which the major ITV companies have a controlling stake.

But if Sky won the ITV contract, it would prompt a row among its rivals and some politicians over Mr Murdoch's influence on the British media. It could also start a bidding war for some of the most famous names in television news: Sir Trevor, the face of ITN, could be enticed to bolster Sky's line-up.
