webTitle: Genetic chickens get DNA copyright tag

fields.headline: Genetic chickens get DNA copyright tag
fields.standfirst:
Biotech firm plans to create strain with extra large breasts for more meat

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: A US biotech company plans to create a strain of chicken genetically engineered to have an extra large breast to yield more meat, with a DNA copyright tag inserted among its genes to stop anyone breeding it without permission.
fields.body:
A US biotech company plans to create a strain of chicken genetically engineered to have an extra large breast to yield more meat, with a DNA copyright tag inserted among its genes to stop anyone breeding it without permission.

If successful, the firm, AviGenics, based on the campus of the University of Georgia in Athens, would be one of the first to enable GM meat to appear on US supermarket shelves, opening up new tensions with Europe over genetic engineering in food.

AviGenics is already one of three US companies racing to turn poultry into drugs factories - adding human genes to chickens to create "transgenic" birds which would then produce human proteins such as insulin in their egg whites.

AviGenics claims to have already created transgenic roosters which have successfully passed on to new generations of chicks the human gene for a substance called alpha interferon, used to treat hepatitis and certain cancers.

The company hopes to use the same technology to create a new kind of everyday eating chicken. Instead of adding human genes to make birds lay drug-rich eggs, genes - not necessarily human - would be added, or chicken genes removed, to give the birds bigger breast muscles, faster growing rates or greater disease resistance.

To keep proprietorial control over these valuable new animals, AviGenics is working on a novel kind of trademark, a unique sequence of DNA which would be introduced into the chicken's genes. The "trademark" would not only be locked into each of the chicken's millions of cells, but would be handed on to the bird's offspring indefinitely.

Contacted by the Guardian last week, the chief executive of AviGenics, Carl Marhaver, confirmed that his company was working to create genetically engineered and trademarked poultry for the dining table, but did not want to comment further.

Referring to recent protests in Minneapolis during a conference on animal genetics, he said he did not want the firm "to become an exhibit in an anti-GM article".

AviGenics does not plan to raise and market GM chickens itself, but to make its new strains available to large, well-established poultry breeders.

The science was developed by Robert Ivarie, professor of genetics at the university and co-founder of AviGenics. He could not be contacted for comment but the promotion on the company's website says: "Poultry is one of our most important meat sources, outranking beef consumption by an increasingly cost and health conscious public.

"With AviGenics-engineered transgenes that control muscle fibre development, proprietary lines of chickens can be created that grow larger breast muscles, enhancing white and, eventually, dark meat yields.

"Poultry breeders are concerned about improving the quality of life for their flocks. Genetic modification of the chicken genome will eventually impact disease resistance, improving the quality of life for birds."

Echoing earlier efforts by GM plant firms to keep a grip on their products by developing "terminator genes", AviGenics says it can use DNA trademarks to control the proliferation of its chickens once they are sold on to breeders.

"Unique DNA sequences can be engineered and introduced into the poultry genome to indelibly mark valuable transgenic and breeder lines, effectively acting as genetic encryption devices," it says.

Until now it had been thought that the first GM animals likely to reach the consumer were farmed fish, genetically engineered to grow faster and bigger or to survive in colder waters than their natural cousins. Research into GM fish is particularly advanced in Canada.

Concerns have already been voiced about the dangers of GM fish escaping and mating with their wild counterparts. But proponents of GM chickens could argue that centuries of selective breeding have already produced birds as different from their wild ancestors as a musclebound GM superchicken would be from one of today's standard broilers.

In the short term, AviGenics investment in GM chickens for food seems to depend on its success or failure in producing GM chickens to make drugs.

Mr Marhaver said AviGenics had made great strides in making hens which laid alpha interferon eggs, and was now expanding its flocks to gear up for commercial production of the drug, the annual market for which is worth about a billion pounds in the US alone.

Two other US companies, GeneWorks LLC and TransXenoGen, are also preparing to launch commercially sized flocks of drug egg laying chickens. TransXenoGen plans to seek a listing on London's Alternative Investment Market.

The technology behind genetic engineering of birds is difficult and sceptics point out that the companies working with chickens, citing commercial secrecy, have been coy about publishing their work in scientific journals.

But if chickens can be made to lay the golden eggs of high-value pharmaceuticals, they will be more cost-effective for would-be "pharmers" than other, existing, GM animals being developed to produce drugs in their milk, such as sheep, cows, goats and rabbits.

webTitle: Pentagon sideshow is pelted by Democrats

fields.headline: Pentagon sideshow is pelted by Democrats
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Pentagon flirted openly with the Republican party yesterday by staging a military trade show less than a mile from the party's National Convention which opens in Philadelphia today.
fields.body:
The Pentagon flirted openly with the Republican party yesterday by staging a military trade show less than a mile from the party's National Convention which opens in Philadelphia today.

The Democrats angrily claimed that the move was a breach of policy separating politics and the military.

The arms exhibition was held at Philadelphia's naval shipyards. Only Republican party members and their guests were admitted to view a range of equipment which included the revolutionary but troubled V-22 helicopter-plane hybrid and equipment used by marine chemical- and biological-attack response teams. Journalists were barred at the gates by uniformed and plainclothes policemen.

Democrats demanded to know how much public money had been spent on staging the event at a time when 6,300 US troops receive so little income they they are on food stamp support. The critics scoffed at the Pentagon's claims that the arms show was not part of the actual party convention.

"It is something that's contemporaneous with the Republican National Convention," the defence department spokesman, Kenneth Bacon, argued. "It's not adjacent - it's not right on the grounds where the convention is being held. It's nearby, but not on the grounds."

Ike Skelton, the most senior Democrat on the House Armed Services committee, said that argument was "a difficult distinction for many people to make... There is no event in American politics more partisan than a national political convention".

The exhibition marks the first time the Pentagon has appeared alongside the giants of corporate America at a party convention and brings into the open a long-running relationship of lobbying and influence-brokering.

The presence of the V-22 Osprey is a vivid example. The controversial aircraft, with tilting rotors allowing fast vertical and horizontal flight, has crashed three times in the past decade. But the US Marine Corps has succeeded in keeping the programme going despite fierce congressional opposition to its high cost and dubious safety record.

Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential contender, tried to kill the project when he was defence secretary under President Bush, his new boss's father. The V-22's appearance in Philadelphia could be interpreted as a not-so-gentle reminder from the Pentagon that, in matters deemed to involve national security, the politicians do not always get their way.

The marines also rolled out an amphibious vehicle and anti-chemical and biological warfare equipment. The air force sent its unmanned surveillance aircraft, the Predator, while the army sent an Apache attack helicopter and a tactical missile defence system.

Charles Lewis, the head of the Washington-based Centre for Public Integrity, described the juxtaposition of soldiers and party delegates as "awkward". The ban on such mingling has been a matter of precedent and policy rather than the law, but Mr Lewis argued: "If there isn't a rule against this, it seems to me there ought to be."

The defence secretary, William Cohen, yesterday defended the decision to hold the arms show. He said it had the backing of two Philadelphia Democrats, a congressman, Robert Brady, and the city's mayor, John Street. Mr Cohen, a Republican serving in Mr Clinton's cabinet, invited the Democrats to host a similar arms show at their own convention in Los Angeles in two weeks' time, but Mr Skelton rejected the idea, saying it would "give the appearance of impropriety".

Newspaper reports yesterday quoted some senior military officers expressing unease about the progressive crumbling of the "firewall" between party politics and the armed forces. One, talking to the New York Times, referred to the display as "the Philadelphia fiasco".

News of the show shared newspaper space yesterday with reports of a new food-aid scheme that the Pentagon has proposed to help feed low-income troops. The aim of the plan is to wean poor soldiers off food stamps, the most basic form of welfare support.

"It is something that's contemporaneous with the Republican National Convention," the defence department spokesman, Kenneth Bacon, argued. "It's not adjacent - it's not right on the grounds where the convention is being held. It's nearby, but not on the grounds." Ike Skelton, the most senior Democrat on the House Armed Services committee, said that argument was "a difficult distinction for many people to make... There is no event in American politics more partisan than a national political convention". The exhibition marks the first time the Pentagon has appeared alongside the giants of corporate America at a party convention and brings into the open a long-running relationship of lobbying and influence-brokering. The presence of the V-22 Osprey is a vivid example. The controversial aircraft, with tilting rotors allowing fast vertical and horizontal flight, has crashed three times in the past decade. But the US Marine Corps has succeeded in keeping the programme going despite fierce congressional opposition to its high cost and dubious safety record. Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential contender, tried to kill the project when he was defence secretary under President Bush, his new boss's father. The V-22's appearance in Philadelphia could be interpreted as a not-so-gentle reminder from the Pentagon that, in matters deemed to involve national security, the politicians do not always get their way. The marines also rolled out an amphibious vehicle and anti-chemical and biological warfare equipment. The air force sent its unmanned surveillance aircraft, the Predator, while the army sent an Apache attack helicopter and a tactical missile defence system. Charles Lewis, the head of the Washington-based Centre for Public Integrity, described the juxtaposition of soldiers and party delegates as "awkward". The ban on such mingling has been a matter of precedent and policy rather than the law, but Mr Lewis argued: "If there isn't a rule against this, it seems to me there ought to be." The defence secretary, William Cohen, yesterday defended the decision to hold the arms show. He said it had the backing of two Philadelphia Democrats, a congressman, Robert Brady, and the city's mayor, John Street. Mr Cohen, a Republican serving in Mr Clinton's cabinet, invited the Democrats to host a similar arms show at their own convention in Los Angeles in two weeks' time, but Mr Skelton rejected the idea, saying it would "give the appearance of impropriety". Newspaper reports yesterday quoted some senior military officers expressing unease about the progressive crumbling of the "firewall" between party politics and the armed forces. One, talking to the New York Times, referred to the display as "the Philadelphia fiasco". News of the show shared newspaper space yesterday with reports of a new food-aid scheme that the Pentagon has proposed to help feed low-income troops. The aim of the plan is to wean poor soldiers off food stamps, the most basic form of welfare support.

fields.trailText: Sperm decision for murderer
fields.body:
Sperm decision for murderer

A murderer will tomorrow learn whether he has won his high court battle to donate sperm for his wife to become pregnant by artificial insemination. Mr Justice Forbes will deliver his judgment on Gavin Mellor, 29, who was jailed for life in 1995 for the killing of George Sims, 71, a holder of an Africa Star for service in the second world war, as he walked home from a working men's club in Crewe, Cheshire.

Joyce grandson calls for ban

Stephen Joyce, the grandson of James Joyce, has called for a ban on Molly Bloom, a Musical Dream, based on the last chapter of Ulysses where Molly recalls her sexual past. The show was planned for the Edinburgh festival fringe on Wednesday.
Kirsty Scott

60 rescued after rig leak

Sixty oil workers were evacuated by a rescue helicopter from RAF Lossiemouth yesterday after a gas leak on the Galaxy 3 rig, 125 miles off the coast of Aberdeen. Twenty-two staff remained on board to bring the leak under control.
Kirsty Scott

Dying man found at airport

A man has died after being found unconscious in a toilet cubicle in the third floor of Gatwick south terminal.

Three ticket holders shared last night's £13.2m rollover national lottery jackpot, with the numbers 29, 30, 33, 37, 45 and 48. The bonus was 15. One ticketholder won the £250,000 jackpot in the Thunderball game. The numbers were 6, 11, 17, 18 and 21. The Thunderball number was 1.

fields.headline: MP accused over shareholdings
fields.trailText: Robert Sheldon, chairman of the Commons standards and privileges committee, has been referred to the parliamentary commissioner for standards by a Tory MP over allegations that he has failed to declare all his shareholdings.
fields.body:
Robert Sheldon, chairman of the Commons standards and privileges committee, has been referred to the parliamentary commissioner for standards by a Tory MP over allegations that he has failed to declare all his shareholdings.

The MP, Ian Bruce, has also claimed in a letter to the commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, that Mr Sheldon breached Commons rules by failing to mention his shareholding in textile firms when making Commons speeches on the plight of manufacturing.

In Mr Bruce's complaint, Mr Sheldon is accused of failing to disclose fully in the register of members' interests companies which had combined shareholder funds of almost £1.5m according to their 1998 accounts.

Although Mr Sheldon clearly long-listed two of his companies in his entry in the register, Mr Bruce argues that he should have registered a third company, Tonrose Ltd, a firm which supplies bed linen. Mr Sheldon refers to Tonrose in his 1999 entry, but apparently one of his other companies, Acronyl, had a large stake in Tonrose as far back as 1992.

Mr Sheldon denies any wrongdoing.

fields.headline: Whitehall split on cloning decision
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics<
fields.trailText: A row between the Department of Health and the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, is holding back a decision on the cloning of human embyros.
fields.body:
A row between the Department of Health and the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, is holding back a decision on the cloning of human embyros.

Government sources acknowledged the department was less enthusiastic about the experiments, which would bring criticism from religious groups.

Both the department and Lord Sainsbury have for six weeks been studying a report from the government's chief medical officer, Sir Liam Donaldson. He is expected to recommend accedence to pressure from within the scientific community to make the cloning process legal, as in the United States.

The government could have published the report before the summer recess, but chose not to do so, possibly because ministers were reluctant to distract from the National Plan for Health. Any go-ahead would be subject to legal controls and a full five year review.

However, Lord Sainsbury said in an interview over the weekend that, in his view, "the potential medical benefits outweigh any other considerations one might have". These remarks were interpreted as signalling the go-ahead for cloning.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said yesterday: "This is a huge issue of concern to church groups and religious groups, who are all expecting the very different ethical issues involved to be given maximum scrutiny."

Dr Fox accused Lord Sainsbury of "sweeping away all the complex ethical issues with complete contempt" and of having neglected the consultation that had been promised.

Lord Sainsbury issued a clarification yesterday, saying that no final decision had been made by the government.

The aim of the proposed research would be to find ways of turning embryo stem cells into personalised replacement tissue for transplantation. Ruth Deech, who chairs the government's human fertilisation and embryology authority, indicated her support for limited research.

She told BBC Radio 4's World This Weekend: "Nobody anywhere wants reproductive cloning, the cloning of babies, but right round the world there is a growing consensus that there would not be any harm, indeed there would be much good, in 'therapeutic cloning' of embryos."

She said the aim of such research would be to find ways to grow new cells and tissues to help people with Parkinson's disease, with Huntington's, with Alzheimer's, with cancer, and with burns. "It will be gradual, and every step will be checked by us. Our powers are backed by law. We give licences, and we can take them away."

fields.headline: Khmer Rouge leaders face trial
fields.trailText: Khmer Rouge leaders who have escaped justice for more than 20 years may still face conviction for mass murder in a long-awaited trial.
fields.body:
Khmer Rouge leaders who have escaped justice for more than 20 years may still face conviction for mass murder in a long-awaited trial.

The Cambodian minister in charge of setting up a tribunal to judge them, Sok An, says that the government is "more than committed" to pursuing them. A draft law to be submitted to the national assembly will require "all senior leaders" to be prosecuted for their crimes during the 1975-79 Khmer Rouge regime.

Asked if that applied to Khieu Samphan and Ieng Sary, the movement's most senior officials since the death of Pol Pot, Sok An said that "all should be tried". The prime minister, Hun Sen, had previously indicated that Ieng Sary, the Khmer Rouge foreign minister who was amnestied in 1996, would be exempt.

"We can be more optimistic now; the truth is too powerful to be denied," said Youk Chhang, director of the Documentation Centre of Cambodia. "We can build up a case in detail especially against the leadership."

The centre has collected more than 400,000 original Khmer Rouge files which contain direct evidence implicating the former regime in genocide. Damning evidence includes a statement by one of Ieng Sary's close aides that "the enemies [in our ranks] must be progressively wiped out".

New evidence suggests that the overall figure for executions in the 1975-79 period, reduced by scholars from early estimates of about 3m, may need to be revised upwards.

The draft law to set up a mixed tribunal, with Cambodian and international judges and prosecutors, is the result of negotiations with the UN during the past three years in which Phnom Penh has insisted on having the final say.

The government reminds its critics that western governments, led by the US in one of the most cynical episodes of the cold war, supported the Khmer Rouge for years after it was overthrown by Vietnamese forces in 1979.

Many ordinary Cambodians remain sceptical about the process. "Hun Sen will delay the proceedings until all the top people have died," said a survivor.

webTitle: Leader: PCC addresses unlicensed photography of the prime minister's son

fields.headline: Snapping at Leo
fields.standfirst:
Do we really need Lord Wakeham?
Special report: Blairs' baby
fields.trailText: The Press Complaints Commission is being invited by the prime minister to gaze down upon little Leo. From their seats on Olympus, its members will address the question of whether unlicensed photography of the prime ministerial babe needs a ruling. Zeus would not hesitate; but Lord Wakeham did not get where he is without immaculate understanding of the dynamics of procrastination.
fields.body:
The Press Complaints Commission is being invited by the prime minister to gaze down upon little Leo. From their seats on Olympus, its members will address the question of whether unlicensed photography of the prime ministerial babe needs a ruling. Zeus would not hesitate; but Lord Wakeham did not get where he is without immaculate understanding of the dynamics of procrastination. All he needs to do is apply the rule of the club. It is straightforward enough. Minors should not be photographed without their parents' consent. There, on the front pages, were the pictures. Open and shut.

This latest episode in the Blair vs press soap opera - not to be pursued in the Tuscan sun, it must be hoped - is puzzling. Usually some kind of "facility" is offered when press and public interest is high. They are. Christening, like marriage, is one of the few things left that draws marginal believers into church. Babies look bonny in white. Here was an event from which a sharp press secretary was bound to extract some costless feel-good. What got printed were indeed, as Chris Smith disinterestedly observed, lovely pictures. The Blairs' wish for a private church service is their right, but they know that, for the time being, they and their children live negotiated lives. By the crude standards of these matters, the press were calm over the drunken elder son episode. Some kind of pay-off was expected.

The Blair children deserve protection from paparazzi but their father is, let us not forget, in pole position to make policy on privacy, libel and the regulation of newspapers. On each of those fronts, he has chosen, since he became party leader, to pursue person-to-person conversation with editors and proprietors (and Lord W) rather than bring legislation forward to begin modernising our newspaper law. Invoking the PCC is, as Mr Blair and his advisers well know, a mere public relations ploy.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Beethoven | The Searchers | Rounders
fields.body:
Beethoven
(Brian Levant, 1991)
10.55am, 6pm, Sky Premier

What do we think of doggy films? Ruff! Ruff! But here's an exception to the rule. Beethoven is a St Bernard who causes chaos in the household of long-suffering Charles Grodin, while seeing off the evil dognapping vet. Grodin's hang-dog humour is a treat in a funny, feelgood movie.

The Searchers
(John Ford, 1956)
8pm, 3.45am, Sky Cinema

John Wayne's Ethan Edwards is his most complex character, a man who does good for the darkest of motives and seems up to the last moments capable of killing a loved one. With greenhorn sidekick Jeff Hunter he embarks on a five-year quest to find his niece (Natalie Wood), who's been kidnapped and, in Ethan's eyes, despoiled by marauding Comanches. Ford's West rarely looked more lovely, but it's a backdrop to sinister, unsettling notions of racism, false hope and bitterness.

Rounders
(John Dahl, 1998)
9.30pm, Sky MovieMax

An ace account of young law student Matt Damon who realises he has a higher calling in life - playing poker. He loses every last cent to Russian cardsharp John Malkovich (Teddy KGB) and when buddy Edward Norton, just out of jail and in dire need of paying off his debts, asks for help, it's showdown time. Gretchen Mol plays the girlfriend trying to keep Damon's mind on his studies.

Chocolat
(Claire Denis, 1988)
11.40pm FilmFour

Told mainly in flashback, with a young woman flying to the Cameroons, telling a fellow traveller about her childhood there. An idyllic life as the French official's daughter and her friendship with houseboy Isaach de Bankolé are undermined by the arrival of a group of plane-crash survivors who insinuate the worst of colonialist values into the once-happy home. An adept debut by Denis - nostalgic but unsentimental, with a pulsing Abdullah Ibrahim soundtrack.

webTitle: Children seen and clearly heard as parents consult on lifestyle choices

fields.headline: Children seen and clearly heard as parents consult on lifestyle choices
fields.trailText: Modern youngsters are increasingly dominating family life, including the choice of the evening meal and the family car, according to a survey published today.
fields.body:
Modern youngsters are increasingly dominating family life, including the choice of the evening meal and the family car, according to a survey published today.

This seems to be the price parents are paying to enjoy a more open relationship with their children than they had with their own parents.

Almost three-quarters of parents in the Abbey National survey of 950 families said they were able to communicate well with their children. So well that in 65% of cases children helped to select holiday destinations, while three-quarters of parents consulted their offspring before redecorating the home.

The survey also found that nine out of 10 children no longer asked what was for supper - they told their parents what to cook. And more than half had the final say on the make, model and colour of the new car.

For 84% of families organising leisure time involved negotiations between parents and children. When it came to moving house, 42% of parents sought the children's views - especially with teenagers.

The study concluded that, in the main, family members were happy with their changing roles, with fathers particularly keen to listen to children and involve them in making decisions.

An Abbey National spokesman, Tim Harrison, said he thought the degree to which children's views and opinions were being respected was unprecedented. "We were amazed at just how much influence children have on family life.

"It is clear that the family is becoming more democratic. Respect between parents and children has become a two-way process, and we would expect that as the importance of the family grows in the 21st century so too will the importance of the children."

Many advertisers have known for some time about child pester power. Research for the Co-operative supermarket chain suggested this month that television advertisers were exploiting this aspect of the modern family.

The Co-op, which stocks many of the products criticised in the study, said it would stop advertising unhealthy foods and drinks if they continued to be targeted at children.

A separate opinion poll of Co-op customers, by NOP, found that 73% of children pleaded with their parents to buy items they had seen publicised on television, and 77% of parents wanted such adverts banned.

webTitle: Boy, 10, saves family of three on his father's jet ski

fields.headline: Boy, 10, saves family of three on his father's jet ski
fields.trailText: When Matthew Dyson returns to his Birmingham primary school in September, his summer holiday tale should be a cut above his classmates' anecdotes.
fields.body:
When Matthew Dyson returns to his Birmingham primary school in September, his summer holiday tale should be a cut above his classmates' anecdotes.

The 10-year-old was yesterday enjoying hero status on the north Wales coast after he commandeered his father's jet ski and rescued a family of three who had been thrown from an inflatable dinghy 500 metres from the shore on Friday afternoon.

Matthew, who had never driven a jet ski before, rode to the rescue when he spotted the Marshall family from Belper, Derbyshire, floundering in the sea off Abererch beach near Pwllheli.

Mr Marshall had been thrown from the boat, which was powered by an outboard motor, and as the dinghy circled out of control at high speed his wife and daughter were also hurled into the sea.

Matthew boarded the jet ski and made for the group. When he reached the Marshalls he told them to stay calm before fishing Mrs Marshall, who cannot swim, and her daughter out of the water and returning them to dry land. His father Mark Dyson, 42, then went back to the scene to collect Mr Marshall.

Matthew's exploits won praise from coastguard and lifeboat authorities but there was a rebuke from his father. "I'm kind of proud of myself, but I won't do the same thing again, because dad was very worried," Matthew said.

"When I was halfway there I started to worry because the mother and daughter seemed to be panicking and the boat was circling so fast.

"The father told me to take the women first. I told the mother and daughter to get on the jet ski but it tipped over. Then it self-righted. The mother, who couldn't swim, sat on the back and the girl, who could, just hung on as we made for shore."

Mr Dyson, a builder, of Barnt Green, Birmingham, said he was proud of his son. "What he did was characteristic. He's only 10, never saw the danger, and his only concern was that three people were in the water.

"His mother and I chastised him afterwards, there were a few tears and now he realises the danger. But it's nice to know he's grown up to care for others. I would have thought twice about going out because it was a very powerful boat which was circling at full throttle precariously close to the three people. Matthew went into the thick of it, told them not to panic and kept a cool head in a crisis.

"But for us on shore it was petrifying to see it unfold. Matthew has only been on the jet ski as my passenger and we're still amazed by what he managed to do."

Owen Roberts, secretary of the Pwllheli lifeboat, said Matthew's action probably saved lives. "Matthew exposed himself to great danger. Yet if he had not acted so swiftly there is a distinct possibility the family could have drowned or been hit by the propeller of their inflatable boat."

A Gwynedd council official praised Matthew, but pointed out he had broken by-laws in riding a jet ski underage.

"You must be 18 to drive a jet ski, or between 15 and 17 if you have a certificate of competence. Anyone under 12 is not allowed to ride alone," he said. "What he did was very brave but please don't do it again."

His father Mark Dyson, 42, then went back to the scene to collect Mr Marshall. Matthew's exploits won praise from coastguard and lifeboat authorities but there was a rebuke from his father. "I'm kind of proud of myself, but I won't do the same thing again, because dad was very worried," Matthew said. "When I was halfway there I started to worry because the mother and daughter seemed to be panicking and the boat was circling so fast. "The father told me to take the women first. I told the mother and daughter to get on the jet ski but it tipped over. Then it self-righted. The mother, who couldn't swim, sat on the back and the girl, who could, just hung on as we made for shore." Mr Dyson, a builder, of Barnt Green, Birmingham, said he was proud of his son. "What he did was characteristic. He's only 10, never saw the danger, and his only concern was that three people were in the water. "His mother and I chastised him afterwards, there were a few tears and now he realises the danger. But it's nice to know he's grown up to care for others. I would have thought twice about going out because it was a very powerful boat which was circling at full throttle precariously close to the three people. Matthew went into the thick of it, told them not to panic and kept a cool head in a crisis. "But for us on shore it was petrifying to see it unfold. Matthew has only been on the jet ski as my passenger and we're still amazed by what he managed to do." Owen Roberts, secretary of the Pwllheli lifeboat, said Matthew's action probably saved lives. "Matthew exposed himself to great danger. Yet if he had not acted so swiftly there is a distinct possibility the family could have drowned or been hit by the propeller of their inflatable boat." A Gwynedd council official praised Matthew, but pointed out he had broken by-laws in riding a jet ski underage. "You must be 18 to drive a jet ski, or between 15 and 17 if you have a certificate of competence. Anyone under 12 is not allowed to ride alone," he said. "What he did was very brave but please don't do it again."

webTitle: Steam fans get unexpected high at fair

fields.headline: Steam fans get unexpected high at fair
fields.trailText: A group of visitors to Britain's most famous steam fair got more puff than they expected when they munched their way through a plate of cakes, unaware they had been baked with cannabis.
fields.body:
A group of visitors to Britain's most famous steam fair got more puff than they expected when they munched their way through a plate of cakes, unaware they had been baked with cannabis.

Yesterday all 12 vintage motorbike enthusiasts were given a lifelong ban from the Bluebell railway steam fair, in Horsted Keynes, West Sussex, after five had to be taken to hospital. The over-spiced cakes had been baked to celebrate a birthday on Saturday night. The five were discharged yesterday and the offending chef was arrested.

Tim Baker, the fair's marketing manager, said that while the middle-aged group were "very respectable" and probably knew nothing of the cake's ingredients, they had been asked to leave in order to maintain the event's reputation.

"It has come as a bit of a shock. This show is all done by volunteers and it has knocked back their morale. The group left this morning and they will not be coming back."

Police and ambulance services were called to the fair on Saturday night after some of the group complained of nausea and hallucinations. "The first we knew about it was when one woman collapsed," said Mr Baker. "It soon became apparent that more people had taken the cake and they soon fell ill."

The group was not connected with the railway and it was the first time drugs had been used at the fair since it began eight years ago, he said. "The enthusiasts were expecting to get high on steam engines this weekend, not drugs."

One visitor said: "You don't expect people to be getting high on hash cookies at a steam rally. There was enough puff from the exhibits."

webTitle: Marisa Tomei in The Flamingo Kid

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: What the stars did before they were famous
fields.trailText: What the stars did before they were famous
fields.body:
Marisa Tomei in The Flamingo Kid (Garry Marshall, 1984 )

Who? Brooklyn-born actress Tomei spent five years on the preposterous daytime soap As The World Turns (as the preposterously named Marcy Thompson Cushing) before her first movie gig here. A role in Cosby Show spin-off A Different World followed, then the risible 1990 gangster comedy Oscar. Tomei is, funnily enough, an Oscar-winner, but not for any of her more highbrow features such as Chaplin (1992) or The Perez Family (1995). Oh no, she got her best supporting actress award for her role as Italian-American broad Mona Lisa Vito in My Cousin Vinnie (1992), playing Joe Pesci's girlfriend. Yes, Joe Pesci. The gong didn't exactly lead onto bigger and better things; instead, she languished in lame romcoms before returning to the Broadway stage in 1998 alongside that celebrated actor Quentin Tarantino in a revival of Wait Until Dark. Her career still isn't exactly stellar, but she did put in a great performance in 1998's Slums Of Beverly Hills as Natasha Lyonne's pill-popping cousin, and she's now working on another romcom, Animal Husbandry, with X-Men star Hugh Jackman and Ashley Judd.

The role: Mandy, a beach bunny at an exclusive club, who goes out with a friend of Jeffrey Willis (Matt Dillon).

Best line: She doesn't get to speak. As a pre-Baywatch bimbo, she just has to look interested in the card game Willis is playing, smile, and look pretty in a flowery bikini.

Cringe factor: She's not visible long enough for it to matter.

Other wannabes: John Turturro as "Ted from Pinky's".

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin calls it "very likeable."

Also not starring in: Exploitation house Troma's gross-out classic The Toxic Avenger (1985) in an uncredited role as "Health Club Girl".

 The Flamingo Kid, Carlton Cinema, Sat August 5, 9pm

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: BBC Proms 2000 | The Old Lady
fields.body:
There's a red-letter concert at the BBC Proms 2000 (7.0pm, Radio 3), with Ton Koopman conducting a major new work by JS Bach. Well, up to a point. It's known that Bach wrote a St Mark Passion for Good Friday 1731 but, although we still have the text, the score disappeared long ago. Now Koopman has reconstructed it, mostly using cantatas of the same period, but also finding that one aria from the 1725 St John Passion fitted the St Mark text perfectly.

According to Paul Volcker, ex-chairman of America's Federal Reserve, the 300-year-old Bank of England is the mother of central banking. In the final instalment of Lesley Curwen's historical survey, Volcker assures her that The Old Lady (8.0pm, Radio 4) is still punching well above her post-imperial weight in the hurly-burly of international finance. But can it last, or is she about to follow the Bundesbank into euro-powerlessness?

fields.headline: Dancing with the devil
fields.trailText: Jamaica Girls | Modern British Architects
fields.body:
Although the star performers in Jamaica Girls (C4, Sat) were the skimpily-clad Corey, Michelle and Tivona, who provided the floorshow for panting punters at the Shades nightclub in the Jamaican resort of Ocho Rios, the eminence grise of the piece was Lloyd Cameron. Cameron is the proprietor of Shades, and while he doesn't disguise the fact that it's not just a strip club ("Shades nightclub operates as an escort agency also", as he put it, indicating rooms for hire upstairs), he manages to convey the impression that somehow this particular sleaze factory came into being as the result of some higher calling. For example, Cameron, nicknamed "Bossy", gathers his dancers for "assembly and prayers" every morning, as if Shades can be miraculously cleansed of the previous night's excesses. He runs it with quasi-military discipline, fines latecomers and insists that all employees attend his weekly meeting. If a dancer misses one, she can't work again (or get paid) until after the next meeting. "This pretty much guarantees us 100 per cent attendance," Bossy deadpanned.

Cameron is an intriguing mixture of dry pragmatism and shameless euphemisms. No doubt he learned both characteristics during the 27 years he spent as an accountant in Britain, before deciding there were more exciting opportunities in the Jamaican leisure industry. After fighting had broken out among the girls in the dormitory, where they sleep four to a bed, he explained: "We use the system of suspensions very often to deal with matters of discipline", as though reading the minutes of a parliamentary committee on penal reform. Of the activities in his club, he said: "We do a variety of very hilarious things, some of them rather risqué, but it's all good fun." His explanation for the fact that Jamaicans regard clubs like Shades with extreme moral disapproval had an anthropological ring to it. "In the western civilisations, Jamaica's about the hardest place for dancers to gain self-respect," he pontificated.

Clearly, there is some discrepancy between Bossy's outward displays of authoritarian rectitude and the true nature of his profession. Indeed, he took a lubricious delight in drilling his dancers in performance technique: "I want you to demonstrate the full use of the pole," he ordered. "You can lick it, you can masturbate it, you can suck it, you can do whatever you want to do with it." And as an equal opportunities employer, he took every opportunity to grope and fondle the girls under the pretext of honing their act. It was left to an anonymous tourist to suggest that Bossy keeps his girls as virtual prisoners by paying them scandalously low wages.

The dancers were under no illusions about their job, and liked to enact a kind of revenge for their male-dominated predicament by playing the song Short Dick Man ("don't wanna eeny weeny teeny weeny shrivelled little short-dick man") while strutting about stage brandishing enormous dildos. "What's a nice girl like me doing in a piece of shit like this?" shrieked Corey, who has been taking computer classes with a view to escaping from the squalor of Bossy-world. Michelle, who reads the Bible and compares her role to that of the scriptural hooker Mary Magdalene, was planning to marry her boyfriend Donovan.

Nicholas Grimshaw isn't a household name like some other architects who build wobbly bridges, pointless domes and so forth, but the survey of his accomplishments in Modern British Architects (C5, Sun) was a forceful reminder of his vision and dynamism. His inner-city Sainsbury's in Camden Town was a brilliant alternative to the monstrous Tesco Gothic which has swept the country like moronic plague, while his Eurostar terminal at Waterloo was a technical and aesthetic feat achieved under extremely awkward conditions. Currently he's working on the Eden project in Cornwall, a botanical garden housed in astonishing transparent domes which Grimshaw can foresee evolving in tandem with new, breathing, organic materials. When he said "we don't do buildings that we're not proud of", it was actually possible to believe him.

fields.headline: Grovel pits
fields.trailText: On The Big Breakfast last week, a moment of frisson arose which cut to the core of the show's dynamic. Mark Lamarr was the guest, plugging his new series, and waiting patiently in the wings to be interviewed, coffee mug in hand.
fields.body:
On The Big Breakfast last week, a moment of frisson arose which cut to the core of the show's dynamic. Mark Lamarr was the guest, plugging his new series, and waiting patiently in the wings to be interviewed, coffee mug in hand.

Johnny Vaughan held court: the attendant group of runners, floor managers and researchers laughing mechanically at Johnny's witticisms. Suddenly, Lamarr interrupted Johnny's flow, making a comment which clearly threw him off-message. "Ooh, ooh, no!" Lamarr shrieked, mock-terrified, "Someone dared speak back to Johnny! Ooh, no!"

It was the first time that the sycophancy towards Vaughan from the show's team had been laid bare on air. Watching The Big Breakfast has become a Spinal Tap experience - witnessing a bunch of groupies held in perpetual fake mirth by their idol as he bores on about the precise details of nothing.

In the most embarrassing part of the show, The Pundown, Johnny laughs knowingly at excruciating puns from the day's tabloids. The degree of latitude given to Vaughan to prove how unfunny he can be beggars belief.

Liza Tarbuck, Johnny's co-host, bites her tongue whenever she's about to say something wittier than Johnny, clearly terrified at the ramifications of outshining the star. Even at Chris Evans' most ego-fuelled moments on The BB, he never steam-rolled Gaby Roslin in the way Vaughan usurps Tarbuck.

Why is this? Johnny Vaughan is one of the most highly regarded TV properties, and his talent for holding a live show together is unquestionable. The Big Breakfast should be the perfect vehicle for him, and yet something's wrong. The paradoxical truth is that whilst the programme is tailor-made for his talents, his nervy on-screen bravado, plastered over two hours, disguises just how good Vaughan can be.

fields.headline: Taking the mick
fields.standfirst: A new BBC sitcom sees the corporation trying to update the tiredest of TV genres. Unfortunately, says  Jacques Peretti  , the results are strangely reminiscent of Dick Emery. Only less funny
fields.trailText: A new BBC sitcom sees the corporation trying to update the tiredest of TV genres. Unfortunately, says Jacques Peretti , the results are strangely reminiscent of Dick Emery. Only less funny
fields.body:
Paul Merton tells a story about the origins of the Irish joke. In England, he says, we tell jokes about the Irish, but in Ireland they tell jokes about the Kerryman. If you go to Kerry, however, they tell jokes about people who live in one particular road. And if you go to that road, they tell jokes about the people who live at number 46. At number 46 - you won't be surprised to hear - they tell jokes about their dad, who, says Merton, can reliably be called the source of all Irish jokes.

BBC's The Fitz lies many miles, even centuries, from the source of the Irish joke. A sitcom about an unhinged Irish family, obvious comparisons will be made with the madcap surrealism of Father Ted, though it's actually closer to Bread, a long-running 80s sitcom about a Liverpudlian family who battled through adversity with nothing but a clutch of comedy stereotypes to pull them through. Following the success of The Royle Family, the BBC obviously feels confident about commissioning more adventurous comedy for the main channel. The Fitz must have looked good on paper, but falls well short in reality. Indeed, whilst Father Ted was jaw-droppingly original, Fitz is a gloomy viewing experience.

The opening titles warn the viewer how "Mad!" (ie unfunny) the show will be, and as a laugh-free 30 minutes begin to tick slowly, painfully, inexorably past, the show slides the viewer from a state of mild expectation to one of deep depression.

Written by Owen O'Neal, The Fitz should have been far, far funnier. O'Neal is a veteran Irish stand-up who lives in London. His stage show has always been touching and shocking by turns. Some years ago, he performed a fantastic tour de force about his early years in London as a builder, fighting racism and drink.

If the BBC had wanted an original work to match The Royle Family, they should have commissioned a sitcom version of this show. Instead, alas, we get the classic compromise: a bit of Father Ted copyism (complete with "fecks" and "shites") and a hefty dose of racist, pre-alternative comedy sitcom.

Some years ago, O'Neal and I produced a programme about the roots of the Irish comedy cliché. Owen argued persuasively that Irish clichés - the whisky priest, the rustic idjut, etc - exist not because the English invented them, but because they're central to the collective myth of agricultural Ireland, perpetuated as much by the Irish as by anyone else. In the 70s, Dick Emery played an Irish detective called, wait for it, Flynn O'Thick. It was racist, of course, but the crudity and audacity of the joke actually made it funny (the very same ingredients that made American shock stand-ups like Bill Hicks so funny). Watching the Fitz, however, I'm no longer sure that such crude un-PC comedy is either as intellectually complex, or as harmless, as Owen and I would have once argued.

In fashion terms, at least, The Fitz shares the blatant stereotyping of Dick Emery: wild ginger hair and loud kipper ties worn by gap-toothed Irishmen. But because it's so self-conscious, so worried about staying just the right side of racist, The Fitz lacks even the innocent offensiveness of Flynn O'Thick - the one thing that made Dick Emery passably amusing.

The Fitz is so rooted in unreality, it makes Ballykissangel look like a Ken Loach movie. The set's like a sketch from The Dave Allen Show, minus the acid punchlines about the church. Corruption of the church is the sine qua non of Irish comedy clichés, yet no one's ever come close to pinning it with the same accuracy as Allen, certainly not The Fitz.

Commissioning O'Neal to write a sitcom, however, is a promising sign from the corporation. Last week, Rhona, written by O'Neal's contemporary, Rhona Cameron, began its run on BBC2.

Clearly, the BBC are attempting to reinvigorate mainstream sitcom - a genre that, in Britain at least, hasn't really moved on from Terry & June. In both O'Neal and Cameron's cases, however, it's a shame the BBC pulled its punches and copied existing shows (Father Ted and Ellen, respectively) rather than giving the writers free rein to do something bolder.

The best sitcom of recent years, One Foot In The Grave, subverted the sitcom tradition with a healthy injection of bile. One Foot... didn't need the panto antics of The Fitz to make its sanguine point about modern Britain - that getting old is hell. The Fitz, by contrast, says nothing about its subject matter - a real missed opportunity at a time when the Irish are transforming from the butt of racist jokes into a modern, post-industrial society.

And not only does it say nothing, but it manages to say nothing with the aid of special effects last seen on Some Mothers Do 'Ave 'Em. Feckin' useless.

 The Fitz, BBC1, Friday August 4,9.30pm Mark Lawson returns next week

And not only does it say nothing, but it manages to say nothing with the aid of special effects last seen on Some Mothers Do 'Ave 'Em. webTitle: At last, this love can speak its name

fields.headline: At last, this love can speak its name
fields.standfirst: The Human Rights Act will force the government to throw out a raft of crimes that penalise homosexual men. But it should also mean greater recognition for gay couples, say  Andrew Belmont  and  Clare Dyer
fields.trailText: The Human Rights Act will force the government to throw out a raft of crimes that penalise homosexual men. But it should also mean greater recognition for gay couples, say  Andrew Belmont  and  Clare Dyer
fields.body:
An anonymous middle- aged civil servant is expected to score a decisive victory today against the British government at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg. He may get substantial compensation. But the ripple effects of his fight will go way beyond justice for one man. The battle waged by ADT, the initials under which his case is filed in Strasbourg, has been a prime catalyst for the home office sex offences review, unveiled last week, which sweeps away a raft of laws criminalising behaviour by homosexuals which is perfectly legal for heterosexuals.

Straight sex involving multiple participants in private is lawful. However, the gross indecency laws, under which ADT was convicted, ban gay sex if more than two people are present. They will almost certainly fall foul of the Human Rights Act, which comes into force next October, incorporating the European convention on human rights into English law. Unless the government takes action to remove the discrimination, prosecutors could face expensive and time-consuming challenges to any charges laid.

The act is likely to have greater and more far-reaching effects for gay people than any other legislation since the partial decriminalisation of homosexuality in the 1960s. Many lawyers believe it could go much further, impacting on the everyday lives of gay people on a number of fronts and accelerating a growing trend for English judges to give greater weight to same-sex relationships.

Historically the English courts have refused to give any legal status to such relationships. And in the past the European court of human rights has denied same-sex couples the same rights as married couples. But things are changing on both fronts.

Last October the House of Lords held that a gay man, Martin Fitzpatrick, who lived with his partner for 18 years and cared for him for eight years after he emerged brain-damaged and paralysed from a fall, could inherit his partner's tenancy. The landmark ruling established that a homosexual couple in a stable relationship could be defined as a family for the purposes of the rent acts, dramatically reversing the views of the lower courts. In a 1997 case at the European court of human rights, the UK government conceded that a lesbian couple looking after children under a joint residence order would constitute "family life". Last December the human rights court decided that denying a gay father custody of his daughter on the grounds of his sexuality was a violation of article 8 of the European convention on human rights, which guarantees respect for private and family life.

The importance of the Human Rights Act is that it differs from previous legislation and will evolve with changing social attitudes. Rather than confining themselves to the strict letter of the law, judges will have to try to achieve the purpose intended by the European convention.

Under English law, a same-sex couple may not marry or formalise their relationship in any way that is recognised by the state. However, a number of other European jurisdictions, including Denmark and France, allow the registration of same-sex couples, which gives them similar but not identical rights to married couples. The Netherlands will be the first country to legislate - effective from next year - to allow same-sex couples to marry.

Same-sex couples who have entered into a registered partnership or marriage in the EC will probably have the same rights in the UK as they would have had in the country where they entered into their marriage or partnership. So if a Dutch gay couple who married in the Netherlands came to the UK, the courts should treat them as married in the UK.

In deciding whether a court should recognise the validity of a gay relationship, the key factors will probably be the length of the relationship and the degree of commitment that the partners have shown to each other - the same criteria used by the immigration authorities in deciding whether a same-sex partner should be allowed to stay in the UK.

A radical interpretation of the Human Rights Act could give gay partners the right to make claims against each other's property when the relationship breaks up. Claims for financial support by the less wealthy partner will become a real possibility.

Same-sex couples could earn greater rights to adopt and bring up children. At present, only married couples may adopt jointly. Single individuals who live with a partner, whether heterosexual or gay, may adopt on their own, but the partner has no formal legal role in the child's life. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division and England's senior family law judge, declared last year that children could be successfully brought up by gay couples. "We should not close our minds to suitable families who are clearly not within the old-fashioned approach," she said.

Greater recognition of same- sex partnerships could have tax consequences. It could be argued that the surviving partner in a gay relationship should escape inheritance tax just as a husband or wife does when a spouse dies.

In interpreting the Human Rights Act, our courts will draw on case law from the Strasbourg court and from other countries with similar legislation. Rulings from the supreme court of Canada, which since 1982 has had a charter of rights and freedoms closely modelled on the European convention on human rights, are a strong pointer to the way the law may develop.

One of the court's most far- reaching and controversial judgments expanded the definition of "spouse" in 1999 to include members of the same sex. If a man and a woman had lived together for at least three years, the law in Ontario allowed them to be treated as "spouses" so one partner could claim financial support from the other when the relationship ended. In a claim brought by a lesbian against her long-term partner, the Canadian supreme court held that gay couples must be treated the same as heterosexual ones.

But English courts are conservative and despite Martin Fitzpatrick's case they are unlikely to accept without question the radical new interpretation of the law that the Human Rights Act will require. Hard-fought and long-drawn-out litigation is certain to follow the implementation of the act in October. However, the ex-service personnel sacked from the armed forces for being gay who finally won compensation in Strasbourg last week have shown that determination will be rewarded.

The supreme court of Canada's ruling last year that a lesbian named only as M could claim financial support from her long-term partner H when the relationship broke down affected 58 federal statutes and hundreds of provincial statutes. The ruling made it unlawful for federal or provincial governments to continue to define "spouse" as "a member of the opposite sex".

M and her partner H - the initials are those of the lawyers who represented them in this mammoth legal battle - started an advertising business and set up home together in Ontario in 1982, in a house owned by H. The business thrived, with H making a greater contribution than M. The couple also built a holiday home in the country. But in the late 80s the business ran into trouble. H took an outside job and mortgaged her home. In 1992 M left and made claims for a share of the home and financial support from H. In response, H claimed, like many a man before her, that M had contributed nothing to the business and had lived with her for a free ride.

Ontario's Family Law Act allowed opposite-sex partners who have lived together for at least three years to claim financial support when the relationship ended. M claimed that this was unconstitutional and discriminated against homosexuals.

In the meantime, the six-year legal battle ended with a settlement in 1998. M agreed to drop her claims to support payments and a share of H's home in return for a share of the proceeds of the holiday home. But the case went on to the supreme court of Canada as a test case. The court agreed with M and held that the Family Law Act infringed the Canadian charter of rights and freedoms, modelled on the European convention on human rights.

 Andrew Belmont is senior partner in Belmont Hodgson, a London law firm specialising in gay rights. Clare Dyer is legal correspondent of the Guardian.

webTitle: Leader: George W Bush's choice of Dick Cheney as vice-presidential running mate

fields.headline: A smart selection
fields.standfirst:
On the right, it's George and Dick
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush's choice of Dick Cheney as his vice-presidential running-mate is bad news for the Democratic candidate, Al Gore. Mr Bush has made a smart pick that spells trouble this autumn.
fields.body: George W Bush's choice of Dick Cheney as his vice-presidential running-mate is bad news for the Democratic candidate, Al Gore. Mr Bush has made a smart pick that spells trouble this autumn. Tough, reliable and experienced, Mr Cheney has one of the safest pairs of hands in American politics. His previous jobs, as White House chief of staff, long-serving congressman, Gulf war supremo at the Pentagon, and Texas oil baron have given him the inside track on how Washington works - something his younger boss lacks. His old guard connections and his familiarity with foreign policy-making and national security issues will help fill the Bush campaign's "gravitas gap". The certitude and consistency of Mr Cheney's unwavering conservatism, ranging from opposition to abortion, gun control and environmental laws to support for corporate America and new missile defences, will appeal to rightwingers and swing-voters once known as "Reagan Democrats". No matter that his views (and those of his formidable wife, Lynne, who is tipped for a job in a future Bush cabinet) could alienate some middle-ground voters. Mr Bush has deliberately shifted to the centre since his primary battles with John McCain. An articulate debater with a quietly impressive demeanour, Mr Cheney will be charged with shoring up the Republicans' natural constituency against the anticipated depredations of ultra-conservative Pat Buchanan, running as the likely Reform party candidate. Unlike "Pitchfork Pat" and burned-out firebrands such as Newt Gingrich, Mr Cheney is the acceptable face of the Republican right. He is a man who knows what he stands for and does what he says. After eight years of Bill Clinton, that is indeed a potent slogan. Mr Gore, who has yet to announce his running-mate, now faces a changed tactical situation. He could call to the colours another seasoned figure, former Senate leader and Belfast mediator George Mitchell. Or more imaginatively, he might try to co-opt Ralph Nader, the Green party candidate and principled citizens' rights campaigner, who threatens to outflank Mr Gore on the left. Beyond Washington, in the country at large, and in Mr Clinton's sullied wake, this election, lacking big new issues and held amid unprecedented prosperity, is likely to turn on questions of trust, integrity and character. Policy aside, that is the message of the Cheney choice. The Democrats ignore it at their peril.

webTitle: Lord Irvine - big in the City?

fields.headline: Lord Irvine - big in the City?
fields.trailText: Writ large
fields.body:
I don't myself believe it but I'm passing it on because it has gained such wide circulation in the legal world, and not just among the usual rumour-mongers. The story is that the Lord Chancellor, Lord Irvine, is soon to resign. Some say he won't serve beyond the next election.

Several reasons are offered. One is that he's achieved everything he aspired to in Labour's first term - devolution, the foundations of House of Lords reform, access to justice - and wants to leave with his reputation as a radical reforming Lord Chancellor at its height. The more cynical claim is that he doesn't want to remain too long on a lord chancellor's salary (£167,760) and would like to earn real money, perhaps as something in the City. A recent twist is that he would have to go after the election anyway, because when Tony Blair resigns as PM - as many expect him to - whoever takes over will want a different lord chancellor. Irvine's successor is assumed to be Lord Williams of Mostyn, the respected attorney general, whose sparkling performances in the House of Lords have attracted much praise. But legal gossip is notoriously unreliable. It's obvious that Derry loves his job to bits, and I can't see him going voluntarily.

 In two separate cases last week, judges lifted the ban on the media naming children convicted of serious crimes. We aren't usually allowed to name under-18s. But the judges have a discretion to remove the anonymity. I am a little uneasy at the frequency with which they are doing so, especially since the precedent set by the judge who permitted James Bulger's killers to be named in spite of their extreme youth. Admittedly, the children in last week's cases had committed horrifying offences - one group killed a student by throwing him off a bridge into the Thames, the other three were guilty of the brutal "Reservoir Dogs" murder. But what is the point of naming them? The judge in the Hungerford bridge killing trial explained the children were not being identified as an additional punishment or being "named and shamed", but because it was important that the public should know as much as possible about the case. I'm glad she rejected the ridiculous naming and shaming reason; children capable of such conduct are hardly going to be shamed by having their identities made known. But naming them is an additional punishment - making certain that they never have a chance of living in decent society when they are let out. The point about the laws protecting children is that we recognise that they aren't as fully responsible as adults for their actions, however despicable, and that there is a possibility of making them fit to re-enter the community. That process is made almost impossible if they cannot receive that attention in privacy. I have no sympathy for the young killers in the two cases. But I do not see how it serves the interests of our society, in the name of freedom of expression, to virtually ensure that these bad children can never become good adults.

 It's not often that high court judges write popular paperbacks. Sir Charles Gray has done it, and it deserves to be a bestseller. He didn't really mean to write a book. He thought at the time that he was just doing his job, writing his judgment after a trial he'd been hearing. But the trial was David Irving's libel suit against the US professor Deborah Lipstadt, over her claims that he was a holocaust denier. Penguin, also a defendant, has now issued Gray's judgment as a £7.99 book. There's no tension in it, since we all know that the trial ended with Irving the loser. Yet the book is a gripping read as well as a demonstration of the skill of a good judge.

I shall be devoting what others call "summer holidays" to a couple of intensive research trips on your behalf, to legally important areas of the Caribbean and the south of France. Law and Writ Large will return on September 25.

fields.headline: Of gods and men
fields.standfirst: Tom Service  is blown away by Das Rheingold and Die Walküre at the Bayreuth opera festival
fields.trailText: Tom Service is blown away by Das Rheingold and Die Walküre at the Bayreuth opera festival
fields.body:
In any opera house, a new production of Wagner's Ring cycle carries a unique weight of expectation. But at the heart of all things Wagnerian, in the composer's theatre at Bayreuth, Germany, the responsibilities for a creative team are hugely magnified. The task for director Jürgen Flimm and conductor Giuseppe Sinopoli is to produce a vision that will continue a tradition reaching back to the first-ever performances of the cycle.

Halfway through - with Das Rheingold and Die Walküre already performed and Siegfried and Götterdämmerung still to come - this Ring has already defined a thrillingly rich theatre of gods, giants and modern commentary. Wotan, the ruler of the gods, and Fricka, his wife, are cast as a pair of 21st-century plutocrats. The stage is littered with boxes and architectural plans, the detritus of a supernatural removal job. Behind them looms a city of scaffolding, that culminates in the imposing tower of Valhalla, which Wotan is building. Ambition is symbolised by architectural excess, with Wotan the chief developer of the celestial real estate.

The skill of Erich Wonder's designs and Florence von Gerkan's costumes is that, for all their worldly references, there is still room for magic and myth - and no character exemplifies these more than Loge, the god of fire. Kim Begley's portrayal of the fiery schemer flickers as brightly and unpredictably as the flames he conjures. He is the controlling force behind nearly every scene of Das Rheingold, playing one side against the other in each dispute.

Wonder's sets make visible the symbiotic bonds between the cave of the Nibelungs (dwarves) and the heights of Valhalla, in a series of lifts and rail-tracks that dominate every scene. Alberich, the Nibelung who steals from the Rhinemaidens the gold that will enable its owner to rule the world, shares Wotan's compulsive desire for power. Like Wotan's building site, Alberich's realm - with its plush office and hoards of besuited workers - bears witness to the obsessions of its creator.

By the second act of Die Walküre, Wotan's power has degenerated into paranoia. Alan Titus gives a towering performance, a complete portrayal of the appalling effects of misbegotten power. In a grim premonition of Götterdämmerung, Wotan wills: "Das Ende, Das Ende!". Titus makes this a definitive moment, as Wotan sees that his self-inflicted wounds must bring about the end, not just of himself, but of all the gods.

Titus's is the central performance of this Walküre, although Gabriele Schnaut's Brünnhilde is theatrically effective. It is the first act of Die Walküre - the most obviously "human" of the Ring so far - that is the most problematic. The mortals Hunding and Sieglinde's dwelling is more detached from normality than that of the gods. Waltraud Meier as Sieglinde and Placido Domingo as Siegmund make for a starry pair of lovers, but somehow they fail to generate the frisson that their godly counterparts manage. However, there is no want of dramatic interest in the post-apocalyptic splendour of the Valkyries, Wotan's warrior daughters who swing from Valhalla's heights alongside a parade of their victims.

Underpinning every moment is Sinopoli's superbly paced conducting. He has allowed the detail and architecture of Wagner's music to flow effortlessly - even with his occasionally slow speeds. Sinopoli and Flimm have built a fascinating foundation in Das Rheingold and Die Walküre; Siegfried and Götter- dämmerung are eagerly awaited.

By the second act of Die Walküre, Wotan's power has degenerated into paranoia. Alan Titus gives a towering performance, a complete portrayal of the appalling effects of misbegotten power. In a grim premonition of Götterdämmerung, Wotan wills: "Das Ende, Das Ende!". Titus makes this a definitive moment, as Wotan sees that his self-inflicted wounds must bring about the end, not just of himself, but of all the gods. Titus's is the central performance of this Walküre, although Gabriele Schnaut's Brünnhilde is theatrically effective. It is the first act of Die Walküre - the most obviously "human" of the Ring so far - that is the most problematic. The mortals Hunding and Sieglinde's dwelling is more detached from normality than that of the gods. Waltraud Meier as Sieglinde and Placido Domingo as Siegmund make for a starry pair of lovers, but somehow they fail to generate the frisson that their godly counterparts manage. However, there is no want of dramatic interest in the post-apocalyptic splendour of the Valkyries, Wotan's warrior daughters who swing from Valhalla's heights alongside a parade of their victims. Underpinning every moment is Sinopoli's superbly paced conducting. He has allowed the detail and architecture of Wagner's music to flow effortlessly - even with his occasionally slow speeds. Sinopoli and Flimm have built a fascinating foundation in Das Rheingold and Die Walküre; Siegfried and Götter- dämmerung are eagerly awaited.

webTitle: 'When Kissinger won the Nobel peace prize, satire died'

fields.headline: 'When Kissinger won the Nobel peace prize, satire died'
fields.standfirst: Todd S Purdom  on why songwriter Tom Lehrer has remained silent for 33 years
fields.trailText: Todd S Purdom on why songwriter Tom Lehrer has remained silent for 33 years
fields.body:
Tom Lehrer, the man who wrote Poisoning Pigeons in the Park, has been described as "the most brilliant song satirist ever recorded". His songs are the stuff of your adolescent imagination: subversive send-ups of the boy scouts, religion, pollution, plagiarism, prudishness. They are twisted, erudite parodies of the perverse: a necrophiliac's love song, a Masochism Tango, a nuclear military march. They are acid attacks on political expedience: " 'Once the rockets are up, who cares where they come down? That's not my department,' says Wernher von Braun."

So when you meet him, Lehrer comes as rather a surprise. Smiling, elfin, a bit stooped but slim and spry at 72, he is nothing so much as sweet. Sure, he confesses to still composing such questionable ditties as Bye- bye, Baby (about "partial-birth" abortion), but now it's strictly to appal himself. He bemoans the decline of civility and grammar and the collapse of the liberal consensus that made his songs of the 50s and 60s seem daring and safely hilarious at the same time.

But he does not pine for the performing career that made him a sensation in nightclubs and concert halls (his last major paid appearance was 33 years ago). He does not mourn the muse that seemed to desert him after Vietnam made it harder to be funny about serious things. Or, as he once put it: "Political satire became obsolete when Henry Kissinger was awarded the Nobel peace prize."

Why should Lehrer be glum, after all? A Harvard-trained mathematician, he spends the cold half of the year in a beautiful college town at the edge of the Pacific, teaching maths at the University of California at Santa Cruz, where he has worked since 1972, after stints at Harvard, Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Wellesley College. He still spends the warm half in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where he first went to Harvard as a precocious 15-year-old.

And Rhino Records today issues The Remains of Tom Lehrer, a boxed set of his works, including a handful of previously unreleased recordings such as I Got It From Agnes (you guessed what "it" is) and Hanukah in Santa Monica, a hymn to Jewish holidays that rhymes Shavuos with East St Louis. (He decided against a line that rhymed a body part with Passover).

"Amazing," Lehrer says modestly of the enduring appeal of his songs, which first saw the light in informal performances in Cambridge, then on a 10in, self-released LP in 1953 and later in the best-selling 1965 album That Was the Year That Was.

Professor Lehrer may stick to the blackboard and not the microphone these days, but his gift for verbal distillation has not deserted him. "When I was in college, there were certain words you couldn't say in front of a girl," he writes in the sleeve notes for the new collection. "Now you can say them, but you can't say 'girl'. "

Lehrer is not a recluse, though he resists all publicity unless he has something to sell, refuses television interviews (because he'd be asked to perform and then might be recognised in airports) and admits having encouraged rumours that he was dead, in the vain hope of cutting down on his junk mail. No, Lehrer is a man who had his moment, enjoyed it, banked his royalties and moved on. "I don't feel the need for anonymous affection," Lehrer said. "If they buy my records, I love that. But I don't think I need people in the dark applauding."

Besides, he adds: "I'm not interested in promoting myself, or revealing to total strangers anything about me. That's not my job. I read some of these things with people who will tell you about their abortions, and their affairs and their divorces and their breakdowns and their parents, and why are they doing that? And I'm sure if you asked them how much money they made last year, they'd tell you it's none of your business."

Lehrer grew up in New York, where his father manufactured ties and his mother took him to musical theatre, igniting a passion that has never wavered. He went to camp with a songwriter named Stephen Sondheim, whom he calls "the greatest lyricist the English language ever produced", but he wasn't especially close to him at the time. "I'm two years older, and when you're 10, you don't hang out with eight-year-olds," according to Lehrer.

He was also good at maths, not uncommon for musicians. "There's something mathematically satisfying about music: notes fit together and harmony and all that. And mathematics has to do with abstractions and making connections."

Formalities like a PhD and tenure eluded him, but Lehrer had a gift for pastiche, borrowing and echoing musical styles and sources from Gilbert and Sullivan to Danny Kaye. Indeed, Lobachevksy, his paean to plagiarism featuring the name of a real, dead, nonplagiarist Russian mathematician, is itself one big inside joke: "A direct plagiarism," Lehrer said, of a Danny Kaye routine about Stanislavsky.

The Lehrer canon, only about 50 recorded songs, falls into three basic clumps: his first two albums from the 50s, with black-comic parodies of various song styles and genres; the overtly political satire of That Was the Year That Was (a collection of songs contributed to the US television programme of the same name and recorded live at the Hungry i. nightclub in San Francisco); and everything else, including Silent E, his tribute to the transformative powers of spelling ("Who can turn a can into a cane?").

The early, risqué songs were well ahead of their time. Be Prepared, his goof on the boy scouts, for example, ends: "If you're looking for adventure of a new and different kind,/And come across a girl scout who is similarly inclined,/Don't be nervous, don't be flustered, don't be scared./Be prepared!"

fields.headline: Soros bid for 750 state buildings
fields.trailText: Billionaire global financier George Soros could become one of the largest property owners in Britain with the likely successful acquisition of 750 government buildings by his Mapeley consortium.
fields.body:
Billionaire global financier George Soros could become one of the largest property owners in Britain with the likely successful acquisition of 750 government buildings by his Mapeley consortium.

Backed by Soros Real Estate Partners, the Mapeley consortium is also understood to be bidding for the £450m property estate that Abbey National is preparing to sell.

The Inland Revenue is expected to announce this week the successful bidder of 750 properties occupied by the Revenue and Customs & Excise. They range from dog kennels run by Customs at ports to Inland Revenue offices and London buildings such as Customs House on the Thames.

The sale is part of the Steps - or strategic transfer of estate to the private sector - programme initiated by the Treasury to manage public assets more efficiently.

The various ministries have been instructed to sell assets worth a total of at least £1bn a
year. The Mapeley consortium would mark the third sale of the disposals with the MoD's married quarters estates having been sold to Japanese investment bank Nomura.

Trillium, a Goldman Sachs investment vehicle, bought control of the DSS portfolio in a separate deal.

The Mapeley consortium is competing against two other bidders: Servus, a Nomura-backed private finance initiative run with outsourcing specialists Serco, and Trillium.

The proposed sale and lease-back would represent one of the largest contracting-out deals in property for the government as it includes a 20-year agreement to supply managed office space to both Inland Revenue and Customs & Excise.

The value of the contract is not known but is estimated to be worth up to £1bn. An Inland Revenue spokeswoman said an announcement on the winning consortium could be published this week.

There are 430 Revenue and 320 Customs buildings.
