fields.headline: Clare in the chair
fields.standfirst: He's the psychiatrist who probes celebrities on Radio 4, gleaning their deepest secrets and fears. But Professor Anthony Clare has been analysing his own life lately and thinks it's time to make changes
fields.trailText: He's the psychiatrist who probes celebrities on Radio 4, gleaning their deepest secrets and fears. But Professor Anthony Clare has been analysing his own life lately and thinks it's time to make changes
fields.body:
Anthony Clare, the psychiatrist, is sitting in his chair in his consulting room in Dublin. There are seagulls wheeling outside the window. Inside is a plant and some stately furniture and on the floor a carpet so thick that your chair, when you move it, leaves marks like the spume in the wake of a cross-channel ferry. There are two Greek masks on a shelf, as if reminding visitors that, no matter how messy and unruly their emotions, they still fit easily within the comedy and tragedy of human experience. For those not convinced, there is also a big box of tissues to blot them up or out instead.

And there he is on the other side of the desk, head on one side, the man who for 30 years has in private counselled and medicated the troubled and dispossessed, while in public on Radio 4 wheedled secrets and vulnerability from the grand or famous or important for our shared delectation. Professor Anthony Clare, doctor and broadcaster: voice of patient understanding, voice of calm acceptance in a storm. "So tell me Boadicea, when did you first notice this urge to push yourself forward?"

All things considered, you might expect him to be on the quiet side when interviewed himself. But, "Ooh," he's saying, closing his eyes campishly for emphasis, "I think it must have been very difficult being married to me. I have changed a bit, but earlier on I would have been very driving, very ambitious. And I think my wife, Jane, would say I am very irritating to argue with."

Irritatingly calm? "No. No. NO. Why am I telling you this? I can be, I can be . . . as any of my friends can tell you . . . my children [he has seven] remember me as slightly explosive. I'd come out of my study and say, 'OH, FOR GOD'S SAKE!' . . . and that would be coming out of a family that was very argumentative, and runs counter to the image of the psychiatrist. Even in my clinics, my patients might have said: 'He can be feisty.' My wife stands up for herself, she can be quite combative too."

He raises his eyes to the ceiling in exaggerated exasperation. "The children would say, 'Oh God, there we go again', if we have another of our arguments about Shakespeare in Love or whatever it happens to be. Hmm. I would not have thought I was an easy person, no, no, no. NO."

Clare is explaining the personal background to his new book, On Men: Masculinity in Crisis, about the decline of "the phallic male", about the importance of finding a new role in a society where men are no longer the providers, the controllers, no longer vital to procreation. He argues that men need to place a greater value on family and social relationships and less on power and achievements. He keeps delving into his own experiences to back all this up - "the career, the career, the Maudsley [hospital, London] and the getting on in British psychiatry and the Bart's chair, and then the broadcasting . . . I think if I hadn't been in psychiatric medicine and if I hadn't been married to a woman like Jane," he says, "I might have got it too late. I nearly got it too late." At 57, he says, he has finally reached "a watershed".

He is a small man with little brown eyes and the face of a benign crow, a young Walter Matthau without the crumpled gloom. But he's much neater. He's wearing shiny patent leather shoes and the short sleeves of his white shirt have been ironed into points. He seems not at all masculine and not at all in crisis. Lots of his gestures are to do with tidying - he coaxes and flicks his greying black hair over a sparse patch at the back, he fiddles with his watch, he rearranges the stapler on his desk. It's true that he does this most when talking about his formative years: the mother who "found it difficult to praise", who believed in life as "a vale of tears"; the father, a solicitor, "who was not a man who talked about his feelings". (Clare has "regrets" that he didn't try to talk to them more, though fears "they didn't have the language".) There is a bit of hair work too when talking about his own "bat squeaks of depression" as a young intern in the US. But, to be frank, all this seems to have less to do with repressed anxiety than the polite boredom of conjuring up a past that seems, to the product of his upbringing at least, a long way off.

Tap into an enthusiasm, on the other hand, and he becomes positively theatrical, throwing himself around his chair as if on stage. He will tell you all about his children (only two still at home, one back all the time with her washing, all "physically affectionate"), his home on the banks of the Liffey, his wife and, of course, his work. He clearly adores his work (but that's men for you). He describes himself as an "eclectic psychiatrist", believing in "the interplay of genetics and personality and circumstance and gender and social expectations and attributes and values and culture".

"People say, 'What the hell is that, some sort of mishmash?' But, temperamentally, I recoil from the schools in psychiatry." His whole body shivers. "I cannot stand the committed ideologists. The Freudians, the Jungians, the Behaviourists." His arms knife the air. "At the moment the great rage is for biological psychiatry. People who tell you seriously that that's it, the genome, we've cracked everything. Doctors learn nothing. The hubris!" He throws his eyes up to the ceiling, twists his torso around in horror.

Later, he picks up a mention of Prozac and thrashes it in the air as if in the throes of an ongoing argument. "There is no evidence whatsoever that the new generation of drugs is therapeutically superior to the old generation," he says, shaking his head so vigorously it's a surprise it doesn't fall off. "None whatsoever. Where is this happy revolution? Of course not. Of course not."

Clare's "phallic" drive has made him medical director at St Patrick's hospital in Dublin where he works most of the week, only whizzing off to the fleshpots of Broadcasting House on the 4pm Friday flight. He sees no contradiction between his two jobs - "they overlap", he says - and in fact thinks journalism has made him a better psychiatrist. He sits back comfortably in his chair to ponder.

"Psychiatry came out of the analytic model where time didn't matter and you just let it all happen. Nonsense! Time is extremely expensive and you've got to use it." On a few occasions, the line between celebrity and clinical interview has been even more blurred. "It's breaking no confidence to say that RD Laing, interestingly the only psychiatrist I've interviewed, was in trouble and talked about it candidly - his drink problem. And Alice Thomas Ellis was very depressed when I saw her and Lewis Wolpert wasn't depressed but might just as easily have been. Often there is a thin line that separates them from someone who is in serious trouble and that thin line might be talent; without that they would be very vulnerable indeed."

The same tricks work in both arenas too. "One way is to wait. They're answering a question and they've stopped and they're starting to think . . . and sometimes you get a genuinely fresh answer then. A second trick is to repeat the last sentence if you think they haven't given you enough. Somebody says, 'Well, you know, my marriage was OK - as marriages go.' You might say, 'What do you mean by that?' Or, you might say, 'As marriages go?' And there is often a way of saying that. You don't need to be Tom Stoppard now. 'As marriages go...? As marriages go?'

"And then don't get too focused too soon - that comes out of medicine. You start big. Some interviewers can't do that. Paxman has to go in immediately. My field is lower paced. You can't risk antagonising the interviewee on the programme, especially if you're in practice as I am. You can't have someone coming out and saying, 'I was mauled by him. Disgusting! What kind of a psychiatrist is that!' " He gives another loud laugh.

These days, he's not so sure that In The Psychiatrist's Chair should continue. Too many interviews everywhere, he says, too much Diana bulimia revelation. He is "giving thought" to giving up. Which brings us to the watershed. He is giving up the medical directorship at the end of the year, to become an ordinary consultant instead. He is trying to say no to some of the journalism: "To resist temptation" he says revealingly.

Instead, Clare wants to spend more time with his family, "with English friends, and Irish friends", to go to the cinema more and the theatre, and the opera, to travel, and to play golf. There is a course next door to his house, "a beautiful golf course", he says with a purr, "a superb golf course".

For this reconstructed male - "almost reconstucted, but not quite" - a new-found identity sounds an awful lot like old-fashioned retirement.

The same tricks work in both arenas too. "One way is to wait. They're answering a question and they've stopped and they're starting to think . . . and sometimes you get a genuinely fresh answer then. A second trick is to repeat the last sentence if you think they haven't given you enough. Somebody says, 'Well, you know, my marriage was OK - as marriages go.' You might say, 'What do you mean by that?' Or, you might say, 'As marriages go?' And there is often a way of saying that. You don't need to be Tom Stoppard now. 'As marriages go...? As marriages go?' "And then don't get too focused too soon - that comes out of medicine. You start big. Some interviewers can't do that. Paxman has to go in immediately. My field is lower paced. You can't risk antagonising the interviewee on the programme, especially if you're in practice as I am. You can't have someone coming out and saying, 'I was mauled by him. Disgusting! He is giving up the medical directorship at the end of the year, to become an ordinary consultant instead. He is trying to say no to some of the journalism: "To resist temptation" he says revealingly. Instead, Clare wants to spend more time with his family, "with English friends, and Irish friends", to go to the cinema more and the theatre, and the opera, to travel, and to play golf. There is a course next door to his house, "a beautiful golf course", he says with a purr, "a superb golf course". For this reconstructed male - "almost reconstucted, but not quite" - a new-found identity sounds an awful lot like old-fashioned retirement.

fields.headline: A dirty job
fields.standfirst: Annie Sprinkle is, she says, a pro-porn feminist - for 25 years she has sung the praises of sexually explicit material for women.  Anita Chaudhuri hears the word
fields.trailText: Annie Sprinkle is, she says, a pro-porn feminist - for 25 years she has sung the praises of sexually explicit material for women.  Anita Chaudhuri hears the word
fields.body:
Annie Sprinkle, the American porn star turned performance artist, would like a word with Jack Straw. "It's outrageous: your customs people won't allow any of my videos into the country. What's the matter with you all? When I come over and perform my live show, they make me cut out anything that shows penetrative sex. I mean, c'mon, God has programmed all of us to be interested in sexuality, it's a gift! Britain has a lot to learn from America."

The recent high court decision to allow seven hardcore films to be sold in licensed sex shops did not extend to any of Sprinkle's productions; not Deep Inside Annie Sprinkle, not the Sluts and Goddesses Video Workshop. However, one east London cinema is screening her latest film, Annie Sprinkle's Herstory of Porn, as part of Porno Chic, a season that sets out to explore the timely issue that pornography, whether we like it or not, has entered mainstream culture through Channel 5, car advertising, cinema, music and the internet.

Sprinkle's film can best be described as docu-porn, charting a 25-year career in the industry with dozens of clips from her films, accompanied by her often humorous commentary. "In erotica you just use the feather, in porn you use the whole chicken," she quips. Much of it is decidedly unappealing, but the latter half of the film, showcasing the work she produced herself, is compelling if only because it shows a woman enjoying sex in a way that one never usually sees in either mainstream pornography or mainstream cinema.

"The film is really art," she claims. "I want it to play in museums. It is not meant to be erotic." This is fortunate since it includes everything from cheap 1970s nasties to a hotchpotch of "New Age" footage featuring yogic chants, lesbian mermaids and "cry-gasms". "I want women's studies students, cultural theorists and film students to see it," she adds. "It's about making people think."

Born Ellen Steinberg, Sprinkle rebelled against her well-to-do teacher parents and became a prostitute when she left school. She drifted into the porn industry and is one of only a handful of women to have come out the other side with her own career. She calls herself a "pro-porn feminist" and is evangelical about the benefits of sexually explicit material to society in general - "There should be sex kitchens in every town like they have soup kitchens, then there would be less rape, less war, less violence" - and to women in particular. "Women need to be educated about how to watch porn," she says. "The reason many women don't like porn is because they are filled with shame about their own bodies, they feel it's wrong to explore their own sexual pleasure."

Surely it has occurred to Sprinkle that there are other, more convincing reasons why many women do not enjoy pornography? Leaving aside the usual charges that it is exploitative, violent and degrading, much of it is mind-numbingly dull and repetitive, badly produced and lacking any aesthetic allure. "Yes, I agree a lot of porn is bad, patriarchal and misogynistic," Sprinkle says. "But no matter where we stand, pornography reflects us all. That's why I went into producing, directing and starring in my own films, so we could have a product by women for women for the first time."

She made a series of films with Candida Royalle, a New York producer who got "women-friendly" films on to the top shelves of video shops both in the US and in Britain. The work was based on the premise that women wanted their pornography to be romantic. The result was a cross between a Gold Blend ad and a Madonna video (you remember, before she got squeamish about page three girls). Trying to second-guess what kind of visual material will stimulate women has so far left the soft porn industry at a loss. Several years ago, a flurry of magazines was launched, including For Women and Bite. These disappeared as abruptly as they appeared, for the simple reason that women didn't buy them.

Kathryn Hoyle, owner of women's sex shop Sh!, believes women are not confident about exploring pornography for themselves; they usually discover it through a partner and this is not necessarily the most positive initiation. "How can women know if they like pornography when it's so difficult to get hold of material?" she asks. "Even with top shelf magazines, buying them is embarrassing. In my local newsagent's, I feel I have to say 'Oh, I'm buying these for work, you know, it's research'. If I feel like that, doing the job I do, so must most other women. There's this feeling that if you are a woman buying porn, you must either be a sad frump who can't get sex any other way, or a nymphomaniac."

At Hoyle's London shop, there is a video machine so women can watch before they buy. "Sometimes I go down to that area of the shop and there are all these women sitting on the floor watching a film, and I feel like handing round popcorn. But if we didn't provide this service, I'm not sure women would buy; they wouldn't feel confident about paying £16 for a video they might not even like."

Is it possible to make a general assumption about what material women enjoy? "No. It's always said women prefer suggestive material rather than explicit, that they enjoy the spoken or written word rather than the visual, but I haven't seen much evidence to support that in my shop."

In Britain, where the laws governing the distribution of pornography are among the toughest in the democratic world, the debate about women and pornography is still in its infancy. It is not a bandwagon British feminists often choose to climb aboard. A recent example was news coverage of the imminent release in this country of Baise-Moi, the controversial French film about two women who go on a spree of sex and murder. It contains explicit sex scenes, as did last year's French film Romance. The only voices of protest so far have come from the National Viewers' and Listeners' Association and the Conservative Family Group. There have been no feminist protests; yes, the film is directed by a woman, but in America that would not be enough to restrain the anti-porn camp. In America, many feminist academics have made entire careers out of pornography.

Among them is University of Michigan law professor Catherine MacKinnon whose anti-porn diatribe Only Words asserts: "Pornography, in the feminist view, is a form of forced sex." MacKinnon and fellow anti-porn campaigner Andrea Dworkin have been dubbed "MacDworkin" by hostile pro-porn feminists and have gone so far as to try to introduce a Pornography Victims Compensation Act which would give women - and men - the right to sue if they felt they had been injured by any form of sexual expression they found offensive.

"I don't think these anti-porn women have seen my films," Sprinkle says. "But loads of other women have. That's why pro-porn feminists are winning the war, the war that says the answer to bad pornography is no pornography. That's not right and more and more feminists are agreeing with that. The solution is for us to make better porn."

• Annie Sprinkle's Herstory of Porn is on at the Lux, Hoxton Sq, London N1, 020-7684 0201

fields.headline: View from the trolley
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson: The age of dissent
fields.body:
My mother has had pneumonia. I dragged her to the doctor, who rang the hospital, found her a bed and sent us straight there. But my poor mother still had to sit in casualty for hours on end. Silly innocents. We thought you just trotted off to hospital with your suitcase and got into bed. Wrong. First of all you have to go through A&E, sit on metal seats and wait among the moaning crowds, wailing infants, roaring drunks and blaring telly, even if you are 94, can't breathe and are practically flaking out on your chair.

So my mother sat wilting while I flapped around trying to hurry things up. It did us no good. It is the hospital doctors, not your GP, who decide whether or not you may have a bed. This was a grisly experience. I have already had one parent die on a hospital trolley and am not keen to have it happen again.

But even a trolley is better than a metal chair and after an hour or so, my mother was lying down on one somewhere quiet. Tea and sandwiches were brought round, doctors and nurses were perfect. "Very thorough!" croaked my mother and eventually, five hours later, she was trundled off to a proper bed and then, the next day, off to the women's geriatric ward.

"Where's the red carpet?" she asked on arrival. Soon she was gaining strength and able to carry out lavatory inspections. Within hours, she had found out which ladies left the lavatories spotless and charmingly perfumed, and had begun to time her visits to follow them. Then there were menus to tick, pills to take, oxygen up your nose, cheery nurses backwards and forwards. My mother's breathing and appetite improved, the hairdresser was booked and things were definitely looking up, until the poor lady in the next bed died in the night.

My mother lay there, feet away, listening to the awful sounds of the Reaper so close by. She didn't have much of a sleep and looked rather pasty the next day. This close encounter did her appetite and breathing no good at all, but she is still improving. A new lady has moved into the empty bed. "Life goes on," says my mother with a grim look. And luckily so does hers. She will be home next week.

fields.headline: Battle of the bulge
fields.standfirst: Have the government's family-friendly policies caused a split between women with children and those without?  Luisa Dillner reports
fields.trailText: Have the government's family-friendly policies caused a split between women with children and those without?  Luisa Dillner reports
fields.body:
So childless employees are seething behind their word processors at the perks given to colleagues with kids, if a study in Management Today is to be believed. As a harassed mother stumbles in late (after dropping one child at school and the other at nursery five miles away because there's a childcare shortage, didn't you know?), wearing baby puke and bags under her eyes, those workmates who are child-free must think she has all the luck. "Half day is it?" they may say - all in good humour, of course.

The fact that over half of a sample of 2,000 managers said that family friendly policies create resentment is hardly surprising. In Britain we have a proud tradition of resenting children (especially at social events). By logical extension, we resent any measures that might make it easier for working mothers to care for them. The research is clear that children need to spend some time with their mothers to stop them growing up and putting bricks through windows. Mothers charge nothing to bring up children and tend to do a better job than social services. The government's emphasis on family friendly policies therefore seems sensible.

There is still a curious assumption that having a child is the ultimate self-indulgence, that a baby is a luxury item. There is inevitably tension between any group of haves and have-nots, and this is heightened when the commodity is children. The have-nots are not a homogenous group - being child-free from choice is worlds away from being unwillingly childless. But both may have good reason to resent parents. Working mothers with children can bang on about the intelligence and rare beauty of their offspring, and seem unaware that people without kids don't share their fascination with north London schools. They may cause havoc in the office by assuming it is their divine right to take off Christmas and two weeks every August because who else but a parent really wants them? Then there's the time off for sports day, the dentist, tummy aches and colds.

Perhaps, too, there really are women who have made "the sacrifice" not to have children in order to pursue careers, who feel bitter seeing the help given to working mothers. But the idea seems archaic, a throwback to Victorian England when stark choices had to be made.

If working women and their partners really don't want to face the emotional and financial havoc children bring, if they really decide their career is incompatible with procreating, this really is a lifestyle choice. They will be able to afford and enjoy uninterrupted skiing holidays, lie in on Sundays and read more than one line of a newspaper at a time. They will be able to have coitus uninterrupted by a toddler pulling their hair. So surely they can't seriously resent it if their colleagues with kids get just a little extra help?

The relationship between working women who do and don't have children can be more painful than that between men and women, though. A working mother may feel embarrassed to ask a woman to cover in a childcare crisis, unsure of why her colleague doesn't have children and worried she'll be bad-mouthed for off-loading her work because she can't control her "other", domestic life. A working mother may feel she has to be better than men and women colleagues who are unencumbered by children.

Meanwhile, women without children may believe they should be taken more seriously, fast-tracked for promotion because they have nothing to distract them from their work. Isn't their childless state an indication that work is more of a priority for them? Why give extra help to working mothers when they should be shunted into a siding to make room for fresh young career women?

It is arguable that working mothers get much help, anyway. It still feels an uphill struggle to work and be a parent. If managers were more willing to treat employees as grown-ups who can be trusted to work outside the office, the working revolution would have occurred much earlier. It is working mothers who should be congratulated rather than resented for forcing the issue.

webTitle: 'Scotty, you're a people person. You'll do good'

fields.headline: 'Scotty, you're a people person. You'll do good'
fields.standfirst: Jacob's Creek has the highest concentration of used-car dealerships in America. When  Lawrence Donegan  got a job there, it took him 10 days to make his first sale - and the car blew up as it left the forecourt. Now, four months later, he is about to be named Salesman of the Month...
fields.trailText: Jacob's Creek has the highest concentration of used-car dealerships in America. When  Lawrence Donegan  got a job there, it took him 10 days to make his first sale - and the car blew up as it left the forecourt. Now, four months later, he is about to be named Salesman of the Month...
fields.body:
Not far from where I live in California's Silicon Valley there are scientists so skilled that they can place millions of transistors on a piece of paper no bigger than a baby's fingernail. By a remarkable coincidence, it turns out there would still be just enough space on that same piece of paper to accommodate everything I know about the workings of the modern automobile.

I am not, never have been, a "car" person. As a kid, I never pinned a Jackie Stewart poster on my bedroom wall. I never took my driving test on my 17th birthday, or ripped apart a camshaft (whatever that is) for the sheer unalloyed joy of putting it back together again. Not for a second have I pondered the advantages of the automatic transmission over the five-speed manual gearbox. Is the Toyota Camry better than the Honda Accord? Does it matter, as long as the wheels go round? I think not.

But guess what? I am currently "leading the board" in the Salesman of the Month competition at Stephen's Creek Pre-Owned Automobiles. I'm ahead of Andrew "the Crocodile" McDonald (recovering alcoholic and the acknowledged best car salesman ever to walk God's earth), Luis Fernandez (Nicaraguan civil war veteran), Jason "MoFo" Preston (rap recording artist), Baghwan Sheree (Indian spiritualist and The Car Salesman Formerly Known as BeBe), Vance McNamee (who once played soccer at school with the comedian Robin Williams), Tom Field (Vietnam war vet and holder of two Purple Hearts for bravery), Tommy "the Tank" Tomasello (who left his last job just after the tax inspectors moved in) and other assorted salesmen whose names are hardly worth remembering because they will be here today and gone tomorrow.

In the past 10 days I have sold $185,000 worth of tin, including a $41,000 Sport Utility Vehicle purchased by two ageing hippies called Dan and Lisa and a $4,350 1988 Dodge Dynasty driven home by 67-year-old, alcoholic Harvard alumnus. I have made $15,230 gross profit for the dealership and $3,046 commission for myself. Best of all, the other morning I asked a customer who walked on to the lot if he needed any help and he replied "leave me alone, I hate car salesmen"; yet one hour later the same man wrote a cheque for $12,875 for a 1998 Toyota with 38,000 miles on the clock.

Forgive me if this sounds boastful, but I have enjoyed a varied life. I have played in pop group in front of 70,00 people at Glastonbury. I have worked for the best newspaper in the world (the Guardian, of course). I have written two books. I have birdied the 17th at the Old Course. I am blessed with the love and friendship of a wonderful woman. But nothing, and I mean nothing, comes close to the feeling of selling a car to someone who, 60 minutes before, believed in his heart of hearts that you were a sleazy, lying, lowlife scumbag. It is better than sex. Trust me, I'm a used-car salesman.

"You're leading the board, Scotty. You want to be number one, don't you?" an incredulous Andrew McDonald said to me yesterday morning as we sat down to our regular Egg McMuffin breakfast. "You're the worst car salesman I've met in 20 years in the business. Tell me, how come you're leading the board?"

"Andrew," I replied, giving his question careful consideration. "I'm buggered if I know."

America's love affair with the motor car is well documented, but beyond the legend of Henry Ford and photographs of James Dean's wrecked Porsche lie some startling statistics. Since the Model T rolled off the production line, 5bn cars have been sold in the United States. Last year alone, according to the National Auto Dealers Association of America, its members sold $534bn worth of vehicles. More than 1m salesman of varying ability and trustworthiness work at dealerships and automalls in communities across the country.

Steven's Creek Auto Row in San Jose, California, is classed as an automall, with dealers ranging from the high-end Mercedes and Cadillac shops to the so-called "pot lots" down the bottom end of the street (where buying a used car is as dangerous as juggling grenades). It is said that Stephen's Creek has the biggest concentration of car dealerships in the United States. I work at a place called Stephen's Creek Pre-Owned Autos, near the eastern end of the boulevard. It's more pot lot than high end, though we don't sell wrecks and, believe it or not, a handful of our used cars even come with a warranty. However, we do specialise in customers with credit problems who might be looking for the modest four-door "commuter car" in the, say, $5,000-$6,000 price range. Salesman on our lot are trained never to lie to a customer, though several of the more successful guys appear to have PhDs in semantics. We work out of a temporary wooden cabin which has been there for 10 years now. The carpets are worn bare, the desks were bought at firesale and the receptionist, Sasha, is indolent beyond salvation. The cars are parked out front on an uncompromising asphalt square, where the temperatures can hit 115 degrees in the summer.

Customers who walk on to the Mercedes dealership across the street are welcomed by gorgeous "greeters" who will usher them inside for a fruit juice and a chat with an automobile consultant. Walking on to our lot is like making a guest appearance in Jaws; you are devoured by salesmen.

Virtually all of our business is done at the weekend. During the week the salesman just sit around eating or discussing the big issues, such as "What is the best shoe for a car salesman?", or "Blue shirt or white shirt - which deflects the sun best?" Answers: Rockport, and white. Occasionally someone will make a special effort to amuse the others, by persuading a passing customer to climb into the trunk of a car, say, or by phoning up a guy who has placed an ad in the AutoTrader selling a smashed-up Ferrari for $30,000.

Salesman: So, are you fixed on this $30,000 price or I can you move a little?

Ferrari Man (attempting to play the hard-nosed salesman): I' m sorry, but the answer is no.

Salesman: But the car is wrecked.

FM: Maybe I could come down a couple of hundred dollars. It's a Ferrari, remember.

Salesman: Well, what about if I gave you a top-notch blow job . . .

It's been four months now and I can scarcely remember why I took the job in the first place. I believe it started when I went to buy a car of my own on Stephen's Creek and ran into a salesman called Wes, an oleaginous giant of a man. "This is it - the final frontier, the last bastion of American capitalism. You can't bargain for your shoes or your trousers, you can't bargain at the dentist or the doctor. But here," Wes told me, sweeping his hands towards the street, "Here, you can haggle over the price of a car for the rest of your life. Sell a car and be a star - it's the best job on the planet, believe me."

Until that point I'd toyed with the idea of working for an old university friend, the CEO of one of Silicon Valley's innumerable high-tech companies. He promised me stock options, more money than I'd ever seen before, retirement at the age of 40. But there was an exhilaration in Wes's voice... The last bastion of American capitalism, the final frontier, sell a car and be a star... that proved irresistible. I was hooked on car sales. In any case, who wants to be a dot.com millionaire?

Getting a job was easy. No one likes car salesmen in the United States, and no one wants to be one. There is the constant rejection and contempt. More to the point - at least in California - the wages are atrocious: $1,000 a month plus commission (20% of gross profit on any vehicle sold). A burger jockey at McDonald's makes more than a bad car salesman.

"It's not a complicated job. With that accent of yours, you'll do good," Tom Field, the sales manager, told me during my 30-second job interview.

"I will?"

"Of course. You're a people person. I can tell."

It took me 10 days to sell my first car, a 1996 Dodge Neon with 54,345 miles on the clock, to a beautiful bank teller from Santa Cruz called Stephanie. It cost her $6,998 plus tax and it blew up as she was driving it home along the outside lane of Highway 17 (officially California's most dangerous road). She received a full refund, but only after a fight with the boss and a 911 call to the cops. The deal was an "unwind", as they say in the trade. No sale, no profit, no commission. Struck from the record.

Gradually, I got better. It took only nine days to sell my next car, a 1996 Mercedes C280 (total commission, $153). In my first month I sold four cars - a mere 31 cars behind the salesman of the month, Andrew McDonald.

"What am I doing wrong?" I asked McDonald, whom I'd secretly appointed as my mentor.

"You ain't selling any fuckin' cars Scotty, that's what you're doing wrong," he replied. "Here, let me show how to do it - you sell a car just like you're selling them a six-pack. Budweiser sir? No problem, let me ring that up for you."

The other salesman took pity on me too. They ruffled my hair, called me affectionate names like Greenpea and let me listen in on their deals. "A hundred and nine thousand miles madam? Don't worry about the miles, it's a Japanese car, the most reliable in the world. That's why you're buying it. Now would you look at that back seat. Purrfect! I don't believe anyone has ever sat it in..."

Every day for a month I sat in baking sun and soaked up their advice - never tell the customer the price unless they ask three times, always tell them you have the car they want, even when you don't, always get them on a test drive, and always, always, get them in the booth ("You like the car, yes? What happened? I've asked myself that a million times. After all, I'm still doing the same things I did when I couldn't sell cars. I still know less than zero about the internal combustion engine and the heap of sales training manuals I bought from Borders have remained unopened since the day I brought them home.

Perhaps it's my accent, my biorhythms or the lucky blue tie I bought at Macy's. Maybe it's the fact that, like Annette Bening's crazed real estate agent in American Beauty, I wake up every day and tell myself: "I will make a sale today. I will make a sale today." Whatever it is, I've got to keep on doing it because the days are rolling by and that Salesman of the Month plaque sure would look great on my bathroom wall.

webTitle: Kashmir truce inflames rival rebel groups

fields.headline: Kashmir truce inflames rival rebel groups
fields.standfirst: Special report: the India-Pakistan conflict
fields.trailText: Militants opposed to Indian rule in Kashmir last night pledged to escalate their campaign of violence following a "treasonous" ceasefire announcement last week by a rival hardline group.
fields.byline: Luke Harding and Rory McCarthy in Islamabad
fields.body:
Militants opposed to Indian rule in Kashmir last night pledged to escalate their campaign of violence following a "treasonous" ceasefire announcement last week by a rival hardline group.

They accused the Hizbul Mojahedin, which has unilaterally laid down its weapons for three months, of being "bought" by India, and vowed that their 10-year jihad, or holy war, would continue. The Indian government has welcomed Hizbul's unexpected move and has invited its leaders for talks.

Several militant organisations yesterday said that they would continue their offensive against Indian military targets. At least 12 people have died in Kashmir gun battles since the ceasefire.

"We strongly reject the so-called ceasefire. We term it a betrayal of the blood of the martyrs," a spokesman for the hardline Jamiatul Mojahedin said.

"This is treason," Mushtaq Askari of the Al-Badar Mojahedin added.

More than a dozen militant organisations last week expelled Hizbul from its leading role in the United Jihad Council, which represents groups fighting in the Kashmir valley.

A senior Indian army commander said that his troops had suspended operations in Kashmir against Hizbul for the first time in 11 years.

Diplomatic sources say the US has been involved in fresh attempts to broker a peace deal in Kashmir. The ceasefire follows the release earlier this year from Indian jails of leading separatist politicians, and a recent attempt by the state's Muslim chief minister, Farooq Abdullah, to win autonomy.

"The mojahedin are now likely to step up their activities. They will want to prove their point that Hizbul's ceasefire decision was not taken in consultation with anybody else," General Mirza Aslam Beg, a former head of the Pakistan army, said.

Senior Indian politicians said the government had given a "very enthusiastic" response to Hizbul's announcement. Talks, however, could only take place within the framework of the constitution, which says Kashmir is an integral part of India, they said.

fields.headline: No: 1688
fields.standfirst: Tsar Nicholas II
fields.trailText: Tsar Nicholas II
fields.body:
Age:
50 when executed by Bolsheviks in 1918.

Also known as:
Bloody Nicholas.

... and to the Russian Orthodox Church as:
St Nicholas, holy martyr. After tomorrow, anyway, when they're expected to canonise him.

...and to his wife Alexandra as:
Darling boysy, lovy, naughty one.

Appearance:
Prince Michael of Kent. That beard, those eyes - they run in the family, you know.

The Kents?
No, ignorant commoner, the extended European royal family. Nicholas was largely of German ancestry and his wife Alexandra was Queen Victoria's granddaughter; they always spoke English to each other.

English? "Darling boysy"?
He told Alexandra he was her "poor little weak-willed Hubby".

He must have been a good tsar, though, if they want to make him a saint?
Yeah, great, his reign ended with one of the bloodiest social rebellions in human history, the Bolshevik revolution and subsequent civil war. That good.

That wasn't his fault, surely?
He believed in the divine right of kings, thought all of Russia belonged to him, shed blood to prevent the introduction of democracy, quietly celebrated anti-semitic pogroms, stood by while his wife fell under the spell of the mad monk Rasputin and was partly responsible for the military disasters which ushered in the revolution.

Now you sound like a commoner.
Some say he behaved with dignity and humility in the months leading up to his execution, when he, his wife, their five children and their servants were shot. Some say he simply had a nervous breakdown.

So they're all martyrs, and they'll all be made saints?
Not the servants, of course. Can't have all those vulgar untitled people cluttering up the holy days.

This St Nicholas, does he do miracles?
Funny you should ask. An icon of the tsar has been touring Russia, weeping myrrh. But most Russians would be content if they could qualify for the next World Cup.

Not to be confused with:
The drugs tsar, the crime tsar, Santa Claus.

fields.headline: Management uncertainty
fields.trailText: Almost a third of managers feel their lives are out of control. Since they are supposed to be in charge, this is fairly alarming. A survey sponsored by Management Today and Ceridian, a consultancy that works in the burgeoning field of flexible benefits (or "work-life packages", as the company calls them) reveals some of the emotional cost incurred after a decade of uncertainty in the office.
fields.body:
Almost a third of managers feel their lives are out of control. Since they are supposed to be in charge, this is fairly alarming. A survey sponsored by Management Today and Ceridian, a consultancy that works in the burgeoning field of flexible benefits (or "work-life packages", as the company calls them) reveals some of the emotional cost incurred after a decade of uncertainty in the office.

It turns out that more than a third of managers do not expect to be with their current firm two years from now. Eight years ago, when recession and downsizing stalked the land, that figure would no doubt have been higher. But in a growing economy, full of slimmed-down organisations anxious to retain what staff they have, this amount of uncertainty is striking.

It is widely agreed that flexible hours would create a happier and more efficient workforce, but few companies dare to try the experiment. Two-thirds of managers believe that being seen around the office is more important than actually getting anything done. That conviction is felt even more widely among mothers (80%).

Three-quarters of those polled said they wished they were free to spend more time with their families. And 30% would take less money for more time off (not all of them parents).

"Shall I kick in the well-paid job for the freedom of self- employment? Enough of the rat race? Watch this space," wrote one respondent. But the grass is always greener, especially when one is too busy to look across the fence at the other side. Two-thirds of mothers admitted that there were times when work was an escape from home.

webTitle: Blairs call in PCC over baby photos

fields.headline: Blairs call in PCC over baby photos
fields.standfirst:
PM seeks to prevent 'open season' on his children

Special report: Blairs' baby
fields.trailText: The prime minister yesterday defended his decision to call in the press complaints commission over the publication of pictures showing him taking his baby son, Leo, to be christened.
fields.body:
The prime minister yesterday defended his decision to call in the press complaints commission over the publication of pictures showing him taking his baby son, Leo, to be christened.

While Downing Street conceded the pictures that appeared in most of the Sunday newspapers were harmless, Tony Blair's spokesman said his family wanted to prevent "open season" on their children.

The Blairs insist they do not want to appear heavy-handed, and do not plan to lodge an official complaint with the commission. Instead they will write to its chairman, Lord Wakeham, asking for clarification of the rules.

The newspaper industry's code of conduct forbids the publication of pictures of children without their parents' consent: Mr Blair and his wife, Cherie, had made it clear before Saturday's event that it was private and they did not want publicity.

However, there were about 300 people outside St John Fisher Roman Catholic church in Sedgefield, the prime minister's constituency, and many took photographs of the Blairs carrying Leo to and from the church.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's spokesman, said: "This is not a formal complaint but we are genuinely seeking [the commission's] advice on how best to handle a difficult area for the family."

He admitted that many people were interested in the event, but said the prime minister was concerned that his children's privacy should not be invaded.

"On the one hand, it was obvious from the number of local people who turned up yesterday that this was a happy event in which people wanted to share, and the pictures published are perfectly inoffensive.

"On the other hand, the prime minister and Mrs Blair are concerned that to give consent to publication on such occasions risks giving open season to the press not just in relation to the baby but their other children too.

"This is a genuine dilemma and one which they hope can be addressed in a sensible way that takes into account their legitimate desire to see their children enjoy as normal an upbringing as possible in the abnormal circumstances of being children of a serving prime minister."

Speaking on the BBC's Breakfast With Frost programme yesterday, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said the photographs were "lovely pictures".

He added, however: "The point the prime minister is trying to make is that he does want Leo to be a very private matter for the family. He doesn't want intrusive attention, he would much rather they got on with the business of bringing up the family in their own way."

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's spokesman, said: "This is not a formal complaint but we are genuinely seeking [the commission's] advice on how best to handle a difficult area for the family." He admitted that many people were interested in the event, but said the prime minister was concerned that his children's privacy should not be invaded. "On the one hand, it was obvious from the number of local people who turned up yesterday that this was a happy event in which people wanted to share, and the pictures published are perfectly inoffensive. "On the other hand, the prime minister and Mrs Blair are concerned that to give consent to publication on such occasions risks giving open season to the press not just in relation to the baby but their other children too. "This is a genuine dilemma and one which they hope can be addressed in a sensible way that takes into account their legitimate desire to see their children enjoy as normal an upbringing as possible in the abnormal circumstances of being children of a serving prime minister." Speaking on the BBC's Breakfast With Frost programme yesterday, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said the photographs were "lovely pictures". He added, however: "The point the prime minister is trying to make is that he does want Leo to be a very private matter for the family. He doesn't want intrusive attention, he would much rather they got on with the business of bringing up the family in their own way."

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 30: The fan
fields.trailText: Fans in the office are rather like ice-cream vans and satchel-sporting French schoolchildren - they appear in large numbers as soon as the first good summer day hits us, but no one is ever quite sure where from. It takes only the smallest flash of blue sky to have us preternaturally optimistic Brits scrambling to a fan for our desks, fully expecting to expire at any point from a long-awaited heatwave .
fields.body:
Fans in the office are rather like ice-cream vans and satchel-sporting French schoolchildren - they appear in large numbers as soon as the first good summer day hits us, but no one is ever quite sure where from. It takes only the smallest flash of blue sky to have us preternaturally optimistic Brits scrambling to a fan for our desks, fully expecting to expire at any point from a long-awaited heatwave .

This is a particularly cruel irony in a summer such as this one, in which we have so far enjoyed about an hour and 20 minutes of sunshine in total. But despite the primeval longing to baste oneself in baby oil and roast like a turkey in the park at lunchtime, it seems we can't bear to run even the smallest risk of being too hot at work.

It's not surprising that fans are so popular in the office, since workplace air-conditioning is something our proud nation manages even less successfully than underground railway commuter lines. How many more holes in the sieve-like ozone layer need to appear before management is convinced that global warming really is happening and that Britain is getting warmer? (OK, so it doesn't feel like it at the moment, but that's not the point.)

Fans of the fan should be careful in how they use their enlarged hairdryer, however, as there are a few important rules of blower etiquette. Consulting with colleagues is always a good start, particularly if your chosen setting subjects your neighbour to a fringe-tossing gale every 15 seconds. Loose pieces of paper should be secured, preferably under those strange glass globes called paper weights that someone once decided the world could not do without. And ribbons should never, ever, be attached to the front. Not because of any health risk, but because it looks unspeakably naff. Best remove them before your fan is hit by the you-know-what.

webTitle: Rebranding yourself - more than just a symbolic gesture

fields.headline: Rebranding yourself - more than just a symbolic gesture
fields.standfirst: Are you being taken for granted, passed over for promotion, your talents ignored? Maybe it's time to market a new image of yourself. After all, if BP can do it, so can you
fields.trailText: There's nothing worse than being predictable. Competent, reliable, good at what you do, but never considered for anything new, or different. That same old, familiar image never surprises and never challenges assumptions about who you are and what you are capable of. Your course is set.
fields.body:
There's nothing worse than being predictable. Competent, reliable, good at what you do, but never considered for anything new, or different. That same old, familiar image never surprises and never challenges assumptions about who you are and what you are capable of. Your course is set.

BP Amoco, the oil company, last week signalled that it was fed up with being predictable. Out went its shield logo, a familiar sight adorning petrol stations up and down Britain's motorways, and in came a new sunflower logo, the "Helios mark", self-consciously retro, with a fashionably lower case "bp". It was a big moment for the company - the first new look in 70 years - and a big story, deemed important enough to make the front pages of the national press.

The costs, about £4.6m to design and a further £132m to daub it on pumps and vans, were nothing compared to the boost BP - sorry, bp - believes the new image will give to its prospects: "Its radiance is a daily reminder of our aspirations and purpose," gasps the company. "In a hundred countries across the globe, a hundred thousand bp employees bring the world energy in the forms of light, warmth and mobility."

Hyperbolic this may be, but the brand's "mission statement" illustrates how companies repackage the familiar to present it as new - and, crucially, to avoid being left behind ("bp" stands now not for the staid old "British Petroleum", but for the more ambitious "beyond petroleum"). But while new logos and multi-million pound image consultants are beyond the reach of the average office worker, that's not to say the stuck-in-a-rut employee can't learn a few things from the corporate revamp.

Margaret Stead is a chartered occupational psychologist and managing director of Career Design International, which specialises in career development programmes. She believes that if a job is not leading you towards your goals, it's time for a rethink. This is more than just a new image - it's about "repositioning" yourself within your "marketplace". "Take someone who is an administrator, and perhaps has been with the same company since leaving school," suggests Stead. "They might well be thought of as part of the 'family', not in terms of future potential. This is when it can be useful to 'rebrand' the individual."

One-to-one coaching, psychometric assessments and career analysis, among other techniques, are on offer, but ultimately the aim is the same: "discovering how to position themselves to achieve what they want to achieve, and how they might present themselves to do this".

Presentation, of course, means rather more than making sure you wear a clean shirt to interviews. Career Design International is just one of a host of services offering to "maximise your assets" - no smutty sniggers please - and "improve your marketing skills". There have always been agencies eager to advance your career through costly training packages. But the difference now is that workers are being encouraged to realise, and work with, the skills and experience they already possess. Repackaging, in fact.

Brook Street, a recruitment agency specialising in temporary secretarial and office staff, latched onto this idea with its recent advertising campaign, splashed across the London Underground, which put the responsibility for change firmly in the hands of workers. "You are your own business," read one ad. "Try saying, 'I'm going to do what I want to do'," was the message on another. "After all, if you're not enjoying the present, what hope is there for the future?"

All clever stuff, expensively dreamed up by top advertisers Team Saatchi. And unusual, too, as the ads featured no telephone number and no website address - the curious had to read to the end of the text to find just the name of the agency. All for a good reason, explains Odette Sullivan, PR, advertising and communications manager at Brook Street. "The idea was to get people talking - and thinking; to reassess, to realise that they don't have to stay in the same job," she says. The feedback was overwhelmingly positive, with workers from all walks of life (even doctors) calling into branches to find out more about the tagline on the ads: "Whatever you want to do with your life, we'll show you how to make a career of it."

Many of those interested had to be directed to other agencies (Brook Street deals mostly with secretarial staff), but Sullivan believes these attitudes are particularly relevant to temporary office workers. "The job for life is dead," she insists. "Now we have professional temps, who are temping for long periods, not because they have to, but because they like the change. You're no longer 'just' a temp: it's a career." The ads, she says, made this more obvious to workers and employers alike: "It is possible to have a permanent attitude and be a temporary worker." You just need to reposition yourself with a new mindset.

So if your personal "corporate logo" is in need of a revamp, where can you start? Temporary work can be an obvious way to change career direction. Jess Davis worked as an A&R co-ordinator in the music business finding new bands, before moving on to a stint in television. But, she says, it didn't suit her and a rethink was necessary. She took a temporary job last year as an administrator at Career Moves, a recruitment consultancy specialising in jobs in the media, while thinking through her options. This turned into a six-month placement covering a sabbatical as office manager. "Dealing with the clients seemed to come very naturally," she explains. "I was looking for something new, and I knew I wanted to be in the music industry. I was in an advantageous position, because I had secretarial skills, so I could temp. But I also had my knowledge of music and I know a lot of people in the industry."

Putting the two together to make a brand new career was the logical step. Fortunately, her bosses at Career Moves agreed; a training programme or two later, Davis is now a recruitment consultant in the music division of the company, finding for others the jobs she once yearned for herself. "Some really juicy jobs do come in," she confesses. "But someone took a chance on me once, and now I can do that for someone else. And they'll be doing what I know they'll love. It's dream job territory."

She admits, however, that landing that ideal job does require extra efforts on the part of the hopeful candidate. "You might have all the skills there, but it's like making a cake - you have to have all the ingredients in the right amounts for it to taste fantastic. Presentation and personality are 100% important."

Stead agrees. "You need to present yourself in the best light. And for that you need an idea of what you want to do with your life. What is your purpose, your mission, your dream?" She cites the example of a young doctor who had left the NHS, disillusioned. His real ambition was to do research into Alzheimer's disease. "He was surrounded by opportunities - all he had to do was decide what he wanted to do with them," Stead explains. "I suggested that he needed to develop himself as a centre of excellence, to network with like-minded people. It was like watching a black and white television turn to colour."

Few people's dreams involve finding a cure for an intractable disease, but no matter. The point is not to be hemmed in by your job description if you think you could do more; not to stay quiet in meetings if you have an idea that might just work; not to stay stuck in that rut until you get your gold watch, a pension and a pat on the back as you wander off into retirement wondering where the best years of your life went. And don't assume your boss will pour scorn on your efforts to steer your career in a new direction. "Some companies do worry that if they offer career coaching, it will encourage workers to leave," says Stead. "The opposite is true. A more focused individual is not only a happier person, but a better employee." Time to talk to the boss?

Useful links:
Careers Design International: www.careersnet.com
Brook Street: www.brookstreet.co.uk
Careermoves: www.cmoves.co.uk

webTitle: New research shows that nepotism really does pay

fields.headline: Relatively successful
fields.standfirst: New research shows that nepotism really does pay.
fields.trailText: Petty bickering, irrational arguments and emotional tirades - isn't it a relief that our colleagues don't get to see the way we occasionally behave at home? Evenings and weekends are when frazzled workers let down their guards with those who know them best, showing the sides they wouldn't dream of revealing to their bosses.
fields.body:
Petty bickering, irrational arguments and emotional tirades - isn't it a relief that our colleagues don't get to see the way we occasionally behave at home? Evenings and weekends are when frazzled workers let down their guards with those who know them best, showing the sides they wouldn't dream of revealing to their bosses.

What happens, though, when your manager urgently needs an important document, but you are still sulking with him for not doing the washing-up the night before? How do you cope if your boss is your partner, or your mother, or your sister? Working alongside a family member presents particular challenges that are rarely covered in management manuals and self-help books. But new research suggests that working with a partner or parent may be the most efficient way to run your business.

"While society disapproves of nepotism, it works better than ever," says Adam Kuper, professor of social anthropology at Brunel University, who conducted the research into family-run firms. For one thing, he says, relatives develop a stronger commitment because they are more likely to benefit from a firm's success. Even employees who aren't part of the family, he argues, gain from the fact that family firms may be more efficiently managed. Plus, raising capital from the family tends to be easier and comes with better terms than from a high street bank.

Working with a family member can be particularly beneficial in a competitive business climate, according to chartered psychologist Ben Williams. Short-term contracts, high job insecurity and bullying management methods are rife in today's working culture, he argues, "so the decision to work with your own or someone else's family can be just what's needed to provide you with a sense of permanence, motivation and freedom - and in turn effectiveness".

For support staff, Williams believes, the benefits can be particularly good. "In small family businesses, everyone has to pitch in. So your role will probably be far wider than most secretaries'. In addition, the learning curve is steep. You'll make more mistakes but you'll be a lot more knowledgeable in the end. If you decide to move on, that experience is recognised as invaluable."

Alison Ellis, 46, worked as her husband's PA in Manchester for 20 years. She says that although it was "an unbelievably hard slog", it was great fun. "We had such a laugh. No boss, no one telling you to be in the office at a certain time, no one demanding that you only take three weeks holiday - and the chance to be together whenever we wanted. It was fantastic." Non-family members of the business, she claims, also benefited. "The good atmosphere is catching."

Those who work for their parents have even more to gain, claims Bridget Hogg, an occupational psychologist. "They learn about the company informally as they grow up. If they go off to do training and then come back, which is an increasingly popular trend, they can also bring a sense of objectivity to the business."

Claire Motler works as a PA for her step-father at Vogue Superstore in High Wycombe as well as living with him, her mother and siblings. "I've worked for him on and off since I was about 12, delivering leaflets, selling my own stuff at his stores and so on," she says. "I think that's made me really wise to exactly what it is that makes his business a success. And my experience with other companies has helped me learn how to make it even more of a success."

But doesn't it get a little claustrophobic? Motler argues that working with relatives allows her to deal with their moods, and thus prevent tension brewing. "At first, I found it hard to put on different hats. If I'd had an argument with him at home, I sulked at work. But I soon learned that's a sure way to make the business suffer."

Before you rush off to hand in your notice to your current corporate boss and call your partner to insist that he or she does the same, however, think carefully, says workplace counsellor Thelma Williams. "For some couples, and indeed other family members, the dynamic works because they have their time apart during the day. For those who need independence, it is only a good idea to go into business together if the work is not entirely office-based or if you have separate space in the evenings and in your social life."

Indeed, research from the Industrial Society suggests that one of the biggest causes of family feuds is the family businesses. "For richer, for poorer" can be pushed to the limits, points out Thelma Williams, if the business doesn't reach its targets. There are particular risks of power struggles, she says, "if there is a support role in the equation. That person may be made to feel inferior and less integral to the team."

And if troubles can arise when you are married to the boss, what happens if you are the only staff member in a firm who isn't related to one of the directors? "I knew of one family-run accountancy firm where non- relatives never got anywhere despite their skills," says Ben Williams. "If it's a good company which uses objective consultants, that's unlikely to happen. But many don't."

The biggest disadvantage of all, however, is that while family-owned businesses make up 60% of UK firms, fewer than a third of them survive to the second generation. According to the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA), this failure is often down to a lack of planning. "Many put family first and don't look at the future needs of the business," explains a spokesperson. Which would suggest that no matter how well you know your employer, it pays to remember that your first priority, in working hours at least, is your job.

Four years on, she's got the hang of it. The Arts Council's role is to develop and promote the arts, and one aspect of Dorey's job is to oversee the administration of the music panel. "Each art form department within the Council has a panel of experts advisers. The panel meets at least four times a year and as well as arranging all the other aspects of the meeting, I take the minutes. It's a difficult meeting to minute as it's a mixture of discussion and debate combined with decision-making and direct action."

It's important to have read any relevant papers before the meeting, Dorey says. "I will usually have typed up most of the papers that are sent out before a panel meeting so I'll be familiar with the topics, but if I'm asked to take minutes for a meeting where I don't have much background knowledge I read the papers carefully beforehand." If possible, she says, it's also a good idea to go through the agenda with the chairperson and jot down the likely outcome of each item. This helps you to focus on the key points of the meeting.

The crucial skill in minute-writing is knowing whether or not a particular point needs to be recorded. This usually entails careful editing when you write up your notes. "Sometimes it is hard to tell if a discussion is relevant until you can place it in context of the whole meeting," says Dorey. And while the minutes should be as brief as possible, they must be readable. They don't exist only for those who attended the meeting but also for people who missed it and need updating, and sometimes for other staff and people from outside the organisation. The reader shouldn't need to look at other documents to understand the minutes.

Traditionally one tends to associate minute-taking with someone fervently scribbling in a shorthand pad, but an increasing number of people are typing notes straight onto a laptop. Dorey takes all her notes in longhand, but far from finding it laborious, she believes this is a definite plus. "Writing things in longhand is obviously slow, so I'm not tempted to write down anything irrelevant."

Immediately after the meeting it's helpful to mark important points in the notes with a highlighter pen. Dorey always aims to write her notes up within a week. The minutes should then be circulated as quickly as possible so that everyone is reminded of the action points from the meeting.

Dorey admits to feeling a bit nervous in the subsequent meeting when the minutes are endorsed in case there are mistakes. "It's usually something minor, like a typo, but nine times out of 10 they are signed off without any amendments. I'm so used to doing minutes now that I don't have any problem with them."

The London Voluntary Service Council runs an Improve Your Minute-Taking course, tel: 020 7700 8113

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: • HOLIDAY COVER
fields.body:
 HOLIDAY COVER

Have you organised your temp cover for the holiday season? "Those who leave planning their cover to the last minute may find the pool of workers insufficient to meet their demand," warns Charles Walker, of recruitment consultants Blue Arrow. "Staff should check rosters to make sure key positions are filled, as delayed millennium celebrations and the miserable weather mean more people than ever are predicted to take holidays."

 THE LUDDITE LIVES

We keep hearing what a fast-paced technological world we inhabit, but it seems most of us are still Luddites at heart. Although 40% of UK managers are comfortable using videoconferencing in meetings, 80% like to have a flipchart and overhead projector in the room, too. The Meetings Industry Association found that conference organisers are increasingly sourcing venues on the internet, and experimenting with online booking for delegates. But you can't beat the old flipchart and markers, it seems.

 TURFED OFF THE SURFING

More and more employers are cutting employees' internet access, convinced that staff are wasting hours looking at leisure and personal websites. The list of the UK's 10 most popular sites offers a peek into workers' habits: it includes three job search sites, four newspapers and two tourism sites. According to internet software firm Netdata Plus, personal internet surfing in a large firm could cost the company thousands each day. Other research has found that 45% of internet usage at work is inappropriate - and that almost three-quarters of pornography traffic occurs between 9am and 5pm.

 LUNCHTIME HABITS

Sandwiches are still the favourite lunchtime snack for British workers, says a report from Eurest. About half the workforce has a sarnie for lunch. The survey also found the cost of lunches has shot up - we pay £1.98 on average, a 65% rise on the £1.20 of 1990. Londoners pay the most at £2.40 a day, while workers in the north east shell out just £1.51. But at least we're allowing ourselves longer to digest our lunch, with an average break of 39 minutes, the longest for a decade.

 FREELANCE FRIEND

Those who like working to their own schedule may have found a friend in Smart Eric, the cartoon figurehead of a new website for freelance secretaries, administrators and book-keepers. The site offers advice to freelances, teleworkers, and companies looking for temporary or freelance staff. You can post your CV on the site, read articles on casual working or participate in online forums with independent consultants in the field. See <A HREF="http://www.smarteric.com."" TARGET="_NEW">www.smarteric.com.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: And the winner is . . .
fields.standfirst: Anne-Marie Trattles has beaten scores of other PAs to become Executary of the Year. She explains how the skills she uses every day helped her to see off the competition
fields.trailText: When Anne-Marie Trattles was announced as the Office Angels/ Guardian Executary of the Year, something very strange happened. Her legs stopped working. "When I heard my name I couldn't stand up," she says, laughing. "My boss's wife practically had to lift me out of the chair. The other five candidates were so strong, and I had found the tests and interviews that we'd had to undergo during the day extremely draining. To be honest, I didn't think I had an earthly chance."
fields.body:
When Anne-Marie Trattles was announced as the Office Angels/ Guardian Executary of the Year, something very strange happened. Her legs stopped working. "When I heard my name I couldn't stand up," she says, laughing. "My boss's wife practically had to lift me out of the chair. The other five candidates were so strong, and I had found the tests and interviews that we'd had to undergo during the day extremely draining. To be honest, I didn't think I had an earthly chance."

The glamorous award ceremony earlier this month in the Ivy restaurant in London was the climax of a long process - one that started without her knowledge. "The first thing I knew about it was when I opened a letter thanking my boss for nominating me," says Trattles, 44. Her manager, Jon Day, is the MD of Rollalong, a design and construction company specialising in mobile offices, based in Wimbourne in Dorset. "First there was an interview at the local Office Angels office and then I was invited to the regional final. When I heard that I'd made it to the final I was thrilled - until about a week beforehand, when nerves totally took over."

So how does one decide on "the best" PA from a selection of extremely talented, and very different, individuals? The final decision on the winner was taken after the candidates had been through a gruelling day-long session made up of psychometric testing, interviews, team-building exercises and crisis-management tests. "I was quite distraught by the end of the day," says Trattles. "I felt I'd really revealed things about myself, my strengths and weaknesses, but I'd learnt a lot too."

The skills she uses in her job helped her to cope with the interviews and tests, she says. Trattles defines her role as "supporting and underpinning" the company's directors. "I always try to be prepared for any eventuality as I work for three other directors and two part-time directors as well as Jon. I have to be pretty flexible, but I think it's important to try to stay ahead of the game, to prepare for what's coming. One of the questions I was asked in the final interview was to describe a situation that had really floored me, really knocked me sideways. But in all honesty I couldn't come up with anything because I always try to be prepared."

Because of her heavy workload, Trattles has a secretary herself, and the two divide the company's administration between them. Most of Trattles's time is spent ensuring that her boss's day runs smoothly, handling about half of his correspondence directly and dealing with clients, builders and big accounts. Her assistant provides basic admin support, typing letters and managing any overspill work from each project.

"I think trust and honesty are essential in a working relationship," she says, "and I have both with Jon. He knows that I won't deal with anything unless I'm sure of the correct response, and we're always popping in and out of each other's office to discuss things. He has an open-door policy, which I feel is unarguably the best way to work."

"Anne-Marie was an all-rounder in terms of the skills we were looking for," says Neeha Khurana, a consultant occupational psychologist specialising in psychometric testing, who was one of the judges. "We identified a number of crucial skills - using initiative, planning, commercial awareness. She had all the skills that we were looking for."

Modesty prevents Trattles speculating on what she had over the other candidates, but she does believe her positive attitude and "can-do" mindset help in any situation. "I try to be innovative," she says. "In my position it's no good being static, you have to think on your feet. However pressured I am, I always try to be polite and keep a smile on my face. It really makes a difference and it means people usually respond politely."

In true Oscar-winning speech style, however, Trattles is anxious to stress that her success is not all of her own doing. "I couldn't have won this without being surrounded by a great team of people. If ever I need something from anyone else in the company, they're always happy to help. And I still believe there's room for improvement - I think you've got to keep on striving to be better, to exceed expectations."

webTitle: Every picture tells a story, but not all have happy endings

fields.headline: Every picture tells a story, but not all have happy endings
fields.trailText: Before you rush off to give yourself a corporate-style makeover, it's worth bearing in mind that not all new looks draw admiring glances.
fields.body:
Before you rush off to give yourself a corporate-style makeover, it's worth bearing in mind that not all new looks draw admiring glances.

A new haircut to get you noticed in the office can be hidden under hat if it goes wonky, but this is not so easy if your new image is plastered over 180 aeroplanes. British Airways' efforts in June 1997 to reposition itself as truly the world's favourite airline by replacing the union jack on tailfins with "ethnic" images, including Chinese calligraphy and Aboriginal art, backfired when critics, led by Margaret Thatcher, condemned the move. When the images were abandoned two years later, a spokesman admitted that their unpopularity was key: "The people of Britain believe their community is not represented as well as it should be."

The lesson? If your new direction requires a change of image, make sure it fits. And remember who you're trying to impress, even if the new you gets some flak: BA insists those 60% of passengers who aren't British loved the designs.

A change of direction can work wonders if you feel that the real you isn't shining through. Long before BBC1's red balloon showed us that the corporation was bright and buoyant and reached all of Britain's pretty bits, BBC2 was chucking paint over a "2" logo between programmes. And driving it around, remote control-style. And training it to do back-flips. It was a huge hit with critics and with the public, who assumed that BBC2 must after all be a quirky, creative, alternative station, not the dull-but-worthy channel of years gone by. A success.

Levi's, too, thought a cuddly image might help to reinvent its brand: last year, its repackaging efforts saw a step away from launderettes and soul music to Flat Eric, a yellow puppet dancing maniacally to flog the Sta-Prest clothing line. But jeans remain Levi's bread and butter, and sales of those dipped by 14% in 1999. The lesson? No matter how good your image, you must have the substance (for which read skills, experience) to back it up.

A major thing to remember when planning your relaunch is that you don't need anything new. BP is still selling petrol, even if the stylised Helios suggests more stratospheric ventures. And while Nike's "Just Do It" slogan tempts the buyer with a promise of ambition, it still wants you to buy a pair of its trainers.

Your personal repackaging need not rely on new training, unpaid work experience or costly management manuals. A barnstorming CV, rather than a dry list of your GCSE results, might be a start. Take what you've got, add a dollop of gall, and start marketing yourself. But take a tip from the William Hague baseball cap school of makeovers. Don't be too ambitious in settling on your new "brand".
