fields.headline: Ethnic attack raises Fiji tension
fields.standfirst:
Unrest spreads as supporters of jailed coup leader face drastic action for holding soldiers
Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: Supporters of the arrested Fijian coup leader George Speight stormed a remote ethnic Indian village on the country's second island, Vanua Levu, yesterday, taking 30 people hostage.
fields.body:
Supporters of the arrested Fijian coup leader George Speight stormed a remote ethnic Indian village on the country's second island, Vanua Levu, yesterday, taking 30 people hostage.

The island is one of few remaining bastions of support for Mr Speight. Witnesses said they heard four or five shots as the rebels rampaged through Dreketi, a farming community near the town of Labasa. A group of 16 youths then took the hostages.

For two hours there was an uneasy standoff before other villagers intervened and the rebels released their captives.

A local resident, Rafaele Waqa, said: "The young men agreed to release them and apologised to the families in the traditional way."

The attack came as the Fijian military extended a deadline for another group of Mr Speight's supporters to release 40 soldiers they were holding at an army barracks nearby.

The rebels have until noon today London time to free the soldiers and give themselves up or face "drastic action", according to the military spokesman, Major Howard Politini.

Last week several reports emerged documenting random attacks on ethnic Indian communities by those still loyal to Mr Speight. Some unconfirmed accounts told of assaults and even rape of ethnic Indian women.

Another standoff was defused yesterday when yet more rebels said they would hand back control of Fiji's largest hydroelectric power station following negotiations on the settlement of a land claim.

These flashpoints are evidence that Fiji is still in a tense and fragile state after two and a half months of unrest and violence.

The disgruntled indigenous Fijian businessman George Speight launched his coup attempt on May 19 when he stormed the parliament building in the capital Suva and took hostage dozens of officials including the ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and his cabinet.

Mr Speight yesterday remained under military arrest, having been moved to a smaller island off the coast of Suva. He could face treason charges for his orchestration of the coup.

A new Fijian government was sworn in on Friday and has promised elections within the next three years. It is predominantly made up of indigenous Fijians but is said to include no outright Speight supporters.

Mr Chaudhry, who arrived in Sydney yesterday for talks with the Australian prime minister, John Howard, disagrees.

He was met at the airport by his Australian-based cousins and the media.

"There is a number of people in the [new] government who were active supporters of the coup so it cannot be considered a valid government," he said.

He was due to have talks with Mr Howard today - at which he was expected to urge him to continue economic and political pressure against Fiji until a democratically elected government is reinstalled.

He will also undergo a full medical check-up while in Australia. He said he was allowed only one meal a day while he was held captive.

webTitle: Brown & Co trim Keynes for the 21st century

fields.headline: Brown & Co trim Keynes for the 21st century
fields.trailText: There was a time, not so long ago, when a Keynesian was as rare as an Englishman in Chelsea's back four. There were a few devotees of the General Theory knocking about in the lower divisions, but the real stars were the monetarists and the neo-classicists. According to the Thatcherites, Keynesianism was responsible for everything that was wrong with Britain - inflation, unemployment, tower blocks, welfare scroungers, the permissive society, single mothers, modern art. You name it.
fields.body:
There was a time, not so long ago, when a Keynesian was as rare as an Englishman in Chelsea's back four. There were a few devotees of the General Theory knocking about in the lower divisions, but the real stars were the monetarists and the neo-classicists. According to the Thatcherites, Keynesianism was responsible for everything that was wrong with Britain - inflation, unemployment, tower blocks, welfare scroungers, the permissive society, single mothers, modern art. You name it.

Now Keynes is being rehabilitated. Gordon Brown's lecture to the Royal Economic Society earlier this month was sprinkled with references to the great man, and the Treasury has started holding private seminars, titled Keynes in the 21st century. The big increase in departmental spending announced two weeks ago was, according to Brown's advisers, the beautiful Keynesian butterfly emerging from the ugly monetarist chrysalis.

Before we get too carried away, however, it is worth noting that the rehabilitation of Keynes is only partial, with his works selectively culled to find the bits that suit current orthodoxy. As such, the view inside the Treasury is that Keynes was misinterpreted and the purity of his thought sullied by his followers.

The real Keynes, they say, actually believed in low inflation, the need to remedy short-term market failure, and that tackling supply-side problems was the key to economic success. In other words, were he alive today, Keynes would not actually be a Keynesian at all, but - surprise, surprise - a fully signed-up member of New Labour!

This line of thinking is evident from the chancellor's lecture. Whereas Keynes made it clear in the very first chapter of the General Theory that "the postulates of classical theory are applicable to a special case only", Brown argued precisely the opposite - that it was the immediate post-war world that represented the special case.

"The stop-go policies which were wrongly said to be Keynesian attempted to tackle high unemployment and slow growth by pulling the macroeconomic levers but reflected an approach Keynes thought appropriate for depression bound economies where the confidence of the 'animal spirits' was low."

The paper given to the Treasury's first Keynes seminar in the spring makes broadly the same point, although its significance is enhanced by the fact that the author - Professor Charlie Bean - has subsequently been appointed chief economist at the Bank of England.

Prof Bean's elegant presentation was based on the film Sliding Doors, the one in which Gwyneth Paltrow operates in two different parallel universes. In this scenario, Keynes and his fictional son, a lecturer at the London School of Economics, meet on a tube train to discuss Brown's Mais lecture in November 1999.

"Well, father, what do you think of the lecture, and indeed of the government's economic policies in general?", asks Maynard junior. "I find much to commend, both in the general philosophy and in the detail," replies Maynard senior.

Maynard junior says that his school of new Keynesians are comfortable with the idea of "a helping hand from government", even though they would place more emphasis than Maynard senior would on the "importance of microeconomic structural measures to correct market failures". The elder Keynes says it is "absolutely right" that pursuit of price stabilty should be the central objective of policy, and that the inflation target is a sound idea which should prevent a liquidity trap.

For those interested in what the chancellor once called post neo-classical endogenous growth theory there is an interesting monograph by Khaled Hussein and Tony Thirlwall in the Journal of Post-Keynesian Economics which argues that there is nothing essentially new about new growth theory, and that the grand old Keynesian Nicholas Kaldor came up with the same insight in 1957.

Maynard junior argues that recent history has shown that supply-side rigidities rather than a shortage of effective demand is primarily responsible for unemployment and gives his dad a little lecture about the benefits of new growth theory - the state's role in building up human capital and boosting investment in research and development - namely that developed economies do not display diminishing returns to capital.

It may be that Keynes would sign up to all this were he alive today. But there are strong grounds for thinking that he would not. For a start, he made it perfectly clear that supply-side reforms were less important in delivering full employment than demand-side policies when he said: "We must not regard the conditions of supply... as the fundamental sources of our troubles... It is the conditions of demand which our diagnosis must search and probe for an explanation."

Keynes also believed that economics was of little use unless it explained what was happening in the real world. He was critical of the "weaker spirits" who adopted "a hypothetical world remote from experience as though it were the world of experience".

What has happened over the past 20 years is that classical economists living in a hypothetical world have bent the facts to fit their theories. American unemployment has fallen steadily for 10 years, not as a result to changes on the supply side but because the Federal Reserve has maintained effective demand at a high level. When effective demand was squeezed in Britain between 1990 and 1992 the result was a doubling of unemployment, despite all the supply-side reforms of the 1980s.

Unemployment has fallen to one million since, in the absence of further structural reform. Indeed to the extent that there have been changes - the introduction of the minimum wage, curbs on working hours and so on - they should have raised the non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment.

Europe's unemployment rose because of relentlessly deflationary macroeconomic policies. Jobs growth has picked up since demand conditions improved and will continue to expand unless the recovery is choked off by the European Central Bank.

Not true believers

For those who have kept true to the Keynesian faith through the dark years, the New Keynesians are little more than compassionate conservatives, Keynesian on the outside but neo-classical on the inside. Professor Paul Davidson makes two points. First, the new Keynesians - like the classicists - tend to believe in the neutrality of money, whereby the real economy operates unhindered by financial considerations. Changes in the money supply only affect prices and not the real level of activity in the economy. There were echoes of this in the chancellor's lecture where he argued that Milton Friedman was right about inflation.

Second, new and old Keynesians differ fundamentally about the function of capital markets. Old Keynesians believed that the purpose of capital markets was to provide liquidity to finance entrepreneurial activity. New Keynesians believe that capital markets should be efficient, and that liberalisation will produce lower real costs of capital, higher growth rates and more jobs. The experience of 25 years of liberalisation suggests - to say the least - that the old Keynesians had a point.

Anyway, this sounds curmudgeonly. It is rather good news that the ghost of Keynes is again haunting the Treasury's dismal corridors. Brown, like Keynes, believes that "the outstanding faults of the economic society in which we live are its failure to provide for full employment and its arbitary and inequitable distribution of wealth and incomes".

Even so, one suspects that Keynes would be arguing for measures to increase demand for labour in Britain's inner cites, for the use of active fiscal policy to rebalance the economy, and for the employment of architects rather than interior decorators to prevent further crises in the global capital markets. But who knows? He may have been reincarnated as Charlie Bean, Mervyn King or Ed Balls.

fields.headline: NHS plan will not give us the lifestyle we deserve
fields.trailText: The NHS plan, whilst in parts has merit, also contains empty promises (Leader, July 28), such as on the new consultant contract and restrictions on private practice. Junior doctors tolerate years of poor working conditions, onerous hours, relatively poor remuneration, exhaustive, continuous professional development and disruption of family life. Trainees feel the 10 years postgraduate service exclusively within the NHS prior to appointment as a consultant is in itself repaying of their "debt to the state".
fields.body:
The NHS plan, whilst in parts has merit, also contains empty promises (Leader, July 28), such as on the new consultant contract and restrictions on private practice. Junior doctors tolerate years of poor working conditions, onerous hours, relatively poor remuneration, exhaustive, continuous professional development and disruption of family life. Trainees feel the 10 years postgraduate service exclusively within the NHS prior to appointment as a consultant is in itself repaying of their "debt to the state".

A significant number of trainees feel aggrieved at the suggestion that they cannot utilise their free time for seven years as a consultant. Private practice fulfils professional satisfaction by enabling one to pursue interests in a setting that most consultants find more relaxing than working within an underfunded NHS. The current NHS income alone does not provide for a lifestyle and rewards that would be considered as normal in comparable professional walks of life. These reforms should only be introduced for those yet to embark on their career pathway. This would enable individuals to choose a career path and make financial plans based on the prospective earnings.
Andrew Collier
President, British Orthopaedic Trainees Association

 In relation to older people, the NHS plan is dominated by the hospital and institutional care perspective rather than concerns for the most effective community-based services. The expansion of intermediate care is a start, but this is not planned within the context of strong community, housing and leisure services.

The response to the royal commission on long-term care makes it clear that the government is concerned by cost rather than by the principles of delivering fair and effective services. The plan does not consider the best models of services for older people; that will be for the national services framework later in the year. However, as the government is encouraging primary care trusts (within the NHS) to take over social services responsibilities, one can only assume that the "medical model" will predominate.

Most people do want joined-up health and social services with a strong emphasise on "social models" of care and community support. Unfortunately the new NHS plan will not deliver this.
Jeremy Ambache
Association of Directors of Social Services

 The abolition of community health councils appeared as a one-liner. Since 1974, CHCs have been the "voice of the patient", supporting patients through NHS complaints, linking with health authorities, hospitals, primary care and the community, scrutinising local health services etc. Under the national plan, these are separated into patient advocates, patient forums, and local authority scrutiny of the NHS. But where is the overall body which will pull these together, giving the overview necessary if there is to be true patient involvement?
Linda Pepper
Manchester

fields.headline: We're on the right road
fields.trailText: George Monbiot presumes that car ownership and use are incompatible with an integrated transport policy (The young will take to the trees, July 27). That has never been our position. A third of households in this country don't have access to cars and the benefits they bring. Greater mobility, providing access to jobs and opportunities, will be one of the most effective ways of tackling social exclusion. In future, car ownership levels are likely to come near those in countries like Germany, France and Italy. I welcome that.
fields.body:
George Monbiot presumes that car ownership and use are incompatible with an integrated transport policy (The young will take to the trees, July 27). That has never been our position. A third of households in this country don't have access to cars and the benefits they bring. Greater mobility, providing access to jobs and opportunities, will be one of the most effective ways of tackling social exclusion. In future, car ownership levels are likely to come near those in countries like Germany, France and Italy. I welcome that.

Our key challenge is to cut traffic congestion and pollution. Instead of the 15% congestion growth currently projected over the next 10 years, the plan will deliver an overall 6% cut and reduce transport's impact on the environment. Widening transport choice, rather than closing down options, is fundamental to achieving this target. We want to increase passenger levels by 50% on the railways, make public transport more attractive and improve and make better use of the existing roads network, rather than building completely new roads.

For the record, the Salisbury by-pass is not being resurrected. Our approach to road schemes is and will be based on a strong presumption against greenlighting roads that would adversely affect environmentally sensitive sites.
Gus MacDonald
Minister for transport

 The 10-year transport plan will be seen to unravel very soon. We know, following Gus MacDonald's evidence to the Commons transport committee, that the 25 light rail schemes are in fact 25 lines, not schemes. Numerous local authorities will throw millions into winning the light-rail lottery to no avail; 600 communities said to want a bypass will try for one of the 100 schemes on offer. More losers will be created when the generated traffic leaves the bypasses and widened motorways and hits the thousands of towns and cities without one of the 100 park and ride sites promised. This plan puts us back 11 years to Mrs Thatcher's grand £23bn plan to build us out of congestion.
Vincent Stops
London

 In advising the government, the Commission for Integrated Transport focused on reducing congestion and attacking pollution and social exclusion, while reluctantly deciding not to target the goal of traffic reduction itself. We have come across no country in the developed world that has reduced traffic volumes at a time of rising economic prosperity. George Monbiot asserts that John Prescott has put forward a transport package for business. But it is also a package for sustainable communities with the tools to increase living standards, stimulate regeneration and tackle social exclusion.

The real question is what level of restraint on this country's prosperity would we accept in the pursuit of reduced traffic levels? And how great an increase in the cost of motoring would the government have to impose to achieve traffic reductions? Politics is the art of the possible and our unanimous advice recognised this in encouraging the government to focus on the delivery of sustainable outcomes.
Prof David Begg
Chairman, Commission for Integrated Transport

 Road building by stealth has indeed continued unabated. The first "multi-modal study" is looking into "transport" on the A21 to Hastings. A Lewes to Tunbridge Wells railway line would have a greater impact than dualling the A21 at a fraction of the cost - £10m as opposed to £200m-plus. This government is still concerned with vehicle movement, not people movement, and traffic accommodation, not control.
Sara Newman
Tunbridge Wells, Kent

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
In a report headed Hain steps up war on arms dealers, page 17, July 28, we said that the foreign office minister Peter Hain had "named a Ukrainian, Victor Bout", as one of the main people breaking sanctions against rebel forces in Angola. Mr Hain, did not identify Mr Bout by nationality or country of origin. Mr Bout is in fact Russian, said, in a UN report, to have been born in Smolensk.

In the lead letter, page 21, July 13, the writers Professor Shalom Lappin and Dr Colin Shindler, took issue with the views expressed in an article published in the Guardian on March 24. Professor Lappin has asked us to point out that he was mistaken in attributing the article to Martin Kettle. It was by Martin Woollacott (Israel's two big wrongs don't make it right).

The Russian sail training vessel is named Sedov, not Sedlov, as it appeared in Country Diary, page 18, July 28.

In an article headed Business rallies to UN ethics scheme, page 12, July 26, we referred to the Prince of Wales Forum on GM Foods. The correct name is The Prince of Wales Business Leaders Forum.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897.
Email: reader@theguardian.com

fields.headline: On a sticky wicket
fields.trailText: I notice that the partner of Rebekah Wade, editor of the News of the World (Letters, July 27), is the actor Ross Kemp. I seem to remember he is the figurehead of the NSPCC Full Stop anti-abuse campaign. I also noticed the NSPCC condemned the NoW actions, saying they were likely to significantly increase the risk of children being attacked in some cases. Is it not possible for Mr Kemp, alias Grant Mitchell, to "have a word in her shell-like"?

Is it not possible for Mr Kemp, alias Grant Mitchell, to "have a word in her shell-like"?
Mathias Disney
London

 During many years working in the health service, I noticed that it only required a scheduled visit by the Queen for standards of cleaning and maintenance in the hospital to reach perfection (Labour stakes credibility on 5-year NHS revolution, July 28). Is there a role here for the monarchy in the 21st century?
Hilary Ryder
Reading, Berks

 I can't imagine that drug traffickers will be unduly concerned when Keith Hellawell confiscates their passports (Report, July 29). Surely the organised criminal of this calibre is resourceful enough to have another batch swiftly made to order?
Helen Tout
London

 Re Judy Martin's concern (Letters, July 29) for the monkey puzzle tree (Araucaria imbricata): she may draw some comfort from the knowledge that, in the Guardian Crossword, Araucaria regularly puzzles us monkeys.
Aelwyn Edwards
Abbots Langley, Herts

 Yorkshire cricket club's chief executive, Chris Hassall, claims the England and Wales Cricket Board "have moved the goalposts" (Yorkshire cry foul, Sport, July 29). Someone please help the poor man.
Nigel Linford
Brighton

fields.headline: The moral Maze
fields.trailText: Your contention (Leader, July 29) that Northern Ireland is not like West Sussex not only gives an unqualified endorsement to the justification claimed by the (mass) murderers released from the Maze, viz the whitewash of war, it also ignores that even in war some conventions are applied by the international community.
fields.body:
Your contention (Leader, July 29) that Northern Ireland is not like West Sussex not only gives an unqualified endorsement to the justification claimed by the (mass) murderers released from the Maze, viz the whitewash of war, it also ignores that even in war some conventions are applied by the international community.

The cold-blooded atrocity of many of these murders made them crimes against humanity. The release was an abject surrender to the threat (explicit or implicit) from "the men of violence" that absent such release, the murders would be resumed. Only history will supply the incredulity that this shameless and futile moral abdication merits.
Mark Knight
Ightham, Kent Knightmmca@btinternet.com

 You justify the release of multiple murderers from the Maze by arguing that Northern Ireland has been at war, so let us apply the rules of war by drawing a parallel with Yugoslavia, where attacks on civilian communities were deemed to be war crimes answerable to the court in the Hague. Most of the killers released by the terms of the Good Friday agreement were guilty of exactly such crimes and would, by those terms, be considered guilty of war crimes. There is no justification for releasing such criminals. They are the beneficiaries of political expediency.
Mark Glanville
London GlansM@netscape.net

 Thank God Blair and Mandelson were not in charge in 1940.
Mervyn Lovell
Swindon, Wilts mervyn@38shrivenham.freeserve.co.uk

The release was an abject surrender to the threat (explicit or implicit) from "the men of violence" that absent such release, the murders would be resumed. Only history will supply the incredulity that this shameless and futile moral abdication merits. Mark Knight Ightham, Kent Knightmmca@btinternet.com  You justify the release of multiple murderers from the Maze by arguing that Northern Ireland has been at war, so let us apply the rules of war by drawing a parallel with Yugoslavia, where attacks on civilian communities were deemed to be war crimes answerable to the court in the Hague. Most of the killers released by the terms of the Good Friday agreement were guilty of exactly such crimes and would, by those terms, be considered guilty of war crimes. There is no justification for releasing such criminals. They are the beneficiaries of political expediency. Mark Glanville London GlansM@netscape.net  Thank God Blair and Mandelson were not in charge in 1940. Mervyn Lovell Swindon, Wilts mervyn@38shrivenham.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Short people
fields.trailText: Lorna Judd (Letters, July 27) doesn't mind being a little old lady, but is concerned the elderly are not considered proper adults. My concern is that little people, whatever their age, are not treated as properly adult. Through my twenties and thirties, I was often mistaken for a child, occasionally even called "lad"; I was 40 when doorstep canvassers last greeted me with "Is your mother in?".
fields.body:
Lorna Judd (Letters, July 27) doesn't mind being a little old lady, but is concerned the elderly are not considered proper adults. My concern is that little people, whatever their age, are not treated as properly adult. Through my twenties and thirties, I was often mistaken for a child, occasionally even called "lad"; I was 40 when doorstep canvassers last greeted me with "Is your mother in?". Now turned 50, I am at last enjoying a few years of being considered a proper grown-up, thanks to whitening hair. I realise it's likely to be a small window of time before I turn into a child again, even if the official label is "little old lady".
Sue Treagus
Manchester

 Lorna Judd's example of differential doses of medication is a poor one. The elderly do metabolise drugs differently from younger adults.
Dr PD Oldfield
Northwich, Cheshire

fields.headline: Weighing up the issues
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Walter (Letters, July 27) is doubtless right that his granddaughter's birth weight in kilos would mean nothing to him, but he should spare a thought for most of us educated in the metric system. Besides, the standard bag of sugar has been 1kg for 20 years. His granddaughter weighed pretty much exactly three bags of sugar. Easy.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Walter (Letters, July 27) is doubtless right that his granddaughter's birth weight in kilos would mean nothing to him, but he should spare a thought for most of us educated in the metric system. Besides, the standard bag of sugar has been 1kg for 20 years. His granddaughter weighed pretty much exactly three bags of sugar. Easy.
David Jones
Liverpool

 Our son was born in 1973 at a worryingly low 2.25 kilos. We had no trouble understanding. He now stands at 1.8 metres and weighs a healthy 80 kilos. We love every millimetre of him.
Sandra & Hugh Wilmot
Gravesend, Kent

 Mr Walter uses the Italian abbreviation for ounce (oz); Italy went metric in the 1840s, when their currency was still £sd. (lire, soldi and denari).
John Wheaver
Milton Keynes, Bucks

 I make a plea to bring back the pound. A half kilo is roughly equivalent to a pound (17.6 ozs, 1.1lb) and the French still use it as la livre. Butter has been sold in 250gram packs for some time but we still think of it as half a pound.
AG Bailey
Southwold, Suffolk

 When I was young in Liguria my mother used to send me to buy "4ozs" of sugar, "1lb" of bread or "1 pt" of milk. The old measures had by common usage been "metricated" ie loz = 25g, 1lb = 500g, 1pt = 500cc.
Gianni Davanda
London

 We seem to be proud of not being able to cope with metric. Canada went metric years ago and I can state positively that Canadians are not starving through an inability to deal with kilos.
CP Young
Poole, Dorset

fields.headline: Cadbury's investigates chocolate recycling claim
fields.trailText: Cadbury's announced yesterday it had stopped using a contractor pending an inquiry into allegations that chocolate earmarked for pig feed was reused in its products.
fields.body:
Cadbury's announced yesterday it had stopped using a contractor pending an inquiry into allegations that chocolate earmarked for pig feed was reused in its products.

A claim was made yesterday in a Sunday newspaper that the long-standing contractor was taking chocolate labelled Unfit for Human Consumption and reusing it in bars such as Dairy Milk and Creme Eggs.

A spokesman for Cadbury's said it would not use chocolate processed by R and JB Higgins of Chaddesley Corbett, Worcestershire, until it had investigated, but added that it had "total confidence" in the firm.

Higgins denied the claims, saying: "The public have nothing to fear." Its workers strip chocolate bars designated as waste, sent from Cadbury's Bournville factory in the West Midlands or from outside distribution centres.

A Cadbury's spokesman said that bars damaged in production, but in every other way perfect, were sent back to Bournville or another factory for remelting. Those near or just past their Best Before date were sent for resale at Cadbury's staff shop, and those past their sell-by date were destined for pig feed. Workers at Higgins were accused by the Sunday Mirror of shifting bars from the pig feed pile onto that to be sent for remelting.

Press Association

fields.headline: Haider teases 'wise men'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: Guided to Austria by an increasingly nervous European Union and bearing tidings of cautious goodwill from Brussels, "three wise men" left Vienna yesterday snubbing gifts of CDs, videos and the infamous "Jörgi bear" - a cuddly bear donated by the extreme rightwinger Jörg Haider.
fields.body:
Guided to Austria by an increasingly nervous European Union and bearing tidings of cautious goodwill from Brussels, "three wise men" left Vienna yesterday snubbing gifts of CDs, videos and the infamous "Jörgi bear" - a cuddly bear donated by the extreme rightwinger Jörg Haider.

Sent to judge whether the diplomatic sanctions on Austria, imposed because of fears of the political character of Mr Haider's Freedom party (FPO), should be lifted, the three-man panel of EU representatives concluded their 72-hour investigative visit tight-lipped after refusing to meet the man at the eye of the storm.

Dubbed the three wise men, former Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari; former Spanish foreign minister Marcelino Oreja; and leading German lawyer Jochen Frowein were appointed earlier this month to monitor Austria's political behaviour.

Their mission is widely considered as a face-saving exercise now that the EU's deadlock with Austria threatens to delay its internal reforms. The impasse began in February when the entry of the FPO into the Austrian coalition government prompted the other 14 EU members to impose sanctions.

But Mr Haider, best known for his controversial remarks about the Nazi period, offered a typically cheeky response by presenting a bag of goodies to the panel, including his mascot teddy bear, a CD of folk songs and a promotional video of the southern province of Carinthia where he is governor.

The plea to visit the province from Europe's enfant terrible cut little ice with the panel, who spent the weekend interviewing political, religious and community leaders in Vienna.

Their report, which will assess whether Austria respects "common European values and does not violate civil rights" is expected to be completed by the end of the summer.

There is pressure on the wise men to deliver the report before a planned autumn referendum in Austria, the result of which may demand the lifting of sanctions. Romano Prodi, president of the EC, said that the commission was working hard to lift the sanctions, but he criticised the referendum, saying it was "a mistake which increases the tension".

The Austrian Social Democrat leader, Alfred Gusenbauer, urged the panel to consider lifting sanctions but he remained firm on his own criticism of the FPO and said the panel should see the party for what it is, "an unchanged rightwing populist party." Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel, head of the People's party, said: "In human rights and the protection of minorities we have the highest standard in Europe."

Little of the content of the meetings has been divulged, but certain aspects of Mr Haider's behaviour which have given rise for concern in Austria, will certainly have been brought to their attention.

Mr Haider recently met the Libyan leader Muammar Gadafy twice in Tripoli. A report in Der Standard said that most FPO MPs had been present at the Iraqi embassy to celebrate its national holiday last year, and a further group of leading FPO members had attended the birthday party of Saddam Hussein.

Mr Haider stood down as leader of the FPO in May, but is still its most influential figure. The replacement FPO party chief and vice-chancellor, Susanne Riess-Passer, took a hastily-arranged break and was unable to meet the men.

webTitle: Campaign to stop builders may cost woman her home

fields.headline: Campaign to stop builders may cost woman her home
fields.trailText: A Dorset woman faces bankruptcy and losing her house after leading a five-year conservation battle that has helped to change national planning guidance on development in the grounds of listed buildings.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A Dorset woman faces bankruptcy and losing her house after leading a five-year conservation battle that has helped to change national planning guidance on development in the grounds of listed buildings.

Downe Hall was a battered but splendid listed 18th century mansion, in an overgrown garden laid out as a miniature Georgian country estate, in the market town of Bridport. Catherine Searle, a grandmother living in the town on income support, launched a campaign to stop expensive houses being built in the hall's grounds after reading a planning notice at the end of its drive.

She lost, and the houses were built and sold after a campaign that went all the way to the House of Lords. But her crusade has had important national consequences.

Because of the Downe Hall furore, English Heritage, the government's conservation adviser, changed its planning guidance to local authorities on "enabling development". This was a developer's ploy of the 1980s: requesting permission to break normal planning and listed building regulations as the only way to secure the future of a listed building.

English Heritage now warns councils that enabling development should be allowed only in the most exceptional circumstances.

Enabling development was the argument accepted by West Dorset district council when it gave planning permission for the houses, breaking its own development plan.

English Heritage also speeded up work on updating its register of nationally important gardens. It had missed the significance of Downe Hall.

The conservation societies are horrified at Ms Searle's plight. Her house is also listed, a two-up two-down ropemaker's cottage near Downe Hall. She has no car and no savings, and the campaign fund has enough left to cover only half the remaining £30,000 costs. Selling the house is the only way she could pay the balance.

"I feel desperately concerned for her," Richard Pollard, secretary of Save Britain's Heritage, said. "It was a vindictive decision to award costs against her, and it is a vindictive action to pursue them."

Her solicitor, Christopher White, of the Bridport firm Milne and Lyall, who has given a lot of unpaid time to the case, has formally asked the council, and the developer, C G Fry and Son, to waive their costs. He is also applying for legal aid to allow Ms Searle to appeal.

He is not optimistic: "The attitude throughout this case has been: how dare she, or a firm of local solicitors, challenge the decision of the council."

The Yeovil solicitor representing Frys is on holiday, but in a statement to the Guardian the council said it was pursuing recovery of its share of the costs, £19,644.85, because public money was spent fighting the case. "This process will be carefully monitored by the council's legal advisers."

Although the campaign attracted wealthy local supporters, the final costs have come down on Ms Searle because her name was on the 1995 application for a judicial review of the planning permission.

Mr Pollard said: "If Catherine loses her house, it will certainly scare off other campaigners from having the courage to follow her example - and that may indeed be the intention."

Mr White said: "Morally she won her case. She has effectively changed the law, and this will never happen again. But she, I am afraid, is the sacrificial lamb."

fields.headline: Eastern Europe awaits
fields.standfirst: EU enlargement is no sideshow
fields.trailText: The obsessive question of whether the United Kingdom should join the single currency has all but driven debate about other aspects of European Union affairs off the domestic agenda. For Poles and Czechs, this is a troubling distortion of priorities.
fields.body:
The obsessive question of whether the United Kingdom should join the single currency has all but driven debate about other aspects of European Union affairs off the domestic agenda. For Poles and Czechs, this is a troubling distortion of priorities. From the perspective of Budapest, Ljubljana or Riga, realising plans to enlarge the EU by up to 13 new members is a momentous matter, far more epic in scale, and resonant in history than febrile wrangling about the monetary cementation of a single market to which the UK already belongs.

When their gaze turns from the UK to other influential EU members such as France and Germany, east European worries grow. Recent speeches by President Jacques Chirac and Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, sketched grandiose visions of a more integrated union powered by an inner core or advance guard of leading countries. They were notably vague when it came to enlargement timetables. Hungary, for example, has been waiting six years already. Supposedly firm dates for entry repeatedly slip; currently there are none at all. Perhaps 2003 for a "first wave" of six applicants; more probably 2005. For Bulgaria and Romania, which applied in 1995, accession may still be a decade away.

Entry negotiations have thrown up some genuine problems. Disagreement runs deep over the extent to which the EU will subsidise inefficient agricultural sectors, particularly in Poland, a land of small farms which resisted communist-era collectivisation. Member states worry about the economic and social impact of large numbers of migrant workers, with the rise of rightwing groups such as Jörg Haider's Austrian Freedom party and east German neo-nazis not far from their minds. Some governments want a long transitional period during which free movement of labour is denied. The European Commission is insisting that a great raft of exacting standards and regulations from food quality and animal health to financial accounting be enacted before countries can join. Heads of government meanwhile wrestle with that fundamental question for all politicians: with all these newcomers, who will be in charge?

The summit, to be hosted by the French presidency in Nice this December, is supposed to provide some answers. Proposals to expand qualified majority voting within the council of ministers and to reorganise the commission are undoubtedly necessary reforms if enlargement is to work. But with the Germans now suggesting yet another time-consuming intergovernmental conference next year and with Laurent Fabius, the French finance minister, advocating broad executive powers for the new "Euro Group" of countries backing the single currency, suspicion grows that the Nice agenda may be as much about facilitating a two-speed Europe as it is about expediting enlargement.

It would be a great disservice to the European ideal were narrow machinations, born of old-school nationalism, to cloud the grander aspiration of a united continent of equal partners, sharing common purposes and values. It is unjust to the countries most scarred by Europe's divisions, and very shortsighted, for the EU in effect to keep putting them off. Thus it is right that Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, visiting Budapest and Prague last week, demanded that the EU quickly agree a firm timetable for expansion. For the French presidency and others must not lose sight of the union's highest aspiration: building a Europe that belongs to all Europeans.

fields.headline: Daphne Pearson
fields.standfirst: First woman to receive a gallantry award in the second world war
fields.trailText: Daphne Pearson, who has died aged 89, was a Women's Auxiliary Air Force Corporal, a medical attendant stationed at Royal Air Force Detling, Kent, in 1940. She was in the WAAF quarters when, shortly after midnight on May 31, she heard the sound of an aircraft clearly in trouble - one engine was out - heading towards the airfield.
fields.body:
Daphne Pearson, who has died aged 89, was a Women's Auxiliary Air Force Corporal, a medical attendant stationed at Royal Air Force Detling, Kent, in 1940. She was in the WAAF quarters when, shortly after midnight on May 31, she heard the sound of an aircraft clearly in trouble - one engine was out - heading towards the airfield.

Pulling on her clothes and grabbing her steel helmet, Pearson ran outside just as the aircraft crashed through trees and ploughed into a field. Ignoring warnings from guards, she dashed towards the airfield perimeter fence, opening the gate as she went for the ambulance and fire crews who would follow, and stumbled down an incline to the damaged aircraft. Others already at the scene were trying to drag the pilot clear of the wreckage.

Shouting at them to let her deal with the airman, she told the men to get the fence down to allow the crash crews to come through. The aircraft was on fire, but Pearson began to pull the pilot away, although he was in such pain that she was forced to delay to give him what first aid she could. Despite his injuries, the pilot was able to warn her that the aircraft still had its full bomb load aboard. Desperate to get the pilot away, Pearson dragged him clear and into cover as the plane's fuel tanks exploded.

She threw herself on top of the pilot to protect him from the blast and flying metal, and covered his head with her helmet as one of the air craft's 120 pound bombs went off. Corporal Pearson was giving the pilot further first aid, with the help of a soldier who had arrived, when there was another huge explosion. The blast knocked the rescuers off their feet and sent showers of flying metal and debris everywhere.

When the ambulance and rescue crews arrived, Pearson went to help the medical officer to lift the stretcher over the fence, and the pilot was then taken to safety. The rest of the bombs went off, but, still ignoring the danger, Pearson ran back to the burning aircraft wreckage in search of the wireless operator; however, he was already dead. Later that morning, Corporal Pearson calmly reported for duty as if nothing out of the ordinary had happened.

The announcement of her award of the Empire Gallantry Medal (EGM) appeared on July 19, 1940, a few weeks after Daphne Pearson was commissioned as an Assistant Section Officer, WAAF. Her EGM was the first award made to a woman for gallantry in the second world war.

Three months later, on September 24, 1940, came the announcement of the king's intention to create a new award that would bear his name, the George Cross. The EGM was to be abolished and all living holders, and those who had been awarded the medal since the outbreak of war, were required to exchange their insignia for the GC. Pearson was the first woman to receive the new award.

Born in Mudeford, Hampshire, Pearson was the daughter of a clergyman, and educated at St Brandon's Clergy Daughters' School, Bristol. She had trained as a photographer and ran her own portrait studio in St Ives, Cornwall, for eight years, before ill health forced her to sell up and to change the direction of her career. At the beginning of the war, she was managing the retail fruit section of a large farm in Kent.

A life-long aviation enthusiast, she had learned to fly and was only a few hours short of gaining her licence when hostilities put an end to civilian flying for the duration. For the rest of the war, despite bouts of ill health, Pearson served in postings with Bomber Command and in services recruiting. After she was demobilised in 1946, she began a job as assistant governor at a women's borstal at Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire, going to evening classes in horticulture. She later worked at the Royal Botanical Gardens, Kew, as assistant to the keeper of the herbarium. Following a successful period running her own shop in Kew, which sold gardening equipment, flowers and fresh produce, in 1959 she emigrated to Australia.

There, while working for the Department of Agriculture, she was able to combine her interest in flying with her knowledge of horticulture. For some years, she helped a friend run a farm outside Melbourne.

Daphne Pearson was a woman of great character. Determined, robust and dignified, but with a great sense of humour, she was intensely patriotic. fields.bodyText: Daphne Pearson, who has died aged 89, was a Women's Auxiliary Air Force Corporal, a medical attendant stationed at Royal Air Force Detling, Kent, in 1940. She was in the WAAF quarters when, shortly after midnight on May 31, she heard the sound of an aircraft clearly in trouble - one engine was out - heading towards the airfield. Pulling on her clothes and grabbing her steel helmet, Pearson ran outside just as the aircraft crashed through trees and ploughed into a field. Ignoring warnings from guards, she dashed towards the airfield perimeter fence, opening the gate as she went for the ambulance and fire crews who would follow, and stumbled down an incline to the damaged aircraft. Others already at the scene were trying to drag the pilot clear of the wreckage. Shouting at them to let her deal with the airman, she told the men to get the fence down to allow the crash crews to come through. The aircraft was on fire, but Pearson began to pull the pilot away, although he was in such pain that she was forced to delay to give him what first aid she could. Despite his injuries, the pilot was able to warn her that the aircraft still had its full bomb load aboard. Desperate to get the pilot away, Pearson dragged him clear and into cover as the plane's fuel tanks exploded. She threw herself on top of the pilot to protect him from the blast and flying metal, and covered his head with her helmet as one of the air craft's 120 pound bombs went off. Corporal Pearson was giving the pilot further first aid, with the help of a soldier who had arrived, when there was another huge explosion. The blast knocked the rescuers off their feet and sent showers of flying metal and debris everywhere. When the ambulance and rescue crews arrived, Pearson went to help the medical officer to lift the stretcher over the fence, and the pilot was then taken to safety. The rest of the bombs went off, but, still ignoring the danger, Pearson ran back to the burning aircraft wreckage in search of the wireless operator; however, he was already dead. Later that morning, Corporal Pearson calmly reported for duty as if nothing out of the ordinary had happened. fields.headline: Wendy French
fields.standfirst: Barrister, advocate for international students, and voluntary worker
fields.trailText: Wendy French, who has died aged 72, was counsellor, mother superior and passionate advocate for the London Goodenough Trust for Overseas Graduates. This is a non-teaching, residential college for postgraduates from the Commonwealth, the US and Europe pursuing professional and academic qualifications in London. She became a governor in 1977 and it was her central cause.
fields.body:
Wendy French, who has died aged 72, was counsellor, mother superior and passionate advocate for the London Goodenough Trust for Overseas Graduates. This is a non-teaching, residential college for postgraduates from the Commonwealth, the US and Europe pursuing professional and academic qualifications in London. She became a governor in 1977 and it was her central cause.

She was in regular correspondence with many of its former students to the end of her life. For more than 20 years she chaired the Trust's management committee, and organised an annual law students' dinner to which she invited, or more often dragooned, the great and the good. In 1992, at short notice, she became chairman of the governors and saw the Trust through a period of change, not all of it to her liking. She retired in 1997 and became its first Governor Emeritus.

Wendy was born into a Welsh brewing family and educated at Harrogate Ladies College and Girton College, Cambridge: a woman from that generation which directed its energy into improving the quality of life for those less fortunate than themselves.

Soon after qualifying as a barrister, she became a Times law reporter and later applied her shrewd eye and pithy comment to the All England Law Reports. In 1957, she married Christopher French, who was knighted in 1979 and became a High Court judge in 1982. With her passion and his quiet courtesy, they were a formidable partnership, sought after both in legal circles and in Oxfordshire. She was a magistrate and chairman of industrial and VAT tribunals.

Wendy's life revolved round three things; her family; the numerous organisations in which she was immersed (including St John's Ambulance, the Inns of Court Mission, the Gainsford Trust, and the Brooke Hospitals for Sick Animals); and the helping of people, particularly the young. Besides the Goodenough Trust, during her stint as High Sheriff of Oxfordshire in 1997, she threw herself into Volunteer Reading Help, to encourage reading in primary schools. Later she was appointed Deputy Lieutenant of the county.

In London House, the home of the Goodenough Trust, hangs June Mendoza's portrait of Wendy; a dynamic woman in typically quizzical pose, the gleam of confrontation in her eye. Shining through is her humour, which was never far from the surface and which made even her fiercest remarks bearable. She was indomitable: she did not give in to self-pity in her last illness, but only regretted what she was leaving unfinished. She chaired her last law students' dinner, glowing with enthusiasm, only weeks before her death, a typical gesture.

A great countrywoman, a well-informed and energetic gardener, she created with Christopher, at Ipsden, a place of warmth and hospitality. Her family also included her beloved Jack Russells. She is survived by her husband, son and daughter.

Lady Wendy (Rosina Phillipa) French, voluntary worker, born October 21 1927; died May 15 2000

fields.headline: UN censures treatment of aborigines
fields.trailText: Australia has come under renewed fire from the United Nations for the way it treats its Aboriginal population.
fields.body:
Australia has come under renewed fire from the United Nations for the way it treats its Aboriginal population.

A report by the UN's Human Rights Committee released at the weekend chastised Australia for its mandatory sentencing laws - the compulsory jailing of offenders for minor crimes.

Australia was also accused of failing to fully compensate the victims of the "stolen generation" - Aborigines who were forcibly removed from their families and brought up in white households.

The report added that the high levels of social exclusion and poverty facing indigenous people were a matter of urgent concern, and that the present levels of protection and promotion of traditional Aboriginal forms of economy and sites of religious or cultural significance were inadequate.

The Australian government came out fighting yesterday with the attorney general, Daryl Williams, saying that the administration had every reason to be proud of its human rights record.

"The government does not agree that many of the steps suggested by the committee are either necessary or desirable," he said.

Many Australians have been calling on the government to do more to bring white and Aboriginal communities together, and to work towards a coalition. Thousands walked across the Sydney Harbour bridge two months ago to protest at the lack of governmental action.

Some believe an apology is needed from the government for victims of the stolen generation, but the prime minister, John Howard, has steadfastly refused, saying that the government is not liable for the acts of previous administrations.

Some Australians and media commentators reacted angrily to the UN's criticism yesterday, accusing it of trying to portray the country as an international pariah, such as South Africa under apartheid.

A leading indigenous rights group, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, said the government should see the report as a positive document that could help it to comply with international treaties.

The report praised Australia for enacting some anti-discrimination laws and for partially helping those taken away from their homes as children. But it clearly levelled its sights at mandatory sentencing, currently active in Western Australia and the Northern Territory.

Juveniles (under 17) convicted of their third home burglary get a 12-month minimum sentence in Western Australia.

Juveniles aged 15-16 who have already been convicted of a property offence get a minimum 28-day sentence in the Northern Territory. Adults get at least 14 days for a first property offence in the Northern Territory, 90 days for a second and one year for further offences.

The report said: "Legislation regarding mandatory imprisonment, which led in many cases to imposition of punishments that were disproportionate to the seriousness of the crimes committed and would seem to be inconsistent with the strategies adopted by the state [Australia] to reduce the over-representation of indigenous persons in the criminal justice system, raised serious issues of compliance with ... the [International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]."

Arrests of Aborigines are currently more than four times those of whites in the Northern Territory.

"In addition, the mandatory detention under the migration act of "unlawful non-citizens", including asylum-seekers, raised question of compliance with covenant," it said.

The UN criticism comes just a couple of weeks after it emerged that Tony Blair's wife, Cherie Booth, in her role as a QC, was involved in presenting a case before the same committee, on behalf of Aborigines from the Northern Territory imprisoned for minor property offences.

Irked by the case, Mr Howard accused the UN of butting its nose into Australian affairs. He will no doubt be further perturbed by this weekend's UN report.

fields.headline: Grenades add to Haiti's isolation
fields.trailText: Two grenade attacks in Port-au-Prince - on the Canadian ambassador's residence and a United Nations' mission - have reinforced Haiti's growing isolation from the international community.
fields.body:
Two grenade attacks in Port-au-Prince - on the Canadian ambassador's residence and a United Nations' mission - have reinforced Haiti's growing isolation from the international community.

Only one device exploded but the violence is a new source of tension between the poorest state in the Americas and western countries which are cutting off aid in protest at alleged electoral fraud.

The UN has expressed dismay at what it maintains are falsified parliamentary results which gave the ruling party, Fanmi Lavalas, a landslide victory. The last round of run-offs took place yesterday.

The first grenade exploded in the driveway of ambassador Gilles Bernier's home on Thursday night. His car was damaged but no one was hurt. Canadian police officers were involved in training Haiti's police after the US invasion of 1994.

The second grenade was found the same day beside the former UN civilian mission in Delmas, on the outskirts of the capital, Port-au-Prince. It was detonated safely by police.

No one has claimed responsibility for the blasts but supporters of Fanmi Lavalas, whose leader is the former president Jean-Bertrand Aristide, have staged furious protests against the international community's refusal to ratify the results.

Buildings in the capital are daubed with graffiti threatening the Organisation of American States, which monitored the polls in May and June. The organisation has since withdrawn from Haiti.

Japan has already suspended £9m in aid this month. The EU last week began a review that could eventually halt a £130m five-year aid package.

Both the US and Canada - Haiti's biggest donors - are threatening to cut off remaining aid. A further £266m in international loans has been on hold for several years awaiting the return of a reconstituted parliament.

Haiti's opposition has accused Fanmi Lavalas and Mr Aristide of attempting to return the country to a dictatorship. Mr Aristide, a former priest, is by far the most popular politician and is expected to be the runaway winner in the November presidential elections.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 'Dead' PoW turns up alive
fields.body:
'Dead' PoW turns up alive

A Hungarian believed to have died on the Russian front in the second world war has been found alive in a Russian psychiatric hospital, a Budapest newspaper has reported.

Dr Andras Veer, director of the National Psychiatric and Neurological Institute in Hungary, visited 75-year-old Andras Tamas in Kotelnich, 310 miles east of Moscow and confirmed that he was a former prisoner of war, captured by Soviet troops in 1945.

Hospital records show that Mr Tamas was admitted in 1947. He has no clear memory of what happened and can barely speak Hungarian. The Hungarian embassy in Moscow has asked that he be returned to Hungary.
AP, Budapest

Tremor shakes Japanese coast

A strong earthquake jolted a string of islands off Tokyo yesterday, one of thousands of tremors to hit the area in recent weeks as a volcano rumbled back to life.

The 6.2-magnitude quake hit hardest on Miyakejima, home to some 4,000 people about 200 miles south of Tokyo, where the volcanic Mount Oyama has spewed columns of ash several times this month. There were no reports of damage or injuries.
AP, Tokyo

Human cargo runs aground

A ship carrying 418 illegal immigrants ran aground yesterday off southern Italy.

Police said that the boat carried Kurds and other would-be immigrants from Sierra Leone, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Senegal and elsewhere. Italian media said nearly 80 children were among them. The ship was towed to the Calabrian port of Crotone.
AP, Crotone

Russian theatre figure shot dead

Sergei Isayev, the head of the Russian Academy for the Performing Arts, has been shot dead at his country house outside Moscow. NTV television reported that Mr Isayev was shot five times from outside the window of the room where his body was found.

Mr Isayev, 49, had worked at the academy for 30 years. Police said they knew of no motive for the shooting, but did not rule out that Isayev was the victim of a contract killing.
AP, Moscow

Ransom paid to free journalist

The German news weekly, Der Spiegel, has admitted paying Philippine rebels a ransom to secure the release of its reporter Andreas Lorenz after nearly four weeks in captivity.

The magazine paid an unspecified "exit fee" through middlemen to secure his release. The Lost Command rebels who abducted Mr Lorenz are not linked to the Abu Sayyaf Muslim militants holding a group of tourists hostage on the Philippine island of Jolo.
Reuters, Berlin

webTitle: Love story frees France's gentle bank robber

fields.headline: Love story frees France's gentle bank robber
fields.trailText: France's favourite bank robber, an amiable gentleman thief who during 40 successful hold-ups and three spectacular prison escapes never hurt a soul, will be released this week having spent all but six months of the past 13 years in prison.
fields.body:
France's favourite bank robber, an amiable gentleman thief who during 40 successful hold-ups and three spectacular prison escapes never hurt a soul, will be released this week having spent all but six months of the past 13 years in prison.

Patrick Brice, 44, first attracted the nation's attention by sending flowers to the cashiers he terrified and bottles of champagne to the gendarmes who pursued him. In the middle of one heist, he proffered banknotes to a distressed old-age pensioner; at another, he provided a chair to a pregnant woman.

But what really won over romantic Gallic hearts was the remarkable love affair between Mr Brice and his wife, Laurence.

Since 1987, Ms Brice has smuggled guns and explosives into high-security prisons, organised getaway cars and safe houses and, apart from the five years spent behind bars herself, has written to her husband every day and visited him three times a week.

"I still don't think I've quite grasped it," Ms Brice said yesterday. "We've been fighting for this for so long. Sometimes I'm afraid they'll find yet another way to keep him inside, and sometimes I have little leaps of joy. This man is my world, and now we're finally going to be together."

Laurence Robin, her maiden name, and Patrick Brice met in 1983, when she was 18 and he 26. She was working in a hotel; he said he was on holiday.

They took off on the back of his motorbike and spent nearly four years on the move; he explained his absences by claiming he was a rigger on France's high-tension power lines.

But in 1987 he was arrested, and Laurence discovered to her horror that her dream lover was in fact wanted throughout France for a string of 13 armed robberies and a jailbreak. He told her, from prison, that he had turned to crime after being convicted of a robbery he did not commit, and said she could leave him. She refused.

"I realised that he had had to run away," she says. "He hadn't done anything. And by then I knew him. I knew how gentle, how honest he is, how he has never hurt anybody. How loyal he is. We'd been together for four years; he is not a bad man. And I loved him."

After a failed escape bid in 1988, when the gun she had taped under a courtroom seat for him was found, Laurence organised Patrick's successful but short-lived breakout from Rennes jail in 1990.

A year later, a wanted woman herself, she walked into Patrick's latest high-security prison with a tear-gas bomb and enough plastic explosive to blow open half a dozen reinforced steel doors.

But the gendarmes had set a trap and were waiting for her.

The couple did, however, manage to lock themselves into a sealed room and spend 22 precious hours in each other's company before surrendering minutes before a police team was due to pounce.

In 1993, with both in jail, they managed to marry - but were beginning to despair of ever spending a life together.

France being France, however, a 1995 court case provided the turning point. A romantically inclined jury took sympathy on the couple, who were clearly more interested in gazing at each other than in mounting their own defence.

Plainly moved, the jury ordered Patrick's multiple sentences served concurrently, making him eligible for parole this year.

Last month, Mr Dupont-Moretti wrote to the justice minister, Elisabeth Guigou, telling her that Patrick had a job waiting for him in a local engineering company and he assured the minister that "the love of these two for each other is the most solid and tangible guarantee of Mr Brice's successful rehabilitation".

Ms Guigou, apparently, agreed - although she spoiled the party by directing Patrick to spend his nights alone in a half-way house for the next six months.

"That's a bit frustrating," Laurence admitted yesterday. "But we've probably been through enough to survive a little hitch like that."

webTitle: Half of school's staff quit amid complaints about pupil violence and new head

fields.headline: It was end of term and everyone was leaving - not pupils, but teachers
fields.standfirst:
Half of school's staff quit amid complaints about pupil violence and new head

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Half of school's staff quit amid complaints about pupil violence and new head
fields.body:
Headteacher George Benham had laid on a barbecue, but the end of term staff party at Cardinal Hinsley high school was a subdued affair. Of 50 teachers at the Roman Catholic boys' school in Willesden, north-west London, 26 were leaving that day. Two others had left already

Because so many were leaving, Mr Benham had requested there be no collections or presentations. He stayed 20 minutes for the sausages, burgers and sala. Though his deputy, Gerry Connolly, later said a few words of thanks to experienced staff, for those present (some of whom had worked at the school for more than 20 years) it was an anti-climactic finale.

It was also the end of a difficult first year for Mr Benham, subject to intense criticism from staff when he unveiled a new management structure for September that would merge departments. Teachers were told they would have to re-apply for their jobs, and there were threats of up to six redundancies.

As it turned out, so many left voluntarily that redundancies were not required. Eighteen new teachers have been appointed, and last week Mr Benham was interviewing for some of the remaining seven vacancies.

So why did so many quit? It depends on who you ask. To Mr Benham and Brent council, the changes are an inevitable outcome of the reorganisation and of staff moving on to better jobs.

Teachers tell a different story. Some spoke to the Guardian, though almost all were reluctant to go on the record, either because they were staying on or they did not want to be seen as disloyal by their new employers. The unions have tried to keep the school out of the media.

Documents obtained by the Guardian include a letter by union representatives to the chairman of governors, John Fox, alleging that the school environment had become "unsafe for pupils and staff", and that Mr Benham was "unwilling or unable to deal effectively with pupils' violent or disruptive behaviour" and in consequence was "jeopardising the safety of pupils and staff, and undermining teaching and learning".

He rejects the complaint, saying it was "strategic game playing" because of anxiety about the reorganisation. "You are dealing partly with a side issue, as tactically how you approach a debate. They didn't want to deal with such a large scale change. We had some difficult kids, no question. Was the school dangerous in that sense? I don't believe it was."

Mr Benham was already controversial when he arrived last September. A former director of education at Brent, he was the council's chief executive from 1995 until 1998, when he stepped down a year early with a £700,000 pay-off, including a car and an annual pension of £51,768 brought forward 10 years. By his own admission, he was responsible for big cuts in teacher numbers at Brent.

Cardinal Hinsley, a voluntary aided, former grant maintained school, has results below average and attracts a thin strand of middle class children. A third of pupils are local, the remainder from elsewhere, including some who cannot get in to the London Oratory.

Respect
The school's last Ofsted report, in 1996, was broadly positive - "a generally well ordered and supportive environment, based upon its Catholic ethos, in which pupils make sound academic progress and develop well socially," inspectors said. "Pupils' behaviour is generally satisfactory and all relationships within the school are good, based on mutual respect."

But pupil numbers were falling, and when the then head, Michael Metcalfe, announced plans for redundancies in the Easter of 1998, teachers passed a vote of no confidence in Mr Metcalfe in June 1998, a move kept secret from parents. In January 1999, he took early retirement. After the post was advertised but not filled, Mr Benham was approached by the Westminster diocese and agreed to take over.

Abolition of grant maintained status lost the school opportunities for extra funding. Mr Benham says he arrived to face a deficit of £154,000, reserves used up, five years of falling pupil rolls, and a long-serving, relatively expensive staff.

The thing about experienced staff, he said, was that "it's brilliant for stability, it's difficult for economics". He told teachers he would reorganise the school; he would be pro-active in recruiting pupils at local primary schools; and he was prepared to take on difficult children. A few weeks into the autumn term, the number of pupils had increased from 780 to 860, meaning more money under the funding formula.

Mr Benham said five pupils expelled from other schools came to Cardinal Hinsley; in all perhaps "six or seven genuinely difficult kids". Other staff claim it was many more. "He was very much in favour of the government's policy of social inclusion," says one senior teacher. (David Blunkett has set schools a target of reducing exclusions by a third.)

Refugee children from Kosovo, Afghanistan, Sri Lanka and Sudan, many of whom could not speak English, came. Some Russian children arrived. Disruptive children among the intake encouraged the wilder elements of the existing intake. "We seemed to have no way of coping with them. It's been such a volatile atmosphere," said one experienced senior teacher who was leaving.

"There was a lot more graffiti, a lot more challenging authority, a lot more aggressiveness towards teachers. They told you to eff off to your face, whereas before that just wasn't the case." Teachers say they were assaulted, women teachers say they were sexually harassed, and when a French teacher had a missile thrown at her in class, she called the police. The boy who did it, the son of a world famous athlete, has since been excluded.

Though there was little racial tension, there were vicious fights. Nearby Roundwood Park became a battleground after school, often with pupils from Willesden high. Mr Benham brought forward the end of the school day so it did not coincide with Willesden's. Two weeks ago three Russian pupils were set upon. Incidents "were happening so fast that you couldn't keep up with them ... there were so many fights", said one teacher. Mr Benham himself said: "We had a couple of really nasty incidents, and I mean really nasty incidents, of boys beating other boys up."

Staff allege he failed to support efforts to discipline pupils, particularly for intimidation or violence against teachers. They claim he took the pupils' side, or allowed excluded pupils back in class too quickly.

Liz Milton, a food technology teacher, says pupils quickly decided Mr Benham was a soft touch. "I was assaulted this year, which has never happened to me before. Benham was totally unsympathetic. He said: 'The boys don't lie'." She adds: "I have never seen so many women crying in the ladies as in the last year."

A petition signed by 49 teachers and three secretaries on March 13 said: "We must express deep concern and distress with regard to the sharp rise in physical and verbal attacks by the pupils on members of teaching and non-teaching staff. This is gravely affecting staff morale and we feel that the general decline in pupil behaviour seriously contravenes the Catholic ethos."

After a staff meeting on June 29, teachers Gary Wallis and Stuart Reid, representatives of the teaching unions at the school, wrote a joint letter to the chairman of governors, Peter Fox. It said that the school was unsafe for both pupils and staff; that staff were deeply dissatisfied with the headteacher because he did not always believe staff who reported serious incidents to him, accepting rather the views of pupils. He "frequently sends pupils who have threatened other pupils or members of staff back into the same class. We regard this as utterly unacceptable and thoroughly dangerous." It went on to say that the head did not consistently consult or involve the teachers concerned, or heads of year, on pupils' unacceptable behaviour, and did not consistently report to relevant staff action taken or targets set; he "appears unwilling or unable to deal effectively with pupils' violent or disruptive behaviour". It concluded: "Conditions under which we are being asked to work and in which pupils are attempting to learn are not humanly acceptable."

In reply, Mr Fox told them to first go to Mr Benham, "in accordance with procedure". Other governors are worried. Geraldine O'Sullivan said: "I'm a parent governor so I'm doubly concerned. I keep saying to my son, 'do you feel OK, do you want to change schools?' We'll give it to Christmas and then see. I want to be loyal to the school, but I am not going to be loyal if my son suffers."

A parent governor, Jeremy Travis, said he was concerned about discipline. "There are quite a lot of issues really. The school does have quite serious problems at the moment. There have been a lot of new students just to try and get the numbers up. I think everyone is being accepted."

Mr Benham denies ignoring teacher complaints. Pupils were excluded, he said; by the end of term, four had been expelled; and three more excluded pupils are believed to be awaiting the outcomes of appeals. He says he was careful not to prejudice appeals against exclusion.

In a statement, Jacky Griffin, director of education at Brent, said: "The school is working with the support of the education authority to address student behavioural problems that have been identified." CCTV cameras are being put in every classroom.

Restructuring

On March 13, Mr Benham announced his restructuring plan. "Everybody knew I had to drive down costs ... Since they have all known me since I was director of education, [they] know that, if I said it was going to happen, it was going to happen."

Five senior management posts are being merged into three; and, instead of 14 heads of department, there will be seven - turning "14 lieutenants into seven majors" as Mr Benham put it. Heads of year posts are also being merged.

The teachers immediately fired off a protest, criticising him for failing to consult and condemning the likely loss of "many long-serving and dedicated teachers". According to teachers, many staff decided to leave after a difficult meeting with Mr Benham on April 6. They allege he said he expected the school would fail its next Ofsted inspection and believed it would be put under special measures. Mr Benham denies that form of words: "I didn't expect it - I'm concerned that there is a danger of that," he told the Guardian.

On April 10, staff condemned the "lack of sound educational evidence behind the proposed restructuring". Several resignations came in late. "It surprised me on May 31 when I got a raft of resignations which I didn't have a handle on at all," said Mr Benham. "I thought I'd done my numbers." The 28 departees are mostly off to new jobs. One has a promotion, to deputy head, though most are moving sideways or downwards. Four are taking early retirement, and one is ill.

To say goodbye, they produced a souvenir pamphlet, The Great Escape, distributed between them. Garry Wallis wrote: "I am full of mixed emotions, not really knowing whether to be happy or sad, but I do feel cheated! The circumstances in which 27 other colleagues and I are leaving, I believe, could have been avoided, and the repercussions of this 'escape' may not be known for some time."

In a statement, Hank Roberts, Brent secretary for both the National Union of Teachers and the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said: "It was clearly a mistake to seek to make all the staff redundant and have to re-apply for their jobs. I believe the management of the school and the governors will have learnt from this and other problems, and adopt a more consensual approach in future."

Mr Benham is "90% delighted" with how the restructuring has turned out. But he accepts: "I have got some vacancies at a very difficult time in London ... London at the moment is crying out for teachers." He adds: "We have got quality people. Some posts have been taken on at lower salary levels. Certainly next year we will be starting with a staff that has less staffroom experience, that's true. The senior management team has plenty of experience." There were "a fair number" of newly qualified teachers.

Some of the old staff who will be there next term think about leaving, others want to see it through. "There have been some very good years, and I think there'll be some to come. I am prepared to see where it goes next," said one. Brent does not appear unduly concerned. Jacky Griffin said: "This is an exciting time for the school, which is embarking with great energy on an ambitious improvement strategy."

fields.headline: Concorde diverted in scare
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText:
A British Airways Concorde bound for New York was
diverted to Canada last night after passengers
complained about a petrol-like smell in the cabin, a
spokeswoman for the airline said.
fields.body:
A British Airways Concorde bound for New York was diverted to Canada last night after passengers complained about a petrol-like smell in the cabin, a spokeswoman for the airline said.

British Airways, which resumed its supersonic flights last Wednesday, the day after the crash in France that claimed 114 lives, said the flight from Heathrow airport landed at Gander, Newfoundland and was grounded pending safety checks.

"It is purely a precautionary measure," said the spokeswoman, Jemma Moore. "The captain became aware of smell at rear of the cabin and we never take any chances."

Following the safety checks, the flight was expected to proceed to New York, she added.

The unscheduled landing in Canada was the second time yesterday that a British Airways Concorde flight experienced problems.

Earlier in the day, a Concorde also bound for New York was delayed by more than an hour at Heathrow airport because of a technical fault with its refuelling system, forcing the company to use a backup plane.

The airline declined to give further details but said that the problem was "specific to the plane involved". The passengers later arrived safely in New York.

The two incidents came as French investigators said that the flames that spewed from the wing of an Air France Concorde minutes before it crashed last Tuesday were probably due to a massive fuel leak rather than an engine problem.

The French Accident Investigation Bureau (BEA) said that part of the debris found on the runway of Roissy-Charles de Gaulle airport, where the plane took off, appeared to come from a fuel tank.

This bolsters the theory that one or more tyres ruptured on takeoff, spewing debris that pierced a part of the plane near one of the engines, leading to a fire. "The flames seen after takeoff do not originate from an engine but, most likely, from an important fuel leak," it said in a statement.

The BEA, which heads the technical inquiry into the disaster, had previously said that as many as two of the tyres may have burst before takeoff.

The Concorde, bound for New York, plunged into a hotel in Gonesse, four miles south-west of the airport, within minutes of taking off, killing all 109 on board and five people on the ground.

Despite fears over the aircraft's safety, Air France is expected to follow BA's lead and resume flights in the next few days. The transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, will meet international aviation experts today to discuss possible new safety measures before he approves the resumption.

After first focusing on a last-minute repair to a thrust reverser, aviation experts are increasingly focusing on the theory of a burst tyre and damage to the undercarriage. Chunks of rubber and metal may have punctured a fuel tank and damaged the engines, turning the 25-year-old jet into what one expert called "a giant cigarette lighter".

Bursting tyres have been known to damage fuel tanks and engines on Concordes. After several near-catastrophes in the early 1980s the US national transportation safety board ruled in 1982 that no Concorde be allowed to take off without an inspection of its tyres and undercarriage.
